I was able to easily find 2-hour metered street parking on the street, but rather unsurprisingly, it cost $3/hour. At least it took credit cards and appeared to be free on Sundays (mental note for next time).

The space is actually really big, but both has cool and awkward parts of the layout and atmosphere. I liked the large windows that looked out towards the street and the second floor with seating which was also facing the outside windows. I didn't like the unfinished wood that was present almost everywhere I looked. Fortunately, the unfinished wood is mainly the beams in the ceiling and not anywhere you would sit.

I got the Hooker's Mocha which was tasty and came with cool latte art (no whipped cream available). I was told you can get it in two sizes: 10oz paper cup or an 8oz ceramic mug. Both sizes come standard with two shots of espresso.

This is definitely a legit place to check out if you are near the area and looking for good coffee.
author: Regina W.

description:
NO WIFI, MANAGER INTIMIDATED YOUNG WOMAN WORKING ALONE.  ACTUALLY FELT SCARED HERE.

Sooo...I work in tech and spend a lot of time bouncing around SF coffee shops, never have I had an experience sitting next to a screaming child.  After reminding the parents of this child that people come here to work, the manager made more of a scene than the baby.  It's odd to me that they charge $6 for a tiny cup of yet claim to be a family place.  All in all THIS IS A TERRIBLE ENVIRONMENT TO WORK (HOPE YOUR PHONE HAS A HOTSPOT BECAUSE THERE'S NO WIFI EITHER).  If you're in and out it's fine but you can get coffee just as good and cheaper elsewhere.  Management isn't good at dealing with problems and AS A YOUNG WOMAN WORKING ALONE I DID NOT APPRECIATE BEING INTIMIDATED AND APPROACHED FROM BEHIND by the manager in a hostile and very accusatory way (over what? I'm still not sure).  This person also had some odd cuts and bruises on his face which made the whole incident feel like the entry to a fight club rather than a boujee over-priced SF coffee shop.  Working alone? Be careful here.
author: Kay W.

description:
You know how when you highlight the 5-star rating when writing a review, you get the "Woohoo! As good as it gets!" caption?

That is how I feel about Sightglass.

I love the rustic-industrial ambiance. The coffee is splendid. The bike racks on the wall coupled with hooks for dog leashes. The baristas. The stacks of beans. Everything.

When writing and trying to focus, sometimes a lively atmosphere is a good thing. Go to the top floor on a busy day and people-watch the hustle and bustle of everyone below. It's almost inspiring!
author: Oliver D.

description: It's a beautiful new addition to the neighborhood! The coffee is quite good and there seems to be plenty of communal seating. Unlike other locations, I didn't see any tea on the menu.
author: Huey K.

description:
Huge coffee shop and roastery.   There is one coffee type shop downstairs and another upstairs.  Not sure if it's the same business or not.  

It's a wide open space though and almost everyone in there on a sat late afternoon seemed to be working on their computers.  Not a lot of socializing here.  

Tried the downstairs drip coffee.  They had 2 to chose from.  Got the decaf because, well, I've hit that age where caffeine any time of the day, keeps me awake at night.  

While I generally like the boutique drip coffee approach, the biggest problem is that by the time you get your cup, add cream, and find a seat, the coffee is no longer hot.  It's just luke warm.  Am not sure that any drip coffee shop has solved this and certainly a problem here.  

Price point is also high.  $5 per cup.
author: Marcus K.

description:
Pros: great coffee. Fresh. Quality. Great taste. Atmosphere is calm and industrial. Modern. Sleek. 

Cons: only choice of almond or whole milk. To go sizes vs. in house cup sizes differ for small, medium and large. NO WIFI!! Hard to find a seat. Coffee is expensive. 

Im honestly not too impressed with this place apart from their coffee, which is why i give 4 not 3 stars. If the review was based more generally on overall, i would give it three stars, mainly for lack of wifi.
author: Tater Tot J.

description:
Coffee was ok..more on the bitter side..I got a regular latte with almond milk, comes in a cute mason jar. 

Upstairs they had other drinks with ice cream..but it was super hot! I felt there was more air flow downstairs. 

Place is in a far location, sorta have to walk through some bad streets to get there, but it wasn't too bad walking back to civic center bart.

Place is fairly big, more seats upstairs, but just hot.
author: Minerva L.

description: Totally full, don't have honey, didn't want to warm my muffin, don't have wifi and I've paid U$14 for 2 espressos and a muffin. Never coming back again
author: Maria F.

description:
This cafe looks pretty dope inside and out. 
Very spacious but they need to put more seats.
I ordered a latte and tasted pretty good.
I came here to do some research while waiting for my bf to get off work but I was disappointed that they don't have wifi 
& I ordered some pastries cause they looked good but it was cold and hard since they don't have an oven to warm it up. 
Kinda wasted my time and probably won't be coming here again.
author: Danicca D.

description:
Great space, great coffee, and nice staff.

Ordered a v60 pour over on my way to Pride. Took a little longer to serve given the amount of people in the store. But the coffee itself was very good. The aroma before your first sip reflected the bold flavors listed. 

The island set up made it easy to witness of the coffee brewing process. They have a roaster facing the street and large windows allowing for natural light to peak through.

Typical interior design people have come and love about SF coffee shops. Would come again if I was in the neighborhood.

Downside: No wifi. Better work somewhere else and grab a coffee to go
author: Brian L.

description: First time trying this place. I dont come to San Fran often and I have to say this place was so bomb! I loved the interior concept and the coffee was heaven.
author: Lia A.

description: The aesthetic is beautiful and the nitro cold brew was amazing. I would say the only downside is no wifi and no outlets - but it's a good spot to read and start conversations.
author: Anuja S.

description:
Delicious coffee! And surprisingly quick. 

The line was a 10-15 minute wait and I got my drinks in 5 minutes. Ordered a mocha and a latte. They use Verve espresso beans (love) and the fresh coffee, espresso shots, and drinks are brewed fresh. Definitely going to check it out again the next time I'm in SF.
author: Heather J.

description:
I don't know man. 

They obviously have a great interior designer. 

Maybe it's because I ordered their cold brew and not an espresso. Or maybe it's because I came to drink coffee and not to take a snap for my highly curated Insta... But, this was just an average cuppa. I was bummed that they only have one size (what can I say, I like my coffee supersized) and that the employees behind the counter were a little too pretentious for my taste. 

I think it's easy to get taken in by the interior and think the beverages and treats are as tasty as the place is pretty. On the plus side, their logo was cute.
author: Abby M.

description:
I fell in love with the coffee shop's interior the moment I stepped foot into this cafe. It well-captures modern day, hipster San Francisco, and I strongly recommend tourists to drop in for a cup of coffee during their visit! There is also a lot of open space, and its high ceiling gives people the illusion that the shop is more spacious than it actually is. For a two-story shop and long line of waiting customers, though, there is very limited seating and no wifi. I wish they opened till later, but it closes a little later than a lot of coffee shops in the area so I guess I'll just have to deal with it.

Simple menu, but freshly-brewed coffee. It takes a while for them to make your coffee, but their authentic drinks are more worth the money than ordering from any Starbucks. It does take some time to find parking, wait in line, get your coffee, and find seating, but it's a great experience!! A must visit!!
author: Angela L.

description:
I was ordering a coffee in a coffee bar
That stizz is true.
But even then I sipped I'd find a much bitter drink
Either iced or paper cup from you.

The five mins we have had have been #hipster times
I still drink you!
But now I think it's time I styleblog on my own
I guess it's just what San Franciscans do.

Dooon't you coffee baaaaby?
Don't youuu coffee ooooooh!
author: Dan B.

description: It's perfect. If I could dream up a coffee shop - this would be it.
author: Alexander M.

description:
Finally got to visit Sightglass on Black Friday for a free public cupping class (signed up on-line, held every week!)

As a starting coffee connoisseur, I'm glad that Sightglass was the first specialty coffee shop to introduce me to various origins of coffee and its brewing methods. 

Upon entering the establishment, you could see that it holds a unique, workshop vibe. Many people are working while enjoying their preference of caffeine intake. They also offer many brewing supplies, such as the Acaia Scale, Hario V-60 etc. 

All in all, great experience and will definitely be back!
author: Ian L.

description:
The atmosphere here is pretty unbeatable! I love the decor and the vibe. It all just works for a really cool environment to come chill & get some work done.

However I had the cold brew on the only time I went and it definitely wasn't my favorite in San Francisco. I liked it! But I think it had a slight bitterness which made it not my favorite.

The service was great and quick though even with a long line. All that said I still gave this place four stars because overall it was great. If you're in the neighborhood stop by.
author: Kerry H.

description:
This coffee shop epitomizes the new age San Francisco. Tourist or local, it is a must go to whether coffee with a friend or doing work on your MacBook. 

Get the pistachio powdered sugar crossiant with blackberry jam. Jaw dropping good!
author: Alex G.

description: Their pastries were really good I tried the raspberry chocolate scone and the almond cake. Both were good, but the scone was my favorite. I got the Colombia coffee and the flavor just got better as I drank it.
author: Andrea R.

description:
As others have noted, the sheer size of the store is all at once illuminating and overwhelming. Gorgeous high ceilings and tons of open space soaked in natural light. I would definitely come here to work or meet up with friends. 

I ordered an almond milk latte - delicious! Smooth, buttery aftertaste and very balanced. All of the baked goods and pastries looked so tempting - maybe next time. 

Restrooms are very clean and they have Aesop resurrection hand soap just outside the restroom!!!!! These products smell AMAZING. It's makes the task of washing your hands pleasurable and the scent remains for a bit of time. 

Overall, one of the better coffee spots I've stumbled across in my travels.
author: Erin E.

description:
Sure, the coffee is expensive, but damn - it's coffee. Like, REAL coffee. Even if you aren't a coffee snob (and I'm definitely not), you realize with your first sip that it puts most other coffee houses to shames. So you definitely get what you pay for here. 

Really awesome space, though even on a random weekday afternoon it will be pretty tough to find a seat sometimes. While they don't have a wi-fi network, there are some free wi-fis available, or you know, you could do things that DON'T involve being chained to the interwebs. Like have a conversation. Or read a book. Novel concept, I know. 

Street parking - if you are willing to walk a few blocks, seems to be plenty of spots.
author: Amelia B.

description: I love this place. No there's no wifi and that's annoying but if there were, I'd be here for hours almost every day. The decor and atmosphere are super cool and the cookies here are to kill for.
author: Quinn Li O.

description:
Fri 5/1/15 there was FREE Affogoto at the new Affogoto Bar upstairs of Sightglass Coffee on 7th St.  Everyone was there!  It was only for their first day 11am-7pm.

Waited in a long line, but got to try Salted Caramel ice cream from Salt & Straw in Portland OR will be having there ice cream here and some light espresso - didn't get the name.

Tasted ok.  I wonder how much it is going to cost since there wasn't a price on the menu.

Got a Pistachio Blackberry Jam Croissant they sell downstairs by the register - it was made by Neighbor's Bakeshop $4.75.  Tasty.

Also got a Kouign Amann from B Patisserie $4.50 - will eat tomorrow.
author: Ann L.

description:
I liked this place! But I'm definitely not much of a coffee connoisseur so not sure how much my opinion counts. I feel like part of my five star review is also how well designed the place is. Despite how not so nice it is on the exterior, the interior is really well furnished and aesthetically pleasing, and I could easily see myself sitting here for awhile with a friend to catch up. 

I got a latte which was pretty good. I never know how to describe lattes since I don't feel like i'm super picky about them. It tasted like coffee? Good balance between espresso flavor and milk so it wasn't too milky though probably a little on the milkier side otherwise I wouldn't have liked it so much. Well crafted coffee.
author: Jasmine X.

description: Excellent atmosphere, wonderful customer service, and a delicious artisan coffee selection.
author: Kristian H.

description: I like coffee don't get me wrong, but it is overpriced for a small cup. My mom took me here and it was $9 for 2 small lattes. At Philz coffee you get more coffee at the same price! It was disappointing that you didn't get to choose the size it was just one size. We also got 2 pastries, the total for 4 items was $18. I was shocked I never spent that much money on ok coffee and pastries!
author: Alix J.

description: They have a nice bike rack before you get in the coffee shop. Good amount of seating too. My only complaints are there's no wifi available, and the menu isn't visible unless you are in front of the register.  It's a small pamphlet on a clipboard. They definitely should consider making a visible menu for all the customers in line so you aren't pressured to make a quick decision once you're at the register.
author: Jenni D.

description: I'm not a coffee person, but I do enjoy a latte here and there. With that said, I'm in love with Sightglass Coffee. Their almond lattes are the smoothest I've ever had, and I'm a huge fan of their almond cold brew, too. Those are my usual two options, and my friends now think I'm a coffee snob because I don't ever want to get coffee in LA unless it's Sightglass. Honestly, I truly don't know much about coffee, I just know what I like. I get all kinds of feels when someone mentions Sightglass, is that wrong?
author: Debbie O.

description:
Come here if you appreciate: 

1) High quality single-origin coffee in multiple varieties, rotating through the menu daily so you can try them all. 
2) Seeing your coffee being roasted in-house by a massive vintage roasting machine.
3) A large, beautiful, and simply designed 2-story space that you can do work, have meetings, first dates, or people watch. 
4) Decadent affogato, serving Portland's own Salt & Straw ice cream and single-origin espresso (upstairs!)
5) Friendly, knowledgeable baristas who take pride in the quality of what they're serving, and will take their time to make your drink the best it can be, regardless of the lines.

Don't come here if you expect:

1) WiFi (BYOWiFi)
2) Syrups (this isn't Starbucks)
3) Charred, dark-roasted coffee (everything served in-house is light/medium roasted and naturally sweet)
author: Kimberly R.

description:
This is the rage huh?! Alright it's pretty darn good coffee. This is my second visit here, first was a cappuccino this time a latte. Both times creamy, buttery and non-bitter. Yes, I said buttery. I suppose that means the oils in the beans are doing their job!

There are plenty of spots to sit and enjoy your cuppa joe. Whether it be on the bench at the door, or any one of the tables upstairs. The spots on the ground floor offer an up close view of the roaster and stacks of beans. A mix of concrete and wood give this building a modern barn/locomotive station sorta feel. I feel like I could be in a time warp back to the industrial revolution, or currently at my friends barn house in Iowa. Either way it's bright, spacious and inviting. 

There are a few pastry options at the counter if you are hungry. Staff are friendly and coffee is served quickly. I only wish they offered WiFi.
author: Jaylena P.

description:
It's O.K...
No big deal.
They should spend more time on the taste and flavor of coffee rather than their interior. Makes you wonder how they make money at all.
author: Chowder K.

description: Sightglass in general is SF coffee culture as it jumps the shark. Prices are hugely inflated, and staff are generally unfriendly. Although this is a pretty nice space, I was particularly put off this shop by the dozen fruit flies buzzing around the queue, which you could watch crawling over the pastries on display while considering your order. We definitively wouldn't get any food from here!
author: Dominique G.

description: Mmm coffee and a really cool atmosphere. A local recommended this place and it was great. I had the berry muffin and the quick fix coffee. This place is in a warehouse and has high ceilings and a loft area for people working. They do not have wifi so plan to hit spot but there is plenty of seating. This is a great place to meet a friend for coffee.
author: Jessie V.

description:
What a coffee roaster! 

In a city inundated with some of the country's best coffee roasters, Sightglass Coffee can be placed near the top of that list. I'm somewhat of an espresso snob (and it's pronounced espres·so, not with an X people!), and find the acidity and balance of Sightglass to be consistently wonderful. 

The main location on 7th st. feels very SOMA and "techie" if you will. I like the fact that they don't offer free wifi otherwise you'd never be able to grab a seat and take a minute to enjoy your hot beverage. 

All in all, solid stop.
author: Benjamin F.

description:
I don't know how much more SF this place could get. Tall ceilings. SOMA/warehouse-y vibe. Lots of light. I love it though. The coffee here is amazing and it's a nice place to chill or catch up with someone.

The only problem I have is that it's pretty much always busy and there isn't much seating, especially since a lot of people just camp here and work. I've always had to find somewhere to stand whenever I've stopped by.
author: Jessie L.

description:
This place is a treat. The floorplan is gorgeous (no WiFi though). The coffee is consistently good (albeit pricey).

I work nearby and I can not justify the $3.75 a cup for drip coffee. I'm sorry, but that is an outrageous price even if it's ambrosia. I have to knock them down a star for that honestly from the 5 star level.

The coffee is served in what I can only call a "Starbucks kid's hot cocoa" size. This is serious advice to the owners of Sightglass: increase the size of your coffee of the day cups. As delicious as your coffee is - I need to do more than get my lips wet in the morning. I need a cup of coffee that is delicious and substantial enough in size to "get me going".

$3.75, I would hope you guys consider making it a 18 oz drink. The cups right now feel like I'm drinking a 10 oz baby coffee.

That said, the coffee is truly 5 star great. You can't get a better cup of regular coffee anywhere else or even the espresso drinks. i just can't handle the prices on a daily basis - it's more expensive than a drug habit drinking coffee here.
author: Doug R.

description: Really cute and rustic coffee spot in SoMa. Suuuuper picturesque. Their granola with almond milk is divine, croissant with blackberry (or black currant ??) jam is really good and so is their chocolate raspberry scone. And of course, their coffee is amazing. I can understand why people love this spot. I'd come here everyday if I lived in SF.
author: Valerie L.

description: If there were wifi, I'd give this place a five star hands down. Friendly staff, great coffee, pretty interior, fairly quiet, filled with imposter hipsters - love it. There are some Asian fobs taking photos of their croissants and coffee for Instagram, and it's truly one of the best areas in San Francisco to do so. There's pretty good seating and tables. Great place to read on a Saturday afternoon and muse over the sophisticated coffee scene in the city.
author: Juliana P.

description:
Love love love the decor from the inside/out.  Hipster vibe the moment you set foot into this coffee shop.  The coffee aroma wakes me up with just a couple sniffs.  The night we went all the tables were packed.  It'll be great if they can provide more tables on the first floor too.  

I ordered a flat white and my friends ordered a hooker mocha you can really taste the quality of the coffee beans in each cup.  It's not overpowered by milk or chocolate :).  Just one cup made my day :).  

However, this place is not good for people who prefers sweet lattes or mochas because they don't offer syrups.
author: Joyce L.

description:
Sightglass coffee is A-OK

Pros:  large space 
good coffee 
clean bathrooms 
great pastries

Cons: there's no menu up high to see you have to wait to you get to the counter to see what's on the menu
They don't warm up your pastry maybe they will if you ask but they don't offer like most coffee joints


All in all it's a pretty cool place to chill and have a cuppa Joe
 Will update my review upon my next visit
author: Mona A.

description:
Some pretty amazing coffee here I must say. Got a vanilla cold brew with almond milk. Very well made coffee. 

Pretty cool little hipster joint (actually a good size with plenty of seating) that has a trendy atmosphere. 

The only bad thing is NO WIFI. But it's all good since I have good wireless on my phone and computer. 

But the coffee here is good. Makes Starbucks taste like supermarket coffee. Parking is limited as there is only street parking.
author: Thomas T.

description:
Huge beautiful location with two levels.

Excellent mocha.

Friendly people.
author: Evan W.

description: Pro tip: Get the everything CROISSANT (yes, it's a thing), and pair it with one of their cold brew options. No better way to wake up. Cool environment, cool baristas, and you can even watch them sift through some coffee beans if you show up at the right time.
author: Matt H.

description: Positives and negatives in this review. Sightglass coffee is delicious. It's always been my favorite in SF. The shop itself is gorgeous, and the coffee is great. However the line was long and slow, the coffee is expensive and the staff aren't friendly, actually downright obnoxious. Much prefer the 7th street staff and vibe.
author: Ajj J.

description: Probably the best local coffee shop in SoMa. If you're gonna splurge on a $4.00 8oz. cup of coffee - this is the place to do it.
author: Nick S.

description: So I visited San Francisco a few weeks ago and coffee was a necessity every morning. A friend and I tried a new place everyday and this was by far my favorite! I do not remember what I got (I know it was with almond milk though), but I remember it was delicious! Like note taking delicious. I was looking through the notes in my phone and I jotted down "Sightglass". And that was all I wrote. Lol. I knew I would want to come back to this place if I found myself in San Francisco again (which is very likely), so I'm glad I saved the name at least! I remember the barista was very friendly. And the interior was nicely decorated. Very modern. It's also in a cool area... but then again, I think all of SF is cool. Anyways, do yourself a favor and come get some coffee here.
author: Mari Q.

description:
Beautiful, high-ceilinged open space. Quietly bustling with the operation of the roasting and order-fulfilling operations. Crowded with XtremeHipsters and other, slightly less affected coffee lovers. Delicious, high quality pastry offerings (enjoyed a kouign amann and a hazelnut cake with candied orange peel.

The cup of coffee I had was the Sulawesi, Toarco Peaberry variety. Tried Blue Bottle, Sextant, Philz, and more, and Sightglass was the best.
author: R M.

description: Had the vanilla iced cold brew, was decent, the decor and size of this location was the best part to me.
author: Elena B.

description: I've been coming to Sightglass for the last couple of weeks. The coffee is phenomenal, staff are nice, and the interior of the building is really cool. My only complaint is that every time I've ordered a pour over, I receive a cup that is filled three quarters of the way with the coffee. The cup is already very small and it's frustrating that you get so little for $5. I finish that coffee before I even get to my car.. wish they could fill the cup up, especially considering how much they charge.
author: Brandon M.

description:
People don't just GO to Sightglass Coffee, you TREAT yourself to it.

First off, the interior just had me in AWE. I love the organic and industrial look that they have going for them. Also, I like that they roast their own beans within the joint! It always smells sooooo good! There is a lot of seating so even if it's the middle of the day, the large tables are full of people that are willing to share an open seat. I normally enjoy my coffee on the second floor looking above the baristas.

I've had their iced coffee with Almond Milk. Although I feel that it's a bit overpriced for the small cup that it comes in, I always get a huge caffeine kick out of it which I can't complain about.

On the rare occasion that I go to Sightglass, I always leave wishing I could've stay longer.
author: Linda K.

description:
With a real estate footprint that resembles more of a bar (two stories, VERY big), I soon found out why - Sightglass has two registers open with a huge barista prep area for the swarms of customers.  Seats (even upstairs) were at a premium during mid-Saturday morning visit.  I tried their very smooth Nigeria gravity-drip selection.  

Not at all disappointed - smooth as silk, I just added a tiny blurp of cream to soften even further.  Great people watching from stools overlooking first floor.  Great place.
author: Patrick K.

description: Note, this review is for the new Sightglass on Divisadero near Page. Can't find it on Yelp yet. Good coffee and pastries, but due to the HIGH cost I will not be going back too often. $20 for two coffees and two croissants?
author: James P.

description:
Before I started working here I was always fascinated by the place. I not only loved the design of the 7th and Folsom location but I was also aware that quality and service was of the utmost importance to the employees that worked there. The philosophy of the place was also quirky but pleasantly old school. In order to embrace a chatty, community friendly, and generally more loving environment the owners chose to forego offering wifi and outlets. They hope that customers will enjoy their drinks and short break at the stress free environment that is Sightglass. I think it's important to realize that people need a place to unwind and forget about work in this bustling concrete jungle of San Francisco. 

The "Brainwash" cafe around the corner is a great place to sit and work if you need one.

I would also like to commend them on their outstanding coffee sourcing and roasting. I've tried a few beans roasted in the bay area and I haven't found something as unique and interesting as Sightglass' light roasts. The menu changes frequently as the staff samples new beans, and you can expect to try a completely new bean at least every other week.
author: Edward D.

description:
Just happened to stumble upon this coffee shop after getting the best sandwich in the city at deli board.

It makes you feel like you're in the northwest (Seattle) very unique interior, very social and the coffee is great.

The only downside is it does not have wifi.
author: Kunal T.

description:
Sight glass is must if you're in the area. Awesome atmosphere, huge seating area, great coffee. 

You can't go wrong with a cappuccino. The desert selection varies depending on when you visit, but their scones are pretty damn tasty.
author: Shaun J.

description: Good spot. Kinda marks the end of the  old San Francisco as this place started right at the second tech take over. Not good or bad. Just is what it is. That's life. Great pastries and capps are always done correctly. Best bathrooms in SOMA. No internet though. Otherwise, 5 stars.
author: H K.

description: Nice and eclectic coffee shop. Industrial setting inside with a section demonstrating the growth and cultivation of coffee. Pastry items also available. Nice, if it is on your way.
author: Can I.

description: I came here after a yoga class across the street and loved my treats! The building itself is amazing, with options to sit upstairs or downstairs. I got the vanilla cold brew with almond milk and the everything croissant. Both were sooo good! I'll def be back and make it a pit stop after going to raven fitness across the st!
author: Samantha G.

description:
It's open today! We were so happy to see this place open on thanksgiving! We had some sort of croissant (curry and savory!) so tasty! Cappuccino was also good, subtle and well made! It has really huge roasting machine inside, it's big and fun place! It has many variety of coffee beans you can buy (and they are good priced $14 per bag!) 
Plus it has many bike racks that you can lock up you bikes. Definitely would recommend if you are looking for great quality coffee. I was impressed!!!
author: Eunsoo J.

description: Loved the coffee and everyone was super tight. Especially Sam! Had a Nicaragua. Sweet!
author: Jaime A.

description:
Love the vibe, the high ceilings, and the ample space. You could get a buzz from the coffee being roasted alone! 

I got a cold vanilla coffee brew - yum! It also came in a cute mason jar, which we obviously all enjoy....they also make a mean cappuccino. We'll definitely be coming back soon!
author: Jennie C.

description:
Very spacious inside, although it gets crowded easily. When it's not or lucking out on finding somewhere to sit down (or stand up if preferred), the great coffee and pastries are great mood boosters.

The vanilla cold brew is my favorite, latte pretty good as well. Didn't really enjoy the mocha and hot chocolate, the chocolate somehow tasted awkward (couldn't tell it had chocolate or not).

No wifi, but people tether anyways. Would definitely come back!
author: Jaclyn C.

description: I really like the look of this coffee shop. It's really open with several levels for people to hang out or work. The pastry selection seems pretty decent and the coffee menu is just what I need. I have heard the affogatos are great, but I have yet to try them. We'll see when the time comes but so far, Sightglass is great coffee
author: Jenn T.

description:
What a find. This coffee shop is a lovely two story joint with an affogato bar located upstairs. This roastery has a rustic feel to it that only boosts the positive vibes. I love this coffee shop because of the communal design of the upstairs; large group tables bring people together, making this place a wonderful spot to discuss ideas and work. 

Highly recommend you check this gem out.
author: Mika A.

description: The iced coffee is so damn good. Seating is almost always an issue. But at least they have gender neutral restrooms!
author: Alex M.

description:
The venue has a simple modern feel with a high ceiling (upstairs available) and wooden themed tables and chairs harmonizing with concrete floor and walls. There are large windows for natural light and dimmed flood lights for table sin the back. As soon as you enter through the large wooden swing doors your nose is filled with rich aroma of coffee. 

The general crowd during the day are nearby startup workers, and there were a number of meetings happening at the tables upstairs. However, I would feel fine bringing any friend to casually chat. 

I ordered a latte and thoroughly enjoyed it. Rich coffee flavor and beautiful latte art. Worth the slightly steeper price. 

Watching the baristas from the upstairs, I could tell each cup was made with well-executed precision, as they even weigh the grounded coffee before running it on the espresso machine.

One thing to keep in mind: NO WIFI. 
If you need to use your computer, have to use your own hotspot. I believe this is intentional so that you can detach yourself, even for a short while, from our technologically inundated society. Still, an inconvenience if you were looking to do some work on your laptop. 

Overall, enjoyed the venue and the drink. Thank you Sightglass!
author: Dongkook L.

description: Great open space and friendly baristas. I don't drink coffee and unfortunately they don't serve tea, but they do have lovely pistachio croissants filled with blackberry jam.
author: Tanya F.

description:
Really cool coffee shop near Soma

Why is there no free wifi? This simply cannot be...

A lot of seating area, and lots of folks hanging out with their laptops, but no wifi :( Disappointment is understated.

On the bright side, the waitstaff are extremely responsive, professional, and nice. The coffee snack cakes and bars are also very, very well made, as is the coffee--the aroma was strong enough to persist even with lots of milk added, which usually never happens!

The decor is certainly one of the nicest I've seen in coffee shops, with lots of open space, and several floors high.

Not a bad place to stop by if you're in the area, but probably not worth the effort to go out of your way to visit.
author: Henry L.

description:
Food/drink:
Coffee = more "floral" but it's ok 
Cookie = yum got the chocolate chip it's nice n taoasted up 



Service 
Order pickup at counter. Workers are personable 


Atmosphere
Love the atmosphere! So trends/hip also with the bike each in the front. Love the large industrial coffee roaster machine, actually I'm not sure what it is. There's bar seating around and lathe Windows so lots of natural lighting high ceilings with skylights and mezzanine area upstairs w additional seating and calving overlooking the rest of the cafe
author: Angela L.

description:
First place I visited while on my coffee hopping experience
They roast their own stuff so that's a plus 
I ordered a cortado/Gibraltar to start my day and a cream cheese croissant
I believe they do not serve Gibraltars and they gave me a cappuccino which was really delicious and well bodied.. the  croissant was also good but they don't make that 
Aesthetically speaking the place is really cool and chill 
I will be returning to try their pour overs some time
author: Luis E M.

description: Coffee is good and the place is spacious with a lot of natural light. Is a good place to catch up with friends but forget coming here to get some work done! No Wifi and power sockets. Is probably a good policy to avoid crowds of people sitting with their laptops for half a day, but for a $4 macchiato I would expect wifi or at least cheaper coffee.... On another note, understanding the policy of no socket I've politely asked if I could leave my laptop for a little behind the counter to charge... a firm NO without appeal met my request. It made me feel a bit uncomfortable, despite I've always found staff here to be very friendly. Not sure I'll be back
author: Alberto F.

description:
Amazing coffee and atmosphere, but the service was terrible. We initially came here in order to get some studying and work done, so we asked for our coffee to drink there. However, upon realizing that they did not offer wifi, we decided to go elsewhere and asked for the coffee to-go instead. The girl stared at us so rudely, as if we were asking for so much. She did it though, so I let it go. My boyfriend tasted the coffee and asked for her to add a little bit of hot water because it wasn't as hot as he would've liked and the coffee only filled the to-go cup halfway. "Well it won't taste good." She snapped rudely. My boyfriend politely said, "it's okay, can you just add a little bit please?" She looked at her coworker with an annoyed look, grabbed the cup, and did as requested, but she did so in the most rude way. At this point my boyfriend was begging me not to say anything and cause a scene so I didn't, but boy did I want to. I don't care how ridiculous a request might sound, or if you're having a bad day, or if you think we are being annoying (which I don't think we were), I do not think it is ever okay for someone working in customer service to treat their customers that way. 

The great drinks and atmosphere may bring us back, but I'm hoping the service is better next time.
author: Jamie K.

description: I'd give Sightglass 5 stars except that the staff is never all that friendly. However, the upside is the incredible product and atmosphere here. I have not yet found a better place for affogato... which says a lot in San Francisco. They take it seriously with amazing espresso and SALT AND STRAW ice cream. Besides that, they have great coffee and espresso drinks, pretty tasty pastries, and a fantastic upstairs loft. I'm a frequent visitor.
author: Camille B.

description:
I've had this bookmarked for a while and finally had a chance to try it out.

The layout is spectacular and very Portlandy. I really like the decor, the space is wide open and feels very comforting. 

None of that matters unless the product sings, right? The coffee is pretty good. I've done a lot of research over the years and have tried some great coffee and not so great coffee and here is what the data tells me. I prefer coffee roasters from San Francisco, Portland, Seattle and Santa Cruz. I only drink Latin American, single origin beans. 

Sightglass has a solid selection of Latin American beans and the Puno Peru is a crisp, clean cup of coffee and that's what I expect from these local roasters. I grabbed a bag of Colombia El Miridiano and I really like it. This is a solid coffee shop,. doing things right and I will definitely return for more.
author: Hector G.

description:
All I can say is! 

Try the Owl's Howl it's bloody lovely blend of flavors, I'll be taking beans back to Australia to enjoy the flavors at home!!! 

The venue is industrial & customer service is to notch! I'll be coming back here if I'm ever back in San Francisco!!!
author: Alan C.

description:
Beautiful ambiance and amazing coffee & pastries, better than Blue Bottle.

This location has 2 floors so there are plenty of seats! I went to meet a friend and this spot was on point.

I ordered a latte and a pastry called morning bun. Delicious delicious. All their pastries come from local SF bakeries.
author: Silvia L.

description:
I drink a lot of coffee. For the past several years I have been fortunate enough to live within walking distance of some wonderful 3rd wave coffee shops. For better or worse, this has made me extremely snobby when it comes to my coffee. 

I humbly admit that I have become THAT person - the one who asks questions like, "Is it organic?" then, "But is it *certified* organic?" and, "who makes your almond milk?"
Because when I'm paying $10 for a cup of coffee these are things I want to know.

That being said, I think Sightglass is really great. The space is gorgeous. (Hell I'd pay $10 just to use that restroom.) It has a hipster vibe, but I've always found the people there to be really nice.  But what really draws me back is the vanilla cold brew. It's refreshing, not two sweet, and has just a hint of that strong coffee bite. It's pretty special.

If their coffee was organic I'd give them 5 stars.
author: Ann Marie H.

description:
Coffee is good. Interior is amazing. But there are also a few things that I don't like...

1. Coffee and pastry are expensive in SF. I get it. But these guys are really pushing the limit. 
2. Air circulation isn't the greatest
3. During my last visit i asked the staff for bean recommendation. He recommended one w/o giving a price warning. Turned out to be a $30 bag. There were lots of people inline and I didn't want to hold up the line. So I just bit the bullet and bought the $30 bag. Wish he would have given me a warning when recommending a $30 bag of beans.
author: Joseph L.

description:
Sightglass is a roastery located in the Soma.  It's a nice hip place to catch up with friends or do some reading as it's quiet.  I saw some people with laptops, but there was no outlet and they don't offer wifi.  The place is very spacious with bar seating downstairs and there's also an upstairs with some communal tables and bar seating as well.  

I ordered the Hooker's Mocha ($5), which was just okay.  I prefer Blue Bottle's Mocha instead as the mocha from Sightglass was missing that chocolatey taste.  The mister ordered the Vanilla Iced Cold Brew, which lacked vanilla flavor.  Overall, we thought the coffee was just okay and wouldn't purposely make a trip out here.
author: Candice H.

description:
I love Sightglass, and I expect to continue to come back here due to their fantastic coffee and espresso, great selection of pastries and other snacks, affogatos, and how close it is to my apartment

Don't expect your drink to come out super quickly here- they definitely take their time but I think it makes for a much better drink. I personally do not come here on weekday mornings, and have heard lines can get pretty crazy. I have instead been here on weekdays and while it is still pretty busy (even hard to find a seat at times) the line has never been to bad. 

I generally get a cappuccino here with almond milk (they only have almond or whole milk, so if you don't want either of those options, may want to skip Sightglass). The cappuccino is really excellent, consistently one of the best I have had. The espresso has the slight sweetness and not much bitterness that you expect from a well pulled espresso shot. There is also the perfect amount of crema, and I have always been pretty happy with the amount of foam as well (their cappucinos are on the more wet side, so if you like a good amount of froth in yours, you may want to order it dry). 

They always have a delicious looking selection of pastries, croissants, scones, and other baked goods. I've only had the bacon scone, which was fairly good, but a little too dense for me. They also have affogato- a little bit of ice cream topped with a shot of espresso. Highly recommend trying this- I loved mine and the espresso shot went super well with the intense, super dark chocolate I chose (they usually have around 3 ice cream flavors and 2 types of espresso to choose from).

Prices are decent- I would say about on par with other similar coffee shops I've been to in SOMA, maybe even a little less than some. Not cheap, but well worth it. The place is huge (2 stories, high ceilings, etc.) but it does get busy with a lot of people hanging out with laptops and such. I have been able to find a seat every time I have been here on Saturday or Sunday though, and you can even usually find parking on the weekend without too much trouble if you choose to drive. 

So far, this has been my favorite place to get a cappuccino in SOMA and I will definitely be back here.
author: Seema U.

description:
This coffee shop is nice but the seating is extremely limited. I feel like they could utilize more of their space to accommodate to guests that want to enjoy their coffee instead of frantically having to get there early to lock down a spot.

Their coffees are great and really a treat. I would say it's a bit overpriced but the experience is unique. The ambiance and decor of sightglass is very defined though I don't particularly get a friendly vibe. Feels lonesome in there, much like a community that never speaks to one another but drinks the same coffee.
author: Jennifer N.

description:
One of the top 3 coffee stops during my 2.5 week trip visiting the West Coast. This location in and of itself is worth the visit. A truly beautiful space, very warm and welcoming. 

The staff here are knowledgeable, friendly and helpful. I came with an hour left before closing but was never made to feel rushed out of the space. Ended up buying a bag of beans to take home, and have been thoroughly enjoying them. Definitely will end up buying more online.

I appreciate that they serve pour-over until closing. One of my other top 3 spots stopped serving pour-over on the afternoon I went. 

See you next year, Sightglass!
author: Natasha A.

description:
This is definitely one of my favorite coffee shops in SF. Although, it was packed on the Saturday that I went and it was hard to find seats. Besides that, their coffee is amazing and I love the ambience of Sightglass. They roast their own coffee as well which added a nice touch to the place.

The baristas are very warm and friendly; they would make the coffee relatively quickly on a busy day. They also had vegan options for small desserts and pastries. Personally, I tried the vegan chocolate cake which was very moist and delicious. I recommend going here for a nice study session (although there are no charging plugs where I was sitting) or just to grab a cup of coffee!
author: JJ S.

description:
Great coffee, spacious environment, hipster feel.

caveats are that there are NO outlets and no sofas/ chairs with cushions.
author: Jennifer J.

description:
Love the ambiance of the whole space. Great spot to sit down and get some work done. Got the vanilla iced coffee and it was aromatic with just the right amount of sweetness. Sightglass is definitely one of my favorite coffee places in SF. 

Cons:
Can get super full

Tip: they have free coffee cuppings that you can get free tickets for online!
author: Janet K.

description:
Sight Glass is an excellent coffee shop in SoMa. There is decent street parking around the area. There are two floors and the windows are very big. The atmosphere inside is very good. It is a good spot to read a book or do some work while enjoying your coffee. I ordered the mocha and it is on par with the best mochas I have tried in other cities.

If you are visiting San Francisco and looking for recommendations, feel free to message me through Yelp and I can share my itinerary, which includes my Yelp reviews. The information for an electronic copy can also be found via my Yelp profile.
author: Patrick W.

description:
I really enjoyed my visit to Sightglass. The space is beautiful and spacious. Lots of bike racks out front. The main coffee bar is in the center of the downstairs area. Upstairs, is more seating and the affogato bar. Lots of people were studying and hanging out.

I had a blood orange olive oil affogato. It was really delicious. I also bought some coffee to bring home. The staff was really friendly and helpful.

I would definitely come here again!
author: Natasha B.

description:
Best coffee I've ever had. DONE!

Huge space, tons of seating, square available for payments. Love that they have a covered garage area at the entry so that bike patrons have somewhere to park their bikes while keeping them and their bikes dry. 

While I ordered I got to take in the true beauty of the space. There is coffee being roasted live to one side with seats all around it like a bar (so you can watch). Huge vaulted warehouse style ceilings with a second (and third floor) mezzanine where you can sit at individual or communal tables to enjoy your fresh brew.

The coffee itself was a thing of beauty. Naturally almost sweet, and completely perfect all on its own - no need for any additives (Milk, cream, sugar).

The best part was watching them turn coffee into an art form. Warming cups with boiling water, perfecting the pour over, repeating the process - mesmerizing. 

Will this turn me into a chemex coffee snob? We will see - I have seen the light and it is beautiful. Thanks Sightglass Coffee for showing me the way
author: Kris U.

description:
TLDR: Good Coffee. No wifi.
Okay, Yelp wants me to write more. So here it goes. :) 
Sightglass is your SF hipster coffeshop, a large space, setup in your typical SF startup style way, with the "unfinished construction" look.
The coffee is great! True of all sighglass locations I have been to.

However, if you came in the hopes of hanging in for a few hours, and working on your blog in the computer, this is probably not your place. There is no wifi!!
I don't know if its a hipster thing, or because this will cause lots of squatters working on their startup, but THERE IS NO WIFI.

Some people were still working, I guess by tethering from their phone.
author: Sourav C.

description: A really cool, chill coffee shop with excellent coffee and an affogato bar!!!  This is the Soma location, which is a little off the beaten path.They also serve some pastries and such. We sat upstairs and I got a birdseye view of the barista preparing all the coffee's it was really cool and interesting to watch  I got a macchiato because I needed a caffeine jolt and I got one, whoo hoo!. They are no more expensive than any other quality coffee shop and their coffee is really very,very good.Might be the best in SF.
author: Karen R.

description:
Hands down, one of my favorite third wave coffee venues as of late. Two stories of coffee making madness... giant roaster running in the middle of the floor, huge cafe section as well. The space is just amazingly beautiful.

Upstairs, there's a coffee lab area, where they showcase their coffee in guided tastings (of which I've only seen a similar space at Portola Coffee labs in Costa Mesa) and an affogato bar... which was what was exactly what I needed on this hot sweltering day... which was accentuated further inside by the temperature inside due to coffee being roasted. 

To my surprise, this was not just dumping espresso on vanilla ice cream... they had 3 different espressos with specific recommended pairings of ice cream. I had what seemed strangest to do affogato with... blood orange ice cream??? But wow. It really paired well with the floral notes of the espresso I had. 

I love this place. In fact, I can't get myself to write much more, because just thinking about sight glass has given me an uncontrollable urge to physically start slow clapping... oh... shoot... can't resist... *clap*.... *clap*... *clap*...
author: Daniel L.

description:
By far the best affogato I've ever had... sorry little Italy. That orange ice cream though... YUMMM!!! 

The design is absolutely gorgeous, only down side is that it's soo hot inside specially if you sit in the upper level.
author: Tamara S.

description:
Place: The venue is amazingly aesthetic, free flowing, and busy at peak times. Bike parking/rack is accessible at the entrance too. It's open and the roaster is full on display for people to watch while they enjoy their coffee. The coffee bar is smack dabbed in the middle of the floor equipped with different brewing stations. 

There's also a loft space upstairs that gives a good view of the bottom floor work. Perfect for people to take pictures of their latte art with a cool background hehe. It's pretty hipstery. It can get really hot up there though, which is probably why they have their affogato bar up there as well. Still cool though, hehe.

Customer service: good baristas with good attitudes. The cashier could chat you up a good time, but can also keep it short if you just need a quick coffee pick up.

Drinks: my goodness the drinks are amazing. I enjoy a good espresso and their selection is well polished for the customers. I put a picture of the menu with this review. It is a bit pricier than other specialty coffee places, but it is in SF.

PRO TIP: they make their iced coffee Japanese style cold brewed (this is different from their vanilla cold brew offering). I highly recommend this especially on a hot day. It's bright and accentuates the floral flavors of the coffee better. The more floral and sweet notes on the coffee, the better. 

Overall, good atmosphere with good coffee selections. It's coffee is roasted with care and right in front of you. I had the espresso and an iced El Salvador. It's good stuff!
author: Mark R.

description:
I don't usually go out of my way to review a coffee place, since I'm such an addict I just get my fix and take it for granted. But this place? Oh man, what a treat.

Yummy, healthy baked goods, best damn pour over in my neighborhood...blessed. You really do get what you pay for here folks. And I don't think you need me to tell you, but this place is a must for the avid Instagrammer. Excellent lighting and decor, fancy coffee, seriously. I'm just here for the coffee, but I do appreciate good ambiance too.
author: Kerry S.

description:
Now that I've been here a few times I would like to sum it up with this:

You can get a great $2 cup of coffee here...for $4...
author: Jim W.

description:
Great atmosphere? Yes
Great service? You bet
The quality of baked goods and coffee? 10/10

When I think of third wave coffee, I think of sightglass. The space they have at this location is gorgeous, the staff was very friendly and personable and, of course, the coffee was great. I had a pour over and really enjoyed it
author: Billy C.

description: Ok, after returning and actually getting a cup of pourover coffee I can officially increase my review from a 3 to a 3.5, but I'm still not rounding up to 4. Is it a good pourover? Yes. Is it as good as it's hyped to be? Not really. I had the Kenyan and it had some nice fruity notes and a full, robust mouthfeel, but also some sour aftertaste. Maybe I'm just not hipster enough to appreciate this place, but I still stand by my original statement: you can get a good cup of joe at Philz for less money...plus, they have wifi.
author: Clarice W.

description: Wonderful coffee and pastry, the mocha was made with dark chocolate and not overly sweet. The staff was friendly and extremely efficient for such a high volume of people. The Oatmeal Toffee cookie was delicious.
author: Karla D.

description: $4.5 for a small regular coffee, and no wifi . I asked why no wifi and the person response was we wanna talk to each other.im like, sweetie I'm alone and have my laptop so I wanna study . I don't wanna talk to anyone. Very expensive coffee for no reason. You can still talk to people and have wifi
author: Zeyad Y.

description: I came into this beautiful coffee store with my wife, cousin  and 6month old.  I was absolutely shocked at the way the employees treated us. When I asked politely if they had called my name they shot back mimicking me and then immediately began talking to the other employees as they all stared at me. The arrogance and rudeness of this staff is by far one of the worst I've ever encountered. I NEVER write bad reviews, but the way I was treated should be an embarrassment to the owner.  Oh, and ps the coffee was so so.
author: elan z.

description:
I love the atmosphere of this place: Open concept, huge windows, two floors, wooden tables, trendy hipster vibe. If I could, I would live here. 
Ordered the vanilla ice cold brew and the macchiato. Ended up taking home a bag of beans 

Tips: 
- Not too far from Union Square (about 20 min walk)
- There's bike parking!
author: Angel D.

description: Great atmosphere. Open space with lots of seating or room for standing. Well made cappuccino. Thy know what they're doing. On a side note, loved the soap for the bathroom. Went out and bought the hand lotion version a few days later. :-) just a little extra perk.
author: Janet E.

description:
Wow, Sightglass Coffee is pretty huge! Probably the biggest coffee shop that I've ever been to in San Francisco. Before I entered, I knew that this was the hub for tech-savvy inhabitants of San Francisco because of the bikes and other modes of transportations racked up before the entrance.

I actually was here for a meeting, but I looked around to examine the whole establishment. They have an island where you can order your coffee and a separate island where customers can sit around while an employee grinds coffee.

There is also a second floor with multiple tables and chairs made out of wood which I thought was very hipster-like.

I ordered a vanilla iced tea and I thought it tasted great! I honestly didn't know what to order but the employee helped me out by narrowing down the taste that I like and made a great suggestion.

My only concern was the lack of air conditioning in the second floor. I was getting really hot during noon time because the sun was directly above the sun roof and there was no escape route for the heat.

Would I come back here again? Definitely!
author: Aj C.

description:
This was both a nice place to stop by to get a coffee and to sit and drink a coffee. I like the Rwanda brew over ice. You have to be willing to wait like 5 minutes for a coffee because it is expertly prepared. Surprisingly, they do not have wifi so not so good if you actually want to work and don't have a hotspot. 

I especially enjoyed the bathrooms because they have one of those communal washing stations with fancy nice-smelling soap and the water came out generously and you could adjust the temperature and it felt like a spa. 

It is a huge space with limited seating downstairs and a bunch of communal tables and 4 person tables upstairs, but it also gets hot up there and seems like they don't have A/C. There was this guy who came by the communal bar where I was sitting upstairs and asked if the seat with my bag on it was taken and I said yeah and he asked the guy to my left then said to me "I'm not just f*ing around, I have work to do!" Then I left and found another table and he came later and took the chair next to me that had a back. They also have a bar upstairs, which is nice, because it has a much shorter line than downstairs. 

They supply coffee to a lot of local places, like breweries (Triple Voodoo's Mocha Shake!) and restaurants, and it is always outstanding.
author: Sara M.

description:
I LOVE sight glass coffee. We drive out of our way for this coffee, and it is worth it every time. 

The building is beautiful, open space, natural lighting, wood paneling, large windows, industrial modern look to it.  Great place to sit and read. 

There are two restrooms, which are clean and well stocked.

Its a popular place, you will most likely have to endure a line, other then the fact it can get busy I only have positive things to say about this place. Love it.
author: Sara P.

description: Came here for a cold brew this morning - beautiful space and lovely spot to do work or chat with friends!  I loved the open layout and sunny feeling.  The coffee was really good and it's a nice neighborhood spot.  Would highly recommend if you are in the area.
author: Kimberly L.

description:
Just because you have had a lot of coffee doesn't mean you have experienced it all. For a brief moment I thought Blue Bottle was the best, but then 7x7 and Yelp persuaded me to try Sightglass. I can't say that their coffee and espresso are better than Stumptown or Blue Bottle, but it is definitely on the same level. 

The espresso is aromatic and silky smooth and the Nicaraguan coffee is light, smooth, and dynamic with its citrus flavors. Price point is in line with what true coffee houses charge for a quality cup of joe. 

The space is simply awesome, reminiscent of a speak-easy, coffee factory with wooden counters, high tables, and communal tables. A full, island-type coffee and espresso bar to watch baristas at work is always quite the attraction. Moreover,  you can watch the baristas and customer flow from the seating area on the second floor. If anyone knows of a spot like this in NY, please let me know!
author: Nelson W.

description: My favorite coffee place in the city. Very cool, relaxing space, great coffee, and very friendly staff. Check out the affogato bar upstairs!
author: Jim A.

description: Great atmosphere of the open two-storey plan. Lots of places to sit and enjoy a brew. Had an espresso (ended up being too bitter) and a cappuccino (no complaints, good temperature and flavor). No wifi as mentioned already so not really tourist-friendly.
author: Dan N.

description:
Let me get this straight... I have been a student for 9 yrs now so I basically live off of coffee. And SIGHTGLASS coffee has changed my life tremendously

I am super OCD about my coffee and food and SIGHTGLASS has not disappointed me yet ! 

I will come back for my two favs : iced vanilla cold brew and almond milk latte every single time  I'm craving coffee.

Thank you for your services SIGHTGLASS!
author: Reet R.

description:
OK. I went back. I gave them a 1 last time due to poor service and, unlike Gen. MacArthur, I said I'd never return. Hey, I like coffee, so shoot me.

The wait staff was friendly this time. More importantly they are a little off the deep end when it comes to brewing drip coffee. All glass carafe/cone and a scale/timer that measures amount of water and time for the pour. That's the end of the pool I want to be in when it comes to coffee. 

So good job and I'm happy to give you a 5. And for everyone who is particular about coffee, give it a try. And for all of you happy drinking average Joe's, the place is really well decorated and comfortable. So, even if the quality of the brew is lost on you, you'll probably like it.
author: August I.

description:
The price is worth it. One of the best pour overs and espressos I had. Staff is chill.
The space is industrial looking but clean design- sign me up!
author: Jane D.

description: Got the latte here and was not impressed at all. The space is industrial cool and spacious so would be a good place to meet up with a friend if in the neighborhood but definitely would not come just for the coffee.
author: Sally S.

description: Solid coffee, nice space, fresh roasted beans. I have tried a variety of coffees, never been disappointed here. Expresso is especially tasty. It's pretty spacious, I like the chic industrial design. The upstairs has a lot of space for enjoying coffee with a few friends. It can get warm up there, it's a roastery so to be expected. Their baked goods are fresh and delicious. A very good quality affogatto from the affogatto bar.
author: Sam M.

description: Very fun unique atmosphere with eclectic customers and authentic baristas. Their gluten free selection was on the dry side but other than that everything was superb!
author: Nadia M.

description:
Sightglass - Coffee Bar & Roastery

This review will be short and sweet.

Seriously the best coffee on the West Coast.

Nough said...
author: Faithmari L.

description:
Really, really good coffee. Fantastic to sit and people watch here. Also they roast the beans here and train the baristas. 
They don't do non-fat milk, but do do decaf and almond milk.
author: Niall C.

description:
I have tried a lot of coffee and consider myself a bit of a connoisseur. I have tried Blue Bottle, Four Barrel, Verve, Starbucks Reserve, Philz, Peet's, Barefoot and Sightglass is by far my favorite.

I think that they have the best coffees. They are roasted perfectly, they are flavorful. They are well done. I have made it at home. I have had it prepared at the coffee house. Both ways, the coffee is great.

These people know what they're doing. I try to get here now whenever I'm in the city.
author: Ryan L.

description: A seriously expansive coffee bar serving up all the current offerings from Sightglass along with the usual line-up of espresso drinks.  A great spot to kick back and get work done or catch up with friends.  Definitely make use of the upstairs seating and the secondary coffee bar there if lines get long downstairs.
author: Eric F.

description: My favorite coffee shop of all time! Love the industrial ambience, transparency, barista bar and the various forms of seating. From benches, elevated table tops to large group tables, you can efficiently work, catch up with friends or people watch. You can almost feel the energy & passion of the patrons here collaborating on start-ups, and great projects. The coffee is absolutely incredible & fresh. They also offer Public Coffee Cuppings where you're invited to taste various types & origins of coffee.
author: Stephanie B.

description:
Sightglass is really unique because of the workshop/lab setup of the cafe. The coffee is good, but going to the shop is an experience in and of itself! I first stopped by on a Saturday afternoon and it was fairly packed, but nothing compared to a Thursday morning (the line was out the door).

Cappuccinos and cold brews are two of my favorite drinks, and Sightglass does a great job with both. The cold brew has a twist with milk and vanilla bean for some extra flavor. I went back again with a friend and we got the mocha and espresso. The mocha was good, but like most other mochas (I prefer the mocha from Philz). Unfortunately, the espresso was pretty sour and we weren't fans.
author: Estelle C.

description: Pricey souvenirs are available, or fancy pastries, cookies or chocolates. Excellent coffee and friendly service.
author: Alisson C.

description:
Great coffeehouse, it's true that you don't have Wi-Fi here but it makes up for in so many other ways. The roaster own beans on site and you can actually see the work being done. I had the hookers coffee which was great for a brisk cool morning.

Take time to enjoy the sights and people watch on the upper level floor and enjoy your coffee.
author: Angel S.

description: Still rude. Still overpriced. I don't think they cover customer service in that crazy elaborate training program of theirs. I SO wish I lived near another coffee shop.
author: Robert M.

description:
Refreshing way to start the day!
Feel part of the whole coffee making process while you queue for your coffee and fresh pastry. 
You just want to keep coming back for more. 
There's usually parking outside (which starts from 9 am, even though it says 7am).
If you are a coffee lover, then this is THE place for you.
author: Natalie B.

description: This is my favorite coffee shop in San Francisco!! I dream about it sometimes... no joke, it's that good. And there interior design is epic!! Great places to hang out if you can find parking
author: Sharmila G.

description: The coffee is great and the atmosphere is striking but it's overpriced, even for high-end SF coffee ($3.75 for a drip coffee?!), and some of the staff are needlessly unfriendly. I MUCH prefer Blue Bottle or Ritual.
author: Geoffrey U.

description:
When you walk into this coffee shop, your jaw sort of drops - the space is gorgeous. The wood paneling and roasting machines and the terrariums just scream rustic hipster cool. There's an upstairs with more seating, including large community tables to share with strangers (or future new friends!) and even bar seating that overlooks the first floor. Love the look of this place. 

But this is serious coffee. The menu is short with like drip coffee, latte, vanilla iced coffee, and a few others. They don't do any of that current holiday special flavoring stuff. It's serious coffee. The girl taking my order kind of gave off an air of ... what would you call it... maybe like coffee snob. Not as friendly as she could have been, but from reading other yelp reviews, I guess customer service isn't a strength of theirs. 

I ordered the latte and it came with pretty latte art. I really like the space - it's very conducive for spending hours here pretending to work on your laptop while drinking some serious coffee. Thank goodness they have some pastries here too. They also sell coffee beans.
author: Sylvia K.

description: Their vanilla ice cold brew with whole milk is amazing! It's the only i order here every time.
author: Ellie D.

description:
Super cute hipster decor and beans roasted fresh in-house. But coffee is just O.K., compared to Blue Bottle. 

I don't drink almond milk or like flavored coffee drinks, but I was pleasantly surprised at how good the iced vanilla latte with almond milk was. The almond milk didn't make the espresso taste sour and the vanilla wasn't too sweet/overpowering!
author: Adrienne K.

description: Affogato is pretty good. They have good choice of coffee beans. WIll come again.
author: Aaggrim S.

description: I love the store on 7th. It's very spacious and a warm environment. The industrial feel of the place fits in well with the coffee that they serve. The only negative is that it's hard to find parking around there and hard to get to via public transit. Nevertheless, this is one of my top five places for coffee in the Bay Area!
author: Johnathan W.

description:
It's so pretty! Everywhere you look there are exposed beams, interesting hardware, beautiful lighting, succulents growing out of walls... 

I was told that they purposely do not offer wi-fi as to increase the likelihood of patrons interacting with one another. The downstairs area does seem to adhere to this-- I think my checking into Yelp singled me out since no one else is on their phone inside.

Upstairs, however, people are spread out on long tables working on laptops. I saw a guy painting. Is this place real?

Tons of space, great coffee, and lots of options to try, taste, and buy. I love a place where you can watch them roast in-house.
author: Trisha F.

description:
Sightglass coffee will be the coffee I measure all other coffees by forevermore. I asked what they recommend first-timers: pour over drip-coffee. I thought to myself, how good could a pour over be? NEVER. UNDERESTIMATE. THE POUR OVER. 

I had an Ethiopian coffee, but honestly, I bet any and all coffee from Sightglass is amazing. It was smooth and light, but that doesn't mean the flavor was light by any means! The coffee was truly a delightful experience every step of the way as it slid through my lips into my mouth and went down my throat. There was a different note of flavor on every part of my tongue that wasn't overpowering, but oh, so enjoyable. And, it paired amazingly with my chocolate cranberry scone.

I bemoan the fact that I do not live in SF for lack of access to this coffee shop. 

Seriously, I'm so sad.
author: Michelle P.

description:
Good but expensive coffee, no wifi, slow service, and kind of rude people working every time I've been there. 

It's a nice cliche urban coffee shop but I'd rather go to one of SF's neighborhood cafes if I want to sit down for a while.
author: Munaf A.

description: Awesome interior and great coffee but the staff was less than pleasant for pretty menial reasons and there's no WiFi. Kinda disappointing but I did love the espresso
author: Jonathan O.

description: This place is tucked away on 7th street, and a little hard to find. The inside is gorgeous and the coffee is great. I had a plain latte and it was delicious, how the foam was caramelized and can we talk about how pretty the coffee art is here? Great place.
author: Megan M.

description:
Decent coffee with a fantastic decor.

The inside of this coffee shop is quite a treat for the eyes.  

Unfortunately the coffee is not as good as the ambiance or long lines would indicate.  

The pourover drips sound cool, but all taste roughly the same.  They're not bad, however, as they all have the nice, tart, fruity taste and nectary finish from light roasted, single-origin beans.  However, there is a much better variety of beans and better selections at Four Barrel or Coffee Culture.  

The cappucinos have great art, but, in my opinion, the milk isn't quite frothed enough.  

The vanilla cold brew is just a sweet coffee drink, similar to the canned Starbucks or Illys you find at grocery stores.  Definitely not worth the price.

One huge negative is they only have one size for all drip coffee, a small 12 ounce cup.  If you want a larger size cup of caffeine to wake you up, go somewhere else.

Pastries are decent but expensive, and all the baristas are nice.
author: Brian S.

description:
I was blown away from how big, clean, and nicely decorated the space was. Although they have tons of seating on both floors it was really crowded on a weekend afternoon with lots of people on their laptops and there weren't any seats left. 

Ordered the vanilla iced cold brew coffee with almond milk ($4). It came in a nice mason jar and was soo refreshing and tasty! Definitely one of the best iced coffees I've ever had. I loved the unique flavor that the almond milk adds to it. I really recommend trying this!

Overall awesome space, coffee, and service!
author: Linda X.

description:
Bi-level, industrial design coffee space. Literally, does it get any better?

I love coffee in "unexpected places" and this place literally was a hidden gem. Felt like a factory garage, to be honest, and I loved the grungy, bare-bones, minimalist feel right as I entered the wooden + rustic space.

I'm so glad I chose the 7th street location to visit -- a production roastery, open coffee bar, community gathering space with tons of communal tables perfect for working or for meetings, and company headquarters all in one! It truly feels like a Sightglass experience, which is what I loved.

It is a STUNNING space, to say the least. It filled me with inspiration immediately as I entered, and I spent my first 15-20 minutes there just walking around, observing the baked goods that stood out amidst the factory-like design of the space, as well as observing the beautiful drinks, the packaging and branding, etc. I loved it all.

Could definitely see myself spending hours here, sipping coffee and cranking out some work.

Definitely worth a visit - it's located in somewhat of a random area (easy to walk right past it?!) but that adds to the charm. Again -- coffee in unexpected places. The best.
author: Roopa S.

description:
This wasn't my first time at Sightglass, nor would it be my last! 

I absolutely LOVE the location - easy to find parking (albeit you pay Mon-Fri and I believe Saturday, but it's totally free on Sunday!), close to Union Square (but not so close that you go crazy with tourists), and oh-so-much space that you don't feel cramped! 

Today's event prompted me to write a review after visiting this location a bajillion times. Just kidding - this would have been my sixth time here, and sixth time having Sightglass.

I usually come here with my bestie to grab coffee while we're in the city during the day. Long story, short, today was different as I was awake at an unusual time for myself (5:30AM). I decided that Sightglass coffee was the only coffee that would give me the kick I needed to drive my butt back to Sactown. 

7:00AM. I pick up my car from the hotel valet and cruise my way down from Union Square to 7th street. It's quiet and the sun is barely rising. I park and walk in to order my usual: caffe latte. 

I'm still half dead from waking up so early, so I didn't pay too much attention to the cashier when he asked me for my order. I just said, "One latte to go please."
Barista/cashier: Ok, that'll be $7.25.
Me: *hands $10.25* *receives $3*
-pause-
Barista/cashier: *hands over something in a bag*
-pause-
Me: Hey... did the price of your latte just go up? Wasn't it like, $4 or something?
Barista/cashier: I'm sorry?
Me: Oh, it's just that you said it was $7.25... that's a bit...
Barista/cashier: I'm so sorry! I thought you said you wanted a croissant!
Me: Oh, no worries! I just wanted a latte; don't really want anything to eat right now.
Barista/cashier: I'll get it done for you. I'm so sorry about that!

He takes the croissant in the bag back and begins to place my order in. After waiting for a couple minutes, another barista calls out my name for my order. Nicely done & well presented again! I wouldn't expect any less from Sightglass.

As I take my latte over to the other counter with the lids, the barista/cashier gentleman called me in a quiet and apologetic voice. He hands me a shot of cold brew mixed with vanilla(?) and apologizes profusely. He really didn't have to! I totally get it - it's early in the morning and things happen! It could've been me not enunciating my order well, so I'm sorry about that! 

To the barista/cashier that was helping me today at like 7:10AM - THANK YOU for making my morning! Now that I've tried your cold brew, I'm looking forward to my next visit in the city! 

TL;DR What's good here?
(+) Coffee - strong, smooth yet bold flavor
(+) Atmosphere - quiet & hipster
(+) Interior - so nice, roomy and I love the display of machines & coffee around! & lots of seating!
(+) Service - see the entire paragraph above; the staff here go above and beyond your expectations! You all are wonderful!
(-) Why aren't you anywhere else except for SF? Please come to LA/OC!
author: Nicole Q.

description: Great looking place and interesting, spacious interior.. smelled good. but definitely a SF pricetag... I had a cold brew that came out 95% MILK 4% ICE and then maybe a hint of coffee flavor. I wanted coffee not milk. Wont be back.
author: Brad S.

description:
Sightglass has gotten increasingly popular, and with good reason too. A warehouse-turned coffee shop, the place feels really open with the high ceilings and mezzanine level seating. The coffee and pastries are amazing, but let's talk about the affogato bar for a second. 

Yes. An affogato bar. When I saw the Eater.com article about Salt & Straw and Sightglass' new partnership, I knew immediately that I had to see it for myself because it was just too good to be true. Featuring unique ice cream flavors (some fancy chocolate I forgot the name of, blood orange and olive oil, and sea salt with caramel ribbons) and three different types of espresso, you can mix and match to create an affogato or cold brew float that best suits your taste buds. I honestly came in wanting some classic vanilla ice cream smothered with espresso, but I appreciate that they're trying to do something different. 

I ended up sharing a sea salt with caramel ribbons affogato with I think the Rwanda espresso(?) and a blood orange float with a friend, and both were amazing. I ended up liking the float better because the sea salt affogato was really heavy, but definitely worth trying in my opinion. 

I love that Sightglass is evolving as the coffee trend grows. I can't wait to see what they come up with next and what other coffee shops do to follow suit!
author: Sabrina C.

description: First of all this is the coolest design for a cafe ever with a very industrial feel. There are active workshops, roasters, grinders surrounding the bar with a loft above. The coffee is great and you can sip it listening to spinning vinyl (edgy alternative while we were here)
author: Kevin C.

description: A little note for whoever was the employee who make my capuccino last Friday afternoon. You were nice, you were attentive, you had good manners and you were also cute, but you make the worst coffee drinks in the entire planet. Seriously dude, this coffee shop will be out of business in a few weeks if you do not improve your coffee-making techniques.
author: Jonathan F.

description:
A friend a i recently went to San Fran for a weekend getaway. We went to the farmers market in the ferry building and noticed the Sightglass stand so thought we should stop by for a quick caffiene fix. LIFE CHANGING. We both got the vanilla iced coffee with almond milk. We liked it so much that we sought out the brick and mortar store the next morning.
