The flavor is amazing, although I wish we could get a large and not just a small...

My friend got coffee to bring home with him. They ground it for him in shop and sent him back with perfect coffee ready to transform into iced coffee.  SIGHTGLASS: COME TO NYC!!!
author: Sarah Z.

description: Excellent espresso.  Excited I was finally able to get out here.  4 because the cold brew was terrible.  Takes on too much vanilla flavor, presumably from soy milk or something.  Will definitely be back for a cappuccino whenever I am out this way
author: Shaun K.

description:
Nice ambience, great service. 

Mediocre location, and the espresso wasn't as good as Ritual (IMO). 

Would definitely go back if I'm in the area and in need of a place to chat with someone over a non-alcoholic beverage.
author: Sam Z.

description: Place was too hipster for me. I ordered the espresso, I'm mean do they ever taste good? Other wise a cool place to stop, the space was cool and pretty minimalistic
author: Darlene V.

description:
Uh, YEAH. This place is so good I want to add an umlaut. It's gOOOd... ooh la la!

-Espresso - I'm appreciating Owl's Howl this visit. I can have it as espresso and then go back and have an espresso based drink w/ milk for dessert and then go back and get a Hooker's mocha if I'm feeling extra sexy. You're so flexible Owl's Howl. Ooh la la la LALALALA la.
-Space - beautiful design and great flow, where the queue breaks on both sides of the 2 registers to break up the caffeine herd. While you wait patiently after tipping well, you can peek at the roasters or stare at metal surfaces and wood grain for sustained lengths of time and somehow no one will judge you or assume you're on acid for observing so closely. They may even join you. 
-If someone actually does join you, there's a good chance he or she or it won the genetic lottery. 
-B.Patisserie pastries are gOOOd.
-No wifi so my friend and I can actually find a place to sit down, chew our pastries, sip our preferred coffees of the day, and pretend we're more refined and civilized than we (I) normally are (am) to improve the likelihood that some coffee imbibing hottie will talk to *my friend* (and to match the nice surroundings, of course).

What is the sound of one hand clapping? I don't know b/c I have coffee in each hand.

OOOh ya, I'm really appreciating you, Sightglass. Keep up the gOOOd work.
author: Alma C.

description:
The coffee is thebomb.com, and tips are demanded. I had no cash, but wanted to try the stuff because a barista told me it was the best in the city.

Gave them my Apple Pay, and the barista swung the screen around for the demanded and unthanked tip.

It's on the pricy  side but it's  all the way delicious. The pastries cookies etc match. It's almost fun to pay too much, I can't explain it. I will def return.
author: Jane S.

description:
Walked here about a mile from the hotel I stayed at. It was the nearest coffee shop that had good rating. 

I'm impressed when I walked in, this place is huge! It's like a restaurant-ish, factory-ish type of place. It has two stories. Didn't get to check out upstairs but there were people up there literally just chillen. 

Love their pastry selection. So many to choose from. I had the Pistachio blackberry croissant and man it was good! It buttery flakey and it was moist in the inside. The sweetness was just perfect. I loved his the blackberries complimented the pistachio, it didn't over power it. It was a hint of it and you know it was blackberries. The regular croissant was delicious as well. Rich, buttery flakey goodness! 

I highly recommend this place!
author: Ardie M.

description: Coffee here is good, affogato here is fantastic. If you're into coldbrew, Sightglass also has a vanilla cold brew that I remember to be quite good (haven't gotten it in a while). I really like the atmosphere here, but the only con (or pro?) is that there is no wifi. This means that there are usually seats to sit at because people aren't camping around with their computers, but this also means you won't be using this as a work from home cafe when you're looking for one.
author: Austin W.

description:
Worst coffee I've ever had! I ordered a mocha and it had unsweetened, dark chocolate. How is that in any way a mocha? Why order a mocha if you don't want it to be sweet? 
The entire place was just a hipster stereotype. If you want gross, but organic and trendy coffee in a place you can feel like you are hipster and cool, then this is the place for you. You can take your $165 gram scale for the perfect coffee and be all ironic in the corner of Sightglass.
author: Nat C.

description:
One of best coffee shops in SF, no joke, these folks know what they are doing!  The vanilla ice cold brew is just heavenly, a good balance of coffee, milk, and vanilla.  They use real vanilla, non of the fake stuff here!  The latte and caps are well made using their signature espresso beans.   I really like their espresso beans, its slightly dark with hints of chocolate and bourbon.

The decor is very rustic, plenty of seats and lounge areas to chat.  Only downside is that this place gets super crowded and a little loud due to the sound echos.  Only reason i downgraded 1 star is due to the excess noise.

Personally i prefer the Sightglass in Mission, its a little more low keyed and more homey.  But both places make amazing drinks and coffee!  I highly recommend if you are a coffee connoisseur.
author: Terence N.

description:
Phenomenal coffee
Lots of tables upstairs to work and chat.
Great place
author: Salim M.

description:
Sightglass is probably one of my favorite coffee shops here in SF. I've been here many times whenever I am in San Francisco. I used to consider myself as a coffee snob (because I would go to different coffee shops almost weekly) but I guess I still don't know all that much about coffee. But I want to say I know a lot compared to before. 

If this is your first time here (or if it's your first time at this type of coffee shops), then you might not exactly know how to feel since the coffee you usually drink (maybe from like Starbucks) is more likely to be Peets or Starbucks. I guess coffee is an art and this type of coffee will grow on you a little more every time you take a sip. 

But that's besides the point. I really like Sightglass for both the coffee and the location. The coffee shop is huge and very spacious. Most other coffee shops in SF tend to be a little smaller because of space constraints. But this is definitely a great spot! Parking is also pretty convenient. I never had trouble finding a spot and I usually park across the street. 

Onto the coffee, I get the latté at every coffee shop so I can compare with the places I've been to. I love their latté though! It's so delicious. I guess you have to acquire the taste because I used to think it was too bitter. But in a good way. It has that bitter taste but you can also taste the beans that were used in the process of making it. It's pretty smooth and I enjoy it a lot. It's never too sweet or anything. The milk and coffee are nicely balanced. I have had their cappuccino as well but I am not very fond of cappuccino in general, so I'm a little biased.

Overall, I definitely enjoy my SF day trips a little better with a Sightglass coffee in hand. I love the atmosphere here. It's a nice place to catch up with friends, get some work done, and also watching them roast the beans while you're sipping on your coffee! Definitely worth making a trip to Sightglass!
author: Wendy Y.

description:
- The ambience of this business is awesome. The location isn't bad for parking. 

- The pastries and the coffee are to die for especially since they make everything fresh right in front of you. The aroma of coffee beans and sweet pastries. 

- The customer service was outstanding and prompt for how busy they get. 

- My only concern and the reason for not giving 5 stars is how Hot they allow it to get in the seating area upstairs. I spoke to a gentleman next to me who's a regular and he says it's like that regularly. I love the layout of the building but Turn on the AC please!
author: Danny R.

description:
Vanilla cold brew w almond milk for the win. 

Sadly, they recently started pre-mixing it. Still tastes good, not AS good.

The other location ( since I was last there ) still does it the original ( better ) way!

Oh and they have B. Patisserie pastries, delish! I recommend the Almond Croissant!
author: L F.

description: Favorite coffee shop in SF? Perhaps. Best ambiance for a coffee shop in SF? For sure. Amazingly cool atmosphere. High warehouse style ceilings. Multiple levels. Open air vibes. And guess what? Simple delicious coffee menu. They do a mean flat white. Probably best in SF. And there coffee is on point as well.
author: Jesse L.

description:
Has the emperor lost his clothes? Perhaps not but he certainly gave me small-mouth with a definite shrug on my last couple of visits here. And it makes me truly melancholy that the architectural beauty of a place can camouflage the indifference of a staff who really didn't care when I got my coffee. Gee, I remember when Sightglass Coffee opened over three years ago as a temporary stand next to a warehouse in the middle of its massive construction into an artisan roastery.

The young woman back then was charming and made quality coffee using a Chemex hourglass. It was nice just to sit casually on the nearby bench and chat with her when it wasn't busy. Well, the renovation is complete, and the result is a cavernous, industrial-chic place with stools lining a wooden counter that faces 7th Street and a mezzanine that accommodates about thirty laptoppers. All signs point to a great place for cross-generational socializing, but the hipster quotient is on high octane here. Ill-mannered behavior like cutting in line is pervasive.

These young, self-absorbed customers - usually dressed in pea coats and patterned scarves - are staring intently into their mobile devices and ignoring any sense of etiquette that have likely preceded them by a generation. What saddens me more is how the staff carries the same attitude - an unsmiling indifference to the possible diversity of their customer base. Instead, fellow hipsters are favored over decided non-hipsters like me who wear discount shirts from the Van Heusen outlet and happen to be carrying a bottle of Drano and a drain snake purchased at Speedy's nearby. How uncool.

I guess neither the order taker nor the barista felt a need to clarify to me that I had to wait for my handmade coffee on the side of the counter opposite the industrial-strength GS2 espresso machine. Upon that news uttered in a ho-hum monotone, I immediately walked around the large oval counter to find my $4 cup of Rwandan coffee uncovered and lukewarm. There was no need for me to stay since no one felt a need to make me feel welcome. Those high school feelings of rejection never go away, do they?

COFFEE - 3 stars...betting the rich flavor of the Rwandan blend was great when it was hot
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...striking industrial-loft decor is hard not to admire even if seating is at a premium
SERVICE - 1 star...a lonely star they should wear on their lapels
TOTAL - 2 stars...sad to downgrade as I think the Morrison brothers have a great concept, but treating all customers with equal respect would be better to me than the discovery of another exotic coffee bean
author: Ed U.

description: What a great space for this coffee shop! I got myself a drip coffee and headed upstairs where there was plenty of communal tables. A great place to meet up with friends over coffee to hang out and catch up.
author: Hong L.

description:
In the age of on-line retail, when the inalienable human right to free shipping nearly has become an addendum to the U.S. Constitution, it's nice to know that - yes - the modern-day pilgrimage still exists.

You know: a pilgrimage. A journey of self-exploration cast as a religious rite of passage. Mecca. Lourdes. A Shinto shrine on a snow-capped mountaintop. A Bhutanese Buddhist temple. A sacred native American hot springs, redwood grove, or steaming volcanic crater. That sort of thing.

Well, that's what an 8 am visit to Sightglass in SoMa is like. It's clearly a working roastery, with the vintage Probat spinning in endless cycles as fresh beans get turned into little gems of caffeine-laced magic. The space is cavernous, with an almost cathedral-like feel to the soaring ceiling and natural light pouring through ample glass panels. You very nearly feel like there should be basins of holy water at the entrance to anoint yourself so that you are worthy of the ritual that is to come. I had to fight the urge not to remove my shoes once I crossed the threshold and approached the counter to order my first coffee of the morning.

The single-origin bags beckon on the right-hand side, simple brown packaging containing a wealth of beans from Latin America, Africa, and the Pacific. The espresso stand churns out almond-milk lattes, near-perfect macchiatos, and caps and cortados and double shots and all the rest.

Meanwhile, the staffers sip, roast, pour, and move from station to station like monks or nuns or sufi mystics or high priests or shamans. You almost can hear the mantras being repeated as the silence of the place starts to overwhelm you.

But it's just coffee, right?

No, I think not. If it were, we'd all be ordering vacuum-packed beans on-line and making macchiatos in the privacy of our own homes. Or getting our coffee beans from Trader Joe's. But it's not 1995 anymore. 

And clearly we don't all live in San Francisco, as appealing a prospect as that sounds. And sometimes we do want to Blue Bottle, or Ritual, or Four Barrel, or Verve, or go slumming at a local Starbucks or Peets (as long as we don't meet anyone we know). I've even Philzed a few times in my life - although I'm not proud of it! 

So that's why we don our pilgrimage cloak, grab our reusable shopping bag, wake up before dawn, and head to places like Sightglass.

For the coffee and the beans and the Hario #2 pour-over filters, of course.

But also for the utterly unique experience of being at that singular place of origin where the Probat turns, the beans empty into bins, the light shines, and the reclaimed wood countertops beckon. 

Pilgrimage sites. The twitter-friendly face of an ancient human practice, as old as religion itself. Just with better espresso.

Is it an addiction - or just extreme religious devotion? Who are we mere mortals to decide such things, anyway? He who is without sin can judge the relative merits of the third-wave coffee pilgrimage. For the rest of us, there is always the next Sightglass out there on the edges of the known coffee world - if we are adventurous enough to get out of our comfort zones and to go and find it.

(Amen).
author: Bradley N.

description:
The space/location of this place is probably why I would come back here a lot. There isn't any WiFi, but thank goodness for phone tethering!  My friends and I came here to work on a Monday. I could've stayed there forever, honestly. 

Happy space + coffee = Happy Jo
author: Joanne W.

description: Awesome iced coffee and the pastries are delicious. The decor is open and pleasing on the eyes:) When I have visitors, I take them to this place as it's one of my favorite coffee spots in SF.
author: Kathy R.

description:
It's a coffee shop with no wifi. Not sure why in here. I can get coffee anywhere.

Pros:
- They make the coffee here.
- Trendy?

Cons: 
- No wifi
- no enough sitting
author: Juan S.

description: Any place with Salt & Straw ice cream is a win. Add the fact that it's an Affogato bar. Super hipster joint crawling with students.
author: Derrick C.

description:
When I first walked in I was really impressed at the architect and layout of the building. Two floors of seating and on the side they roast their own coffee. It was my first time here and I tried their iced coffee with almond milk. Loved it, they use block ice so my coffee wasn't overwhelmed by ice like other coffee places. 

Only downside is no Wifi and only pay street parking but a great place for chatting or working on personal things that don't need Wifi. 

I would totally invite my friends to this place if I'm ever back in the area!
author: Rachelle L.

description:
Note: This review is only of Sightglass's restrooms.

I was walking between the caltrain station on 4th and King and my friend's place on 7th and Minna (a 1.2 mile distance) when I realized I needed to use the restroom. 

Sightglass was right there so I walked in urgently, not making eye contact with the admissibly friendly baristas. No one stopped me, nor was there a lock or code on the bathroom door. 

The restroom was just a toilet and the sinks were outside with both higher quality paper towels and nice hand soap. All in all, it was a comfortable experience.
author: Rishikesh T.

description:
5 stars! Can't say enough good things about this establishment. Went with a friend, I drink a lot of coffee, but I by no means am a very educated coffee drinker, other than stay away from the likes of Starbucks, Peet's, etc. 

The girl working the cash register was more than helpful; maybe not the most enthusiastic, but she wasn't rude. The ambiance is very cool, whoever designed the interior deserves a pat on the back, it's a very hip spot. Today happened to be a hot day, so I went with an iced coffee. I ordered the ethiopian brew; had a light body, add a lil bit of milk and sugar and it's golden. 

Highly recommend this place if you are a coffee lover
author: Aaron C.

description:
I'm a Sightglass fan already, so I'm biased. That coffee is straight up delicious. ("Straight up" exclusively makes me start singing Paula Abdul. Anyone else?)

This location is breezy if not wasteful with its space. The upstairs contains most of the seating, and the downstairs houses a line of people at almost all times, but not much else. 

I love that they serve primarily light roasts. They are delicious, aromatic, and unique. If you enjoy a dark roast, might I recommend the americano to substitute.

While I give them absolute props for the quality of their product, this space loses a star because it could house far more people than it does currently. The ground floor could easily fit more seats and therefore more to-stay customers. The coffee pickup situation is a bit confusing as well: I had one cup of Papua New Guinea, AAK Brothers Coop and one Americano (for my dark roast loving friend). We missed her Americano completely because it came out on the other side of the coffee bar and they called for "Casey" rather than "Katie." Props to them: they made a new one for her after it got tossed out.

Tip: when you're there, STOCK UP on a bag o' beans. I love Blueboon.
author: Amanda D.

description: I come here pretty much every single time in San Francisco and their coffee is amazingly, consistently great each time.  From the countless times I've been here, this is the first time I've tried the affogato bar upstairs.  They use single origin coffee with artisan ice cream from Portland.  I had the Honduras espresso poured over salted caramel gelato and it took all of my self-restraint not to order a second one.
author: Trish S.

description: I got a latte with almond milk and it's was super good!!! You can watch them grind the coffee and also watch them make your drink! It's a really cool space! Definitely coming back here again when I'm in San Fran!
author: Brittany C.

description:
(old review, saved on my computer..)

Love the space, the coffee and the people watching experience here. I've been here a few times, each time was to enjoy their cappuccino or mocha (sometimes both in one visit!). The mocha is very rich, but the chocolate they use is so distinctive that you just have to try it. the espresso blend is acidic and makes you sip slow, but they pull very balanced shots so it is never too much.

I give 4 stars because last time we ordered 2 cappuccinos, one had much more milk than the other, but other than that, I'll always come back to Sightglass when I'm in the neighborhood!
author: Maggie G.

description:
There is no shortage of amazing coffee in SF, so my expectations are unreasonable. However, Sightless deserves every star because they meticulously source coffee from the best growers and deliver drips of gold to my cup. Bean quality and flavor begin to degrade once the coffee is roasted. After a week or two, roasted beans loose a significant amount of flavors. Coffee beans are roasted daily right here on seventh, which means the beans still have maximum flavors. You can select from a couple single origins, or bulk brewed coffee if you are in a hurry. An Ethiopian single origin drip is my default, and of course, highly recommended.

Let's not forget the espresso, which requires good beans and barista talent. Sightless has consistently delivered a delicious macchiato or cappuccino. (Pro tip: macchiato is a great compliment to a drip.)

Looking for a mid-day dessert coffee? Skip the register and proceed upstairs to the Affogato Bar. (Affogatto is espresso poured over ice cream.) The menu typically include a choice between two single origin espressos and three ice-creams, all selected because of complimentary flavors. You select one of each (there is also a de-caff option).
author: Nathan E.

description: There's plenty of bike racks out the front, two floors so you can always find a seat, nice selection of pastries and coffee beans. The dim lighting is suitable for a catch-up with a friend or casual business meeting. The long bar downstairs is a nice place to do some work or read a book, without any judgment.
author: Cason S.

description: Met a friend here for a quick cold brew and a meeting and I can honestly say that I appreciate the openness of the space as well as the quality of the coffee, a rare combination in San Francisco. Quick polite service, plenty of seating upstairs and downstairs, and the natural light coming into the space is also nice. Overall very chill vibe.
author: Morgen B.

description:
This gem was the most hidden greatness I've ever seen! Such a large beautiful business hidden by a deceitful front view! The crew was chill, Lily made my drink terrific Barista. Rommey handled our pour over and was very outgoing, and friendly. Sal working the register was informative and efficient. Quality cup uh joe ! 


With the fresh smell of roasted beans, and casual lounge setting it's definitely a must see for the coffee lovers of the world.
author: Briana Nadine S.

description: Great coffee. Great customer service and most important delicious coffee!!!  Love this location!
author: Tina R.

description:
Honestly, I don't know a lot about coffee, but Sightglass is one of the prettiest coffee shops I have ever been to.

I had a latte--smooth, rich, thick, and of course complete with perfect latte art. I thought it was fine, but I'm really not so crazy about coffee and can't distinguish between different coffee shops' lattes.

But again the space is absolutely gorgeous: high ceilinged with large windows (so much sunlight streaming in!), airy, and finished with warm yellow woods and bright glass. It was such a lovely place to get work done. Minus a star for the lack of free wi-fi (2013 in San Francisco? Free wi-fi is pretty much an unalienable right) as I imagine the majority of people trying to crank work out would need it. Also, I really hate walking through this side of SOMA, but I'll do it for Sightglass.

Love this spot!
author: Kelly R.

description:
Sightglass is my favorite coffee in the City. Yes. I like it more than Blue Bottle, Ritual, and Four Barrel. I always get a cappuccino to go and a bag of beans for home. I never stick around to sit but I do like the open concept and the roaster on display.

Sightglass is definitely making a name for itself. I saw their beans being used in the NYC coffee shops.
author: Kien M.

description:
I had the best latte of my life (so far) at Sightglass. So smooth and rich. One sip and my taste buds were practically dancing in pure happiness. It's definitely not cheap - the cup is pretty small. But the quality more than makes up for it. Not your typical watered-down latte at Starbucks! Plus the latte art is beautiful. A feast for your senses!

Both the cashier guy and the barista were quite friendly. No complaints with the service!

Love the space! It's designed a bit strangely and they could probably fit a lot more seating if they moved some things around, but I think it'd be a lovely place to read a book while inhaling the amazing smells and sipping coffee.
author: Ivonnie S.

description:
Amazing place to hang out. Great location. I try to visit every chance I come to SF on the weekends to hangout:

+ Beautiful location
+ Great coffee

- No Wifi


Probably my favorite SF coffee joint
author: Jack T.

description: Great looking location, open and spacious. I watched them roast their coffee which was a treat. Staff is very friendly and helpful. They recommended the vanilla cold brew which was very tasty and nice on a hot day. Seating fills up fast and there is no wifi which is actually a big bummer. I would spend all day there if it wasn't for that! But bring a book, sit down and relax with some great coffee.
author: Monica M.

description:
Oh Sightglass, how you've changed my life. Their cold brew is amazing! Nothing needs to be added. Fragrant with a hint of vanilla. Seriously, life changing. 

Their soy latte is also perfect, I literally do not add anything. Must try. 

I wish it was closer to where I work so walking would be an option...
author: Audrey N.

description: Loveeee the decor and feel of this coffee shop!! Suuuuper hipster with a large open feel and coffee bars in the center as well as up the stairs. The affogato bar is upstairs - so good! You can choose from a variety of ice cream flavors as well as types of espresso. My personal favorite part of the whole place :) it does get super crowded though, with people hanging out and working with their laptops, so don't expect to be able to find a seat!
author: Grace D.

description: Pretty cool coffee shop in SOMA, just as expensive as all other other coffee shops popping up all over SF. Coffee was pretty good, many would say its comparable to Blue Bottle Coffee, which I guess I would agree. I'm not a coffee connoisseur so... I can't say I know what I'm talking about. The set up is pretty nice, lots of seating downstairs and upstairs, but it was really stuffy when I was last there. Also, they don't have any wifi, what kind of coffee shop doesn't have wifi? I guess the super hip kind. Overall it was a pretty cool place to catch up with friends but not a place I would go out of my way to try.
author: Elaine N.

description:
Very trendy coffee place! Love the decor in here.

The barista was so nice and taking to us about how he makes the designs in the coffee. The vanilla iced coffee was DELICIOUS! You could see the little pieces from the vanilla bean in it. The mocha was okay but the design on top was cute!
author: Alyssa K.

description: Coffee lovers. You're in for a real treat. Not only is the coffee amaze balls, but the pastries, friendly staff and unique decor will have you in coffee heaven. Sip on a cup of joe or fancy blend of the day as you watch berna being roasted right in front of you. As a cyclist, I love being able to hang and lock my bike worry free at the entrance. Never disapointing. Always amazing.
author: Marie-France L.

description:
Easily my favorite coffee shop in San Francisco. I prefer this place to Blue Bottle, and I prefer this location to the other Sightglass in Mission. This is a locals spot with a stunning interior, delicious coffee, and tasty small bites. I especially love that almond milk is available.

Sightglass is definitely a hipster mecca with the selection of vinyl behind the counter and lofty industrial vibe, but the staff doesn't conduct themselves with the judgy aloofness that I've come to associate with places like these. It's an open and relaxed place.
author: S. F.

description:
My go-to every weekend! Nice ambiance - big empty space with high ceiling with upstairs seating as well.  Definitely on the pricier side but I expected that from a hipster coffee shop in SF. Vanilla ice brew is my absolute favorite but their lattes are my usual for hot drinks! Pastries are good- nothing too special and pretty pricey so usually I just go for the coffee. 
PS they only have almond milk and whole milk and there's no wifi available
author: Taryn Q.

description:
Amazing coffee = Perk #1
Stunning SoMa Architectural Space = Perk #2
Perk #1 + Perk #2 = THIS PLACE ROCKS
author: Justin L.

description:
I had a really delicious latte here. As you walk in, you can see the coffee bean roasting machine to your right. Their menu is very simple ie. Regular black, latte, cappuccino, mocha. No fancy flavored syrup here so don't expect that. They make each cup with love and I can see they enjoy making it. It's like art.

I really enjoy the environment here. A good cup of coffee and a good book made a great Sunday Funday for me last weekend. I only wish they have some couches to lounge around in because all the chairs are bar stools. However, there is a back to lean back on.
author: Nancy N.

description:
Architecturally speaking this place is something to see for sure... massive open space with a high vaulted ceiling and an overlooking upper/mezzanine level... overwhelmingly hip (I'll refrain from using the word 'hipster') and just makes you want to grin from ear to ear the moment you step in!

My latte did taste GREAT!!!... despite the atypical looking pour this particular gent created.  I would've preferred a leaf, or even a heart, but a crock & balls??? Really?  (see a link to my pic below).  I am right handed (see relative handle placement in my pic), so as I sipped and looked into my cup, I couldn't help but notice the shaft of cream entering my mouth head first.  Geez!  Despite this, I'll be back though and I have a special request for my pour next time... two words:  V-Jay Jay.... (not really).

TIP:  Don't make a fool out of yourself and ask for any flavorings added to your latte or cappuccino (I did not do this).  They are all about "the bean" here, and asking for sugary syrup to be added is kind of like asking for A-1 or Heinz-57 sauce at a 5 star steak house... don't do it!

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/EF5bwZnRwjGJQlcRvviMKw?select=FSz_LfqZXmZ-pVH6_x1diQ#5DZ4x9vmfKvT5kd9ccQZPQ
author: Jeremy H.

description:
HIPSTER. The first thing that screams out to you once you enter the coffee shop is HIPSTER!

First of all, the place is awesomely gorgeous. You have coders sippin' their coffee, men and women chit chatting, and the bar itself quite small but nice looking and hip. You've got iPad square swiping services everywhere, 5 or 6 people working and a goddamn vinyl!

The drinks were kinda pricy, as I got latte and it cost around 5 dollars for a not-so-big cup. The latte was good, but not great. The cold brew was pretty good, but then again, not out of this world. But hey, who cares anyway? You're here for the atmosphere! If you're looking for a coffee shop that 1) feels hipster (because thats the way you like it) 2) has really really nice inner design and 3) is relatively quiet, then this place is for you! There's even a specific place you can park you bike in vertically!

PS. DON'T forget to get the postcard! It's free and it is THE best looking postcard I've seen in my life.
author: Kelden L.

description:
This has got to be the most relaxing, spacious, unpretentious coffee shop experience that I've ever endured. 

My friend and I came here post midterm week to chat about everything and had the most relaxing, peaceful time. We both ordered lattes that went down smoothly and were created to perfection.

This will surely be my new coffee lounge spot. The ambiance is fabulous and screams industrial chic. 

Places like this remind me of how much I love living in sf. Cheers.
author: Court S.

description:
As everybody has stated, it is GORGEOUS inside. Super open floor plan with upstairs seating available. You can definitely spend a mornoon working away on a laptop or getting lost in a book here. 

Ok, now that I've got that over and done with. In the past I've heard that Sightglass has some pretty acidic roasts. I don't like Four Barrel for that reason (borderline gives me heartburn every now and then, gross) but Sightglass I do like! (and my body had no issues with). Oh, the people who work here are way nicer than the snobby hipsters at Four Barrel.  Sorry not sorry I'm an adult with a job that requires me to dress professional and I don't need your up and down glances at 7am. Screw you guys, Sightglass kicks your ass. OK I DIGRESS. 

really liked that you have an option of which roast/beans for your iced coffee. Super kudos on that. Need to come back to try more.
author: Susy C.

description: Always an excellent cup, with fine baked goods to boot. My latte was delicious and my scone was buttery and delightful.
author: Misha T.

description:
I only stopped by to get a treat and would love to come back for some real coffee time. It's pretty expensive so unless you want to spend an hour or two here sipping your latte, it's probably not worth it. However, if you want a nice place to hang out, this fits the bill perfectly.

And the pastry with the name that I can't pronounce (Kouign-amann) is to die for! It's super flaky and crunchy on the outside, with bits of caramelized sugar, and soft and chewy on the inside. The fruit in the middle is perfect and not too sweet. Leave it to the french to dream up everything delicious.
author: Alice W.

description:
Part of living in San Francisco is paying an exorbitant amount of money for coffee.  Part of living in San Francisco also means you're drinking amazing coffee that is hand brewed, slow dripped and usually, knowing our liberal way of life, free trade and organic. 

This place is no exception. Total hipster atmosphere with a place to park your bike right at the front door, rustic, real wood tables and chairs and an upstairs dining section to watch the magic happen. 

The coffee itself is fabulous, as I hoped it would be after spending 4$ on it. But it's also kinda small... Like, I should have paid 2$ for a half a cup of coffee, not 4... Their pastries are pretty good and they have a wide variety of them. 

Total hipster hangout overall.
author: Laura D.

description: Absolutely love this modern coffee shop. Tasty lattes and awesome decoration. On the expensive side for a very small drink but the coffee is more delicious than most - you really are getting high quality, (highly caffeinated!) beverages.
author: Katie J.

description: I've honestly never been to this place and our photographer for our wedding suggested this spot for a shoot location. We arrived and the place is adorable. I love the ambiance and the colors- simple, rustic, modern, hip. We asked permission to take some simple photo shots and they were very nice about it. She even congratulated me on our engagement- super nice. We ordered 2 cappuccinos and they gave us extra foam and added the coffee art touch "hearts". It made me smile and I was very appreciative. I can't wait to see our photos, but in any case i definitely want to come back to the coffee house.
author: Viclaire S.

description:
Needless to say, most of the table spaces here are dedicated to laptops instead of coffee cups. The ambience is one of the nicest amongst all of the coffee shops I've been to, and it is as SOMA as it might get. Good place for a casual meetup or even a grad school reunion, if you want to be known as "that hipster guy".

Drinks tend to come out quite slow, but it was every bit worth the wait. Why don't you bring your bike along and secure it on the wall just outside the door? One of the most entertaining things to watch when you don't get to sit on the second floor. This place is absolutely thrilling.

Did I mention this place (probably) is the pioneer of affogato? If you don't know what it is, go to this spot and try it. You won't want to try it anywhere else.
author: Wayne C.

description: Amazing coffee. Amazing vibe. Love their iced latte and vanilla cold brew. Love the decor of this location. They also carry pastries from B patisserie.
author: Andrew J.

description:
This coffee shop  is one of my favorite coffee shops located in SOMA area where there are a lot of residences recently under construction.

Inside the shop is a high celling and there is a window in the top of the celling.
I like daytime to spend here because I can feel many sunshine from celling.
Also, I enjoy watching a working roasting machine.

Workers are professional about coffee.
 
I ordered a cup of latte and a sea salt chocolate.
Latte is a little bitter, so It is much better to eat with chocolate.
author: Hiromi S.

description:
I needed caffeine and wifi.  Sightglass had plenty of the former, none of the latter.

It's a beautiful place, perhaps a bit too precious.

But no wifi.  I went down the street.
author: Charles S.

description: Beautiful, open, sunlit space that smells of delicious coffee upon entering.
author: Shereen A.

description: The affogato was really good. The lady was helpful. I chose the build your own affogato, choosing honduras coffe and the salted caramel ice cream
author: Angelica P.

description:
So, I'm not really into coffee shops.  Heck, I don't even drink coffee!  That said, my visit to Sight Glass felt unique enough to comment on.

The first thing I noticed was how open it was.  There's a ton of space and seating, particularly on the second floor (yes, it has two levels) where there are community tables among other seating.  The second was the stylish rustic feel of the place.  Lots of worn looking, uneven wood (so hot right now).  I wondered whether it was actually a coffee shop or some sort of startup incubator.

The barristas are behind an island, offering a 360 degree vantage point of how your coffee (or in my case, HoCho) is produced. The hot chocolate and muffin I had were both nice.  The former wasn't that sweet but I liked the idea of customizing one's own sugar level in this day of excess sugar.

My 5-stars based primarily on how unique the space is.
author: Sebastian N.

description: First and last time at this establishment. I wasted $6.75 for two hour parking meter to find out they have no outlets to plug in electronics. Also, come to find out they do not have wifi. What coffee shop does not have wifi and outlets for electronics? Immediately left after finding this out. I needed to work on some documents for work and enjoy a nice cup of coffee but I guess you could say so far this has put a damper on my day.
author: Jorge M.

description:
I love the seating setup and atmosphere at Sightglass, it's definitely a good place to catch up with friends. The coffee wasn't as good as I expected though. I got a cappuccino, which I usually get for its milky and foamy texture, but this one was way too strong. I think I still prefer Blue Bottle. 

Although the coffee was a little disappointing, this place is a must-try in SF!
author: Vivian W.

description:
this place is the prettiest coffee shop I've ever been to. honestly it is a heaven for any coffee lover. It is a two floor shop and it has plenty space for all.
I came here on a Saturday morning and ordered a cappuccino. The cappuccino was four dollars, which was pleasantly cheap compared to other mainstream coffee places. When it came out it had a pretty foam art.
The coffee itself was okay, it wasn't bitter and had a very earth coffee taste which I enjoyed tremendously, and the foam didn't completely overwhelm my drink. The size is a little small, but the quality was really great.
Overall, definitely check this place out to take cute pictures and enjoy a great coffee shop vibe, but just so you know, the second floor is humid and a little bit hot.
author: Diana O.

description: Delicious cafe mocha and the chocolate croissant was so good, I had to have another. Also, pretty cool vibes, good service, and was fun watching the coffee roast in the background.
author: Michelle D.

description: Hip atmosphere and smooth coffee! Easy to find in the city and lots of space to work and mingle.
author: Elle T.

description:
Coffee is nice. Space is nice. Always a bit too hot. No power outlets or wifi.

It's always full of complete and utter twats talking about their pointless startups. I enjoy listening to the conversations though because it makes me feel morally and intellectually superior.
author: Kate H.

description:
Yes, your coffee is good... but, but... the ATTITUDE of your staff is simply intolerable. I have waited in line for 20 minutes and put up with the absolute indifference of your staff on multiple occasions, but I seriously can't take this shit on another visit. I'll take Blue Bottle, thank you very much.

P.S. The coffee in Sydney is better. Get over yourselves.
author: Susan B.

description:
Amazing coffee, nice atmosphere, plenty of places to sit - everything you want in a coffee shop. The lack of wifi is a little annoying, but there's decent phone signal so no problem to tether.

The pastries are pretty good but I wish they had more of a food selection!
author: George B.

description:
When visiting SF, I highly enjoyed! I have been into coffee shops lately, and this one is worth checking out. It's a very large space, with a loft area where the majority of the seating is upstairs. The main coffee bar is downstairs and there is an Affogato bar upstairs! (An affogato is a scoop of ice cream with a shot of hot espresso poured over it). Their espresso was strong and tasty and they served their Affogato with Salt & Straw ice cream, so this naturally won my heart over, being a Portland native.

I recommend the Sea Salt with Caramel Ribbons ice cream combined with the Guatemala espresso! My boyfriend just got a plain Kenya espresso, which was very flavorful.

It seems as though they change out their espressos and ice cream flavors, but I can trust that everything chosen is very tasteful!
author: Fiona W.

description:
Love their vanilla iced cold brew! I usually order my sweetened lattes and milk teas less sweet, for comparison. However, this cold brew was on point with its regular level of sweetness! I dream about it to this day :) I wouldn't come here to do work because there's always a lot of people traffic and chatter with locals coming and going for their caffeine fix. I would definitely come back to people watch or grab coffee with girlfriends. It's super cute! 

There is parking all along the street so you just gotta get lucky. Do give Sightglass a try when you're in a town. You won't be sorry!
author: Cathy M.

description: Super strong coffee -- the caffeine was enough to keep my 6' 2" friend hyped the rest of the afternoon. Loved the hanging lights and natural light that came in through the front window. I just wish they had more spaces to study/hangout with friends.
author: Brit C.

description: Everything was so good! The coffee, the pastries, the atmosphere! It's definitely worth checking out
author: Alta J.

description: Very hipster and wonderful service!  I had their "Quick cup" which is their regular, pre-made coffee.  Very fresh!
author: Nan W.

description:
Decent coffee (expensive like other single cup coffee places). However, the atmosphere and sitting area are beautiful and spacious. Experience is similar to Four Barrel Coffee Shop in Mission; however, this place was not as crowded when I went in for a cup of coffee.

I enjoyed the coffee; however, I won't walk half mile from my office for a coffee here. It is a great place to hangout and chill with friends if you are around and want a decent cup of coffee.
author: Sid P.

description:
Great coffee 
Prices are a bit high,wouldn't be my 9-5 go to spot.
No wifii :(
If u need to unplug you can do it here.
author: Julie K.

description:
I've been looking for a coffee shop with quality coffee and an environment conducive to me getting my work done, and this is it! I'm a big fan of espresso and iced coffee. I've only had the vanilla cold brew so far, but I enjoyed it and will be back to try some espresso. 

As for the coffee shop environment and vibe, it kind of reminds me of the Starbucks roastery in Seattle with its hip, open floor plan. The upstairs area can get quite warm, so dress accordingly! I left after about an hour because I couldn't handle the heat. Next time, I'll probably stay on the first floor. Or just order more cold brew!
author: Jeremy S.

description: Had a great Affogato! Salted caramel with Colombian espresso. Delicious, can't wait to come back for a latte.
author: Joseph E.

description: Great addition to the neighborhood! Very well done coffee place, its really nice inside. That being said, it is a little pricey and there are no outlets...like at all.
author: Karen P.

description: Yum and yum for the blood orange olive oil affagato! I want one now! But seriously love sightglass and the environment. I stop here as I drive thru SF pick it up and enjoy the awesomeness that is this place!
author: Nessa H.

description:
Beautiful cafe. The ambience is 5 stars. Upstairs, there are larger tables for groups, bar seating for pairs or solos, and several four-seat tables perfect for spreading out and doing work. I could have stayed there forever if my laptop didn't eventually need to be charged (no outlets) and Internet needed to be accessed (no wifi). But I loved it here so much that next time I will just be downloading all my files and opening a bunch of tabs before I go.

I got a vanilla cold brew that got me through barely any sleep the night before. There's no big menu that you can read before getting to the cashier, so thank you for the tip Yelpers.
author: Stella A.

description:
I live around the corner from Sightglass and am a regular customer so I thought I would share my thoughts.

I love Sightglass.  I love the ambiance almost as much as I love the coffee.  It is truly beautiful inside, with lots of natural light (especially upstairs) and a very open floor plan.  I almost always get an iced latte & the veggie tart (all the pastries, not made there, are delicious.  The coffee only comes in one size (one of the many artisan / potentially-annoying features), but I don't mind, I think it's a perfect amount given how strong the coffee is.


That said, I sometimes hate that I love it.  It has great tables for doing work (library style, upstairs) but no wifi, not even a single outlet.  I think the point is to get people to socialize, which I can respect, but it is insanely rude/hipster to not even have outlets, and wifi is practically common courtesy these days.  There also seems to be 10-15 people working at any given time, and yet my coffee still takes forever.  Being from the east coast, it took me a while to get used to this, but now that I know what to expect it doesn't bother me.  But if you are in a hurry and want to grab a quick cup of coffee, this is not the place.


Overall, I go every week, and will continue to do so.  If understand what their approach is, it's a great place; if you're looking for something else, you may be disappointed.


PS- I wish they opened earlier! Even just 30 minutes would be ideal
PPS- sometimes I wish they had tea
author: Rachel M.

description:
It is pretty difficult to walk by this coffee shop and not feel the need to enter. The architecture of this building is incredible! It is huge, extremely spacious, bright, open and rustic. You'll find lots of people on laptops, reading a book or just chatting with a friend. I met a friend of mine here in the afternoon to enjoy a "get away from work" cup of coffee. 

The service was great from the start. The cashier was very friendly and talkative. Almost too much - because he talked and talked after taking one of our orders and once we finally got the second order in a couple others had been made with a different cashier resulting in us getting our coffees about 5-10 minutes apart. But oh well! We are easy going. 

Both of us ordered the Mocha which I found to not taste much like chocolate at all. It had chocolate notes like when you get the Jacob's at Philz or something, but not a mocha. I enjoyed the coffee and drank the entire thing but couldn't help but wonder if I was given the wrong one the entire time. It will remain a mystery! But overall I enjoyed the place and would give it another shot.
author: Mandy A.

description: Cool spot - overpriced coffee - depressed hipster staff.
author: Alex B.

description: The most beautiful cafe in the city? Hands down. Good luck getting a seat on a Sunday afternoon! Until they start blaring Motörhead, then everyone scrams, presumably moved by a sudden urge to help graffiti their friend Chuck's brocave.
author: Be F.

description:
For years I was a devout Four Barrel fan. I thought nothing could touch their mastery of the roasted coffee bean. While still one of the best cups of espresso you'll find south of Seattle... it doesn't hold a candle to what Sightglass has been able to accomplish in a few short years after settling roots in SOMA.

The complexity and acidity of their roast combined with a beautiful venue makes it so darn pleasurable to dodge drifters and apparent fecal matter to saunter through their giant wooden doors.
author: Ruggy J.

description:
This is the perfect, quiet, hipster place to enjoy a nice cup of coffee while getting some reading done or just catching up with a friend. (But note that there is no outlets or WiFi.) There is plenty of seating along the street facing bar area or upstairs overlooking the rest of the coffee shop. 

The baristas are friendly, and the ambiance is relaxing. I love how open the space is, too. Must importantly, I love their coffee and the simplicity of ordering whatever I'm in the mood for! If you are looking to unplug and unwind, Sight Glass is the place to go.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
The interior is magnificent and puts all other coffee shops to shame. It has an industrial, but minimalistic look. The second floor gives a great balcony view overlooking the inner workings of a coffee roaster. I like the wide open spaces and large tables. The one thing missing here was free wi-fi. 

I would agree that the coffee is excellent and one of the few roasters that can compare to Blue Bottle. My latte was perfectly crafted by their skilled baristas. I also tried the Kenya, Runyenjes, Kangunu AA. I'm not that great with taste notes, but I am unconvinced that you can taste watermelon juice (in addition to mango and milk chocolate). Let's not get carried away with the creativity of these aromatics and fruity undertones. At $5 for a pour-over, it might be worthwhile to buy the beans themselves to brew at home. 

I love their motto: Fine coffees for a weary world. Indeed.
author: Bailey Z.

description:
Pretty cool space.
Their lattes and cappuccinos are pretty good. 
They have a stronger taste than some places that I've tried but that's what makes it good.  I don't like it when it tastes too milky, although I do love milk.

The girl knocked over my cappuccino before giving it to me so my art was ruined. She just said "oops" and that was it.
SAD FACE.
author: Heejin L.

description: Love their coffee. Love the decor. Don't really love the customer service but it's not terrible so I'll let that pass. They roast their coffee beans at this location and the smell is just amazing. Great high ceilings and for such a large space they don't cram in the tables and seats. In fact most of the seating is on a second level over looking the first floor of the shop. It's wonderful to be able to relax and enjoy a cup of coffee in a spacious place like this.
author: Susan L.

description:
Perfect spot for reading, probably because of the sun-drenched, cosy barn atmosphere.

Kimchi Morning Bun: 4 stars

Chocolate Chip Cookie: 4 stars
Leaves a beautifully bitter aftertaste appropriate for a coffee-maker's establishment. They use high quality, rich chocolate but the body is neither chewy soft nor caramelized-crunch but instead a crumbly starch. Nevertheless I can see why my partner (a cookie addict) likes these.

Decaf Latte with Almond milk: 5 stars
Rich, fragrant and delicious.
One day they mixed up my partner and my lattes (decaf and regular) and we found out we can actually taste the difference between them! The decaf is sweeter and milkier, the regular tastes stronger and bitter (but my partner prefers it, has more "bite"). Good to know so neither of our days was ruined!

Decaf Cappuccino: 2 stars
Too strong for my liking. I like some cappuccinos at other cafes, but I can only get a latte at Sightglass.

Hot Chocolate: 3.5 stars
It's bitter, not as sweet as the decaf latte. But not like drinking liquid dark chocolate, it's a little too watery for that. The hot chocolates at the Mill and Marla Bakery beat this one.
author: Letitia L.

description:
Of the 6 or so coffee shops I've been to in San Fran to date, I have to say this is my highlight, from a coffee snobbery point of view.

The morning I visited I really felt like a latte, but a latte in America is like ordering a hot cup of milk, so I decided to order a pour over. 

"Could you possibly serve a side of milk with that?" I asked ignorantly.
"You mean you'd like a café au lait?" said the hipster service barista.

Noted: if you want good coffee with milk in the US ask for a "café au lait." But heaven forbid call it a pour over with milk or a latte and you'll probably also have someone roll their eyes at you.

Whatever it was in the end, my coffee got 5 stars, the atmosphere from the loft upstairs gets 5 stars for allowing me to hide away and watch the roasting happen from above and the dark chocolate caramel I had with my pour over in a mug gets 10 stars for bringing out the caramel and bitter tones in my coffee. If only the toffy coffee experts in San Fran could hear me now!
author: Chloe R.

description: Cool little coffee spot. One of the few spots you can actually pop a squat in for a few minutes in the town. Place is HUuUGE super cool ambiance.. Never saw so many bags of coffee in my life, this place is serious about coffee, they are live roasting beans in house.. Real deal stuff going on. All in all.. Me Likey.. Best coffee spot in SF in my opinion.
author: Jason C.

description:
Not necessarily better than blue bottle, but not worse either. My latte had a strong and delicious espresso flavor and was not burdened with sugar. On the other hand, they didn't quite get the mouthfeel right. I think the straight espressos are probably the way to go.

The space is interesting, but packed. I liked watching the roasting, but with few chairs, too much noise, and no tempting pastries, it doesn't seem inviting.
author: Ryan B.

description:
This has got to be one of my favorite coffee spots to go to in San Francisco. San Francisco has a good amount of coffee spots, but I feel like only a certain amount of them carry the swag that this one does. Once you walk in through the doors you immediately feel like you can work out of this place.

It's comfortable, modern, and feels like a industrial place. Not too edgy, but at the same time homey. I love the coffee here and the pastries are delicious too. Try the pistachio croissant that taste very similar to an almond croissant. It's amazing. Too bad they don't have a oven/ heater there to warm it up.

Nonetheless I highly recommend this place for anyone who's trying to just sit back and relax. Maybe even do some work.
author: Nathan L.

description:
Idk how much more "SF" this place could get. Hands-down one of my fav coffee spots. Gives  you a very hip/industrial suave kinda vibe. Great place to hangout for a coffee break or get work done. Heads up- BYOWIFI and no outlets 
Try the famous original iced coffee !!!
author: Shabnam S.

description:
I've been here a few times (when the place I regularly go across the street was closed.) It's more money than I usually want to pay, but has good coffee, and it's nice inside.  I dont get any attitude from the staff,  and coffee comes up pretty quickly. Overall 4 stars, as I don't think I'd study here (wrong vibe) and it's kinda pricey.

But now I need to comment that when I see 'Sightglass Coffee' listed on restaurant menus, I don't order coffee. I have actually been known to run down to a Starbucks to get coffee to go and sneak it into a restaurant rather than have  Sightglass. I have no idea what it is, but every time I've had a crappy cup of bitter, medium bodied awful coffee it was Sightglass. I'm at the point now where I have a sip, cringe, say 'Sightglass?' to the server and they beam all proudly and confirm. 

What is the deal? Can't they make it like Sightglass does? Maybe Sightglass needs to offer certification classes or something....
author: El B.

description: I love the atmosphere here! Very large, open space, and plenty of seating. I got the hooker's mocha $5, which was pretty smooth. They had lots of pastries, and it all looked amazing!! I was excited to see that they had the kouign amann from B.pattisserie because I've been wanting to try it. Wow, it was amazing! It was so flaky with layers and layers of buttery goodness. The middle had a light custard which made it perfect!! Overall, a good place to catch up with a friend over coffee or even to study.
author: Vy T.

description:
Maybe I just don't get it? 
http://stream1.gifsoup.com/view/137869/kanye-shrug-o.gif

This holier than thou coffee movement sweeping across these "hip" cities is great; even encouraged on my part. Instead of the typical Starbucks eyesore on every corner, you're given an academy of art dropouts interpretation of what a café should look like.... Minimalistic, wood throughout, black rimmed glasses and smug stare downs.

That being said, I wanted to like sightglass.... It fit the criteria, was on my way to work and was very "San Francisco" (interpret that as you will). Once you walk in, you  notice the open-ness and its woodsy interior. It almost reminded me of a cracker barrel in the Midwest without being as welcoming. I stood in a line of flannel only to approach a barista with a blank stare; no hello, no nod, no hug.... A stare. I wanted to ask questions, but was almost afraid to. For a moment, it felt like I was meeting a disapproving father in law.... I wanted to get in and out of there and fast. 

I ordered a large coffee and signed my name on an iPad. I then proceeded to linger. And linger. ANNNNDDD linger. Are they going to call my name? my zodiac sign? Or just say "hey yuppie asshole in the suit!". I was on pins and needles anticipating the unknown. Finally, my large coffee was gracefully shouted out from behind a row of ironic-hipster-chic coffee dripping funnels. 

I B-lined to the creamer and sugar to be on my way, but not without an assortment of judgmental stares wondering "why is this guy adding anything to this masterpiece!?" Because I want to, mmmmkay!? 

Once down the street and into the clear (see: dodging human feces and non-judgmental homeless)., I tried a sip and waited. And waited. ANNNNDDD waited.

Nothing. Tastes like coffee.

All in all, I still don't get it. It's better than folgers but not as good as philz. I felt like I paid +/- $3 to be a part of a secret club that secretly didn't want me; I didn't even receive a secret handshake. 

I won't fault you, sight glass, for my lack of coffee pretentiousness... it wasn't bad, I just don't get "it". I don't get the line, or the ipad, or the cult following. You know, "it"!

NICE SPACE DOE! A+++++
author: Ryan L.

description:
Sightglass is one of the most revered coffee shops in San Francisco and perhaps beyond. Right up there with Ritual or Blue Bottle among others. Between a combination of their award winning* roasts, as well as their unique open architecture, they all come highly recommended whenever I read a "best of SF" article. 

A recent excursion to the Green Festival brought my sweetie and me here as it was the only coffee shop open within reasonable distance on a Sunday evening

My first taste of Sightglass beans was from my favorite cafe, Timeless Coffee in Oakland http://www.yelp.com/biz/timeless-coffee-oakland who were using Sightglass roasted coffee until they recently purchased their own roaster. Since Timeless became my favorite coffee shop, I bookmarked Sightglass to see if it's the roaster or the barista that makes the coffee what it is. 

We placed our order for a french press coffee and a soy latte. Since they seem to be following the increasingly annoying hipster trend of serving almond over soy milk, we ended up with an almond milk latte instead. Almond milk is very finicky to work with and rarely if ever tastes great when foamed. It overpowers the espresso so all you really taste is the almond milk which usually has a bitter flavor if you're not used to it. Since they only serve almond milk, I can't really say how the espresso really tasted because I didn't like my drink.

Since they don't serve V3gan desserts here, we snuck in some delicious Angel Cakes http://www.yelp.com/biz/angel-cakes-custom-cupcakes-berkeley cupcakes that made the coffee experience much more palatable.

Despite the unique architecture, I don't see myself ever going here again unless they start serving soy or heck, even coconut milk which doesn't froth as well but at least you can still taste the espresso underneath the subtle coconut flavor.

*No awards have actually been verified. I just see Sightglass beans at many cafes and coffee shops so I ASSume they have won an award or two.
author: John B.

description:
Amazing atmosphere, amazing coffee! 

This feels like a place I would come to just to sit in front of their big windows, looking out into the street as it's raining, with a cup of some hot brew in my hand. 

I love how chill the baristas are, with one guy in particular joining in after I had a little credit card fight with my date to see who would pay for our coffees. If this was closer to where I worked in the city, I'd come here every damn day. 

I've had a taste of their regular black coffee (not sure what the blend was that day), but it was very fragrant, and after weeks of drinking the horrible Starbucks Pike Place Roast, this was very pleasant on my palette. Their vanilla iced cold brew coffee with almond milk is to die for, as the vanilla is accented with the natural sweetness of the almond, AND it comes in a mason jar! 

Damn it, I want to come back soon.
author: Viet N.

description:
Unique coffeehouse with a wooded decor and spacious set up. Although there was plenty of space, seating over the weekend was pretty full - we almost had to stand.

Latte and mocha weren't bad. The latte was more on the bitter side for my taste. Unless I was in the area already, I probably wouldn't make a trip back here. There is a sign stating no dogs allowed inside, but I did see one inside which was annoying (it wasn't a service dog).
author: Josh L.

description:
I've heard so many good things about Sightglass Coffee, so I was super excited to finally pay a visit.

Why two stars? Read on to get the good, the bad, & the ugly.

The good: the space is beautiful. Large, open coffeehouse, with clean & modern decor.

The bad: the barristas were pretentious toolbags. No wifi or outlets - this is not a place you'd go to if your work requires the internet.

The ugly: the coffee. I could not finish it. A couple of sips & I threw it out. This has never happened to me in my life. I think it was far too acidic for me.

Maybe I will come back & give them another chance. Likely, I won't, especially with all the other fantastic coffee places in the city: Philz, Blue Bottle, Ritual, Four Barrel.
author: Grace C.

description: Great location and very attractive decoration/atmosphere. Ideal for meeting up with a few friends or just to read something/study on your own. I wish all of their coffee selection was fair trade, but only a few kinds are...and I could not get as detailed info. I will inquire about it more next time. Definitely delicious latte and coffee cake with fruits.
author: Elif B.

description:
Mmmm, I have mixed vibes about this place.

The architecture and industrial decor of this cafe is amazing. There's two floors of seating, succulents and plenty of sunlight. That being said, that was the only thing that really blew me away about this place.

I don't like using labels, but I definitely get a "hipster" vibe around here. There's no large, clear menu displayed, just a small paper menu at the register so I had to walk up and ask if they served any iced coffees. Kinda got a judgmental stare for that but whatever. I had a long brisk walk and needed to cool down. $4 for a small iced vanilla coffee and $1 tip on their Square register. The cashier walks your cup over to one of the baristas in their loop-shaped coffee-making area, which didn't take long to make. Also, napkins, lids, sugar/milk, etc. are all hidden on a bar in the waaaay back so I missed that and had to ask where they kept the lids. Another stare. Meep.

The ice coffee is decent, but not my favorite and certainly not worth the price. Their pastries look delicious. I want to fit in here and maybe meet with my cool friends here for coffee once in a while just to enjoy the decor, but I only dropped in here because it was close to the court house. This place just isn't my cup of coffee (ba dum tsss)
author: Bonnie S.

description:
The Coffee is good. But very very poor service. 
Ectremely Arrogant staff. They only have whole milk and if you dnt like it too bad.
No wifi. In silicon valley,  really????
Also, the barrista spilled my coffee when making is and when I asked for napkin to clean the saucer he gave me such an attitude and through a bunch of napkin in front of me.
author: yasamin b.

description:
A great warehouse style open space with a full on "factory" "packaging" "small production" operation, obviously a coffee bar with carefully handcrafted drinks and also a great selection of Japanese coffee makers and grinders.

Be careful, your thoughts are likel toy be interrupted by tech talks and at times pretentious loud folks... Part of the valley. Love and hate
author: Dilys S.

description: Definitely everything you would want in a "Indie" coffee house in SF. Long line, huge open space to hang with hipsters. Great decadent pastries to choose from.  But alas the espresso is that typical burnt taste that most coffee houses still haven't figured out how to avoid. Come on Baristas out there LEARN HOW TO MAKE GOOD ESPRESSO
author: Devin B.

description:
oh, LOVE. My love for coffee grows everyday. 
...and when you get the opportunity to try a new spot, i fall in love more and more. (rumor has it, there was an SF cash stash nearby the day i went!...BOO for finding out 1.5 days later) -- located in SoMa.

When we tried to go to Audio Coffee, it was closed on that Sunday, so we walked 2 blocks down to Sightglass. My friends who are more familiar with the SF area said they've heard good things about it, comparable to the popularity of Philz Coffee (makes sense!). Walk in, large warehouse setup, high ceilings, center bar, and coffee being created/packaged all around. It was amazing, and you could smell the amazing too. 

So they're like a real coffee shop, no flavor lattes, etc. So i decided to go with the Iced Vanilla Coffee. I'm not an iced coffee girl, but I needed that vanilla. Came in an adorable mason jar and sipped peacefully. I was soooo into my drink. Coffee satisfaction is hard to find. You can see the team really adding love to their drinks.
author: Darlene B.

description: This place doesn't have any outlets... Never heard of such a thing. Coffee is decent, ambiance is nice.
author: Bridney R.

description:
What a cool place! A huge space with high ceilings and huge windows for light to come in. It feels industrial with the wood & metal exposure, but not in an off-putting way.

Coffee: I got a vanilla cold brew with whole milk. I wish it came in a bigger cup! It was super rich, probably because of the whole milk. Note to try almond milk next time. It was good--pretty acidic and aromatic. Vanilla wasn't too overpowering, which is always a plus.

My friend got a drip coffee. I forgot which one, but Sightglass has a huge selection from Latin America. I want to try the other ones next time. The coffee my friend got was pretty acidic with a light body. A little too acidic for my taste, but I want to try the other options they have!
author: Steph V.

description: Got some good coffee, got some stress off me. Veggie tart, lightened the heart. Had good vibes, made for good times.
author: Andy O.

description:
First, the coffee: it's solid. It's what you expect and learned to love about third wave coffee shops. Nothing jumped out at me that would make it particularly memorable though.

The space: lots and lots of room for people looking to work there. As far as the design though... I don't know, it feels a little bit like I'm in a trendy shopping mall or library. I think I prefer smaller coffee shops that center around the uniqueness of the owner/employees. Just too much going on here to feel like this was anything but a business transaction when I was there.

The people: super friendly though. I also felt cooler just for being there and talking to them
author: Mike M.

description:
So my last review was from the week they opened the coffee cart. Much has changed and they have taken the SF coffee game up several notches as we've all seen.

The most gorgeous, thoughtful, and well executed build out.

The coffee is no different than the space it's set in...

They continue to strive for better no matter how well they've already done.
author: David K.

description: I don't like this place. The space is open, bright, cute, clean, and creates a pleasant white noise. The products are even very tasty (I can't deny that the coffee is tasty). However, I find the cashier/barista more interested in serving the product who she wanted it than how I wanted it. I asked if they could do a couple things and she not only said no but suggested that what I wanted didn't really make any sense. I get it. It's an uppity San Francisco cafe, that serves expensive products and they know how to enjoy it better than its customers. And that's fine. Just not for me. Also, it doesn't have wifi. I get not having outlets, but no wifi either? Dayum. Know what it is before going there. Good for expensive, tasty, coffee (and probably other products) and a get together with a friend or people, but not so good for a lot of other things I like cafes I frequent to feature.
author: Jonathan A.

description:
Sunday, 2:30 PM. 

Quickie:
+ Drink quality
+ Service
+ Hygiene
- Turnaround
+ Atmosphere
+ Spacious

And then...?
Sightglass is versatile: conducive for gatherings, making deals, or getting work done. 

**********
Got my drank on:
1. Iced Latte with honey
     + Slightly sweet with a pervasive roast flavor
author: Chuck N.

description: Great for a quick cup of coffee and something sweet. Great music and overall ambiance/layout.
author: Jordan R.

description:
The vanilla cold brew is delicious, and worth a visit if you have never tried it.

With that said, I probably won't be back. It takes more than just a good cup of coffee to make me a frequent visitor, and the lack of wifi and outlets is a no-go when I'm trying to get some work done.

This would probably be a better place for social meetings, but it's fairly crowded for that.
author: Ariana C.

description: This place was recommended to me by more than a few friends. Great atmosphere. Very cool design of building. Right when you walk in the baristas make you feel very welcomed. The coffee was strong but very good.
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
Went here in search of delicious coffee roasted with care. Found it. 

I asked for the most interesting coffee on offer, the barista described one as weird, and I obviously ordered it . Very unique, very delicious, bought a bag of beans to take home with me, and I might now be ruined in terms of enjoying other coffee in my future.
author: Michael B.

description: Awesome place!!! Best coffee and ambiance. You can't miss the pistachio croissant. Out of this world
author: Karin N.

description: Nicely designed, solid coffee, buuuut the playlist needs work. Play better songs. Otherwise, worth checking out
author: David M.

description: Came here about 4pm. Love the ambience and the decor of the place. It is one of the most spacious and well decorated cafes in SF. However, the coffee was a bit of a let down. I ordered the Vanilla Iced Coffee, which turned out to be a little too diluted. My partner ordered the Owls Espresso. I would suggest you give this place a pass unless you wanna take nice photos.
author: Vjy T.

description: Everyone must try Sightglass' salted caramel affogato!! Salted caramel ice cream that melts in your mouth and in your espresso! Delicious! Definitely a must try! Only the cool kids know about it. ;)
author: Christy Y.

description:
This was a little craft coffee brewing company, if that's what they're called. Awesome that you could really see into their operations and see the drug making in action. Coffee was great, no complaints. Seating and layout made it a bit more complicated to bunker down when you're carrying around a big cup of boiling hot, fresh coffee. 

This is not a coffee house people, so don't expect wifi. Hahah
author: Abe B.

description:
+ good for conversation
+ Costa Rica drip had great flavor
~ pastries looked great, will try next time
author: Dustin H.

description:
Vanilla cold brew with almond milk is my favorite cold brew in all of San Francisco. 

Very cool vibe and ambiance. Great place to meet friends, do your NYT crossword and observe.
author: Amanda K.

description:
This one of my favorite coffee shops in San Francisco. I have never had a disappointing cup here. I love the ambiance and the decor. My one criticism is I wish the employee would tone down the snooty attitude a bit. On one occasion I ordered a dry cappuccino and I got a fairly snotty reply that they only make their cappuccinos one way and that is wet. I get concentrating on what you feel is optimal product but I don't need a lecture on coffee from someone who has been alive less time than I have been drinking good coffee. 

Try the pistachio croissant with an almond milk cap, it really is delicious.
author: James G.

description:
Sightglass is hipster coffee. 

That's not a slur, mind you. In fact, it's just the opposite. There's lots of care given to each roast, and even basic pours like their daily blend come out fresh and clean on the double. It's a lot more subtle than, say, a Blue Bottle coffee. Think more an Americano than a full-bodied roast.

But damn, $4 for a cup? Gone are the days of paying .99 for a cuppa joe.
author: Casey S.

description: I love their coffee, but I just wish it is not $5 for a 12 oz latte :( or anything.. I tried to order iced coffee (black) and it still costs me $4.75 whereas usually a cup of black coffee is $2? I get it though they make it using V60.. but it is too fancy for me for just a cup of black coffee.. oh the world of specialty coffee...
author: Olivia C.

description: I love my coffee black but their Kenya blend of coffee legitimately tastes like urine. My girlfriend got a cappuccino but it was nothing spectacular
author: Nathan B.

description:
Hipsters or non-hispsters, if you like REAL coffee (none of that frappuccinos or blended drinks), then you should definitely give this place a try.

They have a coffee bean roaster in the room. The coffee scent and the whole ambiance of the shop is just tranquilizing~~

If you don't know what to get. You can't go wrong with their Vanilla Latte. The bitterness of the coffee is strong and leaves a natural sweet after taste in your mouth. 

If you're someone like me, who either drinks coffee black or with only a bit of cream (no sugar), you will not be disappointed. I love that bittersweet after taste of coffee in your mouth and they do it just right! This is probably one of the best, if not, THE BEST coffee shop I've been to.
author: Judy Y.

description:
OMG. Hipster Central. And I live in Silverlake, and it's still Hipster Central.

Yes, it's good coffee.

But why does everyone who hangs out there have to look so damn miserable? Oh, what's wrong little hipster? Is it hard being cool? It makes you unhappy? Are you cranky because you're starving yourself to fit into those skinny jeans? Are you mad because you spilled coffee on your favorite black hoodie? Did you just find out that your roommate's been stealing your black eyeliner? Did somebody hurt your feelings by telling you that the real hipsters are in Williamsburg? Your friends got tickets to Silversun Pickups and you didn't? Boo hoo hooooo hoooo.

There are owls. and wood. and bicycles. and plants on the wall in sprouts. for no damn reason. and lots of ironic sunglasses. and the baristas don't smile or make eye contact. i get it. customer service is so passe. there are also giant grinders. so. there's that.

the Ethiopian blend was great and pretty... but i consume a lot of great & pretty coffee and often I'm looking for a place to BE. in addition to great coffee. we sat for about 30 minutes and then left in search of personality.
author: Donna J.

description: Great place with nice open space to grab a coffee and something to eat it have a meeting. Free wifi and lots of room for your work meeting or to catch up with friends. Long line but worth the wait. It's fun and funky. Coffee us great. I had an almond milk latte. Delicious. My favorite was the pistachio blackberry croissant. It was yummy and a very fun flavor combination I hadn't considered.
author: Jessica M.

description:
So my goal for this year is to try out as many cold brews as I can. And while I enjoy coffees in all shapes and sizes, I'll be venturing out looking for the best cold brews.

Sight Glass's take on cold brew features vanilla. You are given an option of regular or almond milk, so I chose to get mine with the almond milk (I usually drink it black). Really damn good cup of coffee; the vanilla flavor wasn't overly sweet or very syrupy, and the almond milk was a nice compliment. Coffee was robust in flavor and not acidic (I find that a sour flavor of cold brew does not mix well with sugar) so that was a plus. 

My cousin ordered a latte, and my Dad had an Ethiopia pour over. I didn't have any sips of either, but they both enjoyed their drinks and had no complaints. 

Interior is spacious and the vibe was comforting. There are two floors so you can head upstairs and check out the baristas while you sip on your cup of Joe. 

Will definitely be back!
author: Christopher N.

description:
The beans I bought were okay...nothing special. The coffee was good but I wish more coffee shops in the Bay Area would come up with some creative drinks, as opposed to just four to five beverages on the menu with no homemade syrups.  I order almond milk and without some sort of syrup, the flavor of the almond milk is white bold, so it was definitely pretty strong with my latte I ordered from here.  Sugar helped the taste, but not by much.

It is a cool place, but I was not super impressed.  I didn't even finish the beans I bought...the flavor was not very bold and this was a recommended bag.
author: Monica J.
