description: Sightglass serves above the above-average coffee in SF; even if there's a lot of people there, because of the high ceiling and layout, you can still hold a nice conversation with someone. Of course, sometimes you have to wait a bit for your coffee because there's lots of people there, and they are still taking care to make them all right.
author: Aaron B.

description:
Their vanilla cold brew is pure poetry. Sightglass takes the prize for my current favorite brew (sorry Stumptown)  - it's smooth, with rich aroma and flavor. A little acidic, but it adds character. You can grab a cup and sit along a bar-like set up surrounding the roaster, watching employees slow-roast the very beans from which your drink is made.

If there's any time to do so, visit this place in winter, or at least in the morning. Although beautifully designed, the interior gets pretty warm (probs in part bc of the roaster), especially in the upstairs seating area in the back.  No wifi, so bring your old-school conversation, books, pens, and paper.
author: Emily Z.

description:
"It's like a temple to coffee," said my cashier. Good description.

The Sightglass in SoMa is a gorgeous two-story coffee shop. 
On the first floor, there's convenient vertical bike parking and huge glass walls facing the street. Inside, a coffee roaster machine roasts beans, folks pack bags of beans, large boxes of fancy equipment sit in the back, and terrariums of succulents line the tables.
In the middle is an area where you can order coffee. Upstairs, there's a secret second coffee ordering place, and more seating that overlooks the first floor.

I went on a Saturday, and it was loud and hot upstairs. It has a ton of seating and a nice mix of tourists, folks working on laptops, and friends hanging out. To me it feels more like a place to show off to out-of-town folks than to get work done.

Oh right, you're supposed to order coffee here. Like the other Sightglass, their cappuccinos are my favorite.
author: Jessica S.

description: I started out my SF trip with my morning coffee fix at Sightglass coffee. The vibe of the coffee shop is super hipster! I loved the interior and the two floors of seating. It's a great place to hang out, grab coffee or study. We ordered two lattes. They were perfect!
author: Eunice L.

description:
I'd put Sightglass in the top 5 of San Francisco coffees, but a few negatives prevent me from giving the full 5 stars.  

Pros
-Ample bike parking 'on premises'
-Variety of different coffees to choose from, including a slightly cheaper "Daily Brew" (although I believe the Daily Brew is premade drip, while the other 2 daily choices are made fresh as a pour over - if I'm wrong I'll revise) 
-Cool SOMA atmosphere with in house roasting and warehouse theme interior 
-Affogato bar is a great addition 
-Staff is friendly and engaging in conversation, willing to answer any questions 

Cons
-Really crowded most of the time and not enough seating - they could be doing more with all the space
-No wifi
-Not many places to charge things, if any
-Coffee is always good, but it's not the best - I would rank Philz and Fourbarrel above it for better taste and variety

In any other market, Sightglass alone would be an easy 5 stars.  In San Francisco, expectations are higher and I can get a better overall experience elsewhere.
author: Ben K.

description: Love the open space of this place, and customer service was good.  I thoroughly enjoyed my iced coffee with soy milk, and it gave the caffeine jolt that I needed.  I don't go to this area of the city that much, but next time I am nearby, I will be sure to stop in!
author: Maile N.

description: The best coffee cafe experience, yet.   Very cool environment.  Love the great smell of coffee as soon as you walk in.   Wish I had a coffee place like this closer to home.
author: Tanya C.

description:
Must be one of the best coffee in SF..
I like the mood-relaxing...with high ceiling..
Not pricy..will go back to the place again
author: Sujung S.

description: Finally. A decent coffee in USA. Great atmosphere. Great coffee. Good service. They don't have soy milk, but they do have almond mild. Tried the walnut, dark chocolate espresso muffin - very tasty.
author: George T.

description:
Zero is the real rating for attitude, today the Barista filled up the coffee up to 2/3 because we asked for no ice as usual and he had the nerve to tell us that we are getting twice the product?  It's a cup of coffee which costs 5 Cents and they sell it for $5.00 which is a 10,000 Percent profit and he said we were cheating the system?  I called him on it and asked him politely: "Please do not ever do that again 

All though we like the coffee and pastries.  We go to this place everyday and spend $5.00 per cold brew.  Usually spend upward $60 with pastries.  and I usually treat all my co-workers and buy.

If this ever happends again, I will take my business elsewhere.
author: Koorosh G.

description:
Came here after trying lots of good coffee in SF, and had heard great things about Sighglass. It's a cute little shop with bike parking, wood finishes and a warehouse feel. There isn't a large menu on the board, rather a small paper next to the cashier. They have the basics, and a iced coffee. I got the latte and it was delicious. Perfect aromatic complexion and was a delight to sip. I loved it.

I also tried a sip of the cappuccino, it was not impressive however. It had too much foamy milk, not enough coffee.
author: Bevi K.

description: Great experience. They take hipster to the next level with unique pastries, beards, cardigans, and deep knowledge of coffee beans. Love that they have an upstairs. ONLY reason for 4 stars is they don't have wifi
author: Steve M.

description: the rustic location is beautiful, the staff is wonderful and yeah i'm paying $2-3 more for a latte than starbucks to taste the hipster but whatever the ambiance is worth it.
author: Alexandra K.

description:
Came here for coffee with friends! 

Love love the ambiance. And it looks like a great place to spend an afternoon.   

The only thing is: I'm not a huge coffee drinker, and so I couldn't really tell quality coffee from not so great coffee. I do wish that the menu would include things other than coffee! 

I ordered a latte. The foam art was beautiful!
author: Teresa C.

description: I'm usually not a fan of hipster cafes but this one is so delightful. Extremely spacious and great atmosphere. Their selection is a bit pricy but the quality justifies it!
author: Sue L.

description: Amazing coffee without a crazy line out the door. Their pistachio croissant is a must try with your next espresso.
author: Gary B.

description: Visiting from out of town and looking for some good coffee. Tried the non dairy cappuccino and could not taste the coffee only the almond milk. I ordered 2 and my wife had the same experience. Extremely disappointed cuz I was so looking forward to trying this place.
author: Fernando C.

description:
Really cool environment to get quality coffee!

I tried their vanilla cold brew coffee with almond milk. Definitely a smooth blend that wasn't overly sweet! It came in a mason jar, if you're into that kinda thing. They import their beans [from somewhere, not quite sure where] and roast them right in the shop itself. Pretty hip place to grab a cup and chill!

Only thing that bothered me was that they don't have wifi. However, I was able to mooch of a surrounding business' network (City Annex 4, I believe), but it wasn't very speedy of course.
author: Jessica L.

description: Love the decor. I was a little hesitant when I saw their limited menu and didnt see any flavored iced coffee drinks other than the vanilla brew. I decided to give it a try and was pleasantly surprised. This is how coffee should taste! They need one of these in LA.
author: Lisa D.

description:
Fan-freaking-tastic coffee and pastries! Friend took a bunch of us to try one of the great coffee places in SF.

I ordered:
- Smoked Little Ham Tart $4.75
- Latte with Almond Milk $4.00

Tina's Tips And Tantrums 
- Limited seating, clean restrooms, and great atmosphere
- One of the places you would want to kick back and study or even have a conversation among friends or significant others
- Staff wasn't too great, they didn't connect or converse as much as I thought they would. It would've been nice if they were more personal whether or not it's for tips or not. Although, working at a coffee shop myself, I always tend to tip.
- Upstairs seating was heated so it was super hot the day we came and it didn't help, but I didn't dock any points for that
- One thing I love about this place is the coffee art and how foamy the lattes are, they do set themselves apart from other coffee shops
- My latte was very distinct in the coffee taste, but it wasn't too bold (which is a good thing on my part). I can't taste things that are too earthy. 
- Friends and I all work at Starbucks so we tend to critique coffee anywhere else
- Pastries in general were all so scrumptious! I tried the coffee cake and the other ham sandwich.
- I loved what I got though, but if you are just looking for something to nibble on, it's not the right choice. If you are looking for something filling, I would suggest the smoked little ham tart. It's not so little!
- It would be the go-to place if I am ever craving coffee and in SF again.
author: Tina N.

description: Sightglass cold brew + salt and straw ice cream = magic.  Seriously the absolutely perfect combination that tastes like it was meant to be.  Must order!
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Nice spot. One of the highly regarded roasters in the city within a warehouse, which adds to the urban coffee shop atmosphere. The pourovers I've had here have been incredibly consistent and their baristas should be showered with praise because of the dedication and professionalism of each cup. I've had some pleasant experiences and conversations with the workers/ baristas, but the place can be so busy that you may miss out on talking to them. 
All the beans they buy are washed processed. 

They offer free public cupping's every Friday at 3-4 pm and they usually have a theme/ location they like to highlight for each particular cupping. This makes it highly accessible to the average person to educate themselves on coffee plantations, where beans are sourced, how roasting works, and just how the company is run in general.
author: Nick F.

description:
I live in Berkeley and I make the trip all the way to SF just to treat myself here.

The experience of the cafe though, is so beautiful, so reflective of the city as a whole. There's an equal amount of tech folks on a coffee break and the artsy creatives scribbling into their moleskins. 

The cafe is kind of industrial, a lot of wood and a lot of metal, and the interior is super spacious. There's an entire floor upstairs with more seating (although no wifi.) You can also purchase beans here! They're wrapped in a thick brown bag material and stamped with their logo and the roast date.
author: Tiffany K.

description: I tried an almond milk latte. Great almond milk and froth on the latte. Kinda expensive for the size. Unique flavors and the place is interesting at least.
author: Kiki H.

description:
What's all that jazz going on? By jazz - I mean the noise and the crowd. Noise is the huge coffee beans roasting machine at work and the crowd are the yuppies and start-up enthusiasts with their macbooks at upper level.

Upon visit, you'd have the pleasure of watching the staff make their coffee from roasting beans, packaging, to the in-house baristas' craft work at espresso bar - all in one space. It's quite an amazing coffee experience - if you care for it. 

This is your garage-turned-coffee house cafe. High-ceiling, spacious yet limited seating. This space reminds me of the Blue Bottle in Williamsburg neighborhood of New York - but this exhibits an even more pleasant atmosphere - less crowded, less pretentious (and that basically sums up the difference between SF and NY, doesn't it?).

Their individually-prepared ice coffee was probably the best I've had - light and aromatic. Latte, solid. Line moves fast so don't be discouraged. They also sell Hookers brand chocolates and some pastries.

Sightglass in SoMa is a bit out of the way from most tourist attractions, but it's definitely worth the short trek if you care for a great coffee experience.
author: Annie L.

description: Great place with great vibes. Coffee is the best I've had in the city so far (yes, I would say better than blue bottle, four barrel, etc.)... too bad there is no wireless here. Using my personal hotspot on my phone to get online .. there goes my data for the month..
author: Patricia K.

description:
Great coffee and pastries. I love the seating on the 2nd floor, but wish they had wifi. 

I took a coffee cupping class here, and the main instructor (I think his name was Jose), was super smart and very friendly. He made learning about coffee fun and approachable. 

I'll be back.
author: Evelyn M.

description:
Tired of obvious chains like star bucks ?
Are you looking for a coffeeshop which is actually about coffee experience and not something else?  
Want some original hardcore coffee experience in rich culture of SF ?
Look my further ! 
You are in right spot 

Bonus they have coffee tasting at Friday's 3pm !
author: Arash R.

description:
Good coffee shop the staff was very friendly and seemed happy to talk "shop" with me as we got into an in-depth conversation about coffee and such.  It was late in the afternoon and I was actually in the mood for tea (I know its a coffee roster), they don't have tea in this location.  So, I opted for a decaf which was amazing!  I can't recall the last time I had decaf, but it was perfect as a pour-over. 
I also had a scone which was OK, was expecting better. But again this is a coffee roster not a bakery.  This place can get packed and HOT... the upper level was roasting and a lack of air cyrculation made it a bit uncomfortable... but that did not seem to bother anyone around. 

So, keep in mind no Tea and its warm... if you can handle that you would go and give it a try.  The coffee is done well and the staff was great.
author: Frank C.

description:
Good coffee. BUT this is NOT a space for study. Apparently, not having wifi is the new hipster thing, because when I asked the barista about wifi he snidely informed me that they 'don't have it'. I guess they want to stray away from the computer toting coffee crowd. For those without unlimited data plans on their phones this simply doesn't work. Great coffee, completely useless place. 

Also it's really hot up in the loft area.
author: Natalia T.

description: I didn't understand the concept of getting coffee or of food as an experience until going to sightglass. Because of the nice layout of this place, it is easy to have good conversations and good coffee. I'm usually pretty cheap, but in this case it is worth it. I can see how I'm paying for an experience as well. My favorite spot to sit at is the balcony overlooking everything. I always leave this place properly caffeinated and happy.
author: Andrea T.

description: One of the cities best. Highly recommended. Source, roast and brewing up some of the worlds finest....
author: James S.

description: Love the coffee and I just tried the affagato bar on the mezzanine today!  Had the most amazing lavendar honey affagato!  The croissant is also delicious.  Very nice atmosphere, definitely a must whenever I am in the area!
author: Fanny W.

description: i just love the taste of Sightglass's primary coffees. i know they have several blends, and i usually ask for whatever the house blend is, and i've never been disappointed. i don't like coffee that is too bitter or acidic, and Sightglass is always just right. (i usually drink my coffee black) other than the coffee itself, this location of Sightglass also has a wonderful atmosphere to offer. once you walk inside, it looks like an industrial barn, with generous seating filled with people on the bottom and top floors but never too loud. they can definitely fit more seating into the cafe, but i appreciate that they don't. service isn't immediate, but not too long. the counter on the first floor sells coffee and baked goods while the one on the second floor is the one that serves the affogato.
author: Meryam B.

description:
Ambiance: This place is pretty amazing and one of my FAVS. The ambiance is very industrial & hipster + service is always friendly. If my laptop didn't need to be charged (no outlets), I could literally spend the whole afternoon here.

Seats: There's seating both upstairs & downstairs- by the counter, by the big windows, by the communal tables, by the bar, by the seats overlooking the entire coffee shop.

Coffee: Their coffee is roasted right inside the shop. Another cool aspect of this place is that you can watch people roasting beans, bagging beans, and making coffee art.

Wifi: No wifi here, so you'll actually have to enjoy this gorgeous space. Or you can people watch from either the big windows OR up on the 2nd floor. Plus, is it just me... or does no wifi also increase your productivity by only 10000%?
author: Cynthia L.

description:
The coffee: one of the best coffee spots I've tried in the city. They have a wide variation of coffee-- individually brewed (I believe) and it's delicious!! Rarely do I drink my coffee black-- I only drink black coffee if it's THAT good and Sightglass, you done did good! The caveat-- I paid almost 5 bucks for my small Ethiopian cup of coffee. They have lattes, cappuccinos and espressos and all that jazz. I'm almost tempted to just buy the lattes for their pretty little latte art. I tried my friend's latte and the espresso tasted kind of burnt. The foam, however, was velvety and good!  

The ambiance: very spacious with a-- dare I say-- "hipster" feel. Sorry, I hate to describe coffee shops as so but that was the immediate vibe I got stepping into the shop. Plenty of seating with an upstairs too. The only thing that knocked off a star was NO WIFI and NO outlets. A huge problem for this day and age where technology consumes the souls of patrons who breathe, eat and sleep computers and smartphone gadgets (guilty!) But definitely not a problem for one who enjoys a cup of joe while reading a book. I'm kind of 50/50 here.

The service: not subpar but also not beyond the sun and moon. I guess you can't expect happy-go-lucky-super-smiley baristas here. Didn't feel an immediate welcoming feel but the barista that helped me was pretty helpful and accommodating. Can't complain! 

Overall take: yes, definitely give it a try it you coffee connoisseur, you!
author: Alexis C.

description: The overall atmosphere was pretty laid back and uniquely hipster. Coming from the east coast to visit, definitely a cool place to check out! The staff was very friendly and gave a pretty good recommendation on their specialty coffee. The only downfall about this place was no outlets :/
author: Wendy D.

description: Very very nice space. I want this shop in Japan .... A bit sour coffee first experience. Let's come to work this time.
author: Miwa I.

description: Love the open space. Wish they had wifi. Seating is a little awkward and it was a little hot in the place to really be able to think. BUT because they don't have wifi, this would be a great place to go get work done if you don't want to be distracted by your computer. The affogato is also great. (:
author: Michelle K.

description:
I've had Sightglass coffee's Owl's Howl at Bellano for years and always found it to be very good although depending on the day/barista, it can be acidic. So when they opened up their cafe in the City, I had to try it. 

The interior is ginormous with a 2 floors. Coffee brewing and baristas in a center island and giant coffee roasting machine to the side. Lots of bars to sit. 

Espresso is another unique flavor with some chocolate and mild fruit plus earthy flavors. This taste different from the espresso I've had at Bellano. Maybe due to the on-sight roasting making the coffee fresher.

On par with Blue Bottle, Verve, etc. although I like Verve best.

My main gripe about this place is that it's a bit of a trek to get to from Civic Center Bart and having to walk through some of the sketchy neighborhoods.
author: Norman S.

description: This will probably be one of the best coffees you will ever have. Great atmosphere and good service. The pastries are amazing. A little on the pricey side however. Overall, a must.
author: Gareth P.

description:
SIGHTGLASSSSSSSS!!!!!!!!!!! 

I get excited every time I see their logo or hear someone talking about them. Thinking about this place brings me so much joy! 

First, disclaimer. I am NOT a coffee expert and pretty much know almost nothing about coffee (I am working on that though). With that said, some of my more refined coffee-lover friends greatly appreciate this place too. 

I always get the Vanilla Iced Cold Brew. It's the most refreshing coffee I've ever had. Perfect mix of the milk and coffee. I normally get almond milk with it! It's light with a hint of sweetness. Pretty much a go-to right after my work-out. It's about time for me to try some of their other drinks though. That's what I keep telling myself but the vanilla iced cold brew is just too good to not get whenever I'm there. 

Oh, and guess what. They sell Neighbor Bakehouse pastries here!!! So you can get great coffee AND tasty croissants. What more can you ask for? Come here ASAP or go to their Ferry Building location!!
author: Ingrid C.

description:
I love that they roast their own coffee beans. The location is easy and the building is HUGE! Don't worry about trying to find a seat. 

The coffee on the other hand was burnt and tasteless, a combination I didn't know existed. I think the hipster roasting the coffee got a little too excited. Wouldn't go back unless I need a place to use some wifi.
author: Succi Q.

description:
During my first visit to Sightglass the service was super friendly and the line went by super quick. It's a beautiful spot inside. 

They have almond milk and soy milk. While they were already sold out of most of their vegan treats, they still had vegan spicy chocolate cookies.
author: Jenna F.

description: The crazy amount of great coffee shops in San Francisco alone is enough to make me want to move away from Chicago!  Sightglass not only is a cute coffee shop but they also make good coffee and baked goods.  I was in the area visiting my friend at her office when I opened yelp to find a nearby coffee shop.  Lo and behold, Sightglass Coffee (one of the shops I bookmarked while planning my trip) happened to be around the corner.  Score!  I ordered the "Hooker Mocha" which when ordering felt a little funny to say along with the bacon, cheddar, and scallion scone.  I really liked the mocha (with almond milk) since typical mochas are very sweet whereas this one was not.  It was creamy but like everyone else said, it doesn't taste like the mocha you are typically accustomed to.  You don't really taste a strong sweet, chocolatey flavor but moreso a cocoa powder/dark chocolate taste.  Some people may not like that but I did since I wasn't in the mood for anything sugary.  The only downside was the drink was pretty pricey, $5, for maybe a 12 oz cup.  I know their beans are good quality but it was still a steep price to pay in my opinion.  The bacon scone was pretty tasty; it was flaky and substantial and I would recommend trying it!  Definitely check out Sightglass to grab a cup of good coffee or purchase some beans from around the world!
author: Melissa A.

description:
For the people that say as good as Blue Bottle, please!! it's much better.
The only issue is too many people like this place and you have to wait.
author: Phil L.

description:
I sit down with my cold brew (low acidity, refreshing), pop open my laptop to get to work and realize that there's no wifi here.

This place is a daytime bar. The exclusion of wifi, high ceilings, and large communal tables encourage socializing. 

They've replaced alcohol with caffeine here and I love it.
author: Alvin D.

description: Super cute and hipster place for young people. The entrance had plants growing on the side of the wall and bicycles hanging, which was immediately an attractive element of this coffee shop. I wasn't much of a coffee drinker, so I ordered a hot chocolate, which came out beautifully designed. There's an upstairs level where people are on their laptops in a wooden setting. Great place for people to work or talk!
author: Gloriane T.

description:
this place is amazing!
Coffee quality is the best and its ambiance is awesome
 I'll definitely be visiting again soon!
author: Jennifer W.

description:
The coffee here is really sour and poor-- they should not use their own beans.
The atmosphere is nice and airy, with lots of techies.  However, there are no power outlets or Wi-fi so you can't actually hold a decent work session here.
author: Alice S.

description: I love this place! Their coffee is really good and strong, and the baristas are very informative and nice. Although it's a little pricey the quality of the products make it worth it.
author: Gloria C.

description:
San Fran noob fact: The numbered blocks are MUCH larger than in most other cities. When I learned that my company's SF office was 5 blocks away from Sightglass I decided that'd be a perfect place to run off and grab a coffee. Well run I did, because breaks can only be so long and damn a SF block is big.

ANYHOW. I hail from Kansas City, and my favorite coffee shop of all time recently served Sightglass Coffee as a guest roaster. I'm a new convert to single origin roasts and pour-overs and all that good stuff, and knew that I wanted to try them out from their mothership. It was a thoroughly impressive experience, and even though it came with a surprise side of cardio, I'm glad that I did. 

Sightglass Coffee is gorgeous. The space is massive and airy, with a ton of natural light. Everything is made of contreet, metal or wood, a very elemental and minimalist look that I can appreciate. There is a massive coffee bar in the middle of the first floor, but most of the space seems dedicated to their roasting operation. There's also a nice retail space that I'd recommend perusing. I opted to drink my coffee and work from upstairs at one of the utilitarian communal tables. Maybe I was just intoxicated by SF in general, It was an inspiring environment. I enjoyed being surrounded by other people that I assumed were working on awesome techy or artsy projects. I'd work here in a heartbeat.

Of course, none of this would matter if the coffee was bad. Thankfully, it's incredible! The aromas are strong and the flavors are pure and unmuddled. I gladly finished my cup and before I left bought a few bags of beans for myself and some friends. I mean, how else can I assure that I can get coffee this good before my next return visit to SF?
author: Matt E.

description:
Very good!  

Love the decor here.  Spacious seating, Super friendly  staffs!!!

I got the Latte with Almond Milk.  It was rich and strong..haha.

Definitly go back when I have time.
author: Liza T.

description: Salt & Straw ice cream up in Portland is probably the best ice cream I've ever had in my entire life. Now, we can get their ice cream down here, combined with delicious Sightglass coffee? Awesome! The cold brew float is definitely where it's at!
author: Kazu O.

description: Wow this place is HIP. I am a Philz girl but wanted to see what all the fuss was about.  Beautiful large open space.  Immaculate airy  aesthetic, almost too hip, but good coffee and a nice selection of offerings.  Philz is still king but Sightglass is on to something.
author: Chelsey G.

description: I'm a fan of the service and ambiance here. The staff is ultra nice and the space is beautiful!!! The chai tea latte was ok... not a lot of flavor but... whatever, it didn't take away from my time here. They have a location up stairs but it was about 500 degrees up there.
author: Michael A.

description:
Had some good coffee and pastries here.  They had a mango jelly scone thing that was great.  The blueberry muffin was ok.  Better than average.  The chocolate croissant was what you'd expect. 

I had a house coffee here.  I don't think they had any single origin stuff here.  It's decent coffee, but after being spoiled with places like Stumptown and such, I don't necessarily get the hype here.
author: Richie W.

description:
Last Sunday I headed up to Sightglass from the South Bay, on my trip up the coast. I put the address in my handy dandy GPS and the British lady asked me if I was fucking with her; 50 minutes? This had better be a damn good cup of coffee.

The building is beautiful; its exposed pipe complements the acid washed cement floors and old growth countertops. I become excited.

I order a El Meridiano pour over; the cashier was a lovely gentleman. He asked if I'd like to pay using credit card or Square Wallet. After I pay, the cashier informs me it'll be a few minutes as they craft my brew. Oh, you fancy. I like this place already. 

Let me get two things out in the open: a) I'm a tourist and b) I'm Asian.

While I wait I walk around and took some photos (look for the photos in the gallery that weren't taken with Instagram and have depth of field); people are smiling and dogs are licking me. Not bad.

Enter stage left: UNPLEASANT "BARISTA"

Unpleasant Barista: "This isn't a zoo bro. We're not animals. Ask to take a picture."
Self: "I'm sorry, I'm just taking photos for my Yelp review. Would you mind if I took another photo of you pouring coffee?"
Unpleasant Barista: "No photos"

Srsly guys. Guys. Srsly. You guys. 

Well this is awkward.

Unpleasant Barista: "El Meridiano for Jon"
Self: "That's me"

I sip the coffee. I've it before. I'm expecting a balanced cup, sweet, top notes of citrus, grape, stone fruit. Instead my pallet is greeted with under extracted, tepid $4.00 cup of coffee. YOU HAD ONE JOB. 

Do you even coffee??

COFFEE LEVEL: 3 stars
SERVICE LEVEL: 5 stars for the cashier, -3 stars for the unpleasant barista.
PRETENTIOUS LEVEL: MAX LEVEL
TOTAL: C-

Editors note: The beans themselves are great, when crafted myself with 220F water using a Hario V60, a 14:1 or 15:1 ratio, and a pre infusion with a 3:30 extraction; 4 stars. Sweet, crisp flavors with subtle earthy hints. Must be operator error.
author: Jonathan N.

description: The place is hipster central, which I can take only in small doses.  But the coffee is good, very smooth, not bitter, not acidic.  Curiously, they have sugar but no syrup.  I've been to coffeehouses that have neither because they want the customers to drink the coffee without sweetness but it seems strange to have one but not the other.
author: Michael K.

description: Ok, ok, I will concede that I do enjoy Sightglass and their coffee.  We've been to their shop twice now, and I just had a latte from the cute little cart at the Ferry Buiding Farmer's Market, and their coffee/lattes are delicious.  Last time I was in their shop I had a maple bacon donut, and it was as amazing as it sounds.  I feel like I owe Sightglass a small apology that I handed them a 3-star rating my first time there; it total amateur hour on my end. Sightglass, like many other fine coffee establishments in our fine city, knows how to do coffee, and expects you to understand that they know what they're doing via their prices.  My $4 latte is now towards the low end of the potential latte price ranges, and I will say that it's definitely delicious.  If you have the option in indulging in their pastries in the display case at the registers, don't think, just do it.
author: Lisa I.

description: Dropping to four stars. Getting overpriced and service is poor. Coffee is still good, but service is bad. Also, getting a seat here is impossible. Sightglass needs to rethink their arrangement and service.
author: Andy D.

description: Very good espresso. I'm more of a fan of more mocha, caramel notes in my espresso which was missing. Roast on site. Large, spacious but no wifi. Not cheap either. Can buy whole beans but only 8 oz. bags.
author: Robert P.

description:
OMG I finally went to Sightglass Coffee. I ran over one night at 650pm right before closing at 7pm. I got in the doors--I needed to get some gifts for some coffee loving people as a novice coffee drinking person. The ladies at the booth were just cleaning up so I bugged them asking them tons of questions. They knew I was noob, I'm sure, and helped me for the most part. Just a couple tips. Don't ask "what's the most popular coffee bean(s)?" for one may respond as the lady responded to me, "there's so many it's hard to choose." I also asked "Could you grind the beans for me?" ...and just don't go there fellow noobs unless you want a socratic dialogue. They will answer with a question and say a lot of complex things that will go over your head. Apparently the type of grind depends on the method you make your coffee. A french press requires the coarsest setting. 

I'm a noob what can ya do. But yeah, I definitely got the "this coffee is not entry level stuff and is for people who know their shiz and appreciate the Coffee Bean". I will need to return to learn more about the ways of the Coffee Bean (though I did write a 40 page undergraduate thesis on product differentiation in the fair trade coffee bean market oh snap adjacent what), and try an actual cup of joe when they aren't closing. But yeah I've had their coffee elsewhere and it's SO GOOD. This is a must-go must-see cafe with the true San Francisco experience (who gets it?).

$11-15/bag of coffee beans (whole beans). Packaging has the clean, chic, elite + "yes we recycle" feel (brown bag packaging + nice logo-ing). It makes for nice, simple packaging.

Anyway, till next time...when I order a...cafe latte..!!!
author: Sarah W.

description: Nice location, open space, high ceiling and beautiful design. Cafe Latte was good. Baristas were friendly
author: Ibo K.

description:
Finally decided to try coffee from the actual brick and mortar today. 

Coffee is good but the counter people suck. Ever heard of service with a smile? It were really wouldn't kill you. Yan needs a shot of espresso before he gets to work.
author: tiffany p.

description:
I love the ambience of this place. Super cute wooden tables and stools, cute vintage-y mirrors/sinks right in an open area outside the two bathrooms (odd but something that really builds character to this place). If you sit in the second floor, you can  see the baristas from above making the coffee.

I had the costa rica "macho" drip coffee and it had the perfect balance of subtlely sweet but bitter with a touch of citrus fragrance left on the tip of your tongue after every sip. Its definitelt a brew i would get again if i was in the area more often.
author: Michelle H.

description:
Hooker's Mocha - delish!
Pistachio Croissant - I still have dreams about it!
Huge space.
author: Minh T.

description: I can't believe how good these coffee roasters are! One of the best cafés in the city of San Francisco, which also sells awesome, high quality, fancy pastries from contemporary and trendy bakeries, such as Piccino. I can't stop purchasing their smooth coffee roasts and to-die-for pastries. They also have an interesting vinyl LP collection that they play during the day. Their service is very professional, too, which is rare in San Francisco. I'm truly grateful for this place, which is truly accessible for those of us who hang out in the SoMa district.
author: Raymond F.

description:
Personally like the "no-wifi." No media distraction, so I can get some work done here! Atmosphere is great, a bit stuffy sometimes.
And of course, the coffee is the best. Cold Brew with almond milk is must-try.

kinda embarrassing, but one time i dropped my coffee... like all of it, and they poured me a new one! awesome service!!!
author: Kevin E.

description: Despite having no wifi...there are still throves of tech people littered throughout this coffee shop just hustling away on their macbooks. If you want a seat in the AM get here before 830am. If it's a sunny day and you're feeling too fat to slide into your skinny jeans sit by the front window...it's a sauna when it's not foggy outside. Plenty of bike parking...on the wall.
author: Laura S.

description: This is one of the coolest cafes I've ever been to! It has such a cool rustic industrial atmosphere and vibe to it. It is usually always packed with people so you have to be prepared to wait to get a seat. But it's worth it!
author: Izzy N.

description: Great coffee, great ambience, great location. I come back here over and over again. It's one of the best coffee shops in town. I feel like I'm doing it a disservice by calling it a coffee shop it's an institution.
author: Zarlakhta W.

description: Sightglass is by far my favorite coffee shop in the SoMa area. The coffee is smooth, not too dark, and not too acidic. The lattes are perfectly creamy, and the hot apple cider is sweet and tasty. Honestly, you can't go wrong here, including with their wonderful pastries. The space is bright and big, and there is never a shortage of seating. Plan ahead, though, if you plan to do work here - they don't have wifi.
author: Kendall S.

description: Visited SF for vacation and was pumped to see a specialty coffee shop right by the house I was staying at. The atmosphere and aesthetics of this place are incredible. The warehouse feel with everything out in the open, the roaster, packaging, training site, etc... Plenty of places to sit and the coffee was incredible. Had the Cortado and loved it. My friend had their vanilla iced coffee and said it was really good as well. Awesome and helpful staff! Highly recommend this place.
author: Gregg S.

description: I absolutely love coming here. The space itself is reason enough to come - so lofty and sunny.  Seeing burlap bags of beans piled in the corner and the roaster churning out freshly roasted coffee make the experience even better. Good people working here, excellent tasting coffee.
author: Christine O.

description:
Be as hipster as you want, I love this place

yes, great coffee

original space
author: Alanna F.

description:
For me, Sightglass is possibly the most beautiful cafe I have been to. 

Like many of the modern cafes popping up everywhere going for that natural/industrial/minimalist look, Sightlgass just nails it. This location is awesome, two stories, large, and open even if the roasting machine sits sort of just off center in the store in clear view for everyone. A great bonus is that just outside the main entrance, there is a rack for you to hang your bicycles off the wall!  The stand where you order your drink and where it's made is located in the center of the store and gives you a good view of everything and how your drinks are made. To the side there is wall of their goods.  When I was there, they had clay/earthenware mugs that were very unique and I had not seen in any other stores. I generally go around and buy the mugs of independent coffee stores, and I really wanted theirs, but I couldn't do it, because I couldn't deal with the rough texture (it felt personally somewhat akin to the feeling that chalkboards give me).

Aside from the aesthetics of the store, the coffee was also very good. I bought a lb of their Owl Espresso which I have been thoroughly enjoying at home. I'm definitely coming back here the next time I'm in San Francisco.
author: Katherine L.

description: Ridiculous that they don't have wifi here. Walked here to enjoy a good cup of coffee and get work done, but couldn't because they don't provide wifi. San Francisco is a tech hub, so it seems so behind the times to not provide it.
author: Shelby B.

description:
After always visiting their stand @ the Ferry Building on Saturday mornings, I was so happy to finally be able to visit their actual shop! 

You order right in the middle of the shop, and the baristas are surrounded my plenty of  standing bar space for you to observe / enjoy your coffee. There are some seats in the front of the shop and upstairs. Overall a very open space, which I love; perfect for some offline studying/book reading/socializing/daydreaming/people-watching - take your pick.

On this trip, I got a macchiato, and of course it was delicious. However, the Hooker's Mocha is one of my favorites (but note, not as mocha-y as Philz' Mocha Tesora). 

On the wall, they have their coffee beans for sale, along with some coffee-making equipment and some Sightglass merch.

Street parking only. 
Two private, one-person bathrooms.

Now, if only I could live near here...
author: Ashley N.

description:
I came here looking for sympathy due to a recent positive test for HIV.

I spent $4 for a 12oz cup of coffee- money that would have been better spent on treatment for my autoimmune disease. 

The Pistachio Croissant with Blackberry Jam is good and helped me take my mind off things
author: Benjamin D.

description:
LOOOOOOOOOOOOVE.

The vanilla iced coffee is a must!! Sightglass is a SF staple so I just had to check it out. Perfect spot to meet up a friend or read a good book. The location is also fairly central to SOMA.
author: Shana B.

description: One of the best latte's i ever experienced! Great atmosphere as well! Will be returning every time i come to SF!
author: Jenna H.

description: Not a whole lot more to say than has already been said about this place. Huge interior and good tunes, go upstairs and find a seat with a view. If you want another beverage besides coffee, try the Bernie's Best apple juice - really refreshing.
author: Gonzalo S.

description: Came in due to the rating from Yelp, not impressed, neither the service nor the coffee.  The other coffee house is way better.
author: Kiana L.

description:
I've been drinking small batch, fresh roast coffee since 1976.  This is some of the best coffee available.  They have 2 roasts to choose from and the people at the counter know a lot about the brew and can help you choose.  There's always a crowd, so don't get jittery until you've had your coffee.

It's a bit funky, a bit too little food and table space.  It's service at the counter, and it's a little spendy, but really a good cup of coffee.

HINT: If you want something simple, go upstairs and avoid the crowded line downstairs.
author: Leslie W.

description:
I am not a coffee person so I cannot critique their coffee, but the coffee I had was not crazily bitter (I like and can stand pretty bitter tastes) yet it was still so strong and kept me up! Also, I did see that they have a large variety of coffee beans from various countries and places! So my review is based on the comfort and feel of the cafe.

Pros:
- Big, spacious, and open cafe with high ceilings.
- Natural wood and simple interior.
- All drip coffee. None pre-made stuff.
- Clean and organized cafe.
- Different study areas (don't know details..)
- Many bike racks before the entrance of the cafe.

Cons:
- Hella people (well at least time I went which was after 2pm on a weekday).
- Bad parking. Come on, can't expect SoMa to have free street parking and a lot of it...

Although there was hella people at the cafe, the noise level was average and not that loud at all. Probably because the cafe is so big and open. The cafe tables are big and can seat a good amount of people and can have their respective convos without bugging the neighbors.
author: Shirley M.

description:
Famous roaster in SF...a must-do if you're a coffee person. The interior is too cool -- bar seating all around, and a second floor balcony with lots of tables and stools. One of my favorite coffee shop interiors by far.
The downside is there's no WiFi, which you'll find is the case with a lot of big roaster coffeehouses. They already get a lot of traffic, so I figure they like to keep things moving and not have people camp out with their laptops.
author: Laura S.

description:
I loved my latte. It tasted warm and round. 

The pastries and confections are a perfect complement to the coffees.

The space is gorgeous! If you go upstairs, you can see the loft office across the space and it's beautifully decorated.
author: Jacquee P.

description: First time to write the review and wanna say this is the best coffee shop that I ever been for! I like the environment here and the vanilla iced latte! Also I ordered a croissant to sharing with my friend. Great!
author: Yitian C.

description:
Awesome space for a remote office. High ceilings and the smell of roasted coffee is intoxicating and comforting to the max. 

Coffee is quality as well as their pastries. If you're not a die hard coffee drinker (ahem... Would you like coffee with your sugar? Catch my drift?) this place will be anti-climatic. You know, like your sex life with your BF of seven years.
author: Cin H.

description:
I'm not even joking, I walked into this place and just literally felt better. The Hallelujah choir sang when I opened the doors. Hahaha. No but, really this place is beautiful and I absolutely love the layout.

The baristas are right in the middle of everything, so you start there with your order. ALL of them were very nice/chill (I mention this because I've experienced a snobby coffee shop before and truly believe this makes or breaks a place). There's seating upstairs (which I didn't get to explore yet) and also towards the front of the shop. There's literally a huge coffee machine-thing too, not sure what it does but I'm sure their coffee is FRESH. Umm, yes please!

I ordered a latte, and instead of soy they have almond milk. LOVED it! I'm more of a tea drinker, but absolutely love Sightglass. AND their cups are THEE BEST.
author: Sammie T.

description: If you want to see the whole process of how coffee is prepared, check this place out! Great coffee and atmosphere. Very hip and modern, great place to visit for tourists!
author: Quintin W.

description: I came for the opening of the Affogato Bar and they were providing free affogatos with ice-cream from Salt and Straw. I tried the Mwasa espresso, which is from Rwanda and "has a cinnamon raisin spice, rum sweetness and a brown sugar finish" with a scoop of the chocolate ice-cream. It was delicious. I don't think I tasted any other coffee with such a bold sweet flavor. I also tried the chocolate ice-cream vanilla iced brew coffee soda float but I don't think i like the taste of sparkling soda with coffee. I don't care for the foamy layer on coffee (i know its the best part) but Sightless made it where the foam was thick and flavorful.
author: Rosanna T.

description: Great coffee, yummy pastries and laid back service in a good way. It is very hipster and all that, but worth a visit. They also have a small array of gifty things which would be perfect gifting for the coffee aficianado.
author: Ni C.

description:
It can be so difficult to keep up with the latest in SF coffee. I've always considered Blue Bottle the classic selection, but recently I've been told I must go to Ritual, then no - Four Barrel is the only true coffee lover's choice. Now I'm being told Sightglass is THE coffee spot. As you can probably tell, I'm not a coffee expert - just a gal who enjoys a tasty cup now and again and spends a lot of time working and hanging out in coffee shops. 

As for the latest in must-drink coffee, I was for the most part really pleased. The coffee of course was delicious and very powerful, as all these trendy places are. I felt like I was going to start crawling on the ceiling after downing my small cup. 

I'm always on the lookout for places that work well for spending hours to catch up with friends, get work done, or read a book, and though this space is beautiful, it didn't really give me that 'make yourself at home' vibe. It's more of the European style of coffee places, with standup counters to down your joe and get going to the rest of your day. It is undeniably gorgeous in there, though, with high ceilings and lots of natural light. 

I also liked that they used Square - always a plus in my book as an emailed receipt means I won't ever lose it. 

All in all one of my top choices for coffee drinking, if not for coffee shop hanging-out!
author: Christina P.

description:
One of those cases... do you REALLY need another 5 start review telling how great this place is??? well, just in case - this place is GREAT! I think it can only compete with the SoCal favorite Intelligencia (only Pasadena location). 

Got some coffee for home this time: left the bag in the for 5 hours, and two days later the car still smelling like espresso... left the bag in the kitchen - no more need for scented candles! 

So much enjoyment from some grounded beans...
author: Marianna K.

description:
I wavered between 4 and 5 stars on this review for the sole reason that there is NO wifi available at Sightglass. Then I realized I was being selfish and went with the 5. No wifi is actually kind of nice. People are so chill and relaxed, reading actual books and newspapers (I love a real newspaper now and then), and there are plenty of tables and spots to hang out not crowded by headphone-d, Mac book-ed lurkers. 

The coffee at Sightglass is delicious and the store itself is gorgeous. The upstairs loft has a great view of the coffee brewing action below and there looks to be event space as well. 

The location is a little bit out of the way for me, but I'd make a special trip to Sightglass anytime. They also have a fun Instagram feed @sightglass if you're into lovely coffee-themed pics.
author: Rachel Y.

description: My favourite place for coffee in San Francisco. Not too loud, just busy enough (unless you end up here on a weekend afternoon, which is bustling), great place to have an afternoon pick-me-up coffee conversational with an old friend. Mind that they do not have wi-fi, so you should bring your own connection. T-mobile tethering works well, and there is a xfinity access point available -- if you have service at home, you can use that too.
author: Dean M.

description: Sightglass has a great space to sit, sip a coffee, and chat with a buddy. The large open room provides a nice atmosphere, however the coffee (the most important aspect, leaves me wanting more. There seems to be only one size of cup available and at $4+ for coffee, it is a bit overpriced. I suppose you are paying extra for the atmosphere and the service, both of which are above average.
author: Hai Lee C.

description: Great breakfast at SightGlass with blueberry muffin, chocolate claw and latte. Wooden and metal cosy athmosphere. What a sight from the 1st floor! Could maybe have some more choice for pastries, but come on we'll forget that tiny detail.
author: Boehm B.

description:
The environment and style is stylish. Besides you can order on the first floor at the big oval shape bar, there is a smaller one on the second floor as well. We seated at the second floor but it was a bit hot. 

Coffee is a bit on the strong side but it is certainly a good gourmet experience
author: Chin Man L.

description:
Sightglass is easily becoming one of my favorites coffee shops (sorry Blue Bottle, Rituals, Philz and Four Barrels).  This place, along with their 20th location feels like the holy grail of coffee shops.  Lately, I have been finding myself walking four or five blocks from the Mid-Market to enjoy their fine coffees and soap (more on this below).

The positives:

-Beautiful architecture.  Converted warehouse into a two level coffee shop.  

-They have Aesop soap and fancy paper towels.You know that feeling you get when you are at the occasional fancy dinner( Gary Danko, Spruce, La Folie).  You go to the restroom, and they have extremely thick paper towels to dry your hands with?  You don't even want to throw the paper towel away because it feels so valuable.  Like maybe there can be another use for this little guy, before it has to kick the can forever. Anyways, it adds a certain touch to the finished product, which in this case is coffee. I looked up the price of this soap, as I fell in love with the scents. It is not cheap ladies and gentlemen.  $50 for a bottle of soap. So tons of respect to Sightglass for letting my hands feel fancy!  

-The coffee is almost always delicious.  Tip:  You really have to let your black coffee sit for at least 5 minutes before you can actually enjoy the flavor notes that each particular coffee bean produces.  This is a tip for enjoying coffee at any coffee establishment, roaster or not.

A couple of negatives:

There cheapest pour over coffee is usually $4.25.  I respect the premium coffee, but I would strongly recommend one for under $4.  Maybe instead of having two different drip  coffee make three?  I learned in economics class, that there is a price elasticity.  The point where the certain price for something, affects the demand.  I guess my price elasticity point for pour over coffee, would be above $4.  If it was below, I probably would enjoy it much more often. Most of the other coffee roasters in town offer such a price.  Highly recommend doing this.

Start making cold brew!  Even if in small batch, it is definitely worth it.  I once tried there iced coffee, and it was really not good.  They spend  the time and energy making through a pour over method, not their standard "quick cup", and then they put ice.  VOILÀ, your iced coffee is ready! Not. Every real coffee lover knows, that if you simply put ice over hot coffee, it kills the flavor notes. It is the cheap way of making iced coffee.  Please, make cold brew instead.
author: Hanna A.

description:
When I started working in SoMa a few months ago the whole area was new to me. Thankfully I was able to find the best [not so] hidden gem in the district: Sightglass! They must have the best beans in the business because every time I get a latte it tastes perfect, despite the number of different baristas they have. They use the nicest professional-grade espresso machines and their work area is always immaculate. They also have some of the best pastries ever made, most notably the berry/pistachio croissants (get them early or they'll be gone by about noon!). They also have a great selection of seating, from window seats on the ground floor (perfect for people-watching), to long bars/stools and large tables upstairs, perfect for impromptu meetings or just working on whatever you want on your laptop or tablet.

Oh and they have super secure bike parking in the entryway. Custom-made offset hanging racks with cable attachment points makes for nice safe peace-of-mind bike parking.
author: Griffin J.

description:
This coffee is not your average joe which is why I wrote this letter to Sightglass.

Dear Sightglass,

You have truly outdone yourself. Everything about you, from the atmosphere to the baristas to the coffee bean quality, is amazing. You are no Starbucks. You are no Peet's Coffee. You are no Coffee Bean and Tea Leaf. You are none of those. You are very different and you are better. You are truly special and unique and the effort and love for what your baristas do really shows and shines through. Thank you for doing what you love and making your customers smile.

Sincerely,

Jacquie H.

My letter truly sums it all up. It sums up the experience and how I feel about Sightglass. 

Here's what I ordered:

One size. 

LATTE ($4): I love this because it was creamy and they had great temperature control since it was not cold or scalding. Not at all bitter.

ESPRESSO ($3): Light and quite refreshing. No acidity detected. Once again, great temperature control.

CAPPUCCINO ($3.5): Not bitter in the least sense and has great depth.

SERVICE: They were very prompt in getting our drinks out. They really love what they do and it really shows in the quality of the coffee. 

DECOR: Loving this space. I don't know but something about it seems magical and makes for a greater experience. The crates filled with coffee beans, the shelves filled with their own roasted coffee beans, the machinery to roast and prep the beans, the two story seating area, and even the windows that let in natural light have that modern and rustic feel that adds to the experience as a whole and makes it just that much better.

Will I return? Yes but only if I'm in the area. As much as I love Sightglass and they are currently my favorite place for coffee (yes, I admire it more than Four Barrel and Verve), I am still not an avid coffee drinker unlike my folks. Verve is sometimes a bit too bitter and needs to work on temperature control and Four Barrel is roast and has excellent depth. Still, Sightglass wins and is probably the best coffee you'll be able to find.
author: Jacquie H.

description: I'll admit I'm not a huge coffee drinker (green tea obsessed) but once in a while I do enjoy a good cup of coffee! I checked out Sightglass on a rainyFriday morning. The atmosphere here is def what drew me in, i loved the industrial look and feel. Compared to most SF coffee shops this place is MASSIVE!! The staff was friendly and very attentive. I had a iced coffee and got a small pastry and sat upstairs. It was nice and open but still very comfortable. Great place to meet and friend and just chat! I will def be back =)
author: Hetal P.

description:
We actually sat in this time.  I had an almond latte (they only do almond milk now), which was pretty decent, not too sweet.  The guy who took our order clearly knew what he was talking about with the coffees, which was nice.  We also got a bacon cheddar scallion scone, which was not dry, but it would have been nice warmed up.  We got some tables looking out at 7th, which is not exactly an awesome view, but it was nice to have the big windows. 

It does have a really warehouse feel, and the pastries would have been better warmed, but they do coffee well.
author: Marilyn H.

description:
The vanilla cold brew is awesome - the vanilla isn't too sweet and doesn't over power the coffee itself. The atmosphere is a nice work environment, as it's a large open space with lots of light. 

It's also a neat spot because you get to see the baristas doing there thing along side other workers who are packing/grinding/roasting coffee.
author: Riana L.

description:
Rain pitterpattering on the pipes outside, down comforter draped over me, fluffy cat curled up in my arms, thermal pjs. Sounds like it's time for mimis, right?

Well, it's not. Why, preytell, besides my general insomnia? The drip coffee I had early afternoon today at Sightglass. I assume I'm losing sleep because it was so potent, though both the singular and subtle flavors of all their roasts that I've tried, as well as the prices I have paid, are enough to keep me up at night.

The anticipation regarding when the cafe/roastery will be unclothed is also keeping me from getting my zzz. First completely veiled, now covered by a transparent tarp, this has been an ongoing tease...but it will be worth having been benched all this time.

Like arabica through a sightglass, these are the restless nights of my caffeinated life.
author: Joanna M.

description:
The best thing about Sightglass is being able to see coffee in the roaster. This place roast and package coffee within the shop and it is just a really great environment. There are plenty of tables upstairs for reading and studying. I do hate that I can not find any plug to charge my phone :(. The decor is very hipstery with cute (airplants and terrariums) and wooden tables and chairs. 

Espresso and cold brew are amazing. My favorite is the cold brew with a bit of almond milk. I've been ordering that since returning to LA and have not had anything as good. I also ordered the Hooker's mocha and was very disappointed. I didn't like the chocolate and it did not taste very good and leave a little weird after taste.
author: Huyen N.

description:
I am in love. This place is the coffee house of my dreams. There are huge bike racks at the door to place your ride, 2.5 levels, and large shared working tables. It's light and airy and in a design aspect, fabulous. The staff isn't pretentious, and there's a good all around vibe. 

As for food, i ate a pistachio jam walnut croissant dealy and while I'm sure i am going to need an extra workout it was totally worth it. 

...and the coffee is good, too. If you're into that sort of thing.  ;)

Will definitely come back when i visit the city again.
author: Kim S.

description: I give credit where credit is due. This place definitely deserves credit. I must admit I depend on the yelp reviews a lot! When I go out of town this is my favorite app to use. However, at times I am let down or missed lead by some reviews. This place was not one of them. It was everything everyone said it would be. It was delicious, staff was friendly, and our food came out fast and it was just what we ordered. I can't wait to come back tomorrow before I head home.
author: Maria J.

description: This might be my favorite coffee house room in San Francisco. I always feel a sense of ease even with the most caffeinated binge here. Great coffee, perfect interior.
author: patrick g.

description:
Awesome espresso! Don't think of tainting it with milk or sugar! 

The place itself is jaw dropping gorgeous!! Clearly a good founder must have been behind this undertaking, thanks for bringing coffee lover's heaven to earth!! :) Where is the next stop? Boston??!
author: Antoni A.

description:
AMAZING, AMAZING, AMAZING!
That is all you need to know.
Unless you want me to go on and on about how delicious the coffee is, or how cute the space is, or how hipster-liscious the crowd is. Cuz I could! But better for you to enjoy all of this for yourself! Just go!
author: Kent T.

description:
I let someone go ahead of me who was in a hurry and then when it was my turn the lady said her line was closed. I told her the story and the other people vouched for it and she was a total bitch, can I say that on yelp?

What the hell was that? That's not customer service. I get kicked to the back of the line?

I don't care if you do pour over or French press or single origin. Not when I'm treated like that --- you're done. 

Treat people decently. Value their time. It's not that hard.
author: Chris M.

description:
sightglass was the first hipster coffee shop that i had ever visited upon moving to san francisco.

it's only a couple years old, and since it opened, it's changed a lot. for one, there's now an upstairs that matches the vibe of the downstairs area. it's lofted, and there are a lot of bar stools / table space to get work done or catch up with friends. a lot of wooden everything, and several times, i've walked upstairs to see people photo-shooting.

coffee here is so so good, but so so overpriced. if you come to a place like sightclass you should stay. don't grab it and go. you're paying for this warehouse-y loft-y atmosphere. there's no wifi here so there aren't as many tech nerdz working on their dumb start ups, which is nice. but there are tech nerdz around because it's in dirty soma near airbnb and paymentwall and whatever.

free parking is pretty easy to find in this area if you're concerned. they also don't mind if you bring in sandwiches or whatever since they only sell yummy yummy expensive pastries.
author: Jennifer L.

description: We ventured upstairs to the affogato bar, so good! Super hipster but amazing space. I would definitely study here. The sea salt caramel ice cream is amazing topped with the Guatemalan espresso. Perfect portion size and a great, delicious pick me up! Would definitely go back and I'd highly recommend it!
author: Stephanie B.

description: This is one of my favorite spots to grab a coffee. Its a great place to work and relax. With large open space and great natural light it makes up a great ambience  . The menu is very limited for pastries and other bakery products but the they have a great range of classic coffees. The coffee roast smell is invigorating!!!
author: Rimi K.

description: Decent coffee and very interesting environment. However no Wifi makes it feel very backwards. The only function I see for this place is catching a coffee and hosting social events.
author: Jude N.

description:
"Waaaaahhhh! No wi-fi!" Good. Who says a place has to have wi-fi? Keep your laptop at home, douchebag. Just because you can hang out at Starbucks all day on your laptop doesn't mean all coffee spots have to follow suit. 

Its clear this place is just for roasting and serving coffee.  If it doesn't do that well, then knock off some review stars. But knocking off stars because they don't offer the privilege of wi-fi and outlets is just wrong. 

Customer service seems to be a complaint here. I have never been treated rudely but I can still see how it might occur.  They don't seem to be friendly. 

I don't order any of this mocha, latte bullshit either. I drink coffee and the occasional espresso. I don't put any cream and sugar either. How can all these people judge coffee here when they don't really drink the coffee. Some lady put in her review she thought the coffee was ok but she ordered a mocha and some iced vanilla thing! WTF? Go to Starbucks for wannabe coffee then!

As for the coffee, its high quality, very good. I like Roast Co. and some others more but this is still excellent. I had an espresso here today and it was perfect. Espresso should be short, bitter, and have a great mouthfeel/texture.

 The chocolate chip cookie and almond cake were solid. Not made there but from reputable places.

In short, I feel most people don't drink coffee the 'right' way so they knock a place for just doing coffee the 'right' way.
author: Dash_Rendar _.

description:
It's a nice place (design wise more so than the coffee) for those that can put up with the attitude.  I've had bad experiences at both sightglass on 7th st and also the one on 20th.
The baristas don't seem to like to customize your drink, and if it comes out not the way you like it, it is what it is....

I have better coffee and much better coffee experiences at many other coffee shops in SF.
author: Nadim T.

description:
This place is the 'ISH!!!! They make their own coffee beans and you get to see the whole process! Sadly, I did not have coffee, so I cannot review the brew. However, what I did have was their Apple Cider and if that is any indication of their brew, OMWOW!!! When I ordered the cider, they asked if I wanted their sweeter brew or their tartier brew! Well, I just HAD to do the tartier side and it was smooth, creamy and DEEEEELICIOUS!!! 
Don't be fooled by the lines though. The staff is SUPER friendly and SUPER quick! So, trust! You will be in & out within 10 minutes!
author: Rob L.

description:
They offer Kouign- Amann from B Patisserie here! The coffee is pretty solid (but I'm also not a coffee expert) - enjoyed the vanilla iced brew, reminded me of my childhood when I would drink iced coffee every morning in Denmark.

Hooker's Mocha - love dark chocolate!
author: Cha C.

description: Seriously good coffee and ambience in this architectural delight. Tucked away in a hidden neighbourhood of San Fran - where locals and tech start-ups unite. Melbourne, Australia - you may have a run for your money... #coffeeculture
author: Angela K.

description:
W-O-W

I have been going to blue bottle coffee for years thinking "this is the best San Francisco Coffee"  but when I stepped into this establishment, I was really wowed.  Its HUGE, there are two levels, a huge wrap around coffee bar, a self serve water station, a bike rack outside, a paper menu that you hold in your hand, and what appeared to be 6 or 7 baristas (well, baristos, really) all working at once.  

this place is truly coffee on another LEVEL.  To give you an idea of the coffee itself, we had a vanilla infused iced coffee with soy milk.  AMAZING.

If your in Soma its a must, and perfect to impress out of town guests.
author: Bret O.

description:
Coffee here is delicious! The coffee beans are roasted right in the shop and you can bet the place smells heavenly! 

I've tried the Vanilla Iced cold brew coffee (w/ almond milk and once with regular milk). Both tasted delicious! The coffee is smooth and barely sweetened. The almond milk adds an extra nuttiness and natural sweetness from almonds. If you order for here, you get the coffee in a cute little mason jar. For to-go, it's served in a cute paper cup. Quality is excellent! Even the ice cubes are nice - solid and a perfect cube (melts slower = less diluted coffee!). I've also tried the mocha. Strong smooth coffee flavor with very dark bitter chocolate. It was lovely, highly suggest this for chocolate lovers.

The ambiance is very chic and hip and service is awesome - people are enthusiastic and friendly. Great atmosphere for chatting with friends, reading, or getting some work done on your laptop. There are plenty of seats/tables on the second floor. Unfortunately, one thing to note is that they do not have free wifi...
 
Space is very clean and comfortable. Bathrooms are very clean and the Aesop handsoap they have smells soooo good .__.  ... : D

I love Sightglass Coffee and I always try to stop by when I'm in the area.
author: Monica T.

description:
Crowded, expensive, no tea, very warm upstairs.

Coffee is good and decoration is nice.
author: Tomasz Z.

description:
The coffee is great! Love the environment too, very nice and comfortable.
Though I think there are a lot of spaces, enough to put more chairs and table...
Customers are quieter here (or maybe just when I visited), which is nice.
author: Ya K.

description:
I'm a tea snob rather than a coffee snob, so I don't fully understand the appeal of this place.  It's very roomy, and has interesting steam punk-like decor, so I like that.  Everyone else raves about the coffee.  

Basically, I bring my coffee snob friends here, and then observe their face for the inevitable signs of delight.
author: Niniane W.

description:
Best coffee I've had to date!!!
Im not even a coffee drinker (on the count of finding it unnecessarily bitter).  But I now know that it doesnt have to be,  when done right.

Had a cup of late (10 oz).  They don't offer any syrup or flavors.  Well brewed coffee could acyually taste delicious without the added flavors!  I have to look into how they actually make it...they may use the drip method (which I'm told is good).

Also, i love the ambiance.   First thing you see as you walk in is the cofee mill.  It smells good too! 

Ps: their coffee is pricy ($4.50) for a 10oz late.   It took them about 15 minutes to make and it shows.
author: Medeset A.

description: If you like strong coffee this is the place to get it. I had the dirty hooker and it kept me up for the rest of the road trip.
author: Iris G.

description:
This is my second visit to this hipster coffee Mecca and the pretentiousness of my barista this time surpassed the last. 

I noticed that they had Kouigh amann from B Patisserie in their pastry case and raved about how amazing they are. But when I asked the barista if she had ever tried them she said, and I quote, "Oh, I don't really eat laminate pastries." This was accompanied by the most disgusted look possible, smeared all over her face. 
A. Really?!?
B. That is not the way to up sell a $4.50 pastry with my $3 cup of drip coffee. 
Someone needs to explain to these people that they work in a service industry. And that passing value judgements is not the best approach to good customer service.
author: Kelley C.

description:
Charged $5 for a coffee that was the size of an infant's sippy cup. It was a barely warm chalky mess... but hey it had a pretty design on top! 
Jokes aside, I do not recommend this place for a midday coffee break. Steer clear and spend your money elsewhere. It appeared to be a hipster mecca that caters to people who are more interested in the ambiance than the coffee they are drinking.

Ps. I am all for supporting independent coffee brewers, but being independent does not mean offering a poor product at an inflated price.
author: Daniel C.

description:
I love their tarts. Mushroom and goat cheese...and their omg just all of them. My go to breakfast place when I'm in a rush to work in SF. If only I had time for a cup of coffee here. 

It's a very cute coffee bar with some great smelling coffee beans, fresh food, great lighting + seating--this place has got the nice chill saturday morning feeling everyday.
author: Tiffanie T.

description: Finca La Esperanza from Nicaragua straight up black is a great way to start your day up. Even if it's 4pm in the afternoon.
author: Kim N.

description:
I'm not a huge coffee fanatic, but i do love sightglass! 

I came here with some friends and was immediately greeted with the aroma of coffee! Yum! I love how spacious and trendy this place it! You can study, catch up with friends or simply enjoy your coffee here. The upstairs area is awesome! It overlooks the entire place so you can watch the baristas do their thing. The line can get long, but be patient. It is totally worth it! 

Being in Soma, there are many bikers. I love how they are biker friendly and even have designated bike racks right outside their front door.
author: Tori V.

description:
I love coffee. ALOT. What I love more than coffee is a great local coffee shop.
Sightglass is pretty rad of a place. Just went for the first time this weekend.

Great cup of coffee at $4 and I love that you can choose the type of coffee you want brewed. Choosing from a menu is always fun. :)

Don't go to Starbucks or Peets anymore if you are in the area.
Go here. Its neat.
author: Cicely T.

description: Not a study in Café. No public Wi-Fi, seats are hard and outlets are nonexistent so that you don't stay for long.
author: Amy H.

description:
Adorable SOMA warehouse space morphed into a coffee roastery and shop. Big open doors leading into a big open space with two floors, and plenty of seating.

There is no wifi, which is kinda nice since it keeps the crowds down, turnover high, and honestly, it keeps you honest about not spending hours facebooking.

Iced coffee comes in mason jars with handles. Mason jars. With handles. 

There's some loft space beyond the Private and training areas where there are neon yellow couches. No indication what it is beyond some fancy lounge for the owners/staff. Hello, secret level of a Tony Hawk Pro Skater video game? Someone tell me how to get access because I want to go to there.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Having tried espresso and drip coffee from most of the roasters from the Bay Area ie. Verve, Blue Bottle, Ritual, Four Barrel, Barefoot, Linea and beyond ie. Stumptown, Victrola, Madcap, Dogwood, Counter Culture, Intelligentsia, I set my sights on the Sightglass flagship location.  And what a sight it is, with a giant skylight and their roasting and bagging facility right in the center of the space.  

There was some unpleasantness, however.  Some douchebag cut to the front of the line, and then the barista nearly served someone behind me when I had been standing at the counter for a couple minutes.  I've experienced that sort of thing at Shilin Night Market trying to order from a stinky tofu stand.  The clientele is more of the brogrammer/tech industry-types rather than the hipsters you get at Ritual and Four Barrel.  Then there were no tables available either downstairs or upstairs at 2pm.  If the coffee had delivered a memorable taste, all would be forgotten. 

I had tried a bag of their Indonesian drip coffee in the past and found it to be a meek version of a bright Stumptown.  This time, I was in the mood to try their mocha.  I wasn't able to ask the barista which espresso blend they used, but I could barely taste it through the nearly flavorless chocolate and very flat steamed milk.  I'm used to drinking my espresso shots from a 20g portafilter basket.  I suspect they prepared my mocha with about half of that amount or twice as much milk.  Everything about it just tasted weak.

I may revisit at some point to sample more of their drip coffee, but honestly I could have made a more flavorful mocha at my office using our standard Dogwood Neon Espresso and melted Tcho chocolate nibs.  I'd be happy to revisit my review should the next visit be a more positive experience.
author: Danny K.

description:
The charm of Sightglass is not to be understated. This converted warehouse coffee shop has a perfect blend of space, light and hipster artistry that makes it a wonderful place to spend the afternoon working or with a good book.

A great touch is the fact that the day-to-day operations of Sightglass are closely integrated into their shop. On one side of the first floor you can watch as employees pack bags of coffee beans, while on the other side a gigantic roaster sifts and cools pound after pound of coffee bean. Upstairs there is a sectioned off work area where Sightglass employees are doing who-knows-what. All this lends itself to a coffee experience that makes it feel like what you have in your hand is so much more than what it appears. 

Side notes: No wifi, no outlets, and the espresso is really STRONG.
author: Dennis R.

description: The place spacious with 2 levels. Each cup of coffee is freshly brew, but I tasted better coffee for the price. No wifi.Clean unisex bathrooms.
author: Sherman C.

description: pretty great coffee, definitely bolder tasting than most. we also had a really yummy blueberry ginger scone. my coffee was piping hot so i got a head start by dipping the scone into it... so good.
author: Taylor N.

description: Very cool and hip coffee shop, with nice vibe and great espresso drinks to match. Like it. They have seating upstairs too. Havent tried anything but coffee here, so cannot comment on pastries and such.
author: Alex G.

description:
This place is absolutely breath taking, the coffee is excellent. I am giving it two stars for a few very serious reasons. What coffee shop doesn't have wifi? Okay...I can deal, I will just tether from my phone. But, wait...no alternative sugar. Okay...I can see this whole let's 'keep it real' vibe...how about the diabetics? Is Truvia not an eco/natural alternative. Knock. 

After I get my 'for here' coffee, I can't wait to get up stairs open my tablet, hop on this conference call for work and start pounding away. It reminded me of my favorite place in Birmingham, Octane...where I would just work, drink a few coffee's, eat a cookie and feel wholesomely accomplished on my business trip. 

But no, they don't have outlets. Yes, outlets...you know to power up your devices after a six hour long flight...

They could argue, that they want to keep it real, no air conditioning, nothing fake, totally hipster, no one needs energy in this place. This is a straight up bad business, you can keep the ambiance with out limiting your clients.  

Buddies, you just missed out on two additional coffees and maybe a cookie purchase today alone. Never mind, me and my business cohort having two coffees a day and any additional pastries. 

Ill be back, but only when I have to have coffee, I wont be making a point to go to this place.
author: Jacci D.

description: Great atmosphere, impeccable space, but for me the coffee is borderline undrinkable. They shun dark roasts which I find pretentious and off-putting, but hey -- that's an SF-wide thing right now. Typically I can still appreciate a good medium or even the occasional blonde roast, but Sightglass' coffee tastes acidic and dishwater-y to me.  I walked out of there today thinking the emperor seemed a bit scantily clad.
author: Shannon C.

description:
