Atmosphere: Coffee roasting on the site & beautiful sunlight shining through the windows (Rating: 5/5)
Coffee: Vanilla Cold Brew w/ whole milk (Rating: 4/5)

Perfect for reading and just hanging out with a good old friend!
author: Jenny W.

description: If they had wi-fi and served me a full latte, I would have given it a 4, but because none of this occurred today a 3 will have to do. A little disappointed, but I will give Sightglass credit for a beautiful space and the coffee is pretty tasty. Service a bit slow today too unfortunately.
author: Coraly S.

description: Sightglass's space is amazing. Great place to sit down and work. The coffee was also very great. They roast their own beans and offer a lot of options.
author: Joshua H.

description: Went here on a Sunday morning and it quite the shop. Tons of open seating, lots of light coming through the windows, and the staff was vey friendly. I had a cappuccino along with a strawberry brioche pastries and both were delightful and a great way to start the day.
author: Leanna G.

description: I had this on my bookmarks for a while now! When I had the opportunity to go up to Norcal this past weekend, I made sure to visit here. The baristas were friendly and the coffee was good. Loved the ambience and it's just a beautiful establishment!
author: Diana K.

description:
Sightglass Coffee is the most impressive-looking "coffee shop" that I've ever set foot in. The interior space is huge (as in, a loft someone would buy to live in for well over a million dollars!) and includes dark wood, large windows, and very cool space. They have an area for bicycles (do they deliver coffee on these bikes?) and even all the bikes look small against the massive space.

It seems like they've carefully planned every detail - even the water glasses are cute, designer mason-jar type glasses. On my most recent trip, I ordered a cappuccino which was delicious and strong and my guy had an espresso which he thoroughly enjoyed. We also shared a ginger muffin which was fresh and yummy! 

Near the coffee counter, they sell cool coffee paraphernalia but, for now at least, I'll just keep coming the 5 or so blocks from my office to enjoy a great, relaxing coffee and experience at Sightglass!
author: Meghan P.

description: LOVE the coffee.  I have been told I am a coffee snob.  Don't necessarily love the title but I do search and seek the best coffee I can wherever I go.  I typically get an almond latte and Sightglass Coffee did it to perfection.  So much so I came back the next day for a repeat and they did not disappoint.
author: Beth B.

description: This is actually a new wave of coffee shop! Great coffee and croissant. Very fashionable interior and good selection of music make coffee time much comfortable.
author: Jerry M.

description:
Just about as hipster as they come. But wow, a beautiful open space that is super conducive to studying, a chat with friends, or whatever else you have on your plate. Very open space with lots of natural light and big windows! 

Their pastries are fantastic, highly recommend you try one, and of course their coffee is great too. 

It's usually fairly crowded, but definitely worth a stop to experience at least once.
author: Marilyn M.

description:
Sightglass has the most incredible space ever. I have literally never seen a more beautiful modern coffee shop in my life. But there's not much you can do with it. You  can't really socialize, you can't work, you can't even drink your coffee comfortably. Because of its structure, the space traps hot air and it's unbearable for any prolonged period of time (especially upstairs where all the hot air stagnates). If you're lucky enough to actually get a seat, you'll feel like you are drinking a hot latte in a sauna. 

They also don't have wifi or any outlets, my guess this is intended to discourage you from staying too long. So between the heat, lack of seating, insanely long waits and general computer-unfriendliness, Sightglass kind of sucks. 

The coffee tastes great though (star), and it is extremely beautiful (star).
author: Nat V.

description:
Coworker and I came here in the morning to do some work. Unfortunately, we only stayed for a little bit because there's no WiFi. However, will definitely be coming back here regularly just to hang out!

Sightglass has a great variety of coffees and blends. There are two registers, so the line moves pretty quickly. I ordered the Wamuguma AB, Kenya individually prepared coffee ($5 for a cup). After the cashier takes your order, he/she will send you down to one of the baristas who will prepare your coffee. Because I ordered an individually prepared coffee, I had the pleasure of watching my barista brew my cup of delicious coffee. I LOVED, LOVED, LOVED my coffee :) I was a happy camper.

This place also has a nice selection of pastries as well. I didn't have anything, but definitely will next time!

The layout of Sightglass is definitely spacious--two floors with plenty of seating on the upper level. I appreciated how open the first floor is where you can actually watch the baristas prepare coffees and as they roast their own coffee beans. 

Highly recommend this place for a nice morning/afternoon coffee hang out or break.
author: Rachel C.

description:
Walking in I was amazed by the large, lofted space. This is the most spacious cafe that  I've ever been to and funny enough it's here in SF.

The coffee here is remarkable. The aroma and the flavor of the cup was exactly to my liking and best of all it didn't have any of the acidity that I notice from other SF coffees that shall remain nameless in this review. 

I have several favorite coffees here in the city but to date Sightglass has the lead.
author: Esther A.

description:
Great coffee in the city. they know their beans and brew. I really enjoyed my cappuccino and I'm little hard to please when come to my coffee. so kudos for that! 
Little snob attitude when I asked for a tea for my friend. but I won't hold it against them...

I really like how the place was decorated and interior design was tasteful.

Bought beans for home and really enjoy their coffee in my home espresso machine. I'll come back when I'm in San Francisco.
author: Eliad G.

description:
Awesome coffee shop in soma.  Love sitting upstairs to enjoy my cup of hand crafted coffee and to watch the barista make endless coffee drinks and latte art.  Love the wood interior and cozy ambiance.  Coffee was delicious, smooth, and flavorful!  a close second to blue bottle, in my opinion.
Sightglass has come a long way, and I am glad they are where they are today.
author: Linda T.

description: Excellent coffee, great store, cool vibes, lots of seating, wifi.. A great package all in all.. Return here regularly
author: Jack O.

description:
Sightglass espresso coupled with the barista's skill translates to blissful caffeine fixes.  As long as the price is not a problem for you, you will leave both happy and caffeinated. 

In addition to the near-perfect lattes, this location's ambiance is perfect for a catch up session with a friend, that book you keep meaning to get to, or even a work space away from your office.  Sightglass has an industrial, open, high-ceiling space with lots of natural light; you'll be overcome with a strong coffee aroma as you walk in and, most likely, will not have to fight to find a seat.  I especially like the seats at the window on the first level or the stools along the rail on the second level (there you'll have a good view for watching the baristas at work). 

All in all, this is one of those establishments that make me miss Bay Area's coffee scene; come, sip, and enjoy.
author: Kimya P.

description:
So many people talk about San Francisco Francisco's coffee shops, and for the most part, this has been invisible to me. See, I have been applied in Wellington New Zealand, and have very high expectations.

Well, sight glass was actually ok. When one first enters, it is doing a bustling business with beans roasting to the right, and being bagged on the left. Straight up the middle is where the coffee is ordered

The barista knew what a flat white is, so that ticked a box, but when asking for a long black there is a blank stare as if I am asking for something best kept in a brothel. So, I settle for an Americano...close enough in the drought of coffee I have been in.

The coffee was reasonably good. Not very much complexity, and possibly a little too astringent from a too long extraction, but nevertheless serviceable. So, it is the best I have had in SFO so far.

Overall a pleasant experience, and I just may need to up the rating a bit.

++Edit...I moved this up to 4stars. Comparing it to Wellington is unfair.
author: Truffle B.

description:
A good area if you need hardware and in this case a coffee shop.
Very good/strong coffee.
Nice staff, no wifi ;-(
author: Katie F.

description: I dig the transformation from a warehouse to a coffee roaster & cafe. There's plenty of seating both down & up, which give an ideal vantage point to watching the magic happen. It does get hop upstairs when roasting though. Filter is served in a mug, which doesn't lend itself to really appreciating the flavours. The staff are friendly and even offered to make me a flat white, given I was from Aus. Worth coming if not for the coffee, at least for a look.
author: Chris K.

description:
Excellence coffee, fantastic vibe, cool people. Yet, NO WIFI!

I'm giving two stars purely because they have just awesome coffee.  The brewing is totally thoughtful and unique.  Probably one of the best you can find in the city.  Not the same level with Starbucks or any other coffee shop chains.  I mean, Sight Glass is probably a MBA if Starbucks is a elementary school kid.  

However, the reason I'm only giving two stars is they have NO WIFI.  Yup you heard me right, you know the thing your need to get on Internet and do stuff? They have NONE.  So next time you need a good coffee to get some work done, this is Not-the-place.
author: Ariel Z.

description: I was clueless as soon I walked in. No sign where to start or the menu. The baristas didn't seem to be familiar with what they were serving.
author: Swapna P.

description:
Two areas can be improved:

1.  Service -- once I ended up behind someone who was testing a prospective barista's test drinks.  Neither the tester or barista told me I might be held up a little for this test.  On a more general note I feel the barista's care more about how they feel about the drink than the customers' experience.

2.  The treats are not as strong there as they are at other places.  Generally they have candies (which I'll eat as a last resort), and baked goods that aren't five star quality, more like three stars.

Two areas they nailed:

1.  The coffee -- lots of excellent choices, I don't drink a ton of coffee so I treat myself to the top-shelf pour-overs and have never had a bad cup.

2.  The space is really nice.  On warm days they open up the front windows, you can sit at the bar near them, read the Sunday NYT and watch the day go by.  (note there are no papers for sale there, you have to plan ahead).
author: John R.

description:
I've heard it's a little on the pricey side for a small cup, but coffee beans imported from Latin american and Africa?? I've gotta try this. 

I'm not a big coffee drinker but this coffee was pretty good! I don't know if it lived up to the hype though.. 

The menu was pretty simple, which was nice, but I wish they had more flavors

I ordered the Hooker's Latte and it had a nice, rich, flavor.. nothing to complain about but nothing I would really crave.
author: Stacey K.

description: Have you ever been hugged by your coffee?  Phenomenal range of flavor in velvet textures. Had macchiato and latte with extra shot. Well worth the walk this morning through Skanky McJank's neighborhood...
author: Jimmy J.

description: Had to see this place before I left... what a beautiful open space. This is a spot you'd see in the pages of Architectural Digest with the large open windows, accessible lofts and flowing skylights. The coffee was delicious and poured with artistic flare. The environment seemed fitting for a eco-green planning meeting. It wasn't a place to curl up with a book, or to re-acquaint with an old friend, but catered to a business crowd with its industrial feel and modern looks. Had to see the hype, it's worth stopping in.
author: Naomi K.

description:
The building, atmosphere, and seating are amazing. It's a great place to come to have coffee with a friend or 2. 

Coffee was ok.

3 stars because THEY DON'T HAVE WIFI! wtf Sightglass! For the price of the coffee, your customers should have access to free wifi. Unfortunately, I won't be returning here to work :(
author: Sumeet S.

description:
Part my transformation into becoming a coffee junkie, I had to come here several times before giving it a fair review. And my conclusion is that this is the best coffee joint in San Francisco - only for the coffee. The drip coffee is hand crafted, single served, and packed full of flavors from the three main coffee regions. It's good to know that they are an equal opportunistic coffee house. Also, the expresso isn't your standard bland and bitter expresso. The flavors explode in your mouth like fireworks on the 4th of July!

People will talk about Blue Bottle, Four Barrel, or Ritual and even Philz but Sightglass is THE spot for high grade coffee in San Francisco.
author: Vien T.

description:
After hearing about many things about sight glass I bookmarked it and forgot about it. But while I was walking towards an event at the concourse exhibits center and happened walked across this beautiful coffee shop. I didnt have my morning coffee yet so coming across sightglass is a godsent. The coffee shop has nice big windows and has a openness to the bar and tables naturally by sky light. 

Looking at their coffee, it's been a while since I had gotten an espresso, so I ordered a macchiato. The macchiato is very delicious here, I love the rich dark and nutty notes the coffee's aroma produces.

The coffee shop here though quite large. It is two stories large while the second story has a baconow view of the ground floor.  Additinally, the noise level is surprisingly lower than expected. So it potentially be an excellent location to work on a few tasks while you enjoy your coffee.

-----
+ Pro: A very nice location.
- Con: Staff wasn't too helpful.
( ^,^) Overall: Best looking coffee bar I ever been to, yet!
author: James N.

description: I'm a coffee snob. I felt a little awkward coming here as I'm not part of the classic hipster clientele. But the coffee is probably the best in the city ( a big claim, I know).  I always get an iced mocha and it's always perfect. My go-to place when I want to treat myself with the perfect cup.
author: David R.

description:
Sightglass is a beautiful warehouse transformed into a coffee shop.  The industrial modern feel has SOMA written all over it.

The large tables on the second floor are perfect for studying.  They remind me of crafting and design tables used by architects, carpenters, and artists.  No wifi or power outlets makes for a much needed break from technology and social-media overindulgence.  

The food selection is on the expensive side (small pastries start at $4.00 and up).  The coffee selection is sparse but quality.  Passion and specialization, how life ought to be.

Let your inner artist shine.
author: Fei L.

description:
I have nothing to say that hasn't already been said. Just a gratuitous 5 star post so I can put this in a list. One of the best coffee roasters out of San Francisco.

Something unique I learned about through my buddy, or at least I think it's unique because I haven't bothered to read the menu the last 15 times I've been here, is the hooker mocha. Which isn't sweet. I assume it's also their regular, just mocha, but my buddy said, "no, it's the hooker mocha!" So I said ok, but either way it was delicious and woody. Like cocoa. Not sweet. I mean you would never catch me ordering a mocha right! Right! Pssh!
author: Allen P.

description: Pleasant environment with neat machinery to look at while enjoying a cold brew and almond cookie.
author: Trieu T.

description:
NO WI-FI! You'll have to steal from the Inn nearby. 

I love the open space and the quality control of how they make their coffee (measuring every drink they make).  On warm/hot days, I wouldn't recommend sitting upstairs, it gets stuffy and very hot. 

I ordered the latte and thought it was ok, but nothing that made me scream "OMG this is the best coffee ever!" I can't seem to see myself buying a SMALL cup of latte for over $3 and over $3 for just a cup of brewed coffee. 

The only reason why I came here is because Sightglass coffee is used in a lot of the local beers I have had. I might just stick to the beer with Sightglass coffee and not go for the coffee itself. 

Service was meh. I told the guy that this is my first time and all I got was a monotone "take your time".... dude, at least recommend something or explain how things are done at Sightglass.. it might have changed my "meh" experience here.
author: Erica T.

description:
Holy crap! Great pour-over coffee! So sweet and citrusy. 4 stars for their coffee! Just what I came to SF from LA for =)

However.....the not so good stuff:

Warning though...this place is like hipster central, if that's your thing. Staff wasn't friendly or very helpful when I mentioned that it was my first time there (So odd! Usually staff at other similar coffee places, like Ritual, will help guide you through their options as a first-timer!)

There was no large visible menu for customers to look at before reaching the counter/cashier. The only menu I could find was a tiny one mounted onto a mini clipboard sitting at the counter. So this would mean that a customer has to read through the entire menu and make their selection only when they have reached the counter...wouldn't this just create more pressure for customers to make their selections in a rush, especially when there is a line? -- Not such a great idea, me thinks.

Putting their roasting equipment and bags of beans on display throughout the floor of the store is pretty novel, but it makes the lay out of the store VERY confusing imho. For instance, after picking up my coffee from the counter, it was not clear to me where to get a lid for my cup and a napkin, and ended up having to ask the staff. Turns out the table with creamer, sugar, lids, and napkins was all the way in the back corner of the store...OKAY. Why not put it closer to where you pick up your drink?? Ever heard of efficiency? (Btw, they don't offer sleeves for the cups, so careful with the piping hot drinks!!)

Tiny cup of pour over coffee, though delicious, was very expensive at $4.25. I could probably get 2x the volume at Philz at that price and with MUCH MUCH better service!
author: Michelle L.

description: Space is gorgeous! Open, well-lit with natural light pouring in from every angle. Wood, steel, concrete, perfect combo! Now on to coffee... Macchiato perfectly sweet, balenced. Had a Honduras on Pour Over which was smooth, buttery, clean. 5 stars hands down!
author: Julia P.

description: Quelqu'un a demandé où se trouvait le coffee shop le plus impressionnant des Etats-Unis ? Bah voilà, c'est à San Francisco, dans le quartier industriel gentrifiant de SoMa !  Pour la parenthèse, SoMa, c'est l'acronyme trendy pour South Market, ou devrais-je dire l'invention des développeurs immobiliers pour donner un côté super appealing à un quartier qui ne l'était pas autrefois. "Vous voulez visiter notre loft pour artiste à 1 million de dollars dans SoMa ?" "SoMa c'est quoi ça ?" "Beh South Market, enfin voyons, le quartier où tout le monde veut être". NY a SoHo, NoHo, NoLita, TriBeCa, BoCoCa,... bah SF a désormais SoMa.  Si vous déambulez dans ce quartier où vous risquez bien de ne croiser désormais que barbus tatoués sur vélo vintage à pignon fixe, développeurs geeks avec un t-shirt Sonic ou designers trendy-grunge qui errent en attendant le prochain vernissage d'une gallerie d'art planquée entre deux entrepôts vides, un passage à SightGlass s'impose absolument, que vous aimiez la café ou pas, c'est une obligation !  Tout simplement parce que le lieu est absolument magnifique et réellement impressionnant. Déjà rien qu'en arrivant devant, les larges baies vitrées avec laptopeurs sur tabourets apparents de l'autre côté et le sas d'entrée avec vélos accrochés aux murs donnent le ton. Ca va être assez hipster...  Ensuite, on entre et on se prend direct l'énorme machine de torréfaction, dans le champ de vision, entourée de sacs de grains verts, de torréfacteurs à l'oeuvre et de chaises hautes qui l'entourent, au cas où vous voudriez vous y asseoir pour admirer le travail. Le décor est planté : on sait où on est !  On découvre alors le reste de l'espace : un immense entrepôt, aux très hauts plafonds, complètement transformé, mais qui a su garder l'esprit d'origine, tout en faisant la part belle au bois et au métal, et en atteignant ainsi un parfait équilibre entre atelier de torréfaction et coffee shop où l'on vient prendre sa fika californienne. (Sa fikalifornienne ?). Cosy et urbain à la fois. Un vrai tour de force en termes de design et d'ambiance.  Le coffee bar central circulaire est ergonomique, le service ultra friendly, les baristas connaissent leur job, et les pâtisseries sont au top, délivrées par quelques artisans locaux sélectionnés avec soin. Le kouign-amman et le croissant aux pistaches sont juste parfaits. Mais les muffins ne sont pas en reste non plus.  Vous pourrez ensuite siroter votre petit noir (ou votre gros latte) à l'étage-mezzanine, sur l'une des tables communes ou "au balcon" afin d'avoir une vue plongeante sur le bâtiment. Cette deuxième option est largement recommandée vu le caractère exceptionnel du lieu. Autant vous imprégner de l'esprit et de l'espace...  Seul bémol : pas de wifi. Nouvelle trend répandue à San Francisco. Officiellement pour que les gens socialisent. Officieusement sans doute pour que vous ne passiez pas là 4h sur votre laptop avec un espresso.   De passage à San Francisco, bien sûr il y a le Golden Gate, les tramways, Nob Hill,...  Mais question visites, SightGlass devrait également être sur la liste. Parce qu'il faut profiter de l'occasion pour voir ce qui peut se faire en termes de transformation d'espace, de réappropriation de lieux abandonnés, de revitalisation de quartiers industriels... Et de coffee shops hallucinants, tout simplement.
author: Xavier P.

description:
Let me summarize:

Ritual is better than Four Barrel is better than Blue bottle is better than Sightglass

Sorry, Sightglass. At least Blue Bottle is humble enough to admit they can't compete with Ritual for quality. You will get a decent cup and your caffeine high here. A-Ok.

Also, my new pet peeve is how when I ask "What is your lightest roast?" they always reply "Well all our coffees are light-ish roast..." because what I am essentially asking them is what their highest quality/freshest beans are and they're not willing to admit they only do mediocrity.
author: A T.

description:
some really good coffee. their latte is to die for. cap not as good as the other coffee shops. but a really cool place to go to and hangout and drink some really good a flavored coffee. not sure what kind of beans they use but they smell awesome. Definitely one of the top coffee shops to try in SF and i would put it up there with blue bottle and philz. it would have been a 5 star if their cap was good. 

The location is not the best, kinda looks shady, but its the city what can you do. but its a nice place to get together with friends and engage in the art of conversation. two thumbs up to this place.
author: Anuj C.

description: Regular coffee is $4 but they brew each cup and I love the open space
author: Magda G.

description:
A wonderful space - open, bright, and welcoming.
Got an almond milk latte, it was delicious.
My friend got a mocha - it was also very good. They don't add sugar to it though, so if you want a sweet mocha you'll have to add the sugar yourself.
author: Ariana L.

description: Even if you don't like coffee, the atmosphere alone is reason enough to come here. The coffee is also very good and the baked goods are killer (however they don't make them in house). I took off 1 star though since the place is slightly pretentious and overpriced.
author: J A.

description:
Sight Glass is an experience. Upon walking in I was immediately impressed with the overall vibe and decor. I'm a huge fan of rustic contemporary, and they achieved it really well. It's also very spacious and has a lot of natural light. The music selection is also a great addition, they even use an actual record player! On top of the visual aesthetic, the coffee products are great too. 
I could hangout here all day, what an inspiring place.
author: Madi G.

description:
Pros: good coffee and pastries excellent window space offering tons of natural light
Two clean restrooms and excellent eclectic 70s rock music played at a modest volume ,lots of places to sit ,friendly baristas  , cool bike rack in vestibule
In house roaster usually chugging away continuously in morning 

Cons: expensive coffee, seats are very cool and modern (mostly bar type seating) but uncomfortable for lounging for a long time as feet need to rest on bar under
author: W M.

description:
Nothing makes me feel more like an outsider than when I visit a San Francisco café. it was ever more so evident at Sightglass.
 
I don't ask much from visiting a coffee shop. All I want is a good cup of coffee, great service, and a place to sit down. This place delivers a mediocre stance on all but one count. 
 
The first thing I felt when entering Sightglass was that I didn't belong. Upon entering the door, there were bikes beautifully hanging against the wall and when you enter the building, it has an industrial look. There are two floors, filled to the brim with a bunch of cool looking folks - which I am not. It looked like a movie scene, no joke, it didn't seem real to me.
 
I shook my feelings aside and proceeded to buy my boyfriend, his friend, and myself a few cups of coffee. The server was very quip, didn't find my light/ humorous nature appealing, and wasn't very welcoming. I don't blame him, this was probably what their clientele wants. So I paid and said, "thank you" and he just looked at me, giving me that look that he was done with me.
 
Cool. I move on and continued my conversation with my boyfriend's friend. The barista looked (apparently no talking is allowed at this joint, they've got specific stare downs on lock) at us to inform us our drinks were ready. I like the thoughtfulness nature of adding a cup of water on the side for espresso orders but my coffee was less than memorable.
 
We proceeded to go upstairs to drink our drinks and carry a conversation. That is one thing this place excels, room to talk and sit. The big tables are on rollers and you can sit by the railing to look at the peons below (sarcasm font).
 
Overall - I felt that this place is average, in my book. It made me miss my own coffee shop, which doesn't exude pretentiousness. My coffee shop is where the owner knows you, the baristas are nothing but warm and cheerful, and the coffee is delicious. Home is where the heart is.
author: Elsvette B.

description:
So happy to be working nearby.

To note:
Yes, they have Iced Coffee.
They only  have Almond Milk.
author: Jane N.

description:
Usually I'm not a big fan of hipster coffee dives, but Sightglass won me over for three reasons:

1) The coffee
2) The hard-to-find coffee
3) Did I mention the coffee?

Gimmicks like the huge coffee roaster in the middle of the shop and pay by ipad swivel aside, the kangunu coffee I tried and later purchased to brew at home was quite spectacular.  True to it's description, the coffee was fruity and unlike most coffees, was roasted so there was no sense of coffee "bitterness" at the end.  The bean was not at all oily, and really after drinking a cup, I found that i could smell the fruity aroma pretty much for the rest of the day.  Coffee perfume? check.  No Starbucks "baristas" here.  The folks clearly know how to brew a cup of coffee.  The staff weren't snobs about it either - they were quite nice.  

Although the industrial decor and randomness of the seating/standing areas might leave you wandering the first time you are here, I think it's rather intentional - milling about was rather.... encouraged.  Warning, though, the shop always seemed busy.  It took quite an effort for me an my chums to find a few chairs.

P.S. as of 2/10/13, their website is down.  Please fix so I can buy more coffee.
author: Yan W.

description:
Walked here about 2 miles from my grandparents' house. This is my second time to visit here. First was a Piccino Valrhona chocolate chip cookie and this time a Latte $4. Waited a long line but the staff were pretty quick and friendly. I like the atmosphere here.  I love the decor best with large windows and unfinished wood.  The set up is quite nice, a lot of seating downstairs and upstairs. I can look out towards the street from the seat on the second floor. 

About my drink - Latte: the taste so sweet - creamy, buttery and non-bitter.  Everything's ok.

The only thing I don't like here is no-wifi. I wish they could offer Wifi. 

Overall, Sightglass Coffee is a great place to come. I gave it four stars. If you're near here, stop by and check out.
author: Kelvin S.

description: Some legitimate caffeination that kept me wired for a good couple of hours. It's a bit pricey, but I guess it was nice and made me feel kind of fancy :)
author: Lindsay H.

description: Sad being a barista that these people don't really give a crap about the coffee they serve. Their Instagram page is really glamorized because they really don't do a great job catering to the customer's need. I won't recommend coming here
author: Britni B.

description:
Date & Time:  Monday December 21, 2009 @ 10:30am
Crowd:  Hipsters
Vibe:  Chill
Decor:  Industrial Coffee Stand & Bench in Glass Shop
Service:  Attractive Barista
Imbibe:  Malted Chocolate Mocha & 1950 Blend(70% Rwanda, 30%  Ethiopia & Malted Milk Chocolate)
Total:  $7
author: Genevieve Y.

description:
(See pics)

Review #1080.

Very very spacious coffee house. High wooden ceiling with sunlight roof and a second floor. Tall communal tables and high chairs with are apart enough to have lots of your own moving room and privacy.

The LP playing gives a nostalgic melody and memory filled lyrics in an art gallery  feel cafe.

Sightglass coffee is more San Francisco style, laid back and while with caffeine that gives you the jolt you desire, it's gentle and not punchy. The cafe also has a good selection of pastries though I had not tried it. However, the pastries, at least on the day that I visited, were out in the open and not covered. I saw 2 flies hovering over and landed here and there. Hopefully they would be covered next time.
author: T L.

description: There is no difference between their coffee and the coffee at Blue Bottle or Fly Wheel. They all taste the same. It's all a poor substitute for Philz. I didn't understand the hype. Much much much better than Peet's or Starbucks, I'll give them that. When I went in I found the staff to be friendly and in no way rude or indifferent, as some reviewers have stated. However, their hiring pool/demographic mirrors Whole Foods, exactly. No WIFI, but a great place to waste hours if they did, probably the reason they don't.
author: Richard V.

description:
I had walked by this place many times on my way to work and wanted to check it out, so I stopped in to work on some homework yesterday afternoon.  I didn't like it and probably won't be back.  The guy who took my order was very nice, the coffee tasted good, and they have bike parking in the foyer, those were the good things.  It was also very clean.

I ordered an iced decaf, which cost $4.35 (seems like a lot for simple coffee), they didn't have simple syrup, and only had one unlabeled dairy creamer out that I think gave me a pretty harsh stomach ache later.  The coffee tasted good, and it's all hand poured right there, so I guess it's pretty hip and minimalist and that's what people like?  

If you don't mind waiting 10 minutes or more for your coffee to be hand poured, and you don't need wifi (they don't have it), and you don't need an outlet to plug anything into (the guy next to me said the staff said there weren't any at all), then maybe this place will be fine for you, but I was very disappointed.  

It was also very loud in there, but I was there at about 4:00 so maybe that's a busy time (that beautiful ambiance everyone swoons over in these reviews is not the best for dimming sounds, and just a sidenote from my professional perspective, those sandblasted virgin wood beams are not an environmentally friendly design choice).  And a server scooped up my cup into a dirty dish bin without asking before I was finished.
author: Sophie C.

description:
It was a hot, hot Sunday afternoon and I was out with my best pal killing some time before going to the kinky workshop around the corner. We stopped by Sighthouse Coffee. I was amused by the unbridled hipster atmosphere, enthusiasm, and attitude of Sighthouse. A plethora of bikes adorning the wall to the left, huge coffee roasters to the right, and enough gleaming woodwork to choke a horse. It smelled great. We were chided in no short order by a plaid shirt clad youngster about iced tea, soy milk, and straws. There is no tea, only coffee, cider, and tap water. There is no soy milk, but almond milk. No straws. Damn it.

They had marvelous gluten free almond cake, luscious pistachio croissant, and delicious iced latte with almond milk, which was served in a mash-up between a mason jar and a beer mug. The place was busy, including several families with well-behaved children, although I don't know what the kids were guzzling; I hope it wasn't coffee. We could not stop giggling.  I recommend the joint.
author: Avery C.

description: Great coffee.  Only whole milk or one of the fake-milk options - whole milk is fine for an indulgence but I like to have a latte every day so that makes this place a place I can't visit on the regular.  The location/staff is so hipster it hurts.  Pretty decent pastries, but coffee is the star here - worth a visit if you're nearby and are a coffee fan.
author: Jeanie C.

description:
So during my short stay in San Fran, I'm pretty sure I visited all of the Sightglass locations. It's clear that this is the go-to coffee option for the city and I enjoyed every cup at every venue. 

This particular spot is large and airy, offering more seating than some of the others and no one is sitting elbow-to-elbow. 

There's additional seating upstairs in a mezzanine level, allowing you to peer down and watch the action below. 

I found the surrounding area a bit daunting to walk through and somewhat dicey, so stepping into Sightglass was a lovely reprieve and a great place to kick back without a care in the world.
author: Mel P.

description:
This is one of those places you go specifically to enjoy a coffee. Or because it smells like heaven since they roast their beans out in the open. Or because it is probably the most photogenic coffee shop in San Francisco.

PROs: The cappuccino is delicious in its own right (no sugar needed), and the pour-over coffee will have you turning into a coffee snob. If I just want to go somewhere and drink coffee in an actual mug, I stop in for a "quick cup", which is also flavorful enough to drink sans cream and sugar. The iced coffee is served in jar and really good with almond milk, too - though I can't get over how good the espresso tastes, so I usually still go cappuccino.

CONs: Many would consider it a con that there is no wifi. That's a choice they made, probably to make it more of a social place. Also, it is a bit more expensive (seems deserved), and it sure can take a long time to get your drink if it's anything but a "quick cup." Don't go here if you are in a rush. I want to say the longest I've waited is 20 minutes, which seemed pretty long for an outlier - but no customers seem to mind. I guess it's understood that they make their drinks in a precise, time-intensive way... so you do get quality for the wait. Usually it's quicker, like 3-5 minutes.

The only other con is that I wish their cappuccinos were a little bigger!
author: Jeremy M.

description:
Even though I'm pretty new to the coffee scene in the bay area, Sightglass's coffee is pretty off the chart. The story is pretty spacious but does NOT have Wifi or wall plugs, so not so great to get work done here (why I put 4/5 stars honestly but really a 4.5 stars place). 

I don't need to keep repeating what other people have raved about their coffee: its freaking awesome. Lots of flavors, and a great selection of beans. I'm not a latte guy so I only get black coffee - and their black coffee is definitely worth the money.
author: Victor C.

description: This coffee shop has an industrial feel. Not the coziest, but there's lots of space and seating. Staff was friendly and laid back. I liked my latte, so I'd come back again.
author: Adrianna A.

description:
Coffees are small, but i guess since it is a gourmet shop so they can get away with it.

Big, open warehouse/loft atmosphere buzzing with hipsters.
author: chris f.

description:
Sightglass Coffee is stunning as a venue. With it's big lofted ceilings and minimalistic interior it brings an edge to San Francisco coffee shops that you don't find at many of your everyday cafes. The coffee is superb and it's evident that coffee is a carefully skilled craft for those that work at and own Sightglass. The vintage coffee roaster which proudly sits in Sightglass's lobby is a clear testimony of the passion behind every cup that is served here.

While I would definitely recommend Sightglass as a destination spot for coffee lovers, if you're looking for a more cozy place to catch up with someone - there are definitely warmer spots and if you enjoy your tea and hot pastries - then Sightglass is not your spot.

It's all about the bean here.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description:
I've never seen any business in the world not willing to accomodate a friendly request of a customer.
After being there few times, I asked them to make an espresso shorter than the regular. I first got told was impossible. Then I got asked what ratio of the regular quantity.
After few minutes I was waiting another guy came to me (maybe the manager?) telling me that they like to do things with their framework and they couldn't accomodate my request. 
The guy kept giving me a fake smile pretending to be friendly, but still I couldn't get my $3.25 (+ taxes) espresso the way I like.
I hope they realized I just asked to stop the coffee machine few seconds earlier than they usually do. I don't think that as a crazy request, it's actually a pretty common request for an espresso coffee. 
What's the meaning of weighting the coffee powder with the scale if then your coffee tastes pretty bad? What's the meaning of the friendly fake smile if you basically slam the door in front of a that easy request?
author: Enrico B.

description:
Sightglass is making some excellent coffee these days. When they first opened I was a little skeptical. Their beans were pricy and maybe their space was a copy of Four Barrel. I don't feel that way anymore. They are top quality. 

Brought my in-laws to the cafe recently and Sightglass did me proud. 
Delicious clean, clear, bright pour-over drip coffee carefully made in Hario V60 drippers. 
The cafe space is quite impressive, centered on a vintage Probat roaster. 

Their beans are very good - tastefully roasted - a variety of single origins and a couple blends. Rainbow Grocery sells them a little cheaper and even some in bulk. 

Chez Panisse Cafe switched from using Blue Bottle to Sightglass coffee this past year. They serve the Banner Dark blend, which, though not literally dark, is exceptional. After an agonizing wait, Sightglass is finally selling this blend to the public. I've got a bag of it right here in my kitchen!
author: RK W.

description:
I really enjoyed my experience at Sightglass coffee.  Right off the bat, the place is just very visually appealing - the tall ceilings and the 2nd level allow for lots of light coming in (but does make the place a bit warm - almost bordering on uncomfortably so).  

I am a huge fan of Blue Bottle Coffee and my husband had told me this was some next level stuff so I was super excited to try it out.  The latte was indeed excellent, and the lovely barista was so friendly that I could hardly believe that I was getting coffee at a much-loved hipster joint.  However, I will say that I still prefer the latte at BB - it somehow just seems a touch smoother.  The difference is minimal though, and I would never turn down the opportunity to have a latte from Sightglass.  

We also bought a bag of the espresso beans for our home setup - my husband is a huge coffee fan and we have an espresso machine at home - but we haven't tried them yet.  I'll be sure and update when we do.  

Overall great ambience and a fabulous experience.  I'm looking forward to coming back sooner rather than later!
author: Erika B.

description: Pop quiz: how many hipster baristas does it take to forget about your order as they meander around talking to one another without acknowledging you all the while a whole bunch of other customers who came in after you got their drinks, finished it and got in their Uber home to the Marina?? Answer: Six freaking baristas! Welcome to sightglass! That summed up my experience. Also no wifi no outlet hookup make this place less than perfect. Nice building tho..
author: Clint S.

description: Awesome space (though it can get pretty hot upstairs).  From East Coast here and it's hard not to mention the difference in coffee culture.  The staff/baristas are so much friendlier and down to earth.  Coffee, people, atmosphere all five stars at Sightglass.  One star knocked off for lack of wifi.
author: Andrew K.

description: Pricy but incredibly good. Some of the best coffee in the area,  and anice space to boot. Great place to watch people stare blankly into their MacBook pros or talk way too loudly about their startup
author: Mark D.

description: I really enjoyed my coffee experience at this place. And it is 'cause of 3 reasons: * the place/ its atmosphere is really nice and welcoming; * the shop is filled with a pleasantly strong aroma of coffee (they roast the coffee right there at the shop); * the latte I had was excellent. I wanna go there again! I am sure I will :)
author: Sandra K.

description: Let me just start off by saying that I'm not a coffee snob in the slightest but I wanted to try out a Sightglass because I heard good things about it and I love trying out new coffee shops. The upstairs seating is pretty nice and this place is extremely roomy with a warehouse feel. Like so much space for SF. I liked the coffee I got, the 2 stars are for the service. My friend asked the barista ringing us up what  she would recommend and she just seemed really annoyed and was like "uhh well what do you like?" Super helpful ....
author: Kathlena H.

description: Their Affogato Bar is legit. Got the Blood Orange Olive Oil ice cream with the Kenya. Unforgettable. I mean, have you ever said that about an affogato before? Never, right? This one was truly special. What are you still reading this review for? Go get one!
author: Diana Y.

description: I was blown away by this coffeehouse! There is such a wide variety of roasted coffee to choose from and I had to splurge in two kinda which were both amazing. I also got an iced vanilla cold brew that made the visit even better. This venue is very large and though consistently busy, has a lot of seating if you're looking to get stuff done over a great cup of coffee.
author: Charlotte A.

description:
I'm not a coffee drinker so I ended up getting hot cider instead. My friend said that the CEO of Twitter and Square invested in this coffee shop. It must be the reason why so many tech people are here working on their laptops. I've heard great things about their coffee. The hot cider was quite tasty as well.

This is a good place to catch up with an old friend. I like the openness and light this location gets.

Definitely well worth seeking out.
author: Amy J.

description: Coffee was good but nothing extraordinary and if you're hungry they have pastries available from the infamous B. Patisserie in their pastry case. Baristas are friendly and chatty. Ambience is hipster and clean, and upstairs there's an affogato bar with plenty of seats. This place is cool to sit and chat with a friend over coffee or read a book, but beyond that it is not very technology friendly. No wifi and no outlets. My friend said the metal seats were uncomfortable for him to sit in after a while.
author: Elissa S.

description: This place was awesome! I'm a big fan of the industrial look, but with some modern design chic-ness thrown in (does that make sense?), and this place nailed it. It had a nice atmosphere that's ideal for sitting around and chatting or getting some work done. It was busy without feeling crowded or overwhelming. The food/drink options are limited, but the ones they do have are great, especially the iced coffee IMO.
author: Bianca C.

description:
This girl always needs a cup of coffee on a weekend morning.
I went in expecting a crowded, stand-to-drink type of cafe (cough, Blue Bottle) but was delightfully surprised by the quiet ambience and beautifully engineered modern architecture. 

I like a cup of good coffee but I am not one of those coffee snobs who hate on Starbucks (I still like Starbucks latte..). Coffee wasn't mind-blowing or anything but the atmosphere was. I can stay inside this beautiful loft all day with a book or an old friend. 

Few things I loved:
1. Open concept bar that reminded me of the most memorable coffee house/bar I went to in Germany

2. Quiet friends, locals, couples sitting around a giant wooden table 

3. Friendly baristas with intriguing European accents

4. Plenty of space to layout your books for studying or a group to hangout and talk for hours

Overall, I'd give this place a five and return again with more time to read on a Sunday morning.
author: Jiwon M.

description:
This place is definitely a super awesome latte experience.

I didn't really expect it when the bf insisted we come here because we're such huge coffee nerds. It's not in an area you'd usually find coffee at and most of it is very industrial looking. The place, then, comes as no surprise that it is located in a huge warehouse. It appears they usually have an upstairs, but it was closed when we went. 

They only do lattes and coffee hot, not cold so that's a good FYI for those looking for a cold refresher. I love the barebones, minimalistic decor inside as well as all the wooden details and their few seats at the bar / by the window. They have a simple menu and friendly baristas. They even use iPads to process your card payments! 

With that said, you do pay a premium for all this good coffee and cool atmosphere. A latte comes in at a whooping $6.
author: Lorrie M.

description:
Huge space, tiny cup. 

Big empty room with a nice wood decor, cool record player and uneven floor.

But... $4.50 for a 10 oz cup of coffee?! That upsets me. I guess they have to pay for the square footage somehow.

Nothing but whole milk? Girl I am trying to lose weight! This isn't helping.

It's great to see a fancy coffee shop pop up on this side of Folsom, but the prices irk me a bit. I'll reevaluate if/when they furnish the loft area. Until then, I'm sticking with Brainwash.
author: Nick K.

description:
Awesome place with great coffee, but there are people upstairs sawing banging and hammering with power tools. We could not have a conversation or get anything done and had to leave.

When I complained to the manager she didn't seem to care and only offered, "that  they would be building for a while but it would be awesome when they were done..." Could not be bothered to apologize, kind of disappointing, I took my business meetings and clients elsewhere.

 Nice customer service

Avoid until the work is done!
author: Dan S.

description: This place has amazing coffee. They roast their own and you can taste the quality. I really love the architecture of the building as well. It is absolutely beautiful!
author: Joy S.

description:
I really don't understand why this place is so popular when it serves such lousy coffee:

1. Coffee to acidic.
2. Cups too small.
3. They don't show pricing until you're at the counter.
4. Smarmy attitude from staff.

The ambiance and location are cool, it gives off a nice vibe inside- I think this is why people go here. But serves mediocre if not bad coffee. 

SKIP IT
author: M P.

description:
Very cool interior. Pretty good coffee. 

Why 2 stars? I tried smiling at the barista taking my order, but I don't think she knew how to smile back. I took about 2 seconds to look at their menu and I felt like I was committing a crime of some sort. I get that you take your coffee very seriously, believe me I do too, but no need to be cold and pretentious. 

The whole vibe there was pretty cold and pretentious as well. I felt plenty of eyes seeping into my soul as I pulled out my laptop and book to get some studying done. Sorry I'm not sorry that I don't have a permanent frown on my face.

If you're looking for a warm and welcoming place, don't go here. If you want a place for decent coffee and don't really care about people being friendly, you've got a winner.
author: Chloe G.

description: When I lived in San Francisco, I used to go to Sight Glass all the time. hands down, the most amazing coffee shop ever! The ambiance, coffee, and the experience is a notch above the rest. I live in East Bay now and I don't get to go as regularly as before. I have been meaning to give them a 5 star Yelp review for a while. Finally got around to it today. If you haven't been there, you are missing out!
author: Parmis M.

description: I really have no idea how this place has 4 stars.  I went in there and all I saw are a bunch of obnoxious baristas.  Is this caused by their surroundings?  Being in San Francisco?  Coffee is not exceptional enough for me to come back to this place nor can I actually recommend this to anyone.  I'm going to assume the 4 stars is merely because of the trend.  The interior is modern and very cozy.  Is the owner/manager promoting this attitude?  There's too many other coffee shops, this isn't worth another look for me.  No thank you.
author: Paige J.

description:
Favorite mocha in the city. The space is huge and gorgeous! Blew me away and brought out the coffee groupie in me. Nicest baristas who don't mind if you want your drink tweaked a bit.

They have soy & whole milk or half and half. Ordered a soy mocha, and it was strong in both espresso and chocolate. They use softened unsweetened dark chocolate which is more like a paste. I added about a teaspoon of raw sugar, and it was perfect. 

Piccino pastries in the case. Fattie cups. They also have decaf. Great service. Love.
author: Catherine N.

description:
Thoroughly enjoyed my perfectly crafted HOT latte, though I was fairly put off by the service of the cashier. 

Attempted to order an ICED latte but was quickly rejected as the cashier commented on how they didn't have ice and only served classic coffee. Ok, how is there no ice? Whatever, I order a "classic" HOT latte then as she literally stands there and judges me for ordering it iced. 

After I realized my friend had ordered an iced pour over, so in fact they DO have ice they just don't do ICED lattes? Ok whatevs, just don't tell me you don't have any ice and then judge me.
author: Julia C.

description: Best coffee place ever. Very good coffee,nice ambiance. Will be back. As many times as possible.
author: Michel N.

description:
One of the prettiest cafes I've ever been inside. 

Gorgeous. 

But while the decor is seven stars. The service, drinks, and prices are very average for SFO. 

Go, take pictures, have a drink, but if I'm buying beans, I'm headed to Four Barrel, Wrecking Ball, or Ritual.
author: Jeremy M.

description:
This is the new mission store that recently. Opened. Great coffee. Pastries are fantastic. Wonder where they buy them from. 
Smaller and cozier than 7th location. 
But guys please check your bathrooms. No paper towel? No toilet paper? No seat covers?
author: Marco M.

description:
What a beautiful space to enjoy a delicious cup of coffee.  Yes - it's a bit pretentious when you walk in, and there's no wi-fi, but I quickly forgot about those things after I got my perfect latte and settled on a balcony seat upstairs.  The design & layout of this place is unlike any other coffee shop I've been to - I feel like I could just sit, relax, and chat with friends for hours.   
 
Not really in a central location but the quality of the coffee & the atmosphere will definitely bring me back.
author: Iris K.

description: Don't come here expecting to read your Flipboard and have a coffee. No wifi. Great space and friendly people, but fail on productivity. #ultralame  Oh, and a 4oz latte with a little midget finger handle will set you back $4. Blow me.
author: Chris N.

description:
I'm lucky enough to say that Sightglass is my go-to local coffee stop on the way to/from work in SOMA. 

The space itself is very modern with an open atmosphere; I love the mixture of textiles: wood, metal, plants all with very big and open windows. I am also mesmerized (no matter how many times I've seen it) by the giant coffee bean roaster that runs while you enjoy your coffee/meal or wait in line. This could just be the coffee nerd in me, but I appreciate this reminder that Sightglass roasts the beans they use to make your coffee in-house and love the opportunity to get to see the process happen.

That being said, their coffee is always fresh, fresh, fresh. My usual order is a "quick cup" (aka "drip" coffee that is already prepared and ready to be poured, rather than selecting a "brewed coffee" from their rotating menu and having it prepared fresh in the pour-over fashion). I enjoy the simplicity of their menu, void of any coffee-tainting sugary syrups, caramels, chocolate curls, etc. Again, it could just be the nerd in me that enjoys just a straight-up cup of coffee without all the frills and bows. One "quick cup" keeps me going all day; it's a strong as it is fresh! Huuuuuuge plus that they don't charge a debit fee! So rare in the City!

My only reason for not giving this place 5 stars is the "holier than thou" attitude that exudes from most of their super hip baristas. I always ask if I can top my coffee off with some cold almond milk, but 8 times out of 10 I am completely ignored by the barista for a good 3-4 minutes. Not even a look in my direction. Having been a barista before, I totally understand how busy it gets (especially for the person on bar), but I also understand how annoying a "hoverer" can be at the handoff station. Don't make me be that guy, I don't want to be that guy!! Of course, there are a select few baristas who remember me and are kind enough to hand me the almond milk, no questions asked, or a couple who I've had nice chit chat with. But the majority are clearly too cool for little old me. 

Overall, I definitely don't mind a but of 'tude in exchange for an excellent cup of coffee.
author: Michelle P.

description:
Over the years, Sightglass' location on 7th street always calls me back every time I'm in the city. The vibe in here is perfect for drinking a cup of coffee and getting your mind right.

Espresso over ice, make it a double and head upstairs to enjoy the drafting style desks and openess of the location.
author: Mike M.

description: Come here for coffee. Incredible coffee, incredible cold press, and incredible staff. Everything is bigger in sight glass. There is plenty of seating. I am impressed with all that this place has to offer. What it lacks in a variety of styles of coffee it makes up and goes beyond with its quality. This place is great.
author: Gregory V.

description: Cool location that is wide open with lots of natural sun light. It's a requirement that if you work there you must have some tattoos or impressive facial hair. I believe those are the marks of a true barista. Pretty straightforward menu, nothing really fancy drink wise. However the beans they roast are pretty awesome, probably gathered from the peaks of Kilimanjaro or Olympus. Best thing to do is grab a cup of Joe and go upstairs and people watch.
author: C W.

description: I think i need to go back and try pour over or straight espresso. My cappuccino tasted like a weak latte.
author: Amy O.

description: The coffee here is amazing, but I come for the atmosphere. I love the giant tables upstairs and the staff is great. I give four stars because it's a bit overpriced and there is now wifi, which can make getting work done very difficult.
author: Lauren O.

description:
Oh wow!!!  Does this place really exist?  One star for amazing roasted coffee on site!  One star for amazing friendly service! One Star for the fact that the cashiers ironic mustache didn't even annoy me! One star for awesome atmosphere and finally another star for originality and conscious employees.  

So we are sitting upstairs and I notice they have this white plastic device next to the sink and it looked really sleek and cool.  Wondering what it was I asked a guy working here what it was and he said it was a soda stream device.   Keeping up with world politics and issues I know they are manufactured in the apartheid Zionist occupied West Bank.  Bringing that up he assured me they will get rid of it.  

So, not only are their practices conscious but the service is cool and diligent.  I wish they had one of these at home in LA.  I had a pleasurable and wonderful time here.  My only complaint is that their cappuccino has little foam and is more like a latè.   They use great organic whole milk and an awesome almond milk I need to get next time.  This place is phenomenal! Must check out for anyone visiting SF or hanging in the bay.
author: ShakaZulu S.

description:
Extremely slow service - don't come here unless you have 10-15 min to wait for a coffee. I just saw someone tell the barista to remove their order because they had to get going after waiting for so long. I normally rate places solely on food quality and hardly ever write reviews, but the service was just so bad that I wanted to warn people in a rush not to make a mistake.

Some of the people working there make no effort to speed up the process, even when the line gets long. Perhaps this makes for the quality but it didn't seem necessary. Not normally a problem but it added a LOT of time to my wait. 

That being said, the pastries are good and the coffee is good (as long as you prefer a more bitter taste). I do prefer four barrel and blue bottle, however.
author: Abbie K.

description: One of my favorite spots in town ... The first thing i can think of is this place hot cappuccino with my pistachio croissant ... Best place for coffee
author: Naene T.

description: I am from Santa Barbara. So to find a coffee house like this is totally rad.  Great coffee and super cool interiors.
author: Steven S.

description:
After eating lunch at a restaurant with no outward-facing sign, I walked around the corner to grab a cup of coffee and loiter. Sightglass is exactly what you might expect from a San Francisco coffee house - minimalist design, iPads as registers, and pour-over coffee as the trend of the moment. But it also brought along with it an adept understanding of the bean, so I didn't mind. And while I got my cappuccino in a to-go cup when I explicitly asked for one "here", I made up for it in the amount of time I leeched their wifi.

"Life, uh, finds a way." - Dr. Ian Malcolm
author: Brad S.

description: Drip coffee that's naturally sweet, amazingly prices, and in a venue that feels open and inspiring for meet ups with friends. Do not bring your laptop- it would ruin the atmosphere. Bring a book or an old friend instead.
author: Regina D.

description: I just love the setting... perfect for work and hang out, super busy on weekdays.. the only downside is that there's  no wifi  :(
author: Alexia L.

description:
The place is cool. It is what I picture in my mind of "hipster coffee boutiques at their best". I really appreciated that their staff (Brian - my barista - in particular) knew their stuff. When paying $5 for a cup of coffee, I find value in information, and this place gave me everything and more. 

A hidden gem, which is making me laugh as I type, is the soap they offer outside their bathrooms. Wow it smells good. 

As for my beverage, I had the Guji, Yetatebe, Ethiopia slow brew and it satisfied the palate and would recommend it. I did not taste much of the Lemon curd, but the coconut flavors came through for me. 

Last, the place is biker friendly so hop on the fixie and get Caffeinated. 

Cheers!
author: Michael T.

description:
This coffeehouse has to be the most unique, attractive, and enjoyable one that I've visited anywhere. The creativity behind the apparent dual function of warehouse and coffeehouse is awe-inspiring! I did a search for 'coffee roaster' and came across Sightglass...and what's one of the first things you see when you walk in? Their roasting operation surrounded by burlap sacks of coffee bean   s and other containers. The best way to describe it: the equivalent of a microbrewery where you can sit around the beautiful stainless steel containers having the brew that's surely in one of them. Congrats on the concept SF...keep this place open!

Like:
Their cold brew - Vanilla bean...wow! 

Wish:
Something like this could survive in the Inland Empire!
author: Hector M.

description:
Love love love the industrial look inside and the coffee beans are great. Definitely high quality and incredibly aromatic. I love that they roast their own beans in shop! They offer some more acidic roasts which I enjoy. 

No wifi but I came here with a friend and we spent a couple hours buzzed on coffee and good conversation. Plenty of seating available but I like going upstairs so I can watch the baristas work from above. Great place and I'm looking forward to my next visit!
author: Winnie T.

description:
Two stars for the actual building. Beautiful layout, very picturesque. 

Everything else was awful. I stood with my friend for 5 minutes near the counter (there was no line), then even walked up to the counter and stood there while the staff just stared blankly or even avoided eye contact. No one said hello, no smiles, just cold hipster stares through thick rimmed glasses... probably planning their next selfie. We walked out. From what I've heard, the coffee is subpar anyway. I'll stick to four barrel, thanks (for nothing)!
author: Kait A.

description: You can never go wrong coming here. First time my gf and I came here, she said latte have her heart beat! I'm like, what do you mean? Then afterwards I felt it, it is that good! We love it here and every time we are in SF we will make the effort in coming here. Must try their Hookers as well!!!
author: Lovetea C.

description:
Through that big tall glass window I saw a man in a blue checkered dress shirt and jeans, with his dark rim glasses, hurriedly walking in. He was the man I was waiting for. For the first time we've known each other, I was early. I turned my attention back to a half constructed email as he pushed the door open, and soon I sensed his arrival, as he gently tapped on my hand that was holding the smart phone. "Hi". He said. I stopped my emailing and handed him a bag filled with pickled herrings in plastic containers and some home made pumpkin bar with chestnut cream. I informed him that I had ordered Non Fat Cappuccino (NFC). They don't do non fat. So almond milk instead. NFC came with same design as the last time I was here. The barista poured a perfect heart on the top of the foam. The man ordered a drip decaf. Said that he would be up all night if he drank caffeinated drink. I would not know that. I did not meet him for coffee much, though that thought had crossed my mind many times over.

We waited for the coffee to drip and caught up. He complimented my new look. "You are making a lot of changes." He said. My mind was somewhere else that day so I said nothing until he said, "You are not even looking at me." I was caught off guard by that comment so I raised my eyes to meet his. I was disturbed by his comment and wanted to know why he was so testy, but just then the decaf drink was ready. He kept his black and bitter. I liked mine foamy and sweet.

I had sent photos I'd taken of this place earlier to this man. In my note I said, "I like the upstairs." So he led me to upstairs. The building itself was airy. It was nice to sit on the bar stools and look down and watch others ordering and making drinks. You could see the office and the roasting facility from where we sat. It had more space than needed, which made this place a little out of place in an increasingly expensive neighborhood, but it also made this place inviting. Conceivably one could spread out on that giant farm table next to us and have a review of a recently drawn architectural blueprint for a house remodeling project.

"You've changed. I have not. And I feel that you are expecting me to change. " Man had pointed out that my external appearance had changed, which was an indication that I had made internal changes as well. I had not. I liked to make physical changes to spruce things up, because staying constant would be boring and uninspiring. Man thought the problem was that I had expected him to change with me. A carefully cultivated friendship whereby two people were on a balanced scale, afraid of the other tipping the scale. Now the man sensed a tipping was going to occur. 

I drank my drink.

I first discovered espresso drinks made the proper way in Vienna. That was 14 years ago. Before Viennese coffee, I thought Italian espresso drinks were made for people on the go, drunk in a hurry in Rome, during lunch break. Not in Vienna, where cafes were filled with books and music. In France I could sit in a cafe drinking espresso drinks for hours on end while waited for the summer storm to pass. Here in SoMa, people took drinks swiftly as they discussed their latest product for their startups.  But not that day, not with that man, even though both of us worked in startups, and he was in fact working actively on a new product for his firm.

"You know what? I think drip coffee took too long." He all of sudden said. To this man everything was about saving time. He had little spare time to speak of. Everyone had to be slotted in. I was one of the slotted spots for the day.

"But,  did you taste the hint of chocolate? Or was it cherry today?" I asked, while smiling. Sightglass was known for their flavor of the day.

"No, it's just bitter and dark." He said, decidedly.

"Then perhaps you should stick with instant coffee. Like the Kopi Lowak I got for you." Balinese coffee was finely ground and mellow, like how I was before.

Not Sightglass. Sightglass coffee has intensity and personality. It's bold and unapologetic, like the version of me I'd like to evolve into some day; or, as the case may be, at least to this man, like the version I had already become.
author: Victoria E.

description: Wow what a find for a coffee place. Love the design and how open this place is. I would love to have a cup of coffee here with a book to read next time I visit. They have a bike rack outside so feel free to ride your bike here and enjoy a cup of coffee. Also, they have an upstairs area where you can have a nice view of the entire place. My ideal place for coffee and productivity!
author: Daniel W.

description:
Place has great coffee and nice chill local vibe and pastries are awesome ...

Bought a bag of coffee and changed my mind on the blend. Asked manager if I could exchange it and they said no because the espresso blend I wanted was cheaper and they'd have to give me money back.... Sooooo what's the problem? Good thing your coffees good
author: Eugene E.

description:
I would give this place a clean average rating. Both good and bad depending on your take of things. 
I will start with...

THE BAD: The service. The baristas are cold and uninviting which is a stark contrast to the warm comfortaing drinks they are selling. They are extremely pretentious, which is confusing because how can someone who works for minimum wage at a coffee shop for a living possibly be pretentious...?
They are not inviting and they dont listen to you. They are too busy wanting things their way. I asked for extra hot and got, actually, extra cool. Colder than if i hadn't said anything at all. I vehemently dislike hot coffee. 

THE GOOD: While the coffee was freezing, it was rather tasty. My croissant was buttery and flaky (of course it would have been better if the staff had offered to heat it, but there is no way they would step out of their comfort zone for the sake of a customer). the place looks very cool and modern. It is warm inside and the upstairs allows for a place to study in peace or meet with friends.

All this leads me to an average rating of 3 stars. Not bad, not good, a grade of C. Am I happy I went? Very. Will I forget about this place by tomorrow and never think to go back again? Of course.
author: Roxanne A.

description:
Fancy, hipster coffee!  Can't go wrong, they have excellent coffee, sweet and savory treats. Be prepared to pay $4 for a small latte and $3 for a cup of black coffee.  Only one size of cup around here.  

Tons of seating, downstairs and upstairs.  Place to safely store your bike, or dog when you walk in.
author: Erin J.

description:
Is it overpriced? yea 7.00 for 2 cappuccinos. but guess what, it's SF

But the space this place has is pretty gosh darn awesome. who needs to rent a work studio when you can buy a 3.50 cup of coffee and stay all day in your own corner at a huge meeting table. 

I went to work after the cup of cappuccino, and I was zoinked for the next 8 hours. I may have to buy a bag next time.

I wouldn't be surprised if Anthony Bourdin came in swearing by this place...
author: eVa J.

description: I fell in love with Sightglass after my 1st visit. The space is amazing and the coffee is even better. They also have pastries, including savory and vegan options. When I visit alone, I get a counter seat on the 2nd floor and "work remotely." The floor plan is open so you get the airy and lofty vibe. The bathrooms are unisex, which I appreciate in a diverse city like San Francisco. The cafe is filled with hipsters and people who work remotely, many of them wearing the customary uniform of beards, hoodies, tight jeans, and backpacks.
author: Sylvia V.

description: 5 stars for the cute barista and for their soap by the sinks... It smells divine!  Their coffee is great and in my opinion, better than Blue Bottle. I also tried their seasonal coffee cake, which had a nice crumb topping. Parking is tough since it's only street, but I wouldn't mind driving around the block several times just to find a place knowing that the coffee is that good!
author: Hayley H.

description:
Cool atmosphere- great vibe, cozy, and definitely unique! Friendly staff - helpful, knowledgable, and accommodating. 
Daily drip is good - light roast, which is a bit to weak in flavor for me, however smooth. With light roasted beans, i found the Latte was weak, milk overpowered and diluted the flavor of the espresso. Overall, better than the coffee chains such as Starbucks, second cup, panera etc.
author: Jenna M.

description:
Since i am in line waiting for a cruffin lets do a review of sights coffee. Before coming here i got dropped infront of the store but across the street and there wwre no signs on the outside of the building and had made a slight detour. Thank god to technolpgy these days with a smart phone and google maps. I dont know what i would do with out u google maps. They also have 2 bathrooms and a large sink outside the bathrooms. They also have a nice slection of totes and mug and tumblers for sale as well. 

So i went in sight glass around 9am on a thursday and i mean there was a line out the door. Prolly about 6 pple ahead of me and the speed of the line went really quick speed. 

When it was my turn i went up to the cashier and say hi how are u and it was silent but a slight smirk, in my mind i was like u ride b!!!! Lol anyways ordered the owl howler latte and then proceeded to pay and it was 4.50. Then i asked if its sweetened or  very sweet since i dont like it too sweet i prefer less is what i told her and then she finally said a word "no" and shook her head. I was like okay. Yea i figure its the city and usually most people are cranky so yea i should know by now. Overall the wait I didnt think it was bad and then it took about 5 to 10 min wait til my drink came out and they hand out drinks on both side of the counter so beware and stay alert which counter they put it at. 

Lets see when i got the cup, it was in a paper cup with black and white design with their logo on it. The owl howler latte is what i got and it was great at first sip and it milky and creamy and the coffee wasnt too strong in it. I mean espresso which they have 2 i believe. There is also a heart on the top of the drink and it made its presentation really nice. And the sweetness wasnt sweet at all or way bitter it was good and perfect to my taste. The cup didnt take long to finish since it wasnt too big. More like a tall or grande size from sb cups. Overall i liked it. 

Now the inside when you first enter they do all the packaging of the beans to be shipped or for customers who want certain beans to take home. Then the couter is an o shape and both side they serve drinks. In the very front of the curve o shape is where they
 Have 3 cashiers to take orders. Then the back of the o shape counter they have rooms for u to stand by the counter. Then in the very front of the store they have coffee roaster machine which is on and going and its cool. Then they have a fence around the machine area with countertops too and u can sit and enjoy ur cup and watch at the same time. They also have counter tops along the front of the store with tall glass windows to look outside the street which is busy and nothing like wow. Then they Also have an upstairs as well for u to sit and study or look down the coffee shop from the balcony indoors. Outside the entrance they have a bike rack for u to hang your bikes. They are not friendly with pets so u leave them outside. They
 have a nice sign outside the entrance.

Overall the layout is nice and very spacious and the drink i had was good and no complaints. Next time im going to dry the ice cold vanilla coffee. Will be back soon. Hope you enjoyed my review and make sure to vote for me  happy yelping tata.
author: Alex T.

description:
This place just got even worse. How do I give negative stars? Noticed price for a a small pour over coffee is $4.25. My previous review said $4. I was either mistaken last time or prices went up. If it wasn't already high, it's insane now. Seriously, who pays $4.25 for a small 6 oz. or so coffee? 

Go to Vega Coffee, it's a small place on Folsom just a block away. They serve Blue Bottle in pour over for only $2.50. If you're not pretentious about your single origin organic free trade coffee beans, go to Wicked Grounds or Brain Wash, also just a block or so away for still good standard drip coffee that's larger yet less than $2.
author: Alpo H.

description: No Wifi, no outlets. Good coffee is good but not enough.
author: Ruobin W.

description: Excellent coffee. Beautiful building. Friendly staff. The lack of wifi can be a bummer but the reality is if they did have wifi nobody would ever leave.
author: Zach R.

description: Nice Cappuccino! The small bites to eat are also very good. We gave it two thumbs up!
author: Celia C.

description:
This coffee has not gotten better and I can't help but love the open warm space.

Whenever I get a chance to read and spend some time on my own this is the first coffee shop I go to. Not because of the coffee necessarily but instead I go to cozy up in the amazing space. It hard to find shops like this in San Francisco because well it's not exactly the cheapest city to live in. When I come in here I feel as if I'm escaping from the constant buzz of the city and that's something I rarely get to do. I love it here and the shop is just phenomenal.
author: Jacqueline C.

description:
Keepin it simple.

1. Coffee quality is legit.
2. Industrial-chic atmosphere is legit.
3. Hipsters and Startup-Geeks Everywhere.
4. No Wi-Fi, No-Power Outlets
5. Buy your coffee, chat, and leave.

Simple and it works.
author: Roy C.

description:
Located on 7th street, surrounded by questionable motels, 
street parking, a quarter for six minutes, 
wood trim accent, golden sigil on the window, 
infamous cement wall, industrial meet organic, 
flat part of the city, fair justification for fixies, 
bike frames on the wall, Bianchi for days,
wide open space, smell the aroma, 
drinks meticulously crafted, latte art on point, 
two hearts, tulip to match the wood grain, 
cruisin' on flavors rich and smooth, that good good, 
rank, don't get it twisted son, 
Sightglass, Ritual, Blue Bottle, Four Barrel
author: Roy C.

description:
Went there for the first time today, really loved the place, a lofty coffee shop, so beautiful... My latte was amazing, super creamy and tasty! 
Service was nice, friendly staff... I'll definitely come back!
author: Paloma M.

description:
Upside-
Good coffee
Ample seats and tables with good height for working
Not too noisy
Nice ambience

Downside- no sockets at all and no wifi
author: Sara N.

description:
I've been to a good number of '3rd wave' coffee joints around the country (Intelligentsia, Toby's Estate, La Colombe, Blue Bottle, etc.) and I would put Sightglass at the bottom of the list. The pour over and espresso I had weren't great. Suspect it was a combination of poorly roasted beans and an ill-pulled shot (in the case of the espresso). 

In terms of the space, it doesn't feel like a cafe. Trying to be too many things: cafe, warehouse, roastery, etc. Not comfortable and without personality. The bar is especially odd; like a poor attempt to replicate the one at Intelli Venice. Sorry to be a hater, but if you're looking for an inspired coffee and environment, look elsewhere. Blue Bottle is always good. :-)
author: Cameron B.

description:
I'm a tea drinker but Sightglass doesn't serve tea. I should dock them a star for that but I can't. I ended up having a latte and it was fantastic. 33 years of not drinking coffee and now I'm finding myself wanting to get another one at Sightglass.  I really went there for a work meeting and the coffee was more or less the price of admission. In the end the upstairs was great for my business meeting and the cup of coffee left a lasting impression.

And, the barista was very nice when I didn't even really know how to order my coffee.
author: sean r.

description: Great coffee and a friendly staff. This is my new favorite coffee shop and roaster. I had a single origin Costa Rican light roast that was bright and balanced. The strawberry pastry was fantastic as well.
author: Dan L.
