description: Unpleasant and rude staff if you have questions. Guess what sightglass - many people who ask questions know more than you do- don't act so high and mighty- you don't know who you might actually be talking to ok
author: Arti M.

description: Industrial deco is pretty cool.  Service was just so-so.  Had a Cap - just ok.  Don't think I will come back though.
author: Ceci L.

description:
I can't believe I haven't head about place til a week ago. Their coffee are so delicious that I had to make serveral trips there within a three span. 

The exterior reminds me a bit of like Blue Bottle because of the layout and the limited menu selection. Next door, they're working on expanding the shop and are going to add tables, counters and chairs. Expected opening date? The barista said 2-3 months. 

First time I went, I ordered the Colombia iced coffee which has a smooth and creamy finish. Garland W. ordered the Costa Rica, Finca which has a sweet carmel and acidic finish. Not something I would order for myself but he seemed to like it. The couple of times I went back I had ordered their latte and is now my winning drink. I don't ever drink latte- never ever! I'm simple, straight coffee w/ a touch of soy. No sugar, no cream, nothing fancy...but Sightglass, you got me with your latte.
author: Jenny K.

description:
Scales laying around. Exacting measures. In house coffee roaster. Beans ground at the order. 

It's hard not to be completely mesmerized during the two minutes you wait for your drip coffee, while achieving total mental clarity.

Suppress the need to thank science for this beautiful cup of joe. 

I really love caffeine.
author: Ben T.

description:
Handmade drip coffee for $2.50.

I am not a coffee expert, but I know a good cup when I taste it. I have a good experience most days, but they switch up their menu options every once in a while, and sometimes I get something that just doesn't suit my taste buds. Oh well, live and learn.

For now, they're just serving out of a cart in the unfinished storefront. The barista told me that that once they complete construction, it'll be a WiFi-free cafe. I think that might be a good vibe actually.
author: Anthony W.

description:
I had just eaten a late lunch (and an early beer) with a female friend, and I was feeling a bit sluggish. My first stop was Peet's, because it was the closest and they have almond milk. However, the location inside Westfield Mall apparently does not. Yelp app to the rescue!

I saw that Sightglass had (mostly) good reviews, so I hauled my butt a few blocks to their storefront. 

First of all, the interior is lovely. It has that refurbished warehouse feel, which adds to the snobby hipster factor. It is very clean and shiny, with wooden tables and chairs both upstairs and on the ground level. If you take a seat on the second floor, the view is incredible. I snapped a photo from the eagle's nest, but a barista turned around and looked *straight at me*, so I wisely decided to scrap it. 

The cashier seemed a little befuddled by my order. I wanted an almond milk latte "for here", but their vegan spicy chewy cookie to-go. He put my cookie on a plate, and the barista made my beverage in a paper to-go cup. Not a big deal, except I was really having a seat and surfing the interwebs for a minute, so I felt guilty using the paper cup that I had to throw away afterwards. I'm slowly trying to become more eco-friendly, and this was a minor faux pas. I really need to invest in my own re-useable coffee thermos. I've been thinking about it for a long, long time, and I think it's finally time I take the plunge and purchase one. 

As for the latte, it was eh, pretty decent. Not the best I've had, but definitely not the worst. The spicy chocolate cookie (which I consumed later in the evening) was much better than the drink. I'm happy that they had a vegan sweet, but I didn't really care for my drink. Maybe the barista was having an off day, as I did hear them complaining about a huge rush earlier this morning. I guess Super Bowl fans wanted to get properly caffeinated to cheer on their team. 

They were playing The Feelies on the loudspeaker, which I really enjoyed, but then they switched it to something else. 

I'll give them another shot (perhaps at a different location), although at $5 a pop, I might be better off sticking to my usual haunts.
author: Brandi W.

description: It's not what I expected, it's such an interesting layout. It's so spread out and open, unlike most places in San Francisco. It's like they decided to make a coffee bar out of a warehouse. There are bag, plastic bins, and cardboard boxes in plain view. And the people scooping the beans and, and grinding the beans, and sitting the beans in a big churner thing. Pretty cool and unique space if you ask me.
author: Kellianne R.

description: This is the second time I stumbled into this local's coffee cult. I ordered hooker's mocha. OMG! Such a nice Sunday afternoon treat! The temperature is perfect, doesn't taste too sweet but very chocolaty. Every sip taste like heaven.   The environment is very relaxing and chilled out. I love this place!
author: Christina X.

description: First thing I noticed when I stepped inside was that ambiance. Busy yet tranquil. Hectic yet organized. The perfect work environment. Everything seemed so darn Instagram worthy. The coffee, however, was not so much in my taste. I really like the smooth darker roasty earthy taste rather than the fruity. But the latte I had was good and the slow drip was pretty interesting in taste. Enjoyed it. Overall I'd come back just for the study environment. Got a lot of work done here. Cwhang approved.
author: Chris W.

description: Walked in here wanting to kill some time. The place has a rustic look, and the baristas are friendly. Heard the Owl coffee is pretty good around here, and they have a nice loft overlooking the lower floor. Just had a cappuccino, and it wasn't really great for the money. As well the coffee was a bit lukewarm than required. Lack of air conditioning in the hot afternoon didn't do me good too. Wouldn't go again.
author: Aniruddha K.

description:
Brotherly love is what this coffee joint is all about.  No sibling rivalry here.  The owners of Sightglass Coffee are two brothers Justin & Jared Morrison and I've had the pleasure of seeing them both in action on several occasions when they first began their 7th street venture.  Justin seems to be able to make drinks like a pro and they've both been stellar(ly) pleasant and approachable.

I have since moved away from ease of access to Sightglass but if I were closer I'd be joining them for a morning coffee every weekday.

Keep it up fellas.
author: Kevin J.

description:
This is now the closest place for a caffeine splurge mid-day.  This would be a 3.5 star review but alas it's not possible. 

Have now sampled their coffee on a variety of occasions and I can't say it's my favorite or in the same league as Four Barrel for me personally. 

Impressive space in the slums of SOMA (still not warming up to the place!) and I appreciate that it's presence will go a long way in changing the neighborhood for the better. 

Have also tried the mocha, which was a bit rich for my taste. And slightly too bitter to really be considered a great. $5

Cool people work there who are passionate about their coffee and have lots of helpful advice for brewing coffee for French Press.
author: Amy Z.

description:
I'm a tea drinker but Sightglass doesn't serve tea. I should dock them a star for that but I can't. I ended up having a latte and it was fantastic. 33 years of not drinking coffee and now I'm finding myself wanting to get another one at Sightglass.  I really went there for a work meeting and the coffee was more or less the price of admission. In the end the upstairs was great for my business meeting and the cup of coffee left a lasting impression.

The barista was very nice when I didn't even really know how to order my coffee.
author: Sean R.

description:
The best coffee I had in San Francisco period. I really found their coffee to be flavorful and full bodied. I am planning on ordering a pound or two online since I am back in San Diego now.

I stumbled on this place by accident when jogging down from the Good Hotel during The Bay to Breakers weekend. They were a god send and 
the staff was completely wonderful.  Looks like they will be opening a cafe next to where you buy coffee, I bet it is going to be fantastic.

Enjoy - but remember, if you like "non-fat" latte's or low-fat whatevers like what Starbucks serves, this is not your place. Since it is small, they have two types of milk:  Soy and Whole...
author: Patricia Patti P W.

description: Walking into this place makes me happy. The energy exuded is comforting. The coffee is spot on (only almond and full fat milk options). Be prepared to wait a while for your coffee, as the barista treats each one like a creation of art. The wooden interior is beautiful and has a feeling of authenticity. There is lots of space upstairs to sit. Most people share large tables. It's a collaboration space, and can be noisy.  There are no power plugs and no wifi. Nevertheless this place is a home to many working away on their tablets and laptops.
author: Amy M.

description:
I'm a tea drinker. I came here with a couple friends and when it was my turn in line I asked if they had tea. Guy said no, we don't have tea sorry. I said oh ok thanks. 







Ps. 4 stars for how awesome the place is set up and for my friends saying the coffee is awesome... as well as the cool heart they made in the cappuccino. I'd definitely come back here just to hang out and read. Normally I love to try new things, but coffee is an acquired taste -  I wouldn't know how to appreciate this coffee vs instant coffee. 1 caffeinated addiction is good enough for me.
author: William L.

description:
We went here on a Saturday afternoon. We've been going to different neighborhoods exploring good coffee shops to work out of. 

The space and location here is fantastic. That alone merits the 4 stars. It is spacious, loft-like, and has tons of seating. Parking is relatively easy to find, as it's on the outskirts of SoMa. But most of the streets is meant for 1 hour parking. 

It's unfortunately we came on such a hot day, as the place is not well ventilated. We were cooking inside there. Had we come on a cooler day, I would've given it the full 4 stars.

The coffee is okay, a bit acidic for our taste. It does take a while to brew. I waited almost 10 minutes to get our regular coffee, and no line-up.
author: Winny F.

description:
Delightful!

A friend in Santa Cruz recommended this place and it really was amazing. 

Between the three of us we tried their two special blends and sampled a few of their cabinet items. 

The coffees: wow

The food would have been better heated up but I still enjoyed it.
author: Jonathan W.

description:
This place is currently under construction, but it looks like it's gonna be a pretty big coffee joint. 
So far, the coffee options are somewhat limited (compared to Philz Coffee). 
I ordered the Costa Rica, Finca Genesis. 
It has this sorta acidic initial taste, and is sorta accompanied by this caramely kinda finish. (as you can tell, I'm kinda handicapped in describing things) 
Whatever...  you're not thaaaat much better than me. 
Try it, pretty good stuff.
author: Garland W.

description:
As someone else said, this is hipster central.  Also, I met a few people here for a meeting and I don't like coffee and they didn't have much to choose from.  How hard is it to have a few tea bags.  It is a coffee shop after all.  

I'm sure their coffee is great and they are great people, but come down from your high horse.  IT"S JUST COFFEE!
author: Carrie B.

description:
This place has become a must-visit when we travel up to SF. Husband LOVES it. And I enjoy it almost as much as him. This place is as cool as you can get. 
We love their open floor plan. Love how spacious everything is. And let's not forget, they do coffee awesome.

Their roasting is no joke and having watched the roasting master at work, wowza. The care and attention they put into their roasting is definitely appreciated when you sip the wonder that is a pour-over or in a latte/capp and so on. 

The baristas are all friendly as far as I can tell and I do believe I could just sit there all day and read a good book while sipping some awesome coffee and enjoying the scent of beans being roasted. If only I lived in SF and have the luxury to do that. If only.
author: Jee S.

description:
Its appeared to be highly over-rated.  Not a very comfortable/cozy "cafe-like" atmosphere (met up here for a grad-school friends' reunion), coffee was quite bad, lukewarm, with no facility of properly heating it up again.

Would like to mention, however, that the baristas worked very hard to ensure that the service was as fast as they could manage, given how short-staffed they were.
author: Coffee B.

description: This is some good ass coffee. They offer both individual and pots of chemex or v60. Even the cheapest, a blend, Blueboon, was so good. I think the Owl's Howl is one of the best espresso coffee out there. I can't wait for a seating area to open up. I like the concept of the sightgass, operating in transparency and traceability. This is also one of the first businesses to adopt Square.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Best coffee in SF. There's really no argument to be had. Better than Ritual. Way better than Fourbarrel. Way, way better than Blue Bottle. I get my morning coffee from the shop and buy bags of the Owl's Howl to use at home.

The kids that work here are all pretty cool (not snotty like some other local spots...). They have the best vinyl collection, too (Cocksparrer's "Shock Troops"!).
author: Herschel F.

description: Best coffee in town. Some of the best pastries in town. Great and hip atmosphere. And they roast their own beans right in the middle. I'd easily say this is my most favourite coffee shop ever!
author: Michelle O.

description:
My workplace is right next to this Sightglass location and I have to be honest: I was a bit nervous to check this place out based on the negative reviews it received for rude/crappy baristas.

I was definitely pleasantly surprised. First of all the place is gorgeous. Beautiful ceiling to floor windows, an upper seating area that gives you a view of the entire downstairs, a mixture between urbanist/modern/rustic decor with lots of wood, and an area that I assume is where they roast/prep beans.

Second, every interaction with the baristas has been more than pleasant. They're nice people and have even taken the time to answer questions I've had. Granted, I haven't been here during rush hour, which may cause the experience to be more negative.

Overall, great place. Be warned that it is not a place to go if you're in a rush.
author: Erwin K.

description: Here, at this very coffee shop, is where I metamorphosed from a coffee lover into a coffee snob. I learned the difference between a blend of "bright flavors of riesling and fruit punch" and a blend of "vanilla wafer, milk chocolate, and a lingering, syrupy finish". I'm not a coffee master yet, but can you say "#coffee #hipster #AlmondMilkOnlyPlease"?
author: Mandy C.

description: Ran into this amazing coffee shop while waiting for my bicycle getting repaired. They don't provide many options though, the coffee here is good on looking and tasting. Atmosphere here is even better. It's a wonderful place for both self studying and meetup.
author: Victor L.

description: Delicious, simply executed coffee. Chill atmosphere, industrial vibe, and friendly people.
author: Marisa O.

description: Appreciated the service and a standard (at a high quality) espresso. The space is wonderful, sleek, capacious, and community seating oriented...really enjoyed for a chat with friend and reading.
author: J K.

description: I took a sip of my cold brewed with almond milk and I was blown away by the taste. It's hands down the best I've ever had. I foresee giving them lots of dollars in the near future.
author: Carmen J.

description:
I'm always on a mission to feed my caffeine addiction. Sounds horrible doesn't it?

Structurally, this place has an industrial looking touch to it.  I think the cafe alone is worth checking out even if you don't want to buy coffee. (although i highly recommend you do, because it's amazing) As you walk in, there is a giant open space and in the middle of it is where you order your coffee and pastries. There are some seating along the downstairs bar, but most of the seating is upstairs that  overlooks the first floor. Too bad I live far, otherwise this would definitely be my go to cafe to get work or some studying done. 

I went with one of their drip coffees. Tasted like a medium roast compared to the one my friend had. I usually drink my coffee with a little bit of almond milk or stevia, but this coffee was so smooth and no bitter aftertaste that i didn't need either (and it had plenty of caffeine so I was ready to bounce of the walls) 

Will definitely be going back up when I get the chance.
author: Victoria L.

description: Oh SightGlass, why'd you do that? I had my day planned out with you being the main attraction and boy was I left disappointed. The establishment is beautiful, any architect in the neighboring area would surely agree. But outside of the beauty lies the taste of bitterness & temperamental taste of espresso. I'll probably stop by after heading to Blue Bottle because this place is gorgeous.
author: Taisha A.

description:
One star because the coffee is really good (I used to buy it all the time at Bi-Rite), the architecture is cool, and the guy at the register was nice.

Otherwise, it's funny to me how while there are so many great places to enjoy coffee in San Francisco, the last two I have tried are under this mindset that because their coffee is good, they can treat people like lepers.  It's not like I am some fat tourist with a fanny pack bugging everyone, and even if I were..

This time, I was confused on how to use the water spout.  I didn't interrupt anyone, but the barista  yelled (in a very condescending manner) "It's like this!" and then walked away.  I profusely apologized and was not answered.  Fine, excuse me, move on, but then, my ICE COFFEE took 35 minutes.  I was aware and ok with the fact that it came in a small cup and can take a while, but then the CUP was HALF FULL.  There were only four other customers, so 35 minutes is long even for the world's most extreme order.  

I like to be positive about cool new business, but come on.  Sorry I'm not some Girl with the Dragon Tattoo hacker-type getting their orders faster than they can take their scooter helmets off.  

....won't be back and though I love it, no more Sightglass Coffee either.
author: Jack M.

description:
Ambience: spacious, open, tall-ceilings, with chill music to set the backdrop. Two floors with abundant seating. Perfect cafe spot to study or catch up with an old friend 

coffee: $4.00 for a soy latte or single-cup brew. Perfect size (small) with a HUGE kick of caffeine. 

baked: $2.50 for a palm-sized oatmeal cookie. probably a skip for the next visit.

overall rating: In my top three (below ritual and four barrel). But this coffee shop is pretty easy to miss as it's located smack in the middle of the block and not the easiest to get to unless you have a car.
author: Patricia K.

description: Best serves. Fresh and great amazing coffee. You can't say no to this kind of coffee. They experiment to coffee to make sure it is right and try to add new drinks.
author: Victor C.

description:
If you're an architect who loves good coffee, this is your place in the SoMA! Also good for those who love the architecture of coffee (read: industrial roasting machine) or just good coffee (locally roasted, fresh and tasty).

The space is a slow accretion of designed layers: at the base, the warehouse itself, 1930s vintage with tensional steel and compressive wood trusses beautifully revealed above the bar; next, glue-lam beams added (circa 1960's?) to support the mezzanine level floating at front and rear of the space; last, recycled admix concrete, roll-formed zinc and die-cut aluminum finish details added for Sightglass. Each addition discrete, yet adding to a unified machinic whole.

Oh yeah, the coffee is great too! Try the Hooker's Mocha --- it's bittersweet carmelized chocolate, adding richness (but not sweetness) to the aromatic overtones of the coffee.
author: Jay A.

description:
Neat little coffee joint in SoMa where you can see the beans getting roasted too. The prices are just about competitive with your local Starbucks, which gives you absolutely no reason not to support such a local business.

The mocha was a little bit on the light side taste-wise. For a place like this which takes their coffee roasting seriously, just get a double espresso and get the full effect of their skills. (I can't do this, unfortunately, as my caffeine tolerance is quite low!)

Protip: They don't have wifi and there's no 'linksys' in the area which can fit the bill either. Having that would bring it to 5 star.
author: Josh K.

description: The best Vegan affogato, almond milk latte, and pour over coffee in San Fran. Definitely check this out if your in the area. Really cool shop.
author: Amanda U.

description: A friend recommended I try the latte at Sightglass coffee so I decided to try it out. So so good. The staff was really friendly and helpful and the coffee shop has a night atmosphere. It was a bit crowded but it was a fun place to hang out.
author: Ashley K.

description: Sightglass Coffee is very hipster. It has two floors with tall ceilings and big windows. Very spacious on the inside. The only available parking is through street parking. I came here around 7 in the morning before work and got a cup of Cappuccino. On top of the cappuccino was the shape of the heart. By the looks of it, I knew it was going to be delicious! One of the best cappuccinos I have had! It was smooth, rich in taste, and not bitter at all. It is a bit expensive for the price of it, but totally worth it for such a good drink! It's the perfect way to start off a good morning!
author: Philana C.

description:
SF has changed a lot about me.  I look in the mirror and wonder where the 20 year old James S disappeared to, the strapping young lad with nary a facial hair to be seen, the one who could drink Bud Light without going off on a ten minute tangent about how San Diego craft breweries are some of the best in the nation, the one who could go to sushi and eat Spicy Mango Tempura Coconut rolls without shame, the one who could have made it through a Coldplay concert without rolling his eyes and stealing sarcastic quips from Pitchfork reviews to ruin the fun of those around him.

If there is one thing this city does, it is take your favorite [food/drink/music], squeeze all the fun out of it, and fast track your palette from "hey this is kind of cool" to some Mission level uber-snob ish.  

Coffee, however, is my one last vestige of "Meh, I love it but don't know anything about it", which means all that is about to follow means absolutely nothing when it comes to the most important part of any coffee shop: the coffee.  So what CAN I review about?

Exposed beams sucka.

I love coming here.  I wait patiently in line, suppress the childish grin on my face, and summon up every inch of hipster cool I have in me as I step up to order.  I ask for a drip coffee, politely read the description and "ooh" and "awe" over the taste notes (gingko or tree sap or whatever), and then beeline for the top floor counter overlooking the space, so I can people watch and take in the architecture.

Coffee spots, to me, have always been about ambiance, and this is my favorite spot in the city to be.  The space is gorgeous with high ceilings and a casual touch of taxidermy.  The patrons are vibrant and interesting (to watch and eavesdrop on that is).  It has awesome energy and architecture that I haven't seen replicated anywhere else.  This is my favorite spot to bring a book and get through 5 pages in an hour, because I am too busy taking it all in.

I'm sure the coffee is good, I never spit it out or anything, but I should probably be careful...five visits from now, I'll probably cross the line of no return and add coffee to the list of subjects my friends know not to bring up around me.
author: James S.

description: During my 4 day trip, I went to sightglass twice, if that says anything. You must come here for the pistachio croissant. Paired with a nice (columbia) iced coffee or a latte and you are set. The place is spacious with the natural lighting and architecture that makes things feel very wide and open. I sat upstairs and watched them make coffee. It wasn't too loud or noisy when I went, but I was there in the early morning during the weekdays both times.
author: Grace C.

description: Great coffee, Great atmosphere, and Great pastries. When asked, all pastries come from local bakeries. I have been here multiple times for office meetings and for a casual expresso. The expresso is served with sparkling water, which brings out so many flavors. The only down side is that there is no wifi.
author: alfred c.

description:
Holy paradoxurus hermaphroditus beans! Sightglass Coffee has the best espresso I've had in ages. 

OK, confession time: I've been an espresso snob for more years than I care to remember. It's gotten to the point that I've switched to pour overs in most places just to avoid disappointment. Sightglass has totally redeemed my faith in the modern coffee house. 

Sightglass delivers its beverages in an airy, warehouse-like setting with plenty of bar space so you can drink your espresso while standing as god intended. 

Sorry BBC -- I still love you guys.
author: Norman G.

description:
Not bad coffee. They have really good pastries though.

My drink of choice here was the cold brew w/ whole milk. Then add a dash of sugar. Perfection.
author: Kevin C.

description:
Sightglass is fastly becoming my favorite FOLSOMA coffee shop, even with the likes of Vega and Pinkie's within a 2 block radius. With their revolving daily offerings, each individual cup is lovingly brewed for my pleasure.

Their specialty brews contains exotic notes of juicy black currant, smoky tobacco, fruity florals and more. Albeit pricey, their coffee's are well worth every penny spent.

Never was I able to justify spending equivalent to a McDonalds Big Mac Meal on a cup of joe but once you've had a taste of Sightglass, you might be singing a different tune.
author: Lisa W.

description: Excellent vegan Mexican chocolate cookie! Wow that was a mouthful to say. It's hipster central but the coffee and snacks are great.
author: Olivia C.

description: One of my favorite coffee bars in SoMa.  And they had an affogato bar set up on the mezzanine this weekend, which is an awesome addition.  I hope it's permanent!
author: Richie T.

description:
Great structure, but that's where the thumbs up starts to point south.

Each overpriced beverage is served with a complimentary side of attitude.

Sadly, such a hipster bastion as this has no Wi-Fi. I suppose the myriad people on their laptops are either playing solitaire or composing their hipster manifesto. Oh, and god help you if you want some kind of sugar substitute.

Unless you ate at the cool kids' table in high school, stick to Brainwash or Wicked Grounds.
author: Rik L.

description:
The Sightglass folks don't fuck around when it comes to coffee. They are serious -- often, to the point of almost being offensive. For many, that's a total aphrodisiac. For others, though, that's a huge turn-off. 

I understand the choice to not provide WiFi to preserve a certain vibe and, yes, I do get the reasons behind the snobbery. But, why serve up a 'tude to those who make nothing but good faith requests that may seem absurd to you (Splenda, ice, or, dear god: Torani), but that they have legitimate reasons for asking about (uh, hello, diabetes? And the rest is called personal preference)? 

I can't deny, though, that Sightglass serves up one of the best cappuccinos in the city, a city already teeming with bougie-hipster coffee places no less. It's smooth, rich, complex, and just so delicious. I also love the venue - it's a gorgeous two stories, large, flooded with light, filled with wood, and very industrial. There's nothing more ideal than catching up with a good friend over a quality cup of coffee in such a beautiful space.

I'll be back (damn you guys).
author: Betty W.

description: I'm not one for mochas but their hookers mocha was sexy delicious. I'd take sightglass coffee over blue bottle any day. Also a very spacious place to hang out, study, and take hipster selfies. I love the fact that they have a functional roaster located on the main floor for the customers to see the beans getting roasted.
author: Mable N.

description:
Amazing. Sightglass offers uniquely tasting coffee from all around the world. Roasted on location the flavors are on point.

Quick Cup is my goto because its fast and reasonably priced. Im totally in love with all of their roasts, and if I have time, the pour overs & the latte's are great but a tad expensive for the size. 

No chargers or wifi which I think is the right decision to keep an inviting atmosphere.
author: Adam M.

description: Great coffee, very friendly / earthy interior for relaxing and catching up with a friend, love the affogato bar - wish they had outlets or free wifi, but I imagine they do that on purpose so as to avoid making this a 'remote work' spot.
author: Riz A.

description: Amazing latte worth the wait. A great place to hang out and have a coffee and watch them roast the beans.. Every cup is individually brewed...
author: Robert O.

description:
Yes the coffee is good, the woodwork is well done.  Personally, I liked to get my coffee here when it was just a cart and a bench.  
I've been here more than three times, each time worse experience.  Last time, the cashier lady thought she was the coolest person ever, and took forever.  A place to go if you don't have anything to do and want to feel hip or something.  -Personally not into the crowd, aesthetic is overkill, more sterile than blue bottle, reminds me of a young Williamsburg yipster wasteland.  Dont think I could even crank out a poem in this space.  good coffee, but I found myself jogging out the door
author: C L.

description: This place has stunning modern decor that makes you feel cool and fresh just standing inside. It is very open concept and the view from the second floor seats (if you can manage to get one) is great. They ground their coffee beans in the open. The coffee itself is very good as well. They have solid macchiatos that have a good balance between sweetness and coffee flavor. I would recommend the caramel flavor. Their lattes are also decent, not too creamy, and smooth on the way down. And of course I have to mention their ice coffees, which are really quite good especially on a hot day. I would recommend getting it 'for here' so that you can get it in a fancy handled mason jar, to give the drink an extra tinge of class and sexiness. They also put up a new vinyl record every day (?), so make sure to check to see if your favorite artists are on display that day.
author: George K.

description:
Morning coffee, gorgeous environment, deeply thoughtful about how they roast. 

Turns out I'm less interested in dark roasts, and this crew really gets how to pull the nuance out of the beans they are buying. 

Had a pour over, was great. Dunno if I truly grock this yet, but wtf, it is fun! :)

Am hoping this new wave of zen of coffee continues, and these guys get it all the way down.
author: Mark H.

description: This is an amazing coffee house: it's spacious but cozy. The coffee they make is freshly toasted & the pastries are Divine! It's industrial unpolished interior design & warehouse/roasting plant look, creates a very warm, chic & modern ambiance. Highly recommended.
author: Ali F.

description: Beautiful space, knowledgable and friendly staff, great coffee. It's popular, but there's still always a place to sit and enjoy your coffee.
author: Katherine B.

description: I actually like this place, it's quite big and I like the industrial feeling of it. The coffee however sucks tho, its ultra acidic and way too expensive. The house coffee looks like discolored acidic water, way too weak every time. I haven't tried the drip coffees, maybe they're better. But The place is awesome to get some quick work done. The parking is quite expensive outside as well ($3.25/hr) but that's SF for you.
author: Milan E.

description: Great space, great vibe, great coffee, and great for cyclists as well... They removed their public wifi to prevent the place from becoming a wasteland of Macbook/iPhone zombies, which is commendable. The coffee here is not cheap and the portions are not large, but the little 16 oz cup packs a mean punch of flavor and caffeine. As far as unique coffee shops go, this one is probably tops, and I am grateful that it is the closest one to my house.
author: Rich W.

description: I really like the industrial aesthetic they have going on. There's tons of places to sit and have your coffee and it's a really large space- huge actually. I was trying to read and kept getting distracted so maybe not the best place for a book. I got a vanilla iced coffee. I really liked the mug they served it in- the whole thing is really made for Instagram. The coffee itself was both a little watery and the taste of coffee I did get was bitter, which isn't really my taste. I probably would've been better off getting coffee black with sugars. Overall, I felt like it was overhyped. It's not bad! Perhaps just not my taste.
author: Kim V.

description:
I really enjoyed this cafe.  The coffee was great ( I had a pour-over ) and the staff were pleasant if somewhat busy and a little distracted.  We took our coffee and sat upstairs chatting and people watching for some time.  Most people there were sitting with open laptops since there is plenty of good table-top space to facilitate this kind of activity.  

The interior design is really cool, every detail seems to have been covered by a very driven designer.  I'll certainly visit again if I get a chance to see the city again.
author: Michael B.

description:
Coffee: I've never had African coffee before, but when I asked for a recommendation, I ended up getting the Ethiopian (black) coffee. It smelled great and tasted just as good. The milk-based ones are tasty as well--not too sweet with typical, but still beautiful latte art. 

Atmosphere: It's so spacious! The whole design of the building is modern and rustic all at once. There's an upstairs and plenty of space to sit. I also love how you watch them make your coffee. It looks so intricate even if it's probably simpler than you'd think. 

Service: The servers are friendly and even tolerable of me and my friend fighting over who would get to treat the other out. One of them was especially nice, even when I accidentally called the coffee "Egyptian" whoops...

Never been to Four Barrel, but so far I'm loving Sight Glass and I'll probably be visiting again.
author: Jenn F.

description: This place is good. The beans here are great - five star worthy. The space is great, huge, also five star worthy. The reason for three stars - I get very annoyed with hipster coffee spots that tell ME how I have to have my cappuccino, by only carrying one type of milk. If I want a nonfat cappuccino, for 4 bucks, I should get a nonfat cappuccino, not full fat. The coffee is good, but if you want your drink made the way that YOU want it, not the way they think you should have it - head over to blue bottle.
author: Jake B.

description:
I can't tell if Sightglass is a self-aware interpretation of what a chic hipster coffee house in San Francisco would look like, or if it's the non-ironic, genuine article. But it doesn't matter because the venue is perfectly imperfect, unvarnished yet well-kept, with an airy, modern feel that celebrates the fact that the building was once a warehouse.

Oh yea, and the affogato bar upstairs rocked my tweed socks!
author: Mike G.

description: Love this space. Lots of beautiful wood and seating space, and high ceilings. It's the kind of place I imagine Taylor Swift is singing about when she says "And on a Wednesday, in a cafe, I watched it begin again." I'd come hang out here more often and spend an hour with a good book if I lived in the area. And yea, the coffee isn't bad either. :)
author: Susan C.

description:
Sorry starbucks I love you but you ain't got nothing on Sightglass coffee. I came here after my coffee connoisseur told me that this was the best coffee in San Fran. I definitely agree.

Parking is difficult to find as most of the customers are hipsters and ride their bicycles to this coffee joint. The only parking available is street parking and you have to make sure you meter is filled cause the meter maids are swift in giving you a ticket. 

The decor of the shop is very contemporary. The entire store is made out of non-painted wooden pillars. Even the tables and chairs are like that as well. I was afraid to get a splinter. When you first walk in you can see a giant coffee roaster making fresh coffee.  

I ordered the simple quick cup, which the coffee was from Ecuador (I believe). Service was pretty fast and they use a ipad to take your credit card. The seating are upstairs and is arranged in a way where it is a community area instead of individual booths and seats. 

The coffee was very flavorful and tasted unique from other coffees I drank. It did keep me awake for the rest of the day. It is a loud atmosphere but I still see people studying/doing work. I will visit this place again when I come back to San Fran!
author: Jonathan L.

description:
Solid coffee. Awesome atmosphere.

My cappuccino was tasty and served at a nice temperature. But the large, spacious warehouse feel was wonderful. Since most coffeehouses are small and intimate, it was a nice change of pace to sit on the upper floor with all the open space. Not too loud either.

I'll be back to get some serious work done!
author: Sarah B.

description: my go to for enjoying that coffee atmosphere wooden tables and steel high chair vibes. tried a pastry once but I'm sure the ones in the am are better. super cool set up they've got going on with the stairs leading to a second level. sit at the big tables if you wanna hear some investor convos, sit at the solo seats near the railing to take that perfecto above the ground looking below picture for Instagram, or sit at the ground level by the window and listen to some guy traveling cross country for a marketing job he discovered via craigslist. I've had many memories here, it's a great place to chill or study and sip your latte while staring at the cute baristas.
author: Laurie M.

description: This place is a nice and cosy coffee shop, really huge so you dont have to worry about finding a spot, but I won´t come back because 1. they have no public wifi and 2. the music coming from the ground floor on a vinyl player has a bad quality, definitely not powerfull enough for the whole place, and from upstairs it's very annoying. I think it's a nice place to meet friends but don't think about working here...
author: Laure D.

description: Sight Glass is more than a coffee shop, it is an experience. The moment you walk in the aroma of beans roasting grabs you and pulls you inside. The rustic/industrial style compliments the top notch espresso equipment. The baristas were friendly and welcomed the attention as their whole operation is visible by the customer. I would highly recommend this coffee house!
author: Megann J.

description: Hipster coffee house central, the uniqueness of this place comes from the interior architecture and feel.  Very modern and city esque, I like it very much which is why I want to go there.  Found out about it fist from a friend who took a photo there on FB. The coffee wasn't insanely good when I had it but it was late in the afternoon and I wanted to have a decaf cold coffee.  This was small but clean tasting.  I really just really love the way the place is setup.  They seem to have a packaging area for coffee and also a loft area where you can sit above the organic looking barista island.  I'll give this place 5 stars just for the interior design.  If you come to the city and don't ever come here, you should just to see the inside and give the coffee a try.
author: Kenny P.

description:
Great coffee, decor and pretty friendly staff.

But no wifi and no outlets presumably because they want to encourage conversation and engagement.  "Cafes are just too quiet."

While I agree to some level, it makes it harder to call this place my regular spot as often I am not with another person and I would like to get some work done during my  morning.  

Part of me can't help but think that they might also do it to turn tables as I imagine lots of people would just park here to work (the Sight Glass Incubator).
author: Alex C.

description:
I visited this location a couple of times on my recent visit to SF.  I am hooked on the Hooker's chocolate latte.  Divine!  
The coffee shop itself is beautiful inside.  I did not give it 5 stars because they literally have less than 10 beverages on the menu, no skim milk.  
The brioche sandwich I had was also divine.
author: Suzie B.

description:
I had high expectations for Sightglass that were definitely met! It's this trendy warehouse in Soma with nice eccentric touches like a vintage roaster and tall barstools and small tables to situate yourself at, and I was impressed by both the decor and how seriously the baristas take their craft.

The bad: The only weakness I could spot here was the spotlight is on the many ethically sourced coffees- my almond latte was sub-par. If you're looking for a good creamy latte with yummy foam, I'd suggest Blue Bottle instead.

The good: My friend's coffee was one of the best coffees I've ever had- and it was up there with the Kopi Luwak and Ritual cups I've tasted. There was a surprisingly tasty acidity to it, and it was just very roasty and strong in flavor. I'm not a coffee pro or a snob, but I could tell this was good stuff.

Overall: nice study spot/trendy hang out in Soma for an exceptional cup of coffee. Worth the price!
author: Jackie T.

description: The space is pretty cool- I like to sit upstairs and watch them roast the beans. Good coffee which means that it can get crowded. I've always been able to find a seat though. More industrial than cozy.
author: Kristen M.

description:
Can't wait to come back. This space is excellent, and very Portlandish. If you like the smell of coffee, just come and enjoy the smell, that is guaranteed to lift you.

Check it out if you are in the area. It's close to TBD, another restaurant I want to try.

ah, addiction.
author: Kathy L.

description:
Love love love the coffee. Love love love the space.

It is always the place we go during weekend for afternoon coffee.

The space is so open and uniquely laid out and designed. It is a wonderful place to hang out or chill or just do nothing and enjoy the time passing by.

Always get coffee beans from there as will, so far, never been disappointed. :)
author: Kai Y.

description: It's so good!! But no WiFi & outlets available. However... they have bike racks right outside the door.
author: mike w.

description:
The Dish: This place is AWESOME. Locals should definitely come here. Good coffee (kinda like Four Barrel and Blue Bottle). Scratch that, AMAZING coffee especially their lattes. That's really all they are known for.

Ambiance: It's really minimalistic and I come here to study when I am trying not to use the Internet (there's no wi-fi). It's a lovely set-up and it's huge. It has an upstairs with more baristas. It's never too crowded so typically, you can find a seat. I really don't know what more to say except how much I love this place and I definitely will be back for more.
author: Gina T.

description:
This is a stylish Coffee factory like Cafe, with ample wood, and coffee factory like furnishings.  The audience is young and hip, quite a trendy place.  The coffee was good, the glasses unique, and the ice cubes very large - in a iced latte.

Some of the chairs don't have back rests, and there's no wifi at this caffe.  They don't serve tea, but they do have croissants.  There's no splenda either, so that might be a deal breaker for me.  Other than that, it's a fun place to hang out.
author: Pascal A.

description: Today I realized that sometimes I come here to get a coffee just so I can wash my hands in the pretty sink with the good smelling soap
author: Margaret H.

description: Trendy and beautiful, but disappointing.    Had their decaf - it was weak and not hot. Wanted a shot added, but $3.00 added to my coffee is just too steep.
author: Debbie L.

description: Love this place, though their Gibraltor is priced weird (it's $3.80 everywhere and here it's $4.50 last I was there).  Love their coffee, the atmosphere and staff.
author: Yazz A.

description: Receiving recommendation from Yichen, a friend of mine who used to be local in SF, I paid a visit to Sighglass Coffee this noon. No doubt it's a great coffee shop. Plus, it roasts beans and supplies other independent shops. Latte is what I had then, it was soft, smooth and not that strong. I've tried Four Barrel, Ritual Coffee and Blue bottle in either single origin or espresso drinks, and I'd have a sip of friend's coffee when I was having different one. Sightglass has the lighter taste among those mentioned shops, close to Culture Espresso Bar in NYC. Its pastries are good enough to be paired with coffee. I'm not going to put more words on its room or decor, just check the pics!
author: Wei-Hsiang H.

description:
My first visit here today for a meeting and I ordered the Hooker's Mocha and Chocolate Croissant. 

During the ordering process, the guy at the register wasn't very inviting or welcoming. 
They took a good 15-20 minutes to make my drink with only 2 people ahead of me. When I finally got my order to then bring upstairs it was already cold.

Hooker's Mocha
Made with Gan ache Bittersweet Chocolate 
Was not sweet, had to add two spoons of sugar
It took way too long to make, to find later that it was cold!

Chocolate Croissant
Was cold and dry.

Nice setting, however. Cool upstairs to do a good large size meeting. But, there is no plugs and I believe no Wifi, according to another reviewer!
author: Desirea O.

description: Swoon. I'm late to Sightglass but I tried their iced coffee at the Ferry building and it was the best I've had in a long time. I needed to have another fix. I started with the iced coffee and a fruit kouign amann from B Patisserie (amazing) and a few hours later ended with a decaf espresso over the sea salt ice cream. Their collaborations (Salt & Straw, B Patisserie) are top notch and match their coffee and the people who work there are so incredibly friendly and helpful. I LOVE this place (and the space) and will be back soon!
author: Ruchi M.

description:
I think I found a new study spot!
Just wished they had wifi and some outlets...
Here on a Friday morning and surprised to see how many people don't have work on a weekday morning--so the place was pretty packed :( 
I'm assuming it'll be hard to find a seat if you're a big group trying to study.

Girl at the register was a little rude when I tried to ask her questions about the coffee but at least my latte came out super pretty!

The pistachio croissant looked REALLY good, but it was a too sweet for my liking... But they have a lot of other pastries I'm curious to try out :)

Pricey, but the crowd upstairs is generally pretty nice and courteous!
author: Maggie L.

description:
Cool environment. Nice staff.
Coffee is more on the sour side, cannot say I am a fan.
Though I would return for the cool environment.
Perhaps create a darker roast?
Not everyone enjoys sour coffee.
author: M E.

description:
First of all, how can a coffee shop exist in SOMA that doesn't offer WiFi?! I didn't even inquire before ordering, figuring it was a given that a massive caffeine temple in the city's startup capital would provide internet to its customers. Alas, I was wrong.

So I decided to take my joe to go, and the employee forgot to give me an insulating sleeve...which I didn't realize until I was a block away and my hand was burning. When I finally tasted the coffee (the Quick Cup) it was thin and watery. 

I don't typically do chains, but after this experience it was straight to Starbucks for me.
author: David Z.

description:
I had a hipstergasm when I came into this business. I said it. Every part of me that enjoys anything hipster just let out a huge release of happiness as I walked into this building. Walking in through the door into such a large awesome beautiful place made me want to cry. I spotted a gorgeous stuffed owl up on one of the railings, and the brick interior and lighting just set a great mood for wanting to drink coffee. The people working on making my coffee were I would dare say hipster. The people seated around the area sipping their coffee were probably the creators of what is considered hipster by the public. My favorite had to be the guy sitting by the window watching people walk by while wearing a jean jacket, jeans and a shtreimel.

Let me get to the coffee. I ordered a cappuccino which took them absolutely no time at all to make for me. On the top of the coffee I found that the barista made a heart into the top of my drink. I took one sip and found the most perfect combination of steamed milk and coffee. Through the whole drink, I never once had a bitter taste of coffee. I am a man who always takes his coffee black and without cream, but to have this gorgeous taste of mellow coffee without the addition of sugar had me almost in tears.

One of the ways I know I have found one of my most favorite spots is if I am constantly telling people about how great my experience was, even an hour later. I talked about this place an hour later, two hours later and even three hours after having my drink. I texted my sister, a SF Yelp elite, that she had to come out to this spot. Because of this business, I almost considered looking for a new apartment in SoMa nearby just so I could enjoy this coffee every day.
author: Michael M.

description:
I've recently (as in the last 15 minutes) come to terms with the fact that my roommate and I have different taste in coffee. (And in men.) I like to drink my coffee black- not fruity, not acidic- black, bold, smoky. She likes cappuccinos. (She likes her men to be hipsters with beards, and I like mine to be geeks and nerds with glasses.) (There is a difference.) 

So my roommate LOVES this place - its known for cappuccinos and hipsters with beards. She has been begging me to go everyday for the past 5 months. So I went today. I ordered a cup of something that had the least fruity description and said a prayer. Took a sip- all fruit and flowers. Drowned it in cream. It tasted better. But that's when I knew, no matter how hard you try, or how good intentioned you are, sometimes its just different strokes for different folks. Next time I'm getting espresso.
author: Emily D.

description: Fantastic coffee and decor. Clean and simple with no frills which lets you focus On The coffee. Also just great to sit in and be a part of. I strongly recommend the morning bun for breakfast with your coffee
author: Audrey W.

description:
Very hipster.
Great soy lattes.
Good mochas, but I prefer ganache over powder.
Very hipster.
author: James G.

description: Sightglass coffee is the best of all of the top flight coffees;  very smooth, robust aftertaste, wonderful long lasting caffeine and oh so very pleasant to drink.  And, the spacious place has plenty of room for private conversations and the expansive windows. with lots of light. make this a cheery place. It's worth every penny.
author: Hobson V.

description:
I like the ambiance of this place alot, its a mix of "coming here to read on my free afternoon" and "sort of casual business meeting" kind of vibe. The ceilings are high, the windows are floor to ceiling, the Sightglass logo is one of my artisanal coffee favorites. 

The coffee is sort of expensive, for what it is. $5 for a drip, not even single origin? That fired sirens in my head. My tongue was throbbing a little bit after the first sip. Not a good sign. After the initial cool down, the coffee was decent. I didn't think it stood out to me alot. 

More recently I've had a much better brew (Kenya) at an ice cream shop in berkeley (Sketch) . 

Service was mediocre, nothing special. I really want to like this place, but with all the other coffee places around, to garner 5 stars is a hard one.
author: Fion L.

description: Horrible service from a staff of super pretentious twenty-somethings. My friend asked for a couple of ice cubes for his Americano and was told no - it would degrade the quality . Fuck you! Give the customer what it wants. This is part of the "new culture" that is ruining (degrading) the quality of living here in SanFrancisco
author: Jimmy W.

description:
Pretty darn amazing coffee.  They only offer whole milk and almond milk however.  The place is very hipster and very beautiful inside.  Be your own mobile hot spot because there is no wi fi.

I recommend!
author: Melanie F.

description:
Absolutely amazing coffee. They really know their stuff, every drink I have ever tried here is just fantastic. The best latte in all of San Francisco in my opinion, Blue bottle & Four Barrel are great, but for espresso drinks I really think Sightglass stands above. Four Barrel is also amazing, but I really prefer sightglass. Their name comes from the transparency all of their coffees have, they really want you to taste all of the coffee's origins, and their efforts really show. My favorite breakfasts recently have been ordering a cappuccino & drip coffee. Great way to start the work day. Oh, and their space is absolutely stunning. An absolute must-see if you like coffee or are in the area. I never think twice about going out of my way to visit Sightglass when I am in SF. 

These guys know coffee. Seriously.
author: Danny P.

description: SightGlass coffee is a grand experience for anyone who loves the coffee house vibe. Plenty of space to roam and enjoy the sound and smells of coffee bliss. The 2nd floor seating offers a sweeping grand view from above, it's a great spot to perch and savor your drink. Front window seating serves up an endless dose of people watching as well as plenty of light for reading. The staff is sharp and very knowledgeable about all of the SightGlass offerings, so trust their guidance...you're in good hands.
author: Randy B.

description:
I left a law school final exam early so I could catch a train from Berkeley to SF in time to grab a cup of coffee from Sightglass before leaving the Bay for the holidays. I'm so glad I did.

I was excited to try it but didn't know what to expect (other than good coffee), and I came upon upon a spare little setup, a lone barista manning the storefront in near-darkness, with an iPad for transactions, a partially obscured view of construction work in progress. I bought a bag of Owl's Howl, another of the Blueboon Blend, and ordered a latte. The latte he served me is without a doubt one of the most glorious substances to have ever touched my lips.

Enjoyed the Blueboon Blend about as much once I got home, especially given the limitations of not having my own setup. With some help from a wonderful barista friend, pulled some shots of the Owl's Howl and got pretty buzzed after going through the entire bag in less than an hour. I probably didn't do it justice, but seriously, nothing but praise for this place.
author: Eddy P.

description: Gorgeous space. KA almond milk latte. Hard to find parking, but well worth the trials.
author: Andrew K.

description: Too bad the coffee doesn't life up to the space. Wow, this place is gorgeous. It's all wood, cement and steel.. probably one of the neatest spaces I've ever seen. You get a dark, evil vibe from the staff, though. And there are no eco "plastic" cups (like every great craft coffee place has) so you drink your iced coffee from a small paper cup. Is this 10 ounces? It's not cold brewed either but it's not bad. The latte is not the best but it is serviceable. Don't expect an eco straw or any sweetener besides sugar because they don't have any. At least they lent me their whole milk. I can deal with a few strict rules but this place is just too joyless.
author: Ari R.

description: Delicious, complicated coffee - complicated in a good way, not like the guy who forgot to tell you about his 5 other girlfriends. They option of almond milk was much appreciated, as well as the barista's willingness, after a pause, to make me a one shot cappuccino (the horror of not wanting the second shot). I also enjoyed the upper seating area - great spot for a catch-up and a few moments of undisturbed contemplation. I will have to find a way to just happen into Sightglass way more often now that I've tasted their splendidness!
author: Erin W.

description:
An airy, cavernous warehouse replete with steel and timber boasting impressive coffee-making paraphernalia.  Seemingly exotic bean bags line up the concrete walls and beautiful slabs of cantilevered wood serve as coffee tables.  It's hard not to be mesmerized by the inspiring space while you're getting their cup o' joe, which is a virtue on its own.  Their cappuccino is rich and smooth, and they have a variety of pastries to pair with.  But this is not just your typical neighborhood coffee house.  They take their coffee making seriously and want to elevate your experience by highlighting their special coffees presented in various brew methods and encouraging an open dialogue with the customer regarding its origin and characteristics. I must say for those coffee aficionados of the Bay Area, this is worth the trek across the new Bay Bridge.

One * short of 5 due to the lack of wifi :(
author: Gertrude V.

description:
The coffee was good, but the service was not, and that's the main reason for the low rating. I arrived at 7:30 on Sunday morning, so there was 1 other person in the coffee shop being helped by someone else, so I felt I could take my time. The purple-haired hipster  "helping" me was totally unhelpful, when I asked her a few questions. Mainly one word answers that only made me have to ask more questions, which I'm sure irritated her. I'm not a local, so sorry I needed some help. 
They only have light brews, which is fine, but some people like a bolder coffee...so don't expect that here. If you're a coffee snob, you'll love this place. But, if you're a normal "need my cup of morning coffee" drinker, you're not going to appreciate this place. I don't like Starbucks by any means, but Sightglass just came off as too pretentious for me to want to go back. I'm probably not the customer they're looking for - it's an unapproachable experience.
author: Julie M.

description: Came in to grab a quick breakfast/ pastry and coffee on my way out of the city. One of the best lattes with almond milk I've had in awhile.
author: Alex T.

description: Sightglass turns coffee into the experience it's meant to be.  Well worth the trip off Market Street.  It's everything you're told coffee should be without the pretentiousness so famous in this town,.
author: Caleb H.

description:
I've been here many times.

Today the cappuccino was awesome and the chocolate chip cookie was delicious. 

I've tried their mocha, sorry I didn't care for it, but I don't drink mochas often.
author: Anisha G.

description: We got the amazing ice cream here and the girl who was working at the counter was SO sweet! Her name is Erin and she was so informative and patient with us since it was our first time here. Give her a raise!
author: Callie S.

description: This space is inspirational. My wife and I were on our honeymoon and found a great deal of joy not only in the velvety smooth cappuccinos with spot on espresso we had, but in the whole ambiance as a whole as well. Thanks Sightglass!
author: Jakob M.

description:
If you can believe it, they've STILL not opened their storefront. What's the delay, guys?! 

Still, great coffee. But one point I forgot to make: they only have whole milk or soy (although I appreciate the fact that when I asked for non-fat I wasn't given a disdainful look when being told their choices, like some other coffee places in the city that shall remain nameless)...

What would make this place better? If they opened one in my neighborhood. Divisadero is calling, Sightglass!
author: Melanie N.

description: I have no idea how they manage to pay their rent with a space this nice. Coffee is good, vines are good. I've had a lot of business meetings here.
author: Alex S.

description:
Sightglass is a wonderful way to spend a day watching people, get some work done and have a lovely latte.

I've been here numerous times now and I feel like I haven't had a bad latte, hot chocolate or organic apple cider yet. I'm always happy with my beverages. For lactose free friends, yes, they have milk substitutes. 

The staff here is really great. They are always friendly when I visit, patient when I'm deciding (even when there is a line) and helpful.

I'd recommend coming here if you are in the city and need a pick me up.

There is usually lots of places to sit. There is a great open bench area in front of the store so you can people watch. There is also an area upstairs with large tables where you can sit with friends.

Overall a great coffee shop!
author: Joyce H.

description: I love this coffee shop! I loved the layout and the interior design. The space is roomy and large... The place is ironically cozy for being such a huge coffee shop. They also had really cute terrariums in the front. I loved that this place was animal friendly. There were so many cute dogs everywhere. The cappuccino was delicious and this place was the perfect coffee shop to go before I started out my day.
author: Dayae K.

description:
no wifi is a little strange but hey...the 80's are in!

It's trendy, but cute and has GF cake :)

I will return.
author: Min M.

description:
I am going to be "that person" haha.

This coffee place just really did nothing for me at all. The best part of this place is the interior is quite unique and the staff is nice. I don't necessarily like the dogs being allowed in the shop, but I can see where it is convenient for people to not have to tie their whining pooch outside the store while they grab coffee.

Far too hispter-ish for me though, it honestly seems like people love using their Macbooks and taking instgram pictures here than anything else.
The coffee was mediocre at best and I always asked for staff recommendations because I am the out-of-towner. The coffee is also over-priced, but I also hail Chicago where the prices for anything are significantly cheaper.

I could name many other coffee shops that I have enjoyed in San Fran quite more than this  one so I don't understand the craze, but to each their own!
author: J.S. E.

description:
This is what you would wish for when ample money can be invested in the whole business. 
Everything about this joint is really good...
Love the feel, the design, love the spaciousness and the coffee was great..... and a great place to hang out in....sit there for work, to study, catch up friends or simply relax....fits all options so well.
Looking forward to coming back...
author: Mick A.

description: Great coffee and nice atmosphere. It's nice to sit with a perfect latte watching the next batch of coffee roasting. If it were closer to where I live, I would be there right now!
author: Ed M.

description: Was my first stop in Frisco and was a good decision. They Vanilla Cold brew was delicious, just wish I had the option to ask for no flavoring or milk. If so maybe I was just to new to notice.
author: Xavier L.

description: One of my favorite coffee spots in the Bay. Can't go wrong here...if you don't mind the hipster crowds...then again...I frequent this place...who am I to judge?? I'm just here for the coffee
author: Ed O.

description: Black coffee was ok. Maybe a bad batch? But you stay for the atmosphere. You get to see them make the coffee right there. Holy it's spaciously beautiful and a great place to people watch.
author: Precious C.

description: The hippest of the hip in the new SF coffee scene. Built in a converted warehouse, it's bright and airy and smells amazing. They roast the coffee right there so the air is filled with the warm and spicy smell of beans. There is plenty of seating upstairs and standing bars downstairs. They have an assortment of yummy fresh pastries and some cool branded gear, too. While it seems to be the shared work space for many young creatives, I was surprised at how few electricity outlets there were. It might be intentional...
author: Jasmine W.

description: Not a work spot. No WiFi or outlets. On the plus it seems well trafficked and the coffee tastes good. Some very pretty people.
author: Harry M.

description:
Worlds worst cup of coffee. AMPM has better coffee. 
I gave it two stars because I have only tried the coffee. The espresso drinks and pastries LOOK good and they have a very nice atmosphere. 
The place was packed and a line was formed so I am missing something. Not great service and If you can't get the basics (coffee) right then you don't get my business. 
$3.00 for a 6oz cup is over priced. I will take my business to Peets.
author: Caleb A.

description:
There is a beam of light descending from Heaven streaming through the skylights in this amazing space directly onto the barista who will make you one Hell of an espresso. Single origin is upstairs. 

Rating Scale:
1 Star: Avoid the town in which this place is located just to be safe.  
2 Star: With so many great places to choose from, why risk this one?
3 Star: I'll try it again or consume here in a pinch.
4 Star: I go here regularly if financially and/or calorically feasible.
5 Star: I look forward to taking my wife or friends here.
author: Michael T.

description: Literally the worst. Pretentious, sickeningly sweet coffee and no wifi? No thank you. I ditched my coffee and left.
author: Kaylie E.

description:
Drink/Service: Coffee is smooth and the kick ass baristas add a rich comfort to your experience. If it weren't for the $4 price tag, there would be multiple trips per day.

Eat: Can't remember the price of the pistachio croissant off the top of my head but it's marvelous. Atypical of a common buttery croissant that has the capacity to make you feel like you had an embarrassing amount of butter, the pistachio croissant has a particular density that makes you feel like you ate something substantial and not conspicuously fatty. And paired with the coffee-- worth a try!

Etc:

- You can come sans bike lock because they allow for you to station your bike inside!

- There really. is. no. wi-fi. Also, I've found outlets hard to come by. In fact, I have yet to find one. But it works well because the combination of no wi-fi/outlets forces you to concentrate for x amount of time if you need to get non-internet-required work done.

- You really can't go wrong with seating. However, if you prefer to spend a day at Sightglass, I'd avoid seating against the front window as the sun can become an unwanted friend during later hours.
author: Nina Y.

description: I really like sightglass! It's a super cool venue and decorated with terrariums, lots of wood, and the roaster is right in the middle for everyone to see. I made a special stop on my way to OSL and was a bit disappointed by the vanilla iced cold brew w almond milk. I usually get the regular coffee and am always super satisfied. The vanilla cold brew is super sweet. If you like sweet coffee, its probably up your alley. I think I'll try to the nitro cold brew next time without any sweetner. If you can adjust the sweetness of the vanilla cold brew, I think it could be super tasty.
author: Maryam Q.

description: The Vanilla Ice Brewed coffee was delicious and I grabbed some beans to take home to my husband who wasn't on this trip with me. It's our Sunday enjoyment coffee and is delicious every time we drink it.
author: Julia H.

description:
I had the cappuccino and it was a medium roast, full-bodied yet smooth drink. Meticulous attention to quality here. Beautiful foam art on top; I always love that.

The space is hip: industrial, arty, spare, airy. Currently, Sightglass serves drinks just off the sidewalk from a kiosk which is outfitted with a fancy espresso machine. They also serve individual drip coffees, three blends from which to choose, and I'll be heading back to try one of those. The space sort of resembles a loading dock, adorned only by the reclaimed wood shelf and the elegant piece of wall art gracing one wall. There is a bench for those who want to linger.

This configuration will change soon, though- a peak behind the curtain reveals a huge warehouse space waiting to be filled, currently being built-out to include not only their immense roaster (they do roast the beans on the premises) but also a very spacious cafe, complete with a gorgeous wave-form bar. Skylights bathe the room in a warm light, contributing to the airiness of the space and placing the gleaming roaster in a natural spotlight. I can't wait for the expansion to be complete; Sightglass is industrial chic at its best and a perfect reflection of the vibe of the neighborhood it inhabits. Until then, I'll enjoy the immediacy of ordering directly from the cart- which is fun in that it feels, 'under the radar', like being 'in' on a secret . . . at least for now;-)

Service is casually friendly, knowledgeable and inked. You can count on a quality cup, here and look forward to more good things when the space is finished!
author: Mark N.

description:
If coffee is a religious experience for you, then this place will be great.
If you want Wifi, quiet, a white mocha or a large coffee then this place will disappoint and/or annoy.
The peak of SF trendy taste where you feel like your should check your attire for fashion compliance on entry.
author: Andrew P.

description: Sightglass is as good as it gets.  I have been to top coffee shops all over the US and put Sightglass in a solid top 3 shops.  Great atmosphere with plenty of room.  They toast almost all day and bag in the shop so you get to see all aspects while enjoying amazing coffee.  They also had great pastries and helpful staff.  This is the only shop in town that we went to multiple times.
author: Charles O.

description: Gorgeous architecture, open space, great lighting, nerdy vibes when you need to geek out on tha mac. I like.
author: Denise M.

description:
There's no denying the coffee is excellent but the place still feels like a work in progress. There's a printed menu on the counter (took me awhile to find it).  Options are limited to coffee of various forms, including pour over drip style drinks.  I didn't spot any pastries at all. They don't have low fat or non-fat milk (why?!) and the drinks come in one size.

* Latte with soy milk ($3.50): beautiful foam art, rich, deep flavor, but it wasn't hot enough and it was definitely small.  

Loved the cup with the Viola Swamp is watching you stamp but it doesn't make up for all the other flaws and inconveniences.
author: Lolia S.

description:
I HATE this place.

I needed some caffeine and I always walked past Sightglass' classy interior, so why not? At the entrance is a swarm of flies. Literally a swarm of flies. Be sure to keep your mouth closed as you walk in. Besides the shoe-gazing soundtrack blaring in the background, this place is somehow really quiet. I didn't HEAR anyone at all. It's a bit unnerving especially when it's supposed to be a coffee shop. I hear friendly chatter even at the Legion of Honor.

Their menu is a teeny tiny print-out situated on their counter. Beverages come only in one size and they don't even state how big it is. It's really odd when you're standing there trying to read the menu and the idle employee at the counter doesn't greet you or pay any attention. I ask for "The Hooker's Mocha," but he throws up his hands and says "I can't hear you!" Ummmm, wtf. I was so shocked by the rudeness I still ordered it and handed over my money. What the hell just happened?? Eh... but what if the beverages are amazing?

So I wait for my drink and it's not so bad I guess; however, the longer I stand there the pretentiousness just sinks in. Sightglass feels so cold, so fake, and so dead that I cannot believe the amount of rave reviews on this place. On the outside Sightglass looks really clean and simple, but inside it feels like an empty level from DOOM. There are a lot of yuppies and hipsters here. A LOT. I thought I've been to some pretentiousness places in my day, but this takes the cake. The irony of it all is that along with all of their coffee grinds and gizmos, they sell frisbees too. Are you kidding me??? This dead, rude, obnoxious place has the audacity to sell frisbees along with their elitist coffee equipment? HELL does not serve whimsical items like frisbees. Yet they won't serve iced coffee to anyone?

As I ponder the peculiarity of selling frisbees in a coffee shop, I see a customer fiddling with one of the coffee drips that they're selling. I'm not embellishing when I say that an employee walks around the guy and gives him a dead as nails dismissive look that says, "WHAT THE HELL DO YOU THINK YOU'RE DOING? YOU AREN'T GOOD ENOUGH FOR THAT." Instead of approaching the customer and asking if he needs any help or questions answered, he just ignores the guy.

My name is finally called and my drink does actually look nice with a bit of coffee art. I graciously say thank you yet only get an apathetic thanks in return. Now I'm not asking for everyone in here to kiss my ass but this is ridiculous. I've just witnessed three different employees be incredibly rude.

Seating is a bit of a joke. They fill up a tiny cup and saucer all the way to the brim and they expect me to walk 20 feet to a counter, or walk up a long staircase to the second floor. I don't mind if you gave me a bigger cup and not filling it up to the brim. It's just crazy with me having to carry this thing without spilling it. Each drop is worth like 50 cents! And it's so stingy small!!!

So I manage to get to the counter. My mocha is lacking in flavor and character. The acid is pretty nice but it's boring. Yeah this place sucks. Absolutely no character to it all at. The customers are equally unfriendly. Plus it turns out that they don't have any wifi for customers at all. WOW. Just, WOW.

____

........SUCKS
author: Michael H.

description:
I love love love this place.  This is my favorite place in the neighborhood.
It's a great place to meet up with people and also a great place to work quietly. 
They are super dog friendly. 
I really hope this place doesn't get super crowded like ritual.
author: Skye W.

description: Stunning coffee shop. Walk in and be greeted by fresh roasting coffee and a great barista bar to order your drink. You can also eat and enjoy your coffee upstairs. Also has bathrooms.
author: Reid Y.

description: Hookers mocha is the way to start everyday.... Great espresso awesome atmosphere
author: Chris P.

description: Randomly passed this place, took one look inside, and knew I had to stop in for a cup of coffee.  The atmosphere here is awesome and very spacious.  You basically sit right in the middle of their coffee company.  They have upstairs seating as well as some seating on the ground floor.  Not much of a menu, but that's fine, makes it easier to make a decision at the register!  Sipping a cup of coffee from the second floor was just very relaxing and nice to get off the street for a break.
author: Bryson L.

description:
There is a very special place for hipsters and that is Sightglass Coffee.  The space is industrial spare with the requisite terrariums out in front and seats that look salvaged from an old bar/school/factory/naval ship/alien space craft.  This space is cool and it was obviously designed to look cool.  Mission accomplished.  

The coffee is nice but I prefer Four Barrel or Blue Bottle.   BB mainly bc of the waffle.
author: Monica L.

description:
Hands down best warehouse/old industrial building conversion I've seen. They roast in house and the Roaster is a cool centre piece of the room.

Coffee is great, don't come here if you're looking for a Starbucks like experience, the choice is limited, but all options are good. Pastries are also great and very fresh, I like the ham and Gruyere morning bun.

The smell of coffee roasting makes this a nice place to hang out, and the lack of wifi makes it a very sociable gathering place for all ages/types.
author: John S.

description:
If your a yuppie you will like the designer styled warehouse... 
If you care about coffee stay away from this place. 

With only one small size of coffee which taste watered down you'll be thoroughly disappointed. I wanted to compensate for their small coffee size and and asked for a Red Eye. The waitress said "What is that?" .. Were not off to a good start here... After asking the bartender she retorted "We don't do that here." Uhhh wtf.

 These guys make Blue Barrel coffee seem like a great deal. Needless to say the workers and patrons here care more about looking cool than coffee, and I sure as hell won't be back.

Their coffee was so bad, after I drank my cup i went to Starbucks and got a triple expresso on ice just to get the taste out of my mouth and some caffeine in the system.  

PS. it was cheeper than Sightglass' drip coffee.... And tasted better.
author: Graham G.

description:
The staff is extremely rude. I walked up to the counter and asked for a menu. The "barista" let out a sarcastic "yeah" and tossed it to me, then immediately turned around to talk to her coworker about some party. 

The coffee honestly tastes like garbage. There's not much else to it. 

If you want the rudeness, but with decent coffee, I recommend Blue Bottle Coffee which is a few blocks away.
author: Yuri R.

description:
Here's the thing about Sightglass: the coffee is fantastic.  For true coffee lovers, this is the place you will live your coffee dreams on a daily basis.  

That being said, for the more casual coffee fan who happens to work nearby, I grow weary of the oft-encountered attitude of superiority emanating from the place. Most people are friendly, yet I sense the all-knowing coffee fanatics are staring me down and wondering what the hell I am doing there. 

My favorite thing to order is their vanilla iced cold brew - not quite a latte, not quite an iced coffee, the taste is delicious, but buyer beware: unless you are used to a steady diet of caffeine, anything you order from here might give you a bigger jolt than you bargained for!
author: Damita C.

description:
I love you coffee. I love bougie coffee places too. The decor is very nice as well! GIANT WOODEN DOOR! One should not complain that it's $4 a cup....you knew what you were getting yourself into.
