Anyways I got the La Planada (Columbia), had notes of coconut, mango and grape. It was very smooth and interestingly enough i started catching those notes at the end of each sip (you know that after taste that's kind of left in your mouth....yeah, it was an after taste of fruityness. I'M INTO IT!)
author: Priscilla W.

description:
The coffee is alright, but that soy cappuccino is really something special. Some coffee is strictly functional (office coffee), but I enjoy my cappuccino as an indulgent treat. I used to skip my company shuttle just so I could enjoy a cup every Friday!

The ambiance of the coffee shop is wonderful. There's lots of professionals mixed in with hipsters; the upstairs balcony is great for people watching...just saying.
author: Caroline W.

description: Its a very hipster and raw coffee shop. Customer all seems like regulars there. They do in house coffee packing. Which you can see their in house semi production.
author: Kmk H.

description:
Quiet on a Saturday early afternoon! Great ambiance; good roasts (lots of flavor. Pretty subtle, though: not going to hit you in the face).

Excellent place to read, chat, sketch, etc.

I appreciate the lack of freelancers and their cord jungles.
author: Alana P.

description: Great spot for an afternoon coffee.  Lots of seating, but no wifi!
author: Jacklyn L.

description: Finally made it here after hearing so many good things about it. It definitely lives up to the hype. A great open space to work or converse over pretty amazing coffee. I was helped by an employee named Jess at the register, and she just did a phenomenal job walking me through my options. I ended up having the vanilla cold brew, which was one of the best iced coffees I've ever had. Can't wait to go back!
author: David D.

description:
It's crazy to think that some people think this place has better coffee than Blue Bottle. Don't get me wrong, the coffee is good, not great. 

Also, at 5 bucks for an individually poured cup of joe, the price is a bit unreasonable compared to some other awesome SF shops.

The space is really cool, lots of cool coffee making goodness and industrial accents.

There isn't a wifi network and surprisingly limited cell service so not ideal for doing work...maybe that's intentional, or maybe just an oversight.
author: Devin R.

description:
Huge open space, but not in the greatest of neighborhoods.

The coffee beans are roasted more on the light side, so if you're looking for darker roasts, this might not suit your taste buds. I'd say that the coffee here is meant to be enjoyed without any cream or sugar so that you can really taste the flavor notes of their roasted selection, because otherwise, you can totally overpower its lighter taste.

I wasn't too big of a fan of their mocha or cappuccino, but it was still good. Straight-up coffee is definitely where it's at. Just make sure you know your surroundings if you come here a little too late in the evening.
author: Patrick K.

description:
I want to love this place.  It is right by where I work. It occupies a space that was a waste land until the owners transformed it into a really cool, open-area, plenty-of-seating hangout.  The servers are generally pretty nice, and on the whole, this place should be a real standout.

Yet, one comes to a coffee shop for  . . . well, the coffee.  And here Sightglass comes up short.  I have twice paid the rather pricy ticket-of-admission for a drip coffee, black, nothing added; and twice I have to say I was very, very disappointed.  I found the coffee to be bitter (not acidic) with more watery notes than the "molasses" and whatnot that the menu promised.  To my mind it tasted like any bagged coffee I could pick up at Safeway.  I don't know that I want to risk another $4+ on a third try.  Shucks.
author: Mark V.

description: Try the Ethiopian pour over, it's my fav. Free wifi and open room with lots of natural lighting... What's not to love?
author: Shir K.

description:
Great place to get coffee. They roast their own and take pride in what they do. Comfortable atmosphere. 

They do coffee right.
author: Susan J.

description:
Sightglass is one of the best coffee shops in San Francisco.

Great coffee, great atmosphere. Only reason I didn't give them five stars is because of the physical location and friendliness of staff.
author: Zachary K.

description:
I ended up having some time to kill around the corner from this coffee shop, and thought I'd check it out. I have to say that the cafe is absolutely beautiful, so I was impressed while I went in. However, my being impressed came to a quick end when I discovered the cheapest cup of coffee available was $3.50, and this is for *pre-brewed* coffee. I thought, what the hell, let's see what the hype is about. So I ended up with a small cup of expensive coffee, added a little cream and sugar, and proceeded to be utterly unimpressed.  Their coffee can't begin to compare to Philz or Blue Bottle, and I don't understand why their prices are so high for something my cheap neighborhood cafe can do way better (and bigger) for $1.75.

Oh, and just in case I wanted to get any work done, this is apparently the only cafe in the city without wireless. Sigh.  

Sorry, but you'll have to do better than a pretty building and trendy vibe to impress me.
author: Carla B.

description:
Enter the Slayer, a $16,000 handmade espresso machine from Seattle handled by, for the Saturday morning I was there, two perfectly kind baristas in heart scarves and leotards.

Although a roasting facility took up the majority of the building, the coffee digs were a rollup loading bay in front, with a plank for a bench which was being warmed by hipsters huddled over their espressos and phones.

The coffee itself was earthy, complex, and almost as good as the weather.

Definitely would have liked to sit inside and mingled with the perfect sneaker and stickered laptop set, but the place was packed, which is roughly 4 people and a dog.

Walk around and walk here, soon.  Really, the macchietto is fine and waiting for you.
author: Jason A.

description:
I've had the opportunity to experience three different Sightglass blends, plus their "highly regarded" espresso.  This is what I think of Sightglass Coffee.

Yuck:  Foldgers = Sightglass = Yuban 
Tolerable:  Starbucks 
Good:  Peaberry's = Peet's 
Gold:  Blue Bottle = High Wire

Don't let Sightglass trick you with their quality non-shiney whole beans and warm aroma.  In truth the taste is mellow, bordering on rotten citrus.  No matter how many beans you use, the real flavor of coffee is missing.  I drink my coffee black, but I've found even by doctoring up Sightglass coffee with tons of cream and sugar only makes it taste like a watered-down pool of dishwater.  BLECH!!!

If you want to mimic the taste of a cup of Sightglass, warm up 1/3 cup of orange juice, mix it with 2/3 cup of hot coffee.  Voila.  You can now enjoy yourself a cup of Sightglass coffee... without the long wait.
author: Gracie O.

description:
Incredible coffee in an amazing space.

I'm not a native San Franciscan but I am a coffee snob. This was recommended to me as the best place to get coffee in San Francisco, even over Four Barrel and Blue Bottle. It completely rocked my world. I went here every day during a 8-day stay. Sometimes I went twice, it was that good. I bought a bag of coffee to bring home.

They select coffee from individual farmers all over the world, no mass produced stuff. The available coffees change daily. They serve coffee by the cup, generally preferring the pour-over method.  This looks incredibly pretentious and over-the-top (pour the water in a circle and don't let it touch the filter!!!!111oneone) and I would scoff if it didn't taste so delicious. It easily competes with the coffee from a $10,000  Clover machine, but you can buy pour-over gear for under $100, including from Sightglass itself!

The coffee was amazing - bright, flavourful, lightly acidic. I tried as many different types as I could, and I wasn't let down.

The Sightglass space they've built is just beautiful too, in contrast to ugly/crackhead SOMA. It's spacious, minimal, and classy. They do their own roasting on site, and it's fun to watch them go through the process. It's a great place to do tech celebrity sighting as well; I saw Jack Dorsey (Twitter & Square co-founder) come in here one morning after securing my morning cup of crack. Sightglass was one of the original Square test sites.

The only knock I can point out is that they didn't have Wi-Fi. It was such a cool space that I wanted to just hang out there, enjoy my coffee and do some work or browse the web. I'm sure this was a very intentional decision though, the place is too wonderfully designed for it to be an oversight. I imagine they are trying to keep the focus on the coffee and socialization and not get a bunch of d-bags hanging around all day with their bluetooth headsets. I can't fault 'em for that.
author: Jeremy G.

description: Amazing ambience! Loved the latte and mocha! Would definitely go back.
author: Deepti A.

description: modern industrial wearhouse vibe...open sliding glass walls...interiors quite airy...goliath roaster the main display...clean glass, sparkling steel, modern finished wood and smooth concrete interiors...the center stage being the counter, hipsterish baristas and coffee creations...requesting a coffee...what kind?...regular coffee?...a sightglass coffee novice...coffee by the cup menu...taking a simple blend...blueboon blend ordered...individual care and drip-to-order...taking longer, but a meticulous procedure....small wait and called...blueboon cup having darker taste...slightly stronger acidic notes...hint of citrus/fruit flavor...enjoying coffee and mention the pastries fantastic rich...foam artwork lattes...interesting artisan blends and roasts...
author: Hen A.

description:
The service was so slow here I started laughing out loud half way through the girl making my regular cup of coffee. After waiting almost 20 minutes for my regular cup of coffee with only three other orders being made in front of me I was literally waiting for the camera guy to pop out from his hidding place and tell me I was on Candid Camera. 

I could have walked to Bed Bath and Beyond to buy a coffee maker, Trader Joes for coffee, back to my house, and made my own cup of coffee faster than the rude, airhead-ish "barista" who poured water into a coffee filter. She was the only person making coffee while all three of the other workers hung out and played with their ipads and chatted. She "had to" rearrange all of the extra coffee filters and empty cups in between making each cup of coffee.

All of my other reviews are always super nice, but this is the slowest service I've ever experienced in my whole life and it must be noted. My boyfriend and I couldn't stop laughing...the service was so slow it was comical. Only come here if you have at least 20 minutes to spare.
author: Juliet S.

description: The pastries were delicious and the coffee was excellent.  The atmosphere is interesting, everything looks new but rustic.  I enjoyed having morning coffee and breakfast here.  I would recommend this place to everyone.
author: Adam C.

description: Wish this place were closer to where I live. It's the bomb! Amazing coffee, awesome ambiance, and lots of space to camp out and plug your computer in to get some work done. Coffee is great. Would be nice to have some more food options though. But overall a total WIN.
author: V T.

description:
Nice place to enjoy your coffee. It probably has one of the best interior design in the Bay for being a coffee shop. I do love their coffee. It would be nice to have more options on the menu - more coffee, drink options. I'm not sure if there's wi-fi....

For those not familiar with the area...there is really no free parking. It's typical of San Francisco so walk or take public transit..oh, you can bike here too since they have a nice bike rack.
author: Nixon L.

description:
This place has it all.

Excellent coffee.  In-house roaster.  Beautiful, open, two-story space.  Delicious pastries.  Great music selection (Loveless on vinyl!!!).

My only complaint would be that the place seems to lack a relationship with the customer.  The employees are nice, but don't really go out of their way to make your experience top notch.

I'd frequent this place over the nearby competitor (Blue Bottle in Mint Plaza) any day, however.
author: Rob W.

description:
Perfection. Tired of overly sweet, dull coffee from Starbucks or Peets, Sightglasss is entirely the opposite. No need for sugar or cream. The drip has spectacular flavor with the precise amount of caffeine needed to perk up your morning.  The lattes and cappuccinos are to die for. The Baristas have the San Francisco "coffee snob" attitude but with a smile on their face and the knowledge of the exact timing and technique to make the perfect cup of coffee.  I must say Sasha is fabulous, with the best attitude and warmest greeting. 

A must- the gluten free orange cake is just HEAVEN.
author: Juliana O.

description:
I landed a job in SOMA about a month ago.  Coming from the Silicon Valley, I was so used to having a Starbucks caddy corner from work, or anywhere I happened to be.  In SOMA, there isn't a Starbucks or even a Peet's anywhere near me!  But, I'm not necessarily complaining either; change is good!

I've been to Blue Bottle which I think is liquid perfection in a recyclable paper cup, but the coworkers kept telling me to check out Sightglass as they prefer it over BB.  Being the caffeine addict that I am, I gave it a shot and invited a coworker along who hasn't made it out to SG either.

First off, the space is amazing!  I love the open air, industrial and modern feel of it all.  SG brings a whole new meaning to the term, "coffee shop."  They import the beans, roast the beans, package the beans, sell the beans, ship the beans, grind the beans and brew the beans all right there.  You won't have a hard time to find a place to sit, that's for sure.  SG makes BB feel like a closet!

We got in line and the coworker and I were looking around, trying to locate their menu.  We got to the counter and saw these little clipboards, which was apparently the menu.  I asked the cashier for an iced beverage suggestion and he suggested one of two Columbian blends they have, so I took him up on it.  The coworker got a latte.

It took about 10-minutes for my beverage to be prepared.  It was a little difficult to determine who's drink was who's as they're not really yelling out the names and the little sticky notes with the names are affixed on the counter, facing the barista.

When my coworker and I got our drinks and took our first sip, we looked at each other and simply raised an eyebrow.  Although the coffee was good, it wasn't mind blowing to that of BB.  The coffee I had was a bit acidic, but that's what the cashier recommended.  Adding cream and sugar definitely helped and eventually enjoyed it.

If you appreciate coffee in all forms and senses, you'll admire SG.  It's too bad they don't serve sandwiches/salads; they certainly have the space and right ambiance for it.  I think it's an excellent spot to meet a friend or client to chat business with.

Overall, I like Sightglass but, I love Blue Bottle.
author: Nick D.

description:
l o v e  this place  
it's big, but still a great place to sit down! the atmosphere is nice - fav coffee place in sf
author: Maren E.

description:
First off, the coffee is great. The line takes forever, which I get - you're doing it by the cup. But when I ask for a little butter with my scone, there's no reason to tell me "we're not a restaurant, we are a coffee shop." No shit, passive-agressive hipster girl. I just paid $4 for about 4 ounces of coffee and milk. I'm AWARE you're a coffee shop. I lost the taste for the scone after that. 

Work on the snarkiness. Be nice.

I had a hard time giving this 3 instead of 2 stars, but I have had previous experiences that were okay, so I'm going on average.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Was at sightglass for a quick stop. Had a macchiato - should've really gone for the affogato. The macchiato was kick ass. The cookies are awesome as well. A very spacious large coffee shop. The staff is extremely knowledgable and makes great suggestions - so ask if you are confused. My only issue with this place is the restroom - they need to invest in some deodorizers (:
author: Prashant R.

description:
Price & Quality- Prices here are fair & the quality is outstanding. Their coffee is beautifully served and roasted. Yum yum yum!

Service- The workers here are super friendly!

Vibe- This place is amazing in that there are so many places to sit with a nice overlooking view at the top! A lot of people too! 

Will i come back?- Whenever i'm in the neighborhood. The location is a bit far from me personally but the quality is a can't beat! Great coffee and a must try for any SF coffee fan!
author: Moises L.

description:
Context: coffee around 11:30 am on a Saturday morning meeting friends.

Atmosphere: place is huge with high ceilings and lots of light. No wifi but lots of people on myfi. About ten people in line and it took about ten minutes to get waited on and another five to get the coffee.  There are two floors. Upstairs is a small special espresso bar, downstairs is the regular coffee.  There are tables and counter like seating. Upstairs there are about five big wood slab tables that seat four and two enormous communal tables and several smaller tables. It's a big space but it was also very warm. Downstairs there are lots of places to stand against small counters and a few tables. Windows overlook 7th street. Two bathrooms and a shared sink area. 

Food: they serve a small but varied selection of pastries including a very yummy pistachio croissant that is kind of caramelized and layered and chewy. They also have regular croissants,poppy seed cake, some vegan options, cookies and these veggie pastries.

Coffee: be prepared almost all they serve is caffeinated coffee. No soda, no seltzer water, a few juices, but no tea. They will do a cappuccino, a latte, and a mocha. The latte was fantastically rich and creamy and smooth with at least a full cup of whole milk. It felt I credibly indulgent and reminded me of ritual in its combination of robust flavor with no bitter afterburn. Cappuccino was very full flavored.
author: Vivek V.

description:
Great place, on par with the other great coffee shops in SF.

Cappuccino Review
They pour a New Zealand flat white style which is micro foam in an 8oz cup, same as Four Barrel, Blue Bottle, Ritual, etc.

The Shot:
Spot on, no complaints at all.

The Milk:
Clover I think. Not bad but not as good as Straus Family Creamery.

Service:
Friendly and quick - they use Square which for me is convenient. Jose was my barista and was very informative and personable.

Ambiance:
Down to earth, hipster-ish, large seating area - not sure if they have WiFi, I was in and out pretty quick

Conclusion:
Everything was on par with the other greats in SF like Blue Bottle and Four Barrel (still my favorite).
author: Bernard F.

description:
I really dont want to give this place a 5, cause it has no wi-fi, but they deserve it. the coffee, pastries, and atmosphere are all 5 worthy. 

walking into sightglass, you might feel out of place cause its sooo hipster, but go in. its worth it. 

I recommend getting the blue berry croissant. It is my favorite croissant ever!! I normally dont like fruits or jams in my pastries, but they find the nice balance that i actually really really enjoy it. It is a bit pricey at $4, but its worth it. when i go there and it's sold out, I actually feel a bit sad. haha, really though. i do. 

back to the coffee. Its terrific! The macchiato is strong and is not milked down like at starbucks. its served in a little shot cup. 

hipster sighting during one visit: 
-a person knitting. 
-5 macs & 2 ipads between 5 people sitting on the front windowsill. what are you guys -doing if there is no wifi? 
-a guy with a "christian life" shirt
-a woman sitting cross legged on the floor waiting for her coffee. 
-a couple of dogs just chillin
author: Genica R.

description: Sightglass is a coffee roaster located in SoMa, 7th street. Its sprawling space is and beautiful and industrial with an aroma of coffee permeating through the warehouse. Like many SF cafes they do not have wifi, and discourage the use of technology. A successful coffee shop like Sightglass does not sell just coffee; they sell pastries from b. patisserie. Coffee blends are light and deep. Shipments take off to various coffee shops around Bay Area.
author: Jay C.

description:
Mm mm delicious Americano!

This place. Some of the best coffee in the city, and the venue is absolutely fantastic. Amazingly chill and open space. Really fun watching them roast the beans. I could see booking this venue for a larger event being a really good idea.
author: Benjamin C.

description:
Nestled in the heart of  San Francisco's Soma District, Siteglass Coffee shop gloriously radiates; roasting and grinding, crafting the worlds finest coffee beans and drinks. Siteglass is the essence of the modern coffee shop. At least once a day, I make the voyage to this place, as if some Hobbit on an epic adventure to the fires of Mount Doom, only with boiling hot coffee awaiting me as a reward, instead of lava; One sip of the black gold, (coffee, that is) and you will know of which I speak. It's magical, it's transformative, I laughed I cried, it changed my life.

Siteglass has a dual coffee station on the ground floor, which are full serviced - they offer excellent Americanos, Espressos, and Lattes... and an absolutely decadent Mocha - legendary across the seven seas of coffee beanery. This nectar can be brought home, as they grind their own beans and bag them up. If you are fortunate enough to visit during the roasting, then you will know true bliss, only previously attainable by several lifetimes of Buddhist  meditation.

The pastries are amazing, but sadly, they are bad for your diet, because you can't just eat one, you are compelled, by shear flavor, to order at least two, preferably three. Better get there early, because they go fast. I once saw two people fighting over a chocolate croissant - one of them being President Barak Obama - I can't believe someone would fight the POTUS over a croissant, but there you have it.
author: Delilah W.

description:
The cafe welcomes you in a beautiful and rustic large room with wooden beamed ceilings and a loft. They treat coffee as art. This is evident from the serving cups and the beautiful patterns made on the coffee top with crema and frothed milk. 

The coffee is roasted in the same room! 

I wish that they had at least some creative coffee drinks. Their coffee menu is classic.
author: Kan P.

description: Worst service ever. They don't have a clear system of getting your coffee so I got super cold coffee and waited way too long while a bunch of baristas were just hanging out and socializing. Assistant manager had the worst response and no sense of customer service.  Who cares how good the coffee is when they don't have a sense of caring about their customers and making it right.
author: Neha A.

description:
Currently my favorite cafe in San Francisco. I love how oily, fruity and delicious the espresso are at Sightglass. And the interior design of the space pleases me greatly. Add tasty savory pastries and Square payments (with my tab open) and I'm a very happy customer.  

I really couldn't dream of having a better neighborhood cafe.
author: Maïa Cybelle C.

description: Was randomly in the neighborhood and stopped in. The space the shop is in deserves 5 stars alone. The Almond Latte I had was very good as well. I see people are complaining about the lack of wifi - my book didn't seem to care.
author: Kevin F.

description: So much hip. So much wow.  Great coffee though. Oh and side bike rack. Because why not.
author: Shamil R.

description:
Loaded up the iPad, and headed here for coffee, eats, and most importantly...to search the job boards. 

Latte and a roll, $7.50. Me: how do I connect to your WiFi? Dude at counter: we don't have WiFi. 

Oh, guess I'll enjoy my teacup sized latte.

 Where's the cinnamon? "We don't have any."
author: Kevin M.

description: I love the ambiance and the look. I prefer four barrel coffee, but its just a matter of taste.
author: Sal R.

description: Probably my favorite coffee place in San Francisco.  It's a little too hipster for me, but the coffee and snacks were delicious and there's a good amount of seating.  Plenty of bike racks, spacious layout, friendly baristas... great place overall.
author: Arthur A.

description:
I want to love this place. I heard great things about it from friends but my experience here wasn't so stellar. The cashier was a bit snobby; smiles were a rarity and when I asked the cashier a question regarding the different type of coffee's and which she preferred, she made it sound like I was beneath her because I didn't know the difference between a sumatra and an affogato. Well... duh! That's why I asked for your suggestion... ask me anything about wine and I would have answered you with a smile and enthusiasm.

Anyway, my friend and I placed our order and the barista made our coffee. She was very delicate with the making of our coffee which was nice to see. We ordered a regular coffee and a soy latte. I've had better soy latte's but the coffee was pretty good. I forgot the name of it though since I was quite perturbed by the customer service.

All in all, the ambiance and how the coffee shop itself is set up is fantastic. I love the earthy feel, the roominess of the place and its two level sitting area. It's a really great place to study or chat with a friend which earns it 2 stars and 1 star for the coffee. What would make it even better? Customer service.
author: Kathleen R.

description: Tried the vanilla cold brew after reading about it here and it did not disappoint. Creamy and delicious.  Space was amazing, great environment.  Will return and will recommend to others.
author: Blake A.

description:
I love this coffee shop right on 7th St in SOMA. This "coffee shop" is actually inside a spacious warehouse with great natural lighting and two floors of seating. There is a coffee roaster near the entrance and you can see it in action every day (AFAIK usually in the afternoons). This place offers excellent espresso drinks, hand-drip coffees and single-origin beans by the pound (I recommend their Blueboon Blend). If you're not yet a coffee addict, I suggest you learn more about the coffee process by attending their coffee cuppings (tastings) available daily. What exactly is the difference you ask in sight/smell/taste between various coffee origins and roastings? What do you mean by bright vs smooth for liveliness, or full-bodied vs medium for body? Well come here to find out and appreciate that cup of coffee even more! I guarantee you will never want to drink instant coffee again.

I've had Sightglass' lattes and cappuccinos. The drinks were very creamy and perfectly made. I was definitely wired for several hours after enjoying this piece of espresso heaven. I've also had their Blueboon blend; true to its description, I found this blend indeed contained notes of chocolate and citrus, but it was a bit too much on the bright (acidic) end for me. I would still get it every time though if I didn't feel like getting the usual latte/cappuccino. Yes the prices are on the high end, but it's not any different than your standard Blue Bottle/Four Barrel/Philz/Ritual premium prices. Otherwise just go to Starbucks for their cheaper yet burnt coffee. The minimalist atmosphere here is perfect for catching up with friends in the afternoon (and not so much for studying without Wi-Fi or power outlets...oh and watching the coffee roaster work its magic is pretty mesmerizing). As a bonus, they're dog friendly and take credit cards. I will be back at least once every week or two.
author: Andy C.

description:
There's not much on the menu to choose from.  The cups are really small.  For $3.25, you get about 2/3 of the SB tall size of latte, which was very smooth by the way with no acidity that I could taste.  Their macchiato are not sold for to go; they are only served in their ceramic cups.  For a coffee addict like me, having just one cup of this a day just isn't enough to get me going.  

The only seats they have is the bench right next to the bar.  They have a water bowl for dogs, gotta love dog-friendly cafes.
author: Tadaa T.

description:
Hipsterville. I like it for it: it's very spacious, the coffee is good, the people are friendly and it's bike-friendly too (you can park your bikes inside coz it's so huge). Pay with Square. People are little too painfully hip but they leave you alone.

No wifi though, which is odd for this neighbourhood (and this crowd).
author: Adrianna T.

description:
You have to stop by Sightglass next time your near 7th and Folsom. One of the most beautiful coffee shops with interiors by Boor Bridges Architects- if you love Flora Grubb Gardens then this is its coffee roaster equivalent! The atmosphere is rustic with high ceilings and full of light, the upstairs balcony has plenty of large tables perfect for important casual business meetings or bar stools for coffee before work. 

I've tried several coffees so far, even their decaf is delish. We used to be tried and true fans of Trouble Coffee, but after several years are ready for a new addiction. See also: yummy pastries.
author: Erin R.

description:
Perhaps this exposes me as the non-coffee connoisseur that I am, but I value coffee shops much more for the venue than the coffee. I also find that legit coffee shops like Sightglass and Four Barrel make bitter mochas. 

I still need to make a lot more rounds of SF coffee shops before I can pick a favorite. Sightglass ranks up there for atmosphere + setting. Two stories with lots of open space - great for meeting up with people. Major down points for not having WiFi. Somehow that doesn't seem to have the intended consequence of increased human interaction, as plenty of people still sit around for hours zoned in on their laptops. Perhaps they're a-tetherin' from their phones. But still, it misleads the rest of us.

If you just need a coffee shop with WiFi in that area, go to Radius around the corner (1123 Folsom). Or Brainwash (1122 Folsom). Brainwash is louder.
author: An Y.

description:
$3.50 for a really small muffin, no wifi, no power outlets. 

Muffin was tasty and atmosphere is great, but unless you are using it to discuss your startup in a posh location, go elsewhere.
author: Alex M.

description: one of the best coffee in SF, this one is much bigger than the other one. lots of people all the time, and taste awesome all the time.
author: Zack Y.

description:
It is really refreshing to go in a  different direction once in a while. Sightglass Coffee is that for me. The coffee is surreal, the employees are  exquisite!
And if you ever want pure....this is the place to go..very different.
author: maria b.

description: Best atmosphere in SF! Solid coffee and beautiful architecture. It's my favorite indoor space to be creative and write.
author: Dawn H.

description:
Fact: I have an at least once a day coffee habit. 
Fact: I spent at least four days hoping to find a deliciously smooth coffee in San Francisco.
Fact: I found said coffee at Sightglass Coffee. 

One thing I hadn't considered when I recently travelled to San Francisco was that coffee as I knew it in Australia would not translate across the waters. Sure, there were Starbucks and various incarnations of the same formula scattered on every street corner, but I needed real coffee. Coffee that had a unique, mellow, smooth, alert the senses kind of taste. 

It took me almost a week but after a recommendation from a local I set foot to find Sightglass Coffee and as soon as I walked in their wooden doors I knew I was home. I'll concede the minimalist design in a converted warehouse / garage instantly appealed to my hipster sensibilities but the smell of freshly roasting coffee beans was something all together sublime. Better yet, the latte with a bacon brioche muffin that became my breakfast that day was exactly what I'd been seeking. Robust, rich, smooth - a sensory delight! 

My only regret? That I didn't have time to eat in and enjoy the atmosphere.
author: Lani P.

description: That's the last time I order a pour over here.  Can't seem to get them to pass my request on to not rinse out my thermos that has raw cream and sucanet inside.  I'd hope the person making my coffee would at least have the common courtesy to ask first before hastily rinsing it out. Not to mention the rude nature that was apparent on top of the cup being so weak that I can see through it.  That was the most watery pour I have ever seen.  Two thumbs down.
author: Greg M.

description:
Extremely cool spot.  Makes me want to pick up a book and study there.  Coffee is solid but definitely not my favorite place in SF. 

Would I go back?  Yes, yes I would.
author: Nho C.

description: The cappuccino I got was excellent. I love the atmosphere is great, it's very open and bright. The people working there are friendly. I would love to go back. The only negative for me is that they don't have wifi or power outlets.
author: Bob G.

description: This place makes the best coffee and this location is so scenic. Not in a great area but there is some metered parking. If getting here is a drag, find them at the farmer's market in Ferry Building! They're outside in the back middle near the mexican place.
author: Emm C.

description: Really great spot! Plenty of space to bring work/study.  Coffee was delicious as well. I like four barrels espresso more but sight glass is definitely a close second. It's a must try!
author: Linda R.

description: Their pastries are delicious. Pistachio & plain croissant. Raspberry chocolate scone. I usually get their daily roast, you have 3 choices, mostly good.
author: Maryam A.

description: Amazing!!! Excellent environment. In a cool industrial building with a big open space. The coffee was amazing. They have two options for ordering a drip coffee. Either a quick cup, which I think is just their basic drip, and then their high end version which is slow poured. I had the slow poured version and it was a terrific cup of coffee. They lightly roast all of their coffee which I don't usually prefer but their coffee was anything but "light". It was rich, complex, and full of flavors. Can't wait to go back for another. Service was great.
author: Whit G.

description: Most mornings I miss this place intensely. Just moved from SOMA to SoCal and wake up craving that GF almond cake and an espresso almost daily. My baristas were always happy to see me, always a great start to my usually hung over morning. Def a judgment free zone. The space is stunning as well. No internet makes for REAL LIFE INTERACTION. can't wait to be back in SF to revel in this beauty. Also at the ferry building farmers market on Saturday. The one in the mission is cool, but I'm partial to my neighborhood spot.
author: Jen V.

description:
I love coming to Sightglass on a weekend. This is one of those semi-"hidden gems" of coffee shops because the space is amazing and even on weekends, the line moves fast and you're usually able to find a table or bench space. If you want to impress your friends with an amazing industrial space, composed of wood and exposed brick - then highly recommend Sightglass! I also LOVE the fact that they carry almond milk because I had asked for a soy latte (as I normally do for next best substitute) but the barista suggested almond milk instead!!!! Made me so giddy!! 

If you're here to get an hour's worth of work done, then this is the place for you. There's a bar downstairs facing the street if you like to people watch or you can head upstairs where there are plenty of tables AND an additional coffee bar for those who are too lazy to walk downstairs. The only things I can complain about are no wifi and NO OUTLETS ANYWHERE..not even in the bathrooms!! Granted, this is a smart move on their part so they increase turnover, but really hard to sit there all day and get work done. Therefore, knocking one star off.
author: Penny Y.

description:
My first visit and I am hooked. I know their coffee is great. Now I got to try out the store. I will return. The only 2 flaws (for me) are:
1. No almond milk available (Cream is best for the experience, obviously. But I try to minimize dairy). Soy is poison. So no need to provide that.
2. I didn't see any gluten free food options. It was a Sunday afternoon. I will have to re-evaluate this when they are better stocked.

Great place though.
author: Ben V.

description:
I tried to think of a reason to only give it four stars but couldn't come up with anything. Sightglass is everything I'd want from a coffee shop/roaster.

If there is any knock against it, it would be the high prices.
author: A.J. T.

description:
Holy crap!

I've lived in the Bay Area for 15 years and coming here is honestly one of the biggest douchbag experiences I've ever had here. It's impossible to describe how horrible this place is without taking up pages of text. I can distilled it to a single point though. After the impossibly long wait for a simple massively overpriced cup of coffee I get to the cream and sugar area only to find no brown sugar and only white. I figure it must be a mistake and request some. Nobody had any idea why I would want such a thing, let alone that they had none...IN SAN FRANCISCO!!!

The utter stupidity of the staff is ecliped by the towering pretensiousness of the space. Ugh.

You must go here at least once to experience how low humanity has sunk.

I give it two stars as the coffee tasted decent.
author: Peter V.

description: This may be the coolest cafe in sf.  There are many but this place send to have it all, it's spacious, the coffee is great, the ham bun thing was delicious even at 1130am.
author: Magnus v.

description:
Sightglass is just a little too hardcore about their coffee for me. I had a cup once, and I'm sure it was very good. But the caffeine content altered the course of my day like I'd snorted a big, fat line--and not in a good way.

That said, the architecture, the terrarium succulents, and the young, adorable, hipsters serving and hanging around make this a truly delightful place to sit and daydream or write or grind your teeth fanatically while you try to calm down from foolishly consenting to drink the coffee.

An herbal tea option or maybe some pastries would help a lot. But no, at Sightglass you can have coffee, or coffee, or a $2 chocolate/caramel candy. Oh goodie, now come the sugar shakes!
author: Kristy L.

description:
They refuse to run a coffee that is less then 4 bucks.  I am done.  Not going back.  They claim they stop running the 3 dollar blend because it is in-between roasts.  I say bullshit.  This place is for the elite of the city.  So stupid.  Why would you alienate all of us who are willing to drop 3 bucks on a great cup but not willing to drop 4. Actually 4 and a quarter.  I'm done.  I will stick with Four Barrel.  They always have a single origin for under 4 bucks and if you need it they have a blend for 2 bucks.... 
I will leave the Sightglass overpriced underwhelming experience for those who can afford to light their money on fire and watch it burn.... 

They put the 3 dollar blend on then they take it off, and then back on.  Just leave it on or another option.  But then again, forget it.  You lost me.
author: Christopher F.

description: fantastic space! so beautiful and you get to see coffee beans roasted and packaged in front of your eyes. There's no wifi here but that doesn't stop people from camping out here. This place has so much light, definitely worth checking out!
author: G C.

description:
This is one of the most beautiful coffee shops you could visit. On top of that, you can watch them roast while you hang out! 

That said, the coffee could be slightly more consistent and I found the staff to be a bit impersonal. The pastries are fantastic though. It's a great place overal and I would go back.
author: Joe A.

description:
In the last week I have tried Ritual, Fourbarrel, and Sightglass. If you're just getting into these roasters and trying them out/deciding which to try first, here is my take: I personally enjoyed Fourbarrel the most. Their Ecuador roast had the most unique flavors and pleasant taste/after-taste.

I wanted to love Sightglass because my ultrahip coffeefiend friends said that it was better than Fourbarrel. At first glance, I felt like I was walking into a contemporary art museum - the whole place looks like a refurbished warehouse - very sleek, very urban. I loved the high ceilings and the huge windows bathing you in light. It had a spacious and airy feeling, so even though it was crowded (all seats/tables full on a Sunday afternoon), I didn't feel stuffed or cramped like some other cafes. There is plenty of seating downstairs and also a variety of tables upstairs. Just like Ritual and Fourbarrel, there is great branding and sense of style.

Since this was our first time, husband asked a couple questions about their three roasts, and the barista, who seemed kind of confused that we were confused, was kind enough to explain them to us. We tried their Columbian roast and their Rwandan roast. The Rwandan roast, which we chose for the fruity notes, was very unique - it almost tasted like tea, which is not necessarily a bad thing. It did, however, taste sort of sour on our palates, and we ended up having to finish half of it with some ice cream from Smitten (~1 mile walking away!). The Columbian roast was nice and strong - a good cup of coffee and definitely smoother and more tasteful than your large chain stores, but it wasn't anything I would rave about or go out of my way for.

So after a week of caffeine crawling, I crown Fourbarrel the winner; I would make the trip across the bridge for their coffee and can't wait to bring all my friends.
author: Jen L.

description:
Beautiful space filled with wonderful aromas and my favorite roast in San Francisco. 

Forgive the irony of being located next door to San Francisco's fastest ISP (Webpass) and not having Wi-Fi. Great coffee is best served with the internet.
author: Jeremiah L.

description:
Another great coffee place. I actually came here two times in one day (once before the Renegade Craft Fair & then after). I live in the Mission so not a first choice for me, but a great place if I want to get a short bike ride in. Also, the place is kind of cold & not as warm and inviting as other coffee shops - but a really really great design. The lab stools aren't so comfy for extended chatting, studying, working.

First time: I got a soy latte and Mindel's pistachio & blackberry croissant (OMFG YUMMY BRILLIANT PASTRY! - http://www.tastingtable.com/entry_detail/sf/7673).

Second time: half caf cappuccino

Sidenote: I think I've decided to stop ordering lattes because they are too milky (this isn't just Sightglass).
author: Amber M.

description: My friend lives close by so we made a pit stop here. The iced coffee was fantastic. It is a little pricey though. I would come back here again, but probably only if I was in the area (there are just too many good coffee places in SF).
author: Allison S.

description:
Stopped in here for a morning coffee while visiting SF and was pleasantly surprised by the very cool interior, nice detailing throughout referencing industrial architecture. I appreciated seeing the roasting equipment and coffee sacks right there in the main room. The one place they fall short in the decor department is the gray plastic trash cans they use in the roasting process, they look out of place and cheap in such an otherwise well thought space. They need some older barrels that fit the theme.

I had a cappuccino and a croissant and I appreciated that the cappuccino was prepared properly, most places like to give you a milkshake to disguise the taste of the coffee. I need to have a straight-up espresso to really judge the coffee which I'll do next time in SF. This is a really nice place to grab some good coffee.
author: Mario C.

description:
Very beautiful roastery with delicious coffee! The space was really large and relaxing. Two stories, machines all over the place, with the espresso bar right in the middle. As opposed to some of the other coffee joints I've tried, the baristas here were especially friendly and not condescending.

I ordered a soy latte, which I enjoyed very much. They managed to make some really cool latte art with the soy milk...which is usually harder! WHOA!

The bathrooms made me laugh a bit. After you do your business, you walk outside...into the main room to wash your hands. It just felt...different...to wash my hands with dudes. Felt like a unisex bathroom except it wasn't. OK that's enough about bathrooms...

My boyfriend really liked the Kenya that we ordered. He says that it had a really subtle, tropical vibe. The coffee was acidic and had a very light body. The Blueboon (Sightglass' blend coffee) was also delightful. I would definitely come here again.
author: Sandra C.

description: Cavernous space where you can see the roaster, where all the magic happens. A mezzanine for startup masters of the world huddles and awesome coffee sipping and people watching. My trip here was an odyssey - was it worth all the hubbub I had built around it in my head? Not sure, but I did grab a bag of beans as a souvenir and am still enjoying it daily.
author: Crystal W.

description:
Once I got inside, the line was long, so that was a good sign. It smelled so good, and everyone was just chillin upstairs or downstairs, sippin on their joe. I really just needed to use the WC though! And their bathroom says that...very cute. I like the ambiance of the place, and the glass and plants... interesting name; I would've asked what it meant but I really had to pee. I asked if there was a restroom for customers, and there is. :)
 
Then I bought (according to my receipt): sweet vegan cake and single hookers???. I left... and ate my vegan cake later on the night. It was sooo moist. It was like a carrot cake but no carrots. I think it had a few prunes in it. It had almond slices on the top. The other item I had was a caramel with nuts, the bottom had salted dark chocolate on it. I loved the sweets, and wish I had bought another vegan cake. The next time I go to SF I'll be sure to try their coffee, and maybe even bring a friend. :)
author: Chrissy O.

description:
First off, this space is beautiful. They put a lot of money and work into creating a really inspiring place to visit. Ideal for a client meeting or if you need a place to work for an hour. The skylights are a great feature and make the place really comfortable. 

The coffee on the other hand is not so good. I ordered an Americano and it was bitter as hell. I'm a regular at Blue Bottle and Four Barrel and order Americano's everywhere I go. The coffee was bitter and had a lingering after taste. My friend visited Sight Glass a few days prior and commented on the same exact issue. Not sure if this is from the bean or how they roasted it, but I'm not a fan. 

Also, their "creamer" station was at the far rear of the space and not convenient to get to. I found myself looking around and had to ask the staff. When I went back there to doctor up my coffee, the dishwasher splashed dirty dish water into my coffee. This was not a pleasant experience. They put the creamer station next to the dish washing station. I hope management will rethink this as it's inconveniently positioned within their cafe.
author: Giselle B.

description:
This review has been a LONG TIME coming for me...

I live a block away from this place. So without a doubt, when I'm in the mood for a quick fix, this is my spot to come to. The coffee is unbelievable here! It is probably one of the few non-cold-brewed iced coffees that I actually look forward to having --- except for the ridiculous price tag that comes with it!

I totally understand the thought of paying ~$4 for a specialty drink (lattes and what have you...) But when I'm paying 4.5 for Iced Drip Coffee... Yea --- that's a bit overboard pal. This is the only real early morning spot to get good coffee in the hood. Instead though, their prices have just lead me to making my own cold brew at home. 

I'll go in every now and then in the mornings if I didn't have a chance to get some beans soaking --- but the other big issue I have with this place is speed... When you have a timed bus to catch, make sure to give yourself  good 10 minutes here to get your coffee. If you see people waiting in the barista area for their drink, tack on a couple of a few extra minutes. For some reason the Baristas don't have a sense of urgency, nor are they able to brew more then one or two nel drip orders at once. Having worked in a few restaurants, I know how important efficiency is in a service environment like this, and sometimes I just want to jump back there and help grind the beans for someone, because for some reason, they can't do it while they are standing there waiting to finish making a single cup of coffee. 

If this place had slightly speedier baristas in the morning, I would probably make it a once a week treat for myself (again due to the pricing...) But I highly doubt I'll come here more then once or twice a month...
author: Mike V.

description:
Cool place!  I pass this coffeehouse in the mornings whenever I take BART to work, and I always want to kick myself (like, literally kick myself. In the face.) for not arriving in SF earlier so I can try out a cup of their coffee before I start my workday. Very spacious inside. It has a very, um, "spacious-y", "warehouse-y", "industrial-y" feel (I unpacked my [fake] adjectives. That's right, I just quoted School House Rock). I imagine this place is probably pretty packed in the mornings, but since I arrived around 5:30pm, I had the place almost to myself. 

     I had an excellent hand-crafted latte while there ("the BEST latte!", as proclaimed by the awesome barista who prepared my drink). The place is a little pricey when compared to Peet's ($3.00 for a cup of single-served coffee, $4.00 for a latte), but this isn't Peet's. It's way better.
author: Jen O.

description: By far one of the best mocha I've experienced very clean and upscale environment very impressed.
author: David A.

description:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SUpY1BT9Xf4

Need I say more? Awesome coffee and dog friendly too!
author: Sue L.

description: I really love the decoration of this cafe. It was located in a ghetto area but the cafe is lovely and cozy. I ordered the Iced Vanilla Latte and it was great!
author: Michelle H.

description: This is some of the best coffee and pastries in the city, imo.  I also very much enjoy their minimalist decor, and I find the staff friendly and interesting.  The only cons are it can be difficult to find seating if they're busy, and equal parts blessing and curse -- there is no internet.
author: Scott U.

description:
3.5 
I've walked by this coffee shop for a month now as I walk to work five days a week. I have never anticipated enough time to get coffee and continue on my way but today I was earlier than usual and thought to finally give this place a try. Inside looks as cool as it does outside. It looks like it used to be a night club, bar, or apartment; it's so spacious with extra upstairs seating. The decor is the definition of hipsters in SF; ipad cashiers, tattooed and gauged baristas, the works. Yummmmy coffee and blueberry ginger muffin. Now some downsides: $7 plus $1 tip is a very pricey breakfast-snack on a daily basis. Also, being awfully slow in the morning while people are trying to get to work is unacceptable. They also called me Susan...then tried to cover it up by saying, "this is also a cappuccino, you can take it".
author: kim w.

description: The only coffee I drink when in SF! Obviously the owners source the best beans from around the world and roast them to perfection. The 7th Street location is a coffee shop like no other; very large, with a cool industrial vibe. There's a vintage working roaster that has actually been roasting whenever I've been there. If only they would open a shop in LA! Can't wait to try their newest location inside MOMA!
author: Vicki B.

description:
While the facility is top-notch and the staff was super nice- I think they're quite overrated. I think they strive for having great coffee but consistently under-roast and it shows in their espresso. Also I keep having their coffee (drip) at retail shops around the city and it seems like they need to be re-trained because *if* they're supposed to be brewing for a light nuanced cup, they're not.   

A lot of people like Sightglass beans and coffee though- and I think if you're going to have it you need to have it at their shop on 7th.  When trying it at home or your own shop- if your grinders and espresso machines aren't finely-tuned and up to snuff you'll think your brew temp is off- but it's usually the way the beans are roasted. 

YMMV
author: El T.

description: I wandered in here one Saturday and got a coffee. It was pretty good. While I was here, they played the first Duran Duran in its entirety. So, they got an extra star for that :) It's a great place to people watch, too.
author: Vanessa S.

description: oh i think i'm in love. with the whole affogato bar concept that is.
author: Tina B.

description:
Great place! Coffee is amazing, Ive tried Fourbarrel (Acidic and sour) and Ritual (Bland) and could not justify paying for their coffee. 

Had a cappuccino and it was delicious! They really know how to pull a shot, velvety foam. PERFECT.

Also took home some fresh costa rican beans, ground it up, and brewed- result = smooth sweet and smoky flavors.

I AM A FAN!
author: Mario M.

description: Can I just say that Sightglass coffee is great! I was never a "real coffee" (i mean everyday) drinker until I started coming here. But here you can really taste the quality. I go here almost everyday. The employees are very friendly and they seem to care about their jobs. And call me a sucker for the little things, but I love the little designs they put in the lattes lol I usually get a latte or the vanilla iced brew (yum). Their pastries are awesome as well. The only reason I didn't give this place 5 stars is because I think there prices are just a smidgen too high...but obviously that hasn't stopped me from coming.
author: Casey P.

description:
In my continuing efforts to find a replacement for Intellgentsia-like coffee in Nor Cal, I stumbled into Sightglass Coffee.

Wow.

First. What a warehouse. I like it very much. 

Second. No power plugs for pretentious Mac users who buy ONE cup and stay for EIGHT hours. Nice. I don't care for it anyway. I am an Android fan. 

Third. The espresso with milk was spot on. This place could convince me to give up Intellgentsia in LA and move here right away.

Only issue is finding parking. Weekends aren't exactly free parking either. Even with meters, you have to constantly replenish time with quarters. 

Enjoying life shouldn't be measured by quarters. But by parking tickets. Cos the coffee here is worth a parking ticket or two.
author: Vince W.

description:
Found this place by accident.  Waited 20 min for my coffee (4th in line).  The female Barista served the Guy behind me his coffee...must a been a regular customer?...WAIT what about ME!!  Finally served but no eye contact, friendly or a thank-you for waiting.  Coffee was very good but customer service is lacking.
BTW..only have/use Almond milk.
author: Betsy B.

description:
A confession - until a month ago I didn't drink coffee. 

I was so proud of it. Until the realities of job searches, class, and late nights with friends started to catch up with me. And then it was a slow descent into drinking more and more coffee. 

A swing by SF, though, made me so happy that I had fallen. Sightglass was a well-deserved break between meetings and the sweet taste of their cappuccino was enough to remind me of the glory that is proper coffee. 

We'll see how long I last - I might go cold turkey again until I can be back in SF.
author: Madeline N.

description:
A recent 7x7 Magazine independent taste test of a number of artisan coffees resulted in one clear winner: Sightglass Coffee. One of the cities newest roasters and distributors, it was formed when Jerad and Justin Morrison, a pair of coffee experts, left Four Barrel (another local favorite) to start their own location.

And it's a beautiful space.

Large, full of seating space (a rarity in San Francisco) and clean restrooms (plural), this is a great place to grab a cup of coffee and chill. I ordered an Americano, as always, and took it black, like my heart, so I was able to take in all the flavors of their roasting and brewing process. It was delicious; all the flavor of Four Barrel without that weird acidic aftertaste I sometimes get. I have to say it was one of the best pulls of all the espressos I've had.

(As a student of the Italian language, I'm well aware that "espresso" can't be pluralized with an "s" appended to it. Oh, well...)

They have a ton of pastries as well; large ones the size of your face. Can't argue with that.
author: Keane L.

description: I heart coffee.  can't imagine living w/o drinking coffee.  I am even grateful that I can start my morning w it.  lol   but would I go Sightglass everyday?  hmm... practically NO  emotionally NO financially heck NO.
author: Jee C.

description: The best part of this place was interior. Very cool. Very diffrent from coffee places in South Bay. Good latte and pastries.
author: Kaori M.

description: Love the interior of this place. Great place to grab some coffee and read or do some work. No wifi though which may turn away some people but you know you it's good to disconnect every now and then.
author: Tahsin I.

description:
I'm a little torn on this review. On the one hand I love their space and their coffee,but on the other it just seemed a little too expensive for what I received. 

Yes their coffee is quite good...I'm not debating that. It is however a little too expensive than what I feel is justified. 

I'll simply call it like this; do you like your coffee more exclusive than Peet's or Starbucks? If yes than come here because their coffee really is great. Is your black cup of coffee worth $5 to you? If not then please go to the a fore mentioned establishments. 

Once again. This should not be taken as a negative review, because I would definitely come here again. This review is based upon how much is good coffee worth to you. I simply can't recommend this place to everyone.
author: Ryan F.

description:
Seriously pretentious. $5 without the tip for an 8oz mocha. Un!@#$%believable!

I dont care how good the coffee is. It's not liquid gold in there. Of course, no option of getting something bigger. That was the quickest $5 i ever spent. 

Ok...The coffee is good. 
But I can't get over the price and size. And theres no reason for it. 
Quality? The drink gets diluted when more milk is added? Uhhhhh how bout I order a Triple or Quad??? ehhhh?
Please, give me a good reason why there are no larger options? Im not talking Starbucks 20ozers, but my god at least 12 & 16. 

Sorry. not going back
author: Dan-O -.

description:
Took me a while to warm up to the coffee but i noticed that somehow their coffees always leave me immensely satisfied. Flavorful, dense, not too acidic. Also, I've never had any watered down coffee. I come by 1-3 times a week. So they are very consistent. 

The pastries, chocolates are also top-notch and I'm not sure where you can have a better coffee/pastry combination anywhere else in the city. 

Top all that off with a beautiful interior? Ladies and Gents, you might just have a world-class coffee joint on your hands. 

And yes, I will gladly pay a little extra to keep this place around. Its not just about coffee, they represent a class of people willing to see their vision through; make things even better than you could have imagined. I support that kind of dedication.
author: Shum S.

description:
The cold-steeped, spice-infused iced is the new blue bottle new orleans iced. Because it is hella tasty and 2/3 the price.

Share a chemex pot "between lovers," and pay with The Future.
author: Megan W.

description: Ein super cooles Café mit der gemütlicher Atmosphäre. Die Location ist schon ziemlich einmalig. Die Preise sid für San Francisco echt super.
author: dieheike85

description:
Two buck cup.

Infamous wine: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Shaw_wine

Soon to be famous coffee: Two bucks for a cup of the house Blueboon blend. 

Menu description says something about tasting notes of sweet orange, cocoa and apricot. Perhaps. Found it smooth and the perfect complement to the Sunday paper.

Space has been finished since my first visit. Upstairs features a birds eye view of the caffeine brilliance happening below. Still modern. Still rustic.

Still just how I like it. All of it.
author: Jason B.

description: I love the ambience and natural sunlight coming through the skylight. the beans from this place pretty good and reasonable price.
author: Steve K.

description:
The coffee is great. But, like most third-wave places in the city, it's a little snobby. My friend wanted his latte "hot", which they didn't do. :-/ 

Two things I should mention if you plan to come here to work all day:

No wifi.
No outlets for your laptop.
author: Chris B.

description:
Would have given 2 stars for the cool looking space but it lost a point for trying to be too uber-industrial-cool - leaving the atmosphere of the place cold, somber and unfeeling. Coffee places should be warm, engaging and communal. But this place is quiet and serious, like it's a sacred holy place for coffee worshippers and you must approach the coffee bar with reverence.  Puuhh-leeeeeeez (eyes roll back into head). Lighten up, Sight Glass!  You take yourselves too seriously.

Here's the breakdown:
- $$$$. Crazy Hamiltons! Approx $6 for coffee in a SMALL cup.
- Wait is too long.
- Not enough seating. Such an inefficient use of space. There is SO much space here yet they can't throw in a few tables. It's obvious they don't want you to stick around.
- Service blows: aloof, sullen, and unfriendly. And if you didn't hear your name being called the first time when your coffee was ready, then your cup could be sitting on the counter growing cold while the rest of the bored disaffected baristas could give a rat's ... (well you know).
- Coffee is SO acidic. Gross.

Buying a cup of coffee from this place is like having the word IDIOT stamped on you forehead while the trying-too-hard-to-be-hipster employees are laughing behind your back because they got your money.

Go to Philz instead.
author: Allie C.

description: I was so disappointed in the coffee. It tasted like cardboard. Literally. And no sizes were indicated on the now ubiquitous brown-paper clipboard menu, so when I saw the high prices, I expected 12 oz, not 6. Service, cleanliness, and ambiance were fine, and the blackberry pistachio croissant was excellent, but seriously, this is the coffee I've been hearing about? My 2 companions regret to agree.
author: Laura R.

description:
I loved the inside of this place! A warehouse feel and so freaking spacious. Took a lot of pics hehe. They also have their own roasting machine and u can sit around there. Lots of seating. I liked the totes and bags of beans displayed on the side. The staff was friendly and got my drink quickly. I got a latte and boy was it strong. Loved it! Not too acidic, I hate when my coffee is too acidic! 

We sat up in the second floor where u have a whole view of the place! Very cool! A little less hipster than four barrel haha. Upstairs there's a bunch of tables and high stool seats. Such a good place with friends or to work on stuff. There's another floor on top of the 2nd floor for employees! Pretty sweet spots for the workers. 

Only complaint is that my latte got cold fairly quickly. The foam had a good consistency, not too many bubbles. But when I watched I realized they dont heat it up that hot, seems like its Lukewarm temp prob around 125-130* degrees. I think they do that to get that specific foam where u can free pour and make a design. I think she could've stuck it under the wand for a little bit more. But that's just me. 

But I would def come here again!
author: Angela C.

description: Only downfall is a I can't order a large vanilla iced cold brew. I love this place! Service is always great & friendly.... I order Vanilla Iced Cold Brew every time and every now and then the ham tart!
author: Heather E.

description:
We found shelter from the rain and cold at Sightglass after taking a tour of the Renegade Craft Festival nearby back in December. I've been coaxing my thus-far coffee-abstaining boyfriend into drinking coffee with me regularly (what's a coffee date, if your partner isn't sharing a cup of jo with you, am I right?). 

The coffee here was great, no burnt after taste for once. I ordered a latte and the boyfriend had a hot chocolate. For the record, he said that he *almost* wanted to order a mocha instead afterwards. That, yelp friends, is progress--and a testament to how lovely Sightglass is.

The space was decked out for the holidays, with trimmings all around and to top it off, antlers on top of the Christmas tree in the main window in lieu of a star. 

In short, I was charmed. I will definitely make it a point to stop by whenever I am in the neighborhood.
author: Patricia Q.

description: First timer. A little pricey, but........Wow! Coffee was outstanding. I had the latte and my wife had the Hooker mocha. Both to die for. We smelled the aroma 50 yards away. Nice gem for coffee lovers.
author: Tim F.

description:
I didn't drink coffee until I was 23 years old.

I distinctly remember sitting at a cafe in Milan waiting for a train. My first espresso wasn't inspired by fatigue or boredom. My first coffee was a result of a long conversation with a passionate barista. (He was passionate about coffee, not about me.)

I sat with him for a full 20 minutes chatting in broken italian about the art of coffee- before I ever had a drop. He spoke of procuring the beans, transporting the beans, the roasting process and fhe final step: roasted bean to grinder to espresso machine to cup.  From what I gathered, even if you did steps 1-3 perfectly everything could go wrong in step 4.  (Which seemed obvious at the time becuase step 4 actually appeared to be 4 additional steps all jammed into 1) In any case, 100's of espressos later, I see Marco was indeed correct. 

The person  (I've only ever seen one official representative at any given time)  at Sight Glass does it all so well, with ease and grace. And in the whole process they are the equivalent of the latte art or possibly the foam-- something crucial but at the end the culmination of a series of efforts.  Not to worry. whoever is behind the scenes doing the rest of the work is also doing their job. Good bean choice-- good roasting. Actually you can see the roaster if you peak behind the curtain. It is a massive dinosaur straight out of cold war East Germany. And you think I'm kidding. I've heard they had that puppy shipped over. 

I'm a fan of Sightglass. And I give them extra points for their quirky throwback name, their muddy brown colored cups and their lack of pretension-- for the time being their operation consists of coffee cart attached to a large (at the time) empty space on a street of no particular interest in SOMA. 

I'll be sure to come back and visit next time I'm home. 

P.S Intelligentsia, don't be upset. I still love you more.
author: erica f.

description:
Soy Cappuccino was yummy!
The cafe is a really big open area where you can watch the baristas at work. Interior design is minimalistic chic. I would come here just to see the pretty place! Great space for casual or business meetings.
author: Miss A.

description: Good Coffee! I had the hooker's mocha . The place is a very industrial coffee place , very open. The barista was so nice.
author: Dianne J.

description: I simply envy the interior of Sightglass Coffee in SOMA. If I could make this place my home I would, it's that amazing. This two story, spacious coffee warehouse has lots of natural light flooding in and plenty of places to sit. I give this place 5 stars because it's clean, professional, brilliantly designed, relaxing, and most importantly has great coffee, and I don't even drink coffee. That saying something! - Ray Clay
author: Ray C.

description:
The location is pretty neat.  Large warehouse feel with lofted areas to hang out at.  I'm curious as to how a coffee place can sustain the rent for such a large location but I guess this area in the SOMA (not to mention the industrial-type building) doesn't command too high of rents.  Great spot to hang out.

However, I tried a couple of the coffees and I'm not a big fan.  It's also pricier than other alternatives (Blue Bottle, Philz).
author: Ken L.

description:
Honestly the best coffee shop I have ever been to, and I speak with a past years experience of searching for the finest little (though Sightglass is far from small) establishments, having been broken of my "regular cup o' joe" virginity.

The woody sort of warehouse feel really provides you that rustic vibe. Additionally, there are amazing staff people just giving you that robot with a heart feel. They know what they are doing; they do it with efficiency; AND they take care of you.

I also like that they source a good amount of locally baked goods to fill your stomach before injecting caffeinated compounds into your blood stream. I had a "glorious" Morning Glory muffin from Mission Beach Cafe (?).

I also had a pour over of Rwanda Kerenge and Blueboon. The first was tart, sweet, and smoky. The second offered a bit of sweet bite with a tangy and rich bottom.

Sightglass is so awesome; it is the sole reason why I will return to stay at the Knight's Inn again and again. Hehe, 3 rhymes in a row. Also, that was in no way an informal advertisement for the hotel!

Lastly, it is pretty cool that there is such a large facility in which to stand while drinking your coffee. I feel so classy when I stand and drink coffee; don't you?
author: Solomon W.

description: So I haven't been here in a while but I have my reasons.. For one, the coffee is okay nothin special. And secondly and most importantly especially located in SOMA where startup people can go to meetup or do work, they don't have wifi. With that said, the place is really nice, open, two-level with a mini bar upstairs. If you're going with a friend just to talk then I guess it's not a bad option but ultimately, the lack of wifi brings it down for me
author: Neil I.

description:
Don't expect a cozy coffee shop with baristas that wear aprons or any seating with cushion.  The space feels awfully grandiose, sterile, and aesthetically noteworthy to Dwell standards.  

Sightglass serves alarmingly great espresso, beans that have been attentively roasted, low in acidity, and therefore makes a seriously butter-rich ristretto shot to accommodate any drink.  Initially ordering my drink was a bit awkward, but a scattered line will form near the spinning iPad/cashier and pastry display.

If it seems a bit high-brow to you, it just might be.  True coffee drinkers hold smug satisfaction in finding a place that honors coffee for its own unique flavor.  If you want a milkshake with a hit of espresso, go to Starbucks.  If your requirements for drinking coffee is fake creamer that smells like oppressive holiday, shower gel from Bath & Body Works go to 7-11 and save a few dollars.
author: Mai O.

description: I really don't get the appeal of this hipster joint. No wifi and hot as hell upstairs. At $4 for a cup of coffee, at least have some air conditioning.
author: Alan N.

description:
Sightglass will serve you pretty good coffee, but there's an even chance they'll pull you a bitter shot of espresso. For some reason, they're only cold brew is pre-sweetened. If Sightglass wants to go on being considered one of the premiere coffee mini-chains in SF they need to up their game. 

And $7 for a four-shot latte is pushing it, even in SF circa-2015.
author: Phil D.

description: Literally one of the best lattes I've ever had. Beautiful, simple and rustic feel in this place. Two stories with balcony seating
author: Shawday B.

description: Although the baristas seem to be a little pretentious, they are friendly enough anyway. I've been here a few times and have tried the cappuccino, mocha, and latte-- all really good. The space is huge and smells amazing. It is always packed.
author: Julia T.

description:
The coffee is good, I'm not such a freak about micro beans and hand crafted 10 minute drip coffee, but this will be a great cuppa. I think the better reason to check it out is the interior and design with the coffee roaster in the middle of the room and enormously high ceilings.  The communal tables were filled with lonely people tuned out on their laptops which made it difficult for people who actually wanted to have human interaction with each since they were clogging up all the seats.

Thumbs up on the design and coffee.

The neighborhood is a bit smelly though.
author: Spoon G.

description: Chose this place to meet and catch up with a very good friend. It's quite spacious for a coffee shop, with high ceilings and the wonderful aroma of roasted coffee beans -- very comforting as we chatted the whole afternoon and early evening. The coffee is definitely tasty, not being overpowered by the milk. I would definitely be a regular and try all of their menu selections if not for the fact that I don't live close by.
author: Sarah S.

description: If you're hipster, grab your warby parkers and hit up Sightglass for a fresh, artisan brew. They're roasting operations mesh into the day-to-day coffee shop operation. Order your drink, give the pastry case a chance, and find a spot in the upstairs lounge -- it's super chill. You can enjoy vinyl classics pushing thru the ambience of coffee makers down below. Enjoy.!
author: Joseph W.

description:
Finding places like Sightglass makes me happy that I live in SF.  It's a crazy hip 3-level space centered around an ever-running coffee roaster in the middle with all the touches you'd expect.  Stainless steel, metal, and earthy-wood interior?  Check.  Fancy drip coffee that'll use up that extra money in your bank account?  Check.   Non-existent cash register replaced by an iPad running Square?  Check.  It's like a hipster implosion of epic proportions - they're even too cool to have WiFi.  Not free wifi, but wifi at all.  Love it!  

But seriously, it's 2012.  And I need wifi at my coffee shop.  And it turns out that I don't really like their coffee that much - the latte I tried was way too mild [flavor and caffine] for me.  But still a solid 4 stars for a great concept!
author: Rosers M.

description: I love this place so much. Best place not only to chill, but also to work, sit with a date, etc. oh and the coffee is fantastic!
author: Anca R.

description:
This place is out of the way unless you're driving.  Soma has huge blocks, and this is about 20 minutes from the Mission if you're walking.

That said it's a really great space (albeit with the roastery still under construction).  But they're pulling fabulous shots, and were even doing a slurping contest when I walked in.  No I mean coffee cupping.
author: Sean S.

description:
The atmosphere of this place is amazing - it's like a huge, warm welcoming barn, with sky-high ceilings (rafters!) and a clean wood aesthetic. The coffee is the best I've found in the city - I like it better than Blue Bottle, even. I've always had great service - even the single drip cups get made pretty fast (and they're worth it), and the baristas have always been happy to answer questions even during their morning rush.

So why only 4 stars? For all its charm, this COFFEE SHOP does not have wireless. (!!!!!!!!!!!!!!)

It's 2012, people. EVERY place should have wireless IMHO, but for a coffee joint, it's unforgivable. However it's the only criticism I have, so they still get 4. Great for a cup of coffee, but forget about staying to enjoy it if you have any work to do.
author: Rachael K.

description:
Excellent latte, I'm sure in part due to the full fat milk, but yeah I still would have preferred if they had other milk options. I also found that mine wasn't superhot but I personally liked that, as normally I have to wait 5-10 minutes until I find coffee cool enough to drink.

I haven't had a mocha in years since I'm used to them being overly sweet and pretty ridiculous, but Sightglass's is in a whole different league. It actually tastes like good chocolate and is not all that sweet.
author: Lisa K.

description: First off let me say that working at a coffee shop I have become somewhat of a coffee snob lol But this place is awesome! The coffee itself is delicious and the chocolate kouign aman was huge, buttery and yummy! However I wish the mocha came in a bigger size because I wanted more. As for price, the coffee itself it comparable to it's competitors, but the pastries were a little pricey. Overall I will most definitely be back for more.
author: brianna t.

description: Love this location way better than the tiny Mission location. Great coffee, love the space.
author: Derrick V.

description:
No Non Fat or Low Fat milk options
Quad Latte $6 Really??? 

$2.5 for an extra shot? 

I will stick with Ritual Non Fat milk, Quad $4.35 and after 10 coffee's you get one free!
author: Ms. T.

description: Walking in to Sightglass for the first time, I was impressed and instantly intrigued by it's incredible architecture - very high, double story ceiling, an upper level plus a private extra mezzanine area! It's so interesting and fun to look at. My coffees have all been superb - they make a very good almond milk latte. Sitting upstairs is fun and gives you a nice feeling of space and air looking down over the lower level. I'll be back every day while I'm visiting San Fran!
author: Rachael A.

description: Total hipster hangout! Love the high ceilings, the rustic tables, open design, seating on 3 levels (though the top level appears to be a restricted area) and the the crowd it attracts. I  can see how this could be heaven for a coffee aficionado which I am not but I still liked it.  Only missing thing... seat covers in the toilet.
author: Sunil R.

description: "I don't usually leave the Mission. But when I do, it's for Sightglass Coffee," said the most interesting girl in the room without batting an eye.
author: Liz C.

description:
Awww yeah, excellent coffee with excellent service, music etc. Overall, great scene. Never had a bad experience here. 

It's all about that salted hooker's caramel.
author: Margaret S.

description: $4.25 is crazy overpriced for a flavorless coffee. They were nice about refunding me, though. Sure, it's a nice looking venue, but poor use of a massive space. And no wifi! Thumbs down.
author: Jonathan M.

description:
