I am writing up an article for a local blog on the grand opening of Sightglass' bigger warehouse/cafe area and was sorely disappointed with the whole experience. I bought my coffee (way overpriced even amongst ritual, bluebottle and 4 barrel IMO) and wanted to get some info from the staff. 

I asked what the plan/expectation for this place is. Their reply? "to serve coffee" Well DUH! I meant will there be food, wifi, coffee nights, cupping sessions, etc? Looking around the space (noticing no tables or chairs set up anywhere) I moved along from dumb answer number one.. I asked if they were planning on setting up tables and chairs. Answer? "Ya, well there will be chairs and tables set up eventually.. this is kind of a medium opening. I think we are planning on having a real grand opening in a month or so." My reaction= wtf?! This was advertised as a grand opening.. this is a complete and utter waste of my time. I saw other patrons in the same boat as me.. confused!

Beyond being disorganized, the company seems to be more interested in having a bigger spot for their staff to hang out in than making their customers feel welcome. I guess if you aren't down with the coffee crew, you aren't down enough to hang out there.

Might give it another shot in a couple of months.. we'll see.
author: Seema M.

description:
Got the impression upon placing my order that I was not really their desired clientele. Not hip and trendy enough. I bought a cup of coffee BB muffin. Cost $6.25, gave them 7.00 and they pocketed the tip w/o giving me to option to tip as I was planning in the jar in front of me. WTF. Are you entitled to this spare change? That was totally uncool move.

The coffee was the their Blue Boon blend or other. It seemed a bit acidic to me. I have high end coffee like this so maybe it's your cup of tea but honestly, not for me. I've had Blue Bottle too, better cup than this place. 

I checked the pricing of the roasted beans while waiting for my cup of coffee. Seemed over priced to me. On avg $15.00/0.75 lb. I'd buy Illy before buying their coffee beans. I can't say that I will be returning but I don't suspect they'll miss my type. ha ha
author: Ed S.

description: Great product, but signing and and menu are minimal and confusing for first-timers; somewhat questionable value, but tastes great!
author: Chris B.

description: Why no wireless Internet? Oh well, I still love you sightglass. Maybe for your taxidermied owl. Or the airplants on the wall, or maybe even for your sweet geometric wallpaper. I just like being in your cool looking space. That's all. Oh yes, your coffee is amazing too. And the treats!! I die
author: Amy W.

description:
When I'm at the office I try to avoid coffee at all costs! I don't want to become one of those "I'm going to go POSTAL on your ass if I don't have my cup of JOE in the morning" type of person. However there is nothing wrong with an occasional good ol' SOY LATTE after a sunny afternoon of bike shopping. 

While waiting for our bike to be built, the staff over at Marin Bikes strongly recommended we walk over to Sightglass. And damn glad I did, their soy latte was delicious! Smooth and not too sweet, exactly what I want in a Soy Latte. It wasn't overloaded with tons of sugar or taste pre-made like something you would grab at Starbucks. I'm sure all coffee aficionados would definitely appreciate a cup of coffee from Sightglass. I'm also sure they'll appreciate anything made with the "SLAYER."

I look forward to visiting Sightglass again when the roastery and coffee bar is up and running! Thumbs Up on the POS system! :)

Mmmmmm....on the next try...Hooker's Chocolate? Anyone?
author: Lisa T.

description:
I got an Americano.  It was good coffee, i enjoyed it.
BUT
It was also the most expensive and teeny-tiniest cup i have ever seen.

The building is huge... which could be a plus. They have a badass looking roaster with what looks like a large bar around it.
BUT
No one is allowed anywhere other than the small fraction of the place.
There is NO PUBLIC BATHROOM.
(As coffee connoisseurs; having a tiny toilet room isn't much to ask for considering you will definitely have to pee after having a cup of that)
INSTEAD
They tell you to "go around the corner to Brainwash" 
"just ask for the password and they'll tell you"
WTF?
Does Brainwash know Sightglass is sending customers to use their "customer only" bathrooms? (and not buy anything)

That's very snooty-tooty and rude of Sightglass.  :P
author: Astro S.

description:
I've spent a great deal of my life looking for my perfect cup of coffee...my profile has informed yelpers that I love coffee as much as my life and kids...

Sightglass to have brewed my life long dream
do not take this review lightly 

I have has coffee everywhere from diners to coffee trucks to sitting on Bondi Beach in Australia (I might add Speedos does brew a good one) a place called Cafe Rimon in Israel yes a lovely cupI have been to Miami many times not a single coffee place comes to mind.

So here in San Francisco HERE is my perfect cup

cafe Sightglass
its dreamy good DREAMY perfect 
wait it was No dream it was perfect
this is a big place with a cbunch of tables up stares

if coffee toasty bread and a coffee appeal to you then its worth a drive from almost anywhere

plus very friendly service
a perfect cup 
this review gushes praise for that beautiful cup of course I am going back
author: Johnny M.

description:
the coffee is obviously delicious, and I guess that's what matters most a coffee shop, right!?  Except, part of me can't get over the fact that they don't even offer wi-fi, and the staff is a bit pretentious.

I still go for my $4.00 latte most mornings, but I could have done without the judgment from behind their uber-hip plastic frames when I asked for...gasp....fat free milk.
author: Michelle D.

description: I love the ambience of this place.  Sure, it's pretty yuppie hipster, but at least the coffee that goes with it is wonderful! My favorite coffee in San Francisco.  Way better in my opinion than the popular Blue Bottle coffee.
author: Joseph A.

description:
If you like great coffee, are interested in design, and like converted warehouse spaces, then you'll definitely love this SOMA spot.  

I was originally introduced to this coffee shop/roastery as a quiet space to have a informal meeting and I've since been back a number of times. The massive floor plan ensures that even when busy it doesn't feel crowded. On top of this the way in which the tables, most of which are located in a pseudo loft upstairs , are set up makes Sightglass an ideal place to get work done by yourself and not be disturbed by your neighbors.

Oh and the pastries are wonderful as well, try the various croissants, they're delicious.
author: Daniel S.

description:
Things I like about sightglass: the refreshingly acidic tones that give out a much different flavor than the warmy toasty beans of ritual or the thick, syrupy blue bottle. I like the creative layout and the space that is thoughtful and wide.

Things I dislike about sightglass: 4-5 dollar coffee. even an americano was pricey and i got about 1/3 of the size of what i would get elsewhere. perhaps they've fixed the seating since i was last there, but as of my last visit, there were like, 5 stools, and that's about it. 

i love the idea -- but having gotten no impression from the baristas nor others there, I'm not really excited to come back. Part of the charm of other coffee places is that communal/lively feeling, and i'm really missing that here. hooker's sweet treats at least gives me that.
author: Asaf K.

description:
The Hooker's* are a little bit pricey, but worth every penny! So grab a box to go along with you coffee.

*Sea salted Dark Chocolate Covered Caramels
author: Theresa D.

description:
No hype on sightglass. This is legit.

This is what coffee tastes like if you do everything right.
author: Nicholas H.

description: Tried the Guatemala fresh brew, tasted a bit sour? I drink a lot of coffee so that was a bit odd. Another loss in star for no wifi ... First coffee shop I have visited with no wifi.
author: Lindsay C.

description: I'd say pretty much everything you hear about this place is accurate.  The people here like what they do, coffee is good quality.  There are a bunch of tech people here talking about their ideas for start up businesses.  I really like the decor in here and the way they have it set up.  Definitely my SoMa go to.
author: Charles C.

description: Great coffee, no doubt. But the staff come across as arrogant and rude. Whether your product is amazing or mediocre it can't hurt to be nice.
author: Jonathan W.

description:
In writing my reviews, I really try to refrain from hyperbole. In this case, however, it's not hyperbole to say that this is the best cup of coffee I have ever had, on any continent, in my entire life.

I stopped into Boot and Shoe Service (A restaurant) in the Oakland, Lake Merritt Area to get a cup of coffee. They brewed it through a filter into my to-go cup. As I was walking down the street I took a sip and it stopped me in my tracks! This is how coffee must taste in heaven. Such care is taken in the roasting process and such care is taken in the brewing of each cup that it leaves you feeling that Sight Glass Coffee made it just for you. 

I just purchased a pound of Owl's Espresso and a pound of the blend for my house. I'm going to use their coffee on my food truck and people are going to be blown away! Guys, I'm making a field trip up there to see you ASAP!

Thank you Sight Glass Coffee.
author: Mark H.

description: Sightglass Coffee is one of most awesome coffee place i have ever been to. They got huge space with seats, and wifi at the upper deck. The entire glass is built like wood interior which makes it cooler than anything else. I highly recommend it as a workplace for entrepreneurs in San Francisco. Just keep buying coffee!
author: Prateek G.

description: The coffee is 'eh middle of the road. I read the reviews 'no wifi' which I can understand and roll with, but there are no outlets and no soy milk either. Fuck this place. At least post what you don't have so I don't waste my money and charge on my phone finding somewhere that actually wants me to stick around. Staff is rude about the total lack of outlets as well. I understand that I am not entitled to their electricity. But the intentional hiding of outlets is rude and weird.
author: Laura A.

description:
Stopped into Sight Glass Coffee at the new cafe for the first time. Was so excited by their selection of breakfast and dessert pastries I impulsively devoured a light cake like brownie filled with crunchy hazelnuts and a layer of drippy salted caramel from Telltale Preserve Co. 

Back to the coffee - had a latte where the freshly roasted coffee really was the star. So good.

The seating is oriented around the window and roaster, more Italian coffee bar style than sit and work on your computer all day style. Lovely wall of windows, perfect for reading and meeting.

The location is kind of in the middle of everything, convenient off the freeway, on it, from the train, or even the police station (what better way to reward yourself than an expert cup of joe?)

If you haven't been to Sight Glass do visit one of San Francisco's best roasters.
author: Susie W.

description: The spot is beautiful and the coffee is delicious, and OMG, what a cool little point of sale system they have (nice work Jack!!).  But, like this review, the portions are so tiny!
author: Jon E.

description:
I added Sightglass to my walking route while taking on additional properties to supervise.  

The added work is neutralized by lovely stops into Sightglass to pick up a blueberry muffin with olive oil and sunflower seeds on top. 

The coffee is tops.  

The interior's open space and exposed steel and wooden beams, lovely.  

Not so much, the ventilation in the bathrooms.  I'll just leave it at that.  

Make it a point to find yourself in this formerly industrial-zoned neighborhood for a terrific cup of coffee and sit for a bit.
author: Colleen C.

description: I think this cafe has one of the best coffees in San Francisco. Not only they have great coffee, the cafe is very spacious. It has two floors and most of the time, tech nerds are there for hours so it may be difficult to find a spot to hang out.
author: Ricky M.

description: Get the Vanilla Ice Coffee with whole milk! I generally don't drink coffee but was very happy with theirs! The ambiance is hipster central but I don't care. It has a big open space and very clean.
author: Hasang Paul K.

description: Excellent vanilla cold brew iced coffee with almond milk. Pastries and snacks are high quality but don't expect a full meal. There is no Wi-Fi here... Lots of seating and cool atmosphere. One of my favorite coffee spots in SF and on the same level as Philz and Blue Bottle
author: Andrew K.

description: The only coffee on the planet I can drink black! Love this place. The vibe is so cool here people working are friendly and the coffee is mighty powerful! The pastries are delicious and when you're here you feel like you're a part of something really special!
author: Amanda S.

description:
My roommate and I wanted to go here once to hang out and do our homework in our very first weeks when we lived close by. But they had no internet!! It's a place to enjoy coffee and company. No computers, maybe you can bring a book if you come on your own or play with your phone.
I went on a first date here about a month ago, and when I googled to find where this place was (I hadn't paid attention to the name the first time I stopped by) it was described as the "best coffee in town" and....the coffee is pretty good! I really like the ambience because tables and everything are made out of wood, and the place is very spacious. I feel like it can never get too crowded, and there is an upstairs floor where you can sit and talk as long as you want. I would definitely recommend it if you're with someone else, or just like good coffee. The menu is very minimalistic but they have all the basic coffees so everyone can find an option they like. I like this because it cuts the time waiting in line because people have less options and can't be too particular on their order.  My date didn't like anything on the menu so he asked for something different - still simple though - and they made it without problems.
author: Dodi G.

description: The Honduras pour over was fantastic! Complex and made to perfection. The bacon cheddar scone was delicious addition.
author: Samantha W.

description: I loved this place! Fun, hip atmosphere, rich, amazing coffee, and they have almond milk for those of us who avoid cow liquid.  The place has a great buzz.
author: Carla C.

description:
For a city priding itself on great food, SF sure has a lot of really bad coffee. Returning after two years in Edinburgh, a city with an almost exactly reversed disposition, I was despairing of finding a place for a good morning cuppa. But then a friend -- an Edinburgh friend -- told me about Sightglass. This place is what I gather Blue Bottle was like in the early days: a garage, a bench and a bunch of enthusiatic guys making really, really good joe. They roast their own, make solid drip, and could even (some of them) throw together a passable flat white. 

Sightglass has expansion plans, and who knows where that leads? So come in now while they still make great coffee for a small, enthusiastic audience.
author: Marc T.

description:
It was Ruggy J who pointed Colleen C and me in this direction as we trekked out for a misty morning walk. Destination: Caffeine. 

A little tough to spot - even with the added clue of a sandwich board sign on the corner of Folsom and 8th - but once we clued in, we were set. Reminiscent of a scene from a show like Portlandia, we set to ordering 3 Americanos from the duck in side of what looks like a rather large roasting facility. Cash - or in this case - square is taken only at the end when your coffees have been delivered which makes for a bit of confusion in a pre-caffeinated haze. The staff are pretty friendly about it though. 

The only receipt choice I was given was text, but it failed to execute. Luckily for us, the expert espresso shot pull more than made up for it and we could get on to our days, and back out to the street... because Sightglass is much more geared for coffee and walking than sipping and sitting.
author: Crystal H.

description: I loved this little Coffee joint. Wonderful environment. The only thing I dont like is that there is no wifi at locale and very few outlets available, so it makes it difficult to go and work here. The coffee is absolutely amazing!
author: Elizabeth D.

description: A lovely coffee shop. Heaps and Heaps of coffee beans piled high in canvas sacks just to the right of the entry way. Large beautiful windows, hardwood decor, concrete floor, and high ceilings. Great coffee and espresso and they carry caramels and chocolates by Hookers (see Hookers review).
author: Elizabeth T.

description: Must try. Good iced coffee selections. Nice interior design. Excellent coffee.
author: Anonymous ?.

description: This place is absurdly nice (from an architectural perspective). When I walked in, I wasn't sure if I wanted to get a coffee or move in. Maybe both. I tried the coffee (not from the typical machine but straight from a french press) and the blueberry pistachio croissant... which cost me ~$10. I'm pretty sure you'd feel more comfortable in this setting if you walked in with skinny jeans, thick rimmed glasses and an ironic t-shirt.
author: Dora C.

description:
They now carry DYNAMO donuts *DROOOL*

Love the LATTEs!! It's a special Friday treat for me at Sightglass.

The space is open, airy, different. Not your typical cafe.
author: Oanh N.

description:
It was... 11 o'clock? 

One of those foggy Sunday mornings where you wake up late and can't seem to shake the fuzz for a few hours. In this random and deserted area after of town, digging on caffeine, daydreaming of Ritual, Blue Bottle, Coffee Bar...

Unhealthily dependent on my electronic device, I pulled it out and yelped nearby, completely sure the case was hopeless, that was no chance on earth of anything decent... 

wait, something just around the corner!

I stepped into a bare and open storefront with only concrete floors, wood shelf, brown ceramic cups, roasting-ware, and a silver espresso machine. A barista in a colorful scarf was serving rich, earthy espresso.
author: Elizabeth M.

description:
The interior is gorgeous. The coffee was definitely good, but didn't necessarily stand out against any of the other artisinal places I've been in Seattle, Portland or California in general. The caneles were amazing though, other pastries were also very good. 

The prices were steep. I wish they had wifi and some more comfortable seating, but for such an amazing space and being able to watch the roasting process I still enjoyed myself. The canele really was perfect.
author: Michael F.

description: Came here for a cup of coffee while waiting for a table at Bar Agricole.  The space looks great.  There wasn't any furniture when I went, but it would be a nice place to chill at.  The coffee was good but not amazing.  I would come back if I was in the area.  Four stars anyway for roasting it right there!
author: Erika C.

description:
This is a hard joint to review, because it's really either a 4.5 star review or a 1 star review depending on why you go to a coffee shop.  

I've been there several times since it's full opening.  Each time the coffee was very good -- comparable to the other high end coffee shops in S.F.  The baked goods were very good -- among the best I've had at a S.F. cafe.  The interior is spacious and well designed.  This is a fantastic place to pop into to grab a coffee and danish and be on your way.

On the other hand, if you want to sit in a comfy chair... well there are only six stools in the entire place.  The rest is standing room only.  No place to plug in anything, so don't be expecting to charge up any devices while you are here.  If you are looking for a place to lounge, walk down the Street and grab a table at Brainwash or Wicked Grounds.  

btw, it's great to see that area of SOMA swing the way it has, with new stores opening daily.  One can only imagine when the full Twitter effect hits, what the place will look like.
author: John T.

description:
BOOM!!! Finally some coffee that is amazing and addicting. Awesome real estate location with roasting on the premises! It' always nice to sit and stare out the large window at the passers by! Interesting folk are often walking by, while sipping on some amazing Joe. 
I would also like to add, best beans, turned to best capp! I love the designs made in my foam!!
author: Jay K.

description: Sightglass coffee is one of my favorites. partially because the coffee is fantastic and partially because the design of their retail store is sort of amazeballs. it's a very spacious hipster type place. they've got a few terrariums in there, a taxidermy owl, high ceilings and two levels of chatting space. they do pretty things with your mocha's foam and the giant sliding glass door in the front is awesome. you should probably check it out sometime. invite me while you're at it.
author: Regina C.

description:
Hipsters paradise. Here's how my visit went:

1. found parking on 7th without a problem. Metered parking $3.00/hr. M-Sa max 2 hours, Sun max 4 hours. Decided not to drive around to look for non metered parking because I was an an out of order one ka ching! But do bring a big bag of quarters if you expect to stay for awhile. 

2. I  walk into a warm, naturally lit, cafe. Laid back environment, lots of woody tones, kind of like a decorated warehouse that was trying really hard to not try hard.

3. The Ordering.
CB: "Soy Latte please"
Barista: "Sorry, no soy, just almond milk is that ok?"
CB: "Ok, can you ice it please?"
Barista: "Sorry, no I can't the espresso turns papery and gross when poured over ice. I do have some pour over ice options" 
CB: " it's okay, i'll take it hot. Can you drizzle some honey on top?"
Barista: "Sorry, no we do things pretty simple here, no honey. I do have some raw sugar you can sprinkle on top."
CB: "ok that's fine." At this point I was like hmm maybe I shouldn't dare ask for Vanilla syrup.... 
Then I get this really delicious crossaint from the case. So point is, not TOO many coffee options. They keep it REAL simple here. But at least the barista wasn't pretentious or as rude as others had described. He was really nice about things. There were definitely more pastry options than coffee options. Anyways, the lattee was DELICIOUS. I sprinkled some extra sugar on it and i was a happy camper.

Total: $8.75 More than my average starbucks bill, but things did taste pretty good, fresh and natural. So I was a fan.  They do take credit cards thank goodness! 

4. The ambiance: I went upstairs carefully carrying my coffee and my plate of food, but not too bad. Upstairs you find two large tables with room for about 10 people. One long counter overlooking the cafe with room for abouter 5- 7 adn then 4 tables against the wall with room for 4-5. On the first floor they have some long counters with stools as well. It was pretty easy to find a place to sit and read.

Overall, I'd be happy to come back here again. It had a hipster vibe, yes ridicuously. But i did like how laid back things were. 

PS. the bathrooms were  kind of gross the day I went. I walked into one, no TP. I walked into another and it made me want to vomit and the door nob on the inside of the bathroom was wet. GROSS. Also mysterious puddles in the bathroom too... Definitely needed tons of hand sanitizer for that one. That deserves a star lost. Hopefully just a fluke and they get their bathroom act together like their coffee act!
author: Christine B.

description:
Dear Sightglass, I would tell you this in person but I'm always late to work when I visit and surrounded by pretentious SOMA hipsters (of which I may or may not admittedly be one) so I always chicken out. But now that I'm at work I have time/courage so here goes:

Your decaf is incredibly disappointing. 

I would really appreciate it if you put the same effort and pride into it that I've heard you put into your other beverages. 

Thanks for listening.
author: Thea K.

description:
Sad fact:  Unless you've been drinking local, micro-roasted only, you probably don't actually know what good coffee tastes like.  See, most coffee is roasted dark, so it tastes like roast.  Big producers buy crappy beans, and you have to burn them a bit to hide the mediocre flavors.   Even some small roaster head into the land of dark, trying to appeal to the ruined commercial drinker's palet. People love that dark, bitter swag, but you aren't actually tasting coffee, just roast.

If you want to actually taste coffee, and not burnt beans that formerly tasted like coffee until someone roasted the snot out of them, go to Sightglass.  They do the best job in SF of roasting; you can taste the origin character of the bean, and if there is roast flavor, it's there to compliment, not cover up.  There's a couple other local places that come in a close second, but these cats nail it, every time.

They can be a little grumpy when it's busy, but it's never egregious.  I think the time line for their full cafe opening is toward the end of Obama's second term, based on current progress.  The lack of available decaf espresso is a bit of a chafe (SG: I'll buy you a decaf bean grinder, if that's what takes).    Despite those niggles, they roast so damn good... this is the top of the pile in SF.
author: A B.

description: Pastries are a delight, and the interior / atmosphere are a charming blend of roasting warehouse and hipster-urban coffee-shop. It's a beautiful, large, well-lit space that's great for sit down meeting. The only major downside is the lack of outlets and wifi - for a soma and startup scene staple this is almost unacceptable - though they do seem to be getting away with it.
author: Milan T.

description:
Amazing coffee.
Attractive people. 
Awesome space.
author: Maya G.

description:
Just to clarify, this is a coffee stop, not a coffee shop. Don't plan on setting up your mobile office here!

I try to buy beans here on a Tuesday or Thursday right as they are roasted. Then I spend the following week completely strung out by brewing and consuming far more coffee than is healthy or normal, especially if it is Kenyan.

The espresso offerings are another reason I cannot possibly hope to win a game of Jenga or Operation. It is challenging to bicycle past and not stop in for an espresso shot. The addiction progresses.
author: Alan F.

description: This is my first stop every time I visit San Francisco (well, after the bathroom, Facebook, and Scruff). It is very San Francisco: gorgeous, delicious, and a tad irritating. The coffee is amazing, comparable to the best high-end cages in San Francisco and LA. The space, which looks like a thesis project for a PhD in Dwell Magazinology, is bright and open and woody. There's even a taxidermied owl perched over the the main floor. Yes, I want to live in This space. But the management don't want you to hang out longer than it takes to read half a New Yorker article. The chairs bug after 15 minutes and there's no wifi and not an outlet to be found. Still, I return. Again and again.
author: Ted G.

description:
I've never had a smoother cappuccino. 

At $3 and in quite a small cup, it's got the perfect amount of that caffeine kick that will jumpstart my morning. 

Sightglass is the real thang. I wish everything in life was as smoooooth as their coffee.
author: Vanessa W.

description: Quite a good latte that was (rich, deep, good body, full of caffeine). Ultra-cool space. Clean like Seinfeld's apartment.
author: Derek N.

description: Ah, man that hits the spot. Nothing like a great cup of black coffee.
author: Dale C.

description:
Strong positives: Awesome coffee, great space.  Fun to watch the roasting and packaging in process.  The line moved quickly, unlike in some other coffee places that were otherwise very good.

The coffee was very nearly as good as Blue Bottle's (very expensive) siphon brew at a third of the price.  Keep the adulterants far away from your cup - it definitely needs no milk, sugar, or anything else.  I had a Colombian, my gf had a Rwandan, and both were amazing.  Their roasters and baristas clearly know what they're doing.

Small negatives: Lack of Wifi didn't kill me, since I use my phone for that, and the place was pretty crowded anyway.  The ginger blueberry muffin I had was pretty bad, though.  This obviously isn't a dealbreaker, but I had an amazing blackberry and pistachio croissant at Four Barrel, so something halfway decent at Sightglass would have been nice.
author: Ira P.

description: A delicious cup of drip coffee for sure, but over $5 bucks for an albeit large cup of single source kenyan is a bit much.
author: David S.

description:
Beautiful space.
 barista overcharged me for 2 coffees and after asking her about it she did not think to apologize instead acted as if I had asked to be overcharged (almost 9$ for two small coffees)... it was bizarre and awkward. 

otherwise, coffee tasted fine,  beautiful tables, night light.  But no wifi. 

sorry but no wifi=no buying expensive coffee.  If this place had wifi i'd probably go there daily regardless of the dumb barista chick
author: Keenan M.

description: The coffee is good. The ambience is nice, but when your shop is located in a tech hub like SoMa, you should provide your customers with outlets. I flew into town for a meeting and had 18% battery on my computer. I explained my situation to one of your employees, and she still made me unplug my laptop from an outlet I found upstairs (where phone chargers were available), which means I had to pack up and leave. Your shop was equally close as a national chain to the office where my meeting was, and next time, unfortunately I will be choosing the other coffee shop. Her rationale as to why the owners might have designed it that way when people clearly come here to work: "maybe they wanted people to come here and talk." Yes, people want to talk...while using their various devices that require charging. Stop trying to be cute, you're part of the new soulless tech SF, just embrace it and be useful.
author: Jennifer B.

description: This was a great coffee shop and I would recommend this to most but its doesn't cater to all people
author: Andreas C.

description:
with so many great coffee shops in SF, this place does not fail to disappoint me either. i ordered their soy latte and I was impressed by the taste of it. first of all, they put the right amount of coffee to soy milk ratio so that the soy milk is not overpowering the coffee. (i was disappointed at four barrel's soy latte since their soy milk was overpowering) 

the price is not cheap but it's not ridiculously expensive either. my soy latte came out to $3.50 for a small cup, but i don't know why people complain about the price. would you seriously rather pay like maybe $.50 at most cheaper at starbucks and get mediocre coffee?

i would put this place slightly above four barrel (but not by much, they're both great still!)
author: Spencer E.

description:
This coffee shop is amazing. From its super stylish warehouse feeling to its decor and servers, everything is really cool.

I love the feeling of this kind of cafe, a feeling there the baristas here are artists that love coffee more than anything else. The "crafted fresh roasted house made coffee" feeling is all over the place here, awesome.

And of course, the place is really beautiful, so make sure to stay around and enjoy the environment. The prices are a bit on the higher end.

To make it perfect they need to offer free wi-fi ;)
author: Gisele M.

description: Had an AMAZING shot of espresso here just now. Crema was thick & golden, flavor rich & nutty, presentation was awesome, and the service was extremely friendly. I'm gonna be going back to Sight Glass every time I come to SF for sure
author: Shannon P.

description:
I'm giving Sightglass 4 stars because I do like their beverages and their beans - I get them all the time at Matching Half in NOPA.  But, NO cup of coffee should cost $4.25 (unless each bean was individually ground by hand).  

I can get the same pour-over at Matching Half (ok, fine, maybe it's not made using a Hario kettle and a Chemex), for half the price!

Don't have us subsidize the cost of that Slayer.
author: Sripal M.

description:
Let me be honest the quality of coffee in this place is over my head. The process and attention to detail is amazing on, what I am guessing, is the best way to brew coffee. The actual facility is also a remarkable accomplishment. Big old windows line the street and wood fixtures through out the place make it a frequent afternoon stop for our office. 

By no means cheep but really could not be a better experience for getting coffee that looks and taste like it gets a lot of love.
author: Ryan B.

description: This is my favourite coffee place in SF. The staff are super friendly, they get great pastries from other bakeries and the coffee is phenomenal. I always get espresso drinks, but have been told the drip coffee is just as good.
author: Mike B.

description: Really cool space, very hip.  Very airy and spacious.  There was a long line on Saturday afternoon.  We ordered an americano and latte.  As Yelpers have indicated, they're not good about customizing drinks.  I asked for an upside down latte with the shot on top and the cashier said that wasn't an option.  But at least my drink was very smooth.  We also ordered some baked goods including chocolate chip cookies - those were pretty good.
author: Vivian W.

description: After hearing all the hype about Sightglass (voted over Blue Bottle and Philz?!), I needed to trek over there to find out for myself.  When I first walked in, I was really impressed by the beautiful space.  Compared to all the top-notch coffee places in SF, this place was huge, open, beautiful.  I ordered a latte, and upon first sip, I wasn't that into it.  It was definitely more bitter than I had expected, and I even had to add sugar to it (usually prefer not to add sugar to my lattes).  I didn't end up finishing it, and I walked away feeling a bit disappointed.  Maybe it was an off day, but I still think Blue Bottle and Philz reign supreme.
author: Mel G.

description:
Sweet! Went back recently and discovered they had miraculously changed the few little things that didn't jive the first time around.

The counter situation is much more clearly laid out, and they've opened up the top area for seating - it has all these great long rough-wood tables that are perfect for groups and collaborative projects (as long as you don't need wifi).

I'm so on board with everything Sightglass chooses to be. A little deliberately pretentious, perhaps, but in the very best way possible.
author: C. G.

description: The atmosphere and decor is cool, but that's where it stops. No wifi. The don't sell tea (of any types) and the staff is short and snarky. I honestly don't know why it's so crowded. If you want an environment that is reminiscent of the old, cool, SF coffee houses ...keep looking!
author: Michael H.

description: The space is pretty cool and you can see the whole operation...very interesting. Friendly staff and of course...the coffee was absolutely delicious. I would have to say it's one of the best latte's I've had in the city, if not the best...will definitely come back to this place every time I get a chance.
author: George M.

description: Fantastic expresso drinks and lovely surroundings while you sip!
author: Matthew J M.

description: First of all, I RARLEY write reviews on here so when I go out of my way to write one, I mean it. This place was so disappointing. I am from out of town, and am an avid coffee drinker so I know what I like- this was NOT what I like. I ordered a hot mocha which costed $5 (decent, it's what I usually pay) but it was a cup the size of a kids drink, probably 8 ounces. We also ordered an iced mocha and it came in the same hot, 8oz cup, just with a few ice cubes in it. The staff was just okay. The barista didn't talk or even look happy and the only one who spoke to me was the cashier and it was only to take my money. This place seems either very pretentious or they just don't really care. I give two stars because my hot mocha was bearable (even though I did throw it away after a few sips...) but the iced mocha, NO WAY. STAY AWAY. It tasted like cold, bitter, and dead espresso mixed with some water and maybe some nonfat milk or something. It tasted like water pretty much. Bitter, burnt water. Threw it away after one sip. Thanks for wasting $10 from my bank account for bad coffee, underwhelming service, and an atmosphere that was not welcoming and where everyone seemed too engulfed in their laptops to even look remotely happy on this nice day. I came visiting out of town and I only have one chance to get coffee on the day I am here and I am extremely let down by this shop. Yes, it is cute and has that nice ascetic inside but do not let that fool you. I wish I could get my money back. I will not be coming here any time soon or recommending it to anyone I know.
author: Erin J.

description:
There is a great marketing mind behind this cafe. It has the young, cool vibe. They play vinyl on a Macintosh system,. You order a coffee? They drip it into a 12 oz cup. The cappuccino has designs drawn in it (not so new but nice to see nonetheless). Actually, none of this is new but it is presented in a fresh and cool manner. Shouldn't forget to mention the cappuccino was delicious.

There is a very relaxing and friendly atmosphere. I went in to buy a cappuccino to take away and felt I wanted to linger a little and wound up finishing my drink there instead. The space is large and mostly empty leaving you with an unhurried, very relaxed feeling. And the staff are quite friendly, no complaints there. 

This is a quality place. It's a little expensive and that alone may hurt it's chances for survival. I don't think it has hit it's supply-demand equilibrium. The beans are a trifle on the high side as well. $20 for a 12 oz. bag is not going to have me running back for more to satisfy my morning swill though it might be nice for a dinner party.

Pricing aside, the creators and designers of this place have it down. I hope this style of place is on the rise.

Kudos.
author: Mark K.

description:
Sightglass is my favorite coffee. They do lighter roasts, which brings out flavors that I didn't know coffee could have. They tend to have a couple of different roasts on pourover, and I like to come with a friend so we can try both. It takes a little longer because they make each cup, but I never felt it was unreasonable for a place that isn't in a rush. Downstairs they have long bars and stools to sit at, which is great for chatting with one person or contemplating the terrainiums decorating the area.

This is sipping coffee. If you just want a fix or you like to put a lot of stuff in your coffee, don't bother with Sightglass--you will probably find their prices big and quantities small. If you want to savor something special, stop by, leave your laptop in your bag, and enjoy.
author: E R.

description: You can't deny it, it's good coffee. Is it the BEST place in the whole city for a good vibe? Maybe, maybe not. Personally, no I don't think so, and this mostly has to do with the uninviting feel I get from the employees when I'm there. I get it- you're at work, you don't want to be that bubbly person at the register all day, faking it. But I just feel unwelcome for some reason..maybe because I 'm the type that enjoys a random chat or friendly encounter, but my star knock-off doesn't have to do with the coffee quality. It' great, and you won't be disappointed.
author: Courtney M.

description: The coffee is delicious. They treat coffee making as an art and go through so much trouble to make it perfectly for you. Sometimes I'll just wander in and walk around, so I look cool. But usually I just get coffee and drink it while people watching from the loft above.
author: Christine S.

description:
Great coffee, amazing space, cool atmosphere, nice staff.
We stayed around the block for a few days and had complimentary "coffee" but it was definitely not going in my mouth. I passed Sightglass the night before trying it and had to go there the next day. What an incredible space, so open and airy. I am not a huge coffee drinker/snob but appreciate the good stuff. Got a single cup of Ecuador coffee, don't remember the specifics but it was damn good. We came back each of the next two days and I got lattes. They care about their coffee and it shows.
author: Brandi H.

description: Bummed that the cold brew was only served New Orleans Style w/ sugar but the atmosphere and other drinks were nothing less than outstanding. A must try.
author: Max H.

description:
"Oh. We don't ice our espresso."

Wow. Well, LA-DEE-DAH.

If I hadn't been with friends I would have just walked out. It wasn't just what she said, but the way she said it. The very embodiment of hipster snoot. Wonder why hipsters have a reputation? Places like this. Newsflash: It's a coffee shop, not Buckingham Palace. In fact, I suspect you'd get a warmer reception from the guards outside Buckingham Palace. And it's not like the coffee is all that great.

If you want mediocre coffee, service with a tude, and to be surrounded by oh-too-good-for-you hipster chic, this is your place. Me? First and last time.
author: Edward J.

description: It was okay. Very hipster. Like the kind where I can't get comfortable because there's hipsters everywhere pretending not to care. Coffee was okay too. It was just okay.
author: Dominique D.

description:
For coffee, this place should really be rated as $$$ or $$$$.  The cheapest, smallest cup is around $5.00.  In my eyes, even Starbucks is highway robbery when people could make pretty much the same stuff right in their own kitchens for 1/4 of the price. So be prepared to pay the price.

These people take coffee seriously. Every cup is individually slow dripped-- this makes the wait for the coffee a little longer than you would want if you're trying to get in & get out. I would say it takes about 6-9 minutes for a coffee depending on the number of customers.  I had a Guatemalan strain.. which was mid priced.  They have coffees for $6-7 for a small cup if you really really want to splurge. Seems like coffee is the way to go. Espresso drinks were much cheaper but have gotten poor reviews.

The coffee is on the acidic side- which I like, and the caffeine content is HIGH. You definitely get the bang for you buck there.  I drink coffee everyday, usually I never feel the buzz, but halfway through my expensive small cup of coffee I was flying!

However, the slow drip coffee seems to be the only thing really working here.  The design of the place is modern and interesting but very empty and it feels confused.  Like the owner can't decide to leave it modern or add chairs and tables. There are a couple places to sit, but not many.  The cream, sugar, etc. are in the weirdest hardest to find place-- and a place of this caliber should have simple syrup, IMO.

If you're into high-tech-- you'll love the payment/ordering system.  Everything done with ipads, with attached credit card readers-- you can add the tip electronically, you sign with your finger, and you can choose to email, print or have no receipt.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
Rain or shine, the baristas at Sightglass always seem to have a smile on their faces. I pass here at least once a day and finally ventured in for a cup of coffee, dripped just for me. Though I wish the cup was bigger (I already want another cup), this is a fantastic cup of Joe. 

I watched as several others ordered and waited for their lattes, hot chocolate, and espresso... each made with love and care. Patrons stood, chatted, and laughed despite the terrible weather we're having. The service great, the location convenient, and the beans superb. Next time I'm going to go for a mocha... I want to try this chocolate others speak of.
author: Kristin F.

description: Bacon and gruyere brioche... so good. Beautiful space. Next time I'll try the coffee.
author: Angie C.

description:
they have switched from soy milk to almond milk.  :(  i don't love almond milk (unless it's homemade), but the one they use is pretty neutral in flavor and decent.

$5 is kind of a lot to pay for a mocha, especially when there's not much chocolate in it.
author: Helen T.

description: This is some seriously good stuff.  I've never been to the cafe, but I have a bag of their Papua New Guinea http://sightglasscoffee.com/indonesia-1/papua-new-guinea-kunjin-estate.html -- I purchased it in Local 123 in Berkeley.  This coffee recalls the thrill of my first beans from Blue Bottle.  Blue Bottle is still very good, of course, but some of their recent offerings have not soared.  Sightglass keeps the bar high, maybe even raising it.  I'm very definitely a fan!
author: Kenneth R.

description:
Yessss, 

at last, a gourmet café in SoMa.

Refreshing interior design, clever details, open and bright.
Pastries are amazing, and I always get my (hot) chocolate fix.
People serving you are consistently nice, the music is eclectic, really good vibes.
A promising additional dimension with their upcoming upstairs level.

Definitely a fine café to have in the neighborhood.
author: marion p.

description: I have been to many coffee shops in the Bay Area, and I have to say that this place is the best so far. I love the atmosphere, the decor and the baristas are superb. I usually have the almond latte, and it is always perfect. I highly recommend this place, if you love coffee you must come here!
author: Ross H.

description: This coffee is okay, rather bitter. The building great and there are tons of places to sit!
author: Chelsea G.

description:
Funny story about this place. When it first opened, I was walking around and looking for blue bottle coffee. I didn't see a name for this place, and it looked and smelled like it had coffee, but I wasn't sure.

So, I walk in, and ask the lady in there if she knows where Blue Bottle Coffee is. 

She goes, oh you should try the coffee here. And I ask "What is this place". She goes its "Slight Glass".

I hear "Psyche Class" (Psychology class).

I look around, and there were 2-3 people sitting in a row on a wooden bench, there was a curtain covering a back area (where they are building a bigger coffee bar) but I thought there were waiting to go to psyche class, behind the curtain.

So, I look her dead in the eyes and I go, "Oh, I'm not in that class".

It got awkward hard and fast within seconds. She continues looking at me, with a giant question mark over her head. Her expression conveyed to me that I had done something stupid. I back track, and said, wait this is "psyche class"? She goes, nope. Slight Glass.

I got the coffee. I drank it. And I LOVED it. 

Ever since then, I have been coming here often. My experience has been much less awkward, and I excited to see when they will expand. We need some class and good coffee in the neighborhood. Brainwash is good, but the coffee does kind of taste a little like rocket fuel. 

Stop by and have some coffee here, you won't be disappointed :)
author: Anish B.

description: excited about finding a onsite roasting company. Disappointed in this hipster idea that we can't have a choice of low fat or full fat milk. A $4 dollar latte in a cappuccino cup.  Outsourced pasties really great!
author: Alison B.

description:
Totally baffled by this.

We ordered a mocha and it tasted nothing like a mocha, much less coffee. It was also in a child-size cup and $4.75. Totally duped! Went there because I'm a fin of @jack and @square, but was expecting a lot more!
author: Caitlin L.

description: didn't think it was that great. been to many places , this reminded me of Red Rock of Mountain view coffee . choice is quite limits
author: Elijah S.

description:
Possibly my favorite coffee shop in all of San Francisco.  Love that there is bike parking, and that you can sit around the roaster and chat.  

Of course the coffee is delicious too
author: Dave W.

description: If you love coffee and having that coffee served in a place with a cool laid back vibe.  Then this is it.   Along with enough seating and an open and airy space with concrete floors and an industrial flavor to its styling, with wood tables & hardwood floors upstairs, and concrete walls, and a cool stairway leading to the loft.  (Which also has ample seating, yet another plus!) First thing that I noticed was the lovey aroma of FRESH coffee, they roast their own coffee!  Along with an impressive array of goodies to eat, pastries, sweets and sandwiches.  I had my usual vanilla latte, but with almond milk, instead of soy.  It was made with an artistic flair you'd expect from a place that looks this cool, from the inside as well as the outside.  My latte had a beautiful "heart flower", impressive.  I'm so glad I "discovered" this coffee heaven, while driving up 7th, you can't miss it, as its painted dark brown, the color of wonderful, glorious coffee!   A latte,  along with a good book, and a seat by the window, and I'm very happy indeed.  And ready hit the shops at the Square.
author: Winny S.

description:
A glorious temple to the caffeine gods.

Outstanding coffee in a beautifully redone restored warehouse.  Coffee is subjective, of course, but I think Sightglass's espresso roast trumps other more established SF institutions (Four Barrel, Blue Bottle, Ritual, etc.).  The decision to offer only soy and whole milk is a bold one, but I'm fine with it.

No WiFi or noticeable outlets, but a nice scene of urbanites spread across an immense space.   No real food to speak of, the focus is really on the drinks.  If this place was closer to home, I'd be there every day.

(Note: Discount all pre-2011 reviews, the place did a massive renovation last year)
author: Matt G.

description:
Good lord. 

This place is amazing; more than a coffee shop, also a designers dream. Does't hurt that my americana was delicious and kept me jacked for the entire day. The SOMA district is growing and I'm a supporter of that!
author: Mennlay A.

description: Great coffee, and vibe is really great. Lots of people chatting. Tried the gluten free almond cake (dry and not recommended), but the coffee was great!
author: Christine P.

description:
I'm not a connoisseur of coffee, so I can't attest to it being better than blue bottle or philz, but it's definitely not over roasted like starbucks or peet's. They take their time brewing each cup, so get ready for a wait.

What really sets this place apart though is the space. It's an amazing place to study, hang out, or just get coffee. Great place to just sit and talk and enjoy a lazy sunday afternoon. It looks like they roast their own beans there, and the overall use of wood, glass and concrete in an open loft environment makes it very warm and inviting.
author: Henry T.

description:
PROS: Great space. Cool design. Delicious coffees and teas.

CONS: No internet / wi-fi. High prices, even for SF ($3.50 for a small piece of lemon cake).
author: Wes F.

description:
For YEARS... (dare I say DECADES) I've been looking for an espresso similar to what I got in Europe. I've search high and low in the US. Tried the creme de la creme of espresso bars and FINALLY found the espresso blend that's not bitter. Totally smooth and actually has real sweet tones to it.

Owls Howl!!!!

The answer to all my prayers!!! AND they are local! SWEET!!! Thank you Sightglass for this wonderful coffee roast!
author: She R. A.

description: This place is gorgeously designed with great lighting, huge windows, chill music and GREAT coffee. It's also the epitome of hipster central. While I don't think the coffee is quite as good as Blue Bottle, it's definitely giving it a run for its money. Vanilla cold brew is perfect for chilling with a book or friend on a weekend.
author: Steve S.

description:
For context: despite being naturally caffeinated, and despite several attempts at giving the stuff up entirely, I hereby admit I am a coffee lover. I frequent Philz and Coffeebar.

I refuse to give into the temptation of declaring any place "the best in SF" because SF has really, really delicious coffee with somewhat different offerings that are unfair to compare.

Anyway, Sightglass falls into the "really delicious coffee" category. 

(In the interest of full disclosure, I don't like Blue Bottle. It tastes a bit bitter to me and it jangles my nerves.) 

This Sightglass location is gorgeous - spacious and industrial, with plants and high ceilings and excellent people watching. I'd be happy to work here all day.
author: D Z.

description:
Loved it!!!

Great atmosphere, great look, AMAZING coffee!!! It was my first time going to Sightglass so I asked the barista a few questions, which he answered easliy. Coffee came within a minute or so. One taste and i was hooked!!!! 

The coffee needs NO cream or sugar, I will def be coming back!!
author: Brandon H.

description:
This place is cool ... It has a very hip kinda feel to it ... I gotta admit sometimes when I walk in I do feeler a tiny bit cooler .. 

The space is huge .. think rustic warehouse done up to look like coffee roast ... They play cool 60-70's music usually when I am there and the coffee comes out fairly quick ... 

Staff is friendly for the most part ... never really a problem ... Its ok ... I guess I can say is I am a fan ...
author: Anthony S.

description: I've been back to the 7th St. location a few times now.  The espresso has improved!  The ashy taste is mostly gone lately.  I'll have to switch my review to 5 stars if it stays this way.
author: Tom J.

description:
The coffee was amazing. I had a mocha. It was perfect. Atmosphere was great as was the customer service.

The building was beyond impressive. I wouldn't mind living there...
author: Kathe W.

description: What a beautiful coffee shop. Good for studying. Its big enough for you not to feel claustrophobic and crowded, but still gives you the privacy you need to get things done. No wifi though.
author: Alan T.

description:
Yes, it doesn't have WiFi.
Yes, it's expensive.
Yes, it may filled with coffee snobs.

But it is legit, strong, and authentic coffee. It's bold, which is what we all want in a coffee anyway, isn't it? The atmosphere is also spacious and trendy. 
Coffee lovers, go here now.
author: Hannah B.

description: o sightglass! almond milk? i guess soymilk is not eco friendly, but almond milk lattes? the almond milk cannot stand up to the espresso and i cannot stand up for your almond milk lattes. this place is always packed now. i remember when it was just a kiosk with SOY lattes. if soy is bad, can we discover a liquid that can make just as good a latte? the new baristas are just a tad age phobic. o sightglass you dont need me anymore! blue bottle down the street has gotten worse too...a good barista is heaven sent and rare.
author: becke a.

description: Some Yelp members have let me down by saying that Sightglass Coffee is better than Blue Bottle. With that being said, Sightglass Lattes are pretty good, nice and strong, with a bitter finish. A bummer about the product sold is the size/portion you get, for me, too small. As well as the non-variety of milk when you want a Latte it's nice to have more options. The space is pretty cool so that is a plus and I'm a fan of any establishment that has a sink on the outside of the bathroom to wash your hands.
author: Josie C.

description: No tea, no stars. Sure, it's a coffee place, but it wouldn't kill them to have a couple of tea bags and some hot water. You'd get the opposite impression from the barista, however.
author: Patrick M.

description: Beautiful presentation. Clearly excellent coffee beans. Nearly cold cappuccino. Recommend the filtered.
author: cat s.

description:
I didn't try the coffee bc I'm too sensitive to phenylthiocarbamide, but their carmelized hazelnut financier is delicious! It was incredibly moist with crisp, perfectly browned edges and the hazelnuts were impeccably roasted and carmelized :D :D :D :D washed it down with a cute glass of water :P

Their interior is still under construction, but they said they should be up and running in about a week. Can't wait to visit when it's all spiffy and new :)

2 thumbs way up!
author: SF F.

description: The cafe itself is lovely and very well organized with desks and working areas. Coffee is nice, perhaps burnt a bit (bitter) and average service. Would come back just to chill out in the cool space.
author: Alice T.

description: Great coffee, great service and knowledgeable staff. THE ONLY reason it get's four stars instead of five: no press pots. I like my coffee dirty.
author: David S.

description:
Taking the coffee:  Excellent cappuccino.  A little pricey, but it was tasty and I was up into the wee hours of the morning.  Yay caffeine??...!

Looking at the view:  It was strange that there aren't any seats upstairs (maybe one day soon?).  However, I loove the wide open space of the place, and on the recent Sunday afternoon, it was a good place to go and participate in my newly acquired, favorite pastime: HIPSTER-WATCHING.

Yes, ladies and gentlemen, no longer is it people watching-- that's too boring.  No, my friends, it now is HIPSTER-WATCHING.  

It's the hipster thing to do.
author: Jeanne Y.

description: Best cappuccino of my life!  love the atmosphere as well.  The only reason I give it 4 stars is because I am not a coffee connoisseur and would have loved a little help ordering.   Unfortunately instead I got a look like I was from another planet when I asked for caramel in my coffee.  For shame!
author: Chris V.

description: Best coffee in San Francisco. One sip made me a believer. Fabulous space with industrial feel. Ultra-hip staff because they play cool tunes, make you smooth coffee, and use Square Wallet. You can virtually pay with a simple nod of your head. Your photo pops right up on their iPad screen. My personal fav: Owl's Howl. Love the name, and love the way this coffee doesn't taste burnt. Hey, aren't we all over that kind of burnt coffee taste now anyway? Sightglass. Take out your Spyglass and go find it.
author: Shadi G.

description:
My jaw dropped when i walked in, beautiful.  I was then impressed as I noticed the vintage McIntosh (C26, MC2205, and MQ101) stereo playing records off a pioneer turntable.

I didn't get a cup here, only beans which were quite delicious.

The place was very empty on a Saturday at 10am, just how I like it.
author: Ameer N.

description: Some of the best coffee around. Simple menu, great atmosphere. It's too bad they don't offer wifi.
author: Richard K.

description:
I have very high hopes for Sightglass. The reason I'm not giving them 5 stars is because they are not fully established yet. They are still under construction and hence serve their drinks in a recessed area of their store front. Inside you can see the roaster and the area where they will have seating but for now you are stuck with vying for a spot on a wood bench, standing and drinking or doing the unthinkable for any self respecting espresso based drink aficionado and get it "to-go" (ghassssp!!)

Let's review their technical merits:

- Locally roasted, fresh coffee beans: 
Check. They have a fully functioning roaster on site.
- Baristas with proper training on pulling espresso & steaming milk: 
Check. Very high marks here. 
- High quality Milk: 
Check. Clover Organic. Extra points for doing the Organic version which is more expensive and other similar Third Wave Coffee shops go with regular Clover.
- Latte Art:
Check. Solid

As you can see from the technical specs they have great potential to earn a 5 star rating from me (not that they would care). I'll definitely keep a close eye on these guys and try to make it back there after they open up the cafe for seating inside.
author: Fouzi H.

description:
These guys know their coffee and beans. Extremely knowledgeable and helpful. As of right now there's still construction so it's just a makeshift coffee cart near the entrance. 

Had a delicious espresso that was mild creamy and full of flavor, deep honey with some citrus. 

Also ended up taking a 3/4 pound of owls howl espresso blend, it smells so damn good I wish I could eat it.
author: Paul A.

description:
This coffee shop is amazing. Friends say its the best in San Francisco! 
So I went to try it out! 
I had a great experience! 
This is one of those coffee shops that are very trendy, and has that coffee thats not burnt or bitter! 
It's a big rustic but clean modern hipster style with seating upstairs. Everything is made of wood. I love the style! 
Upstairs there were people taste testing coffee. You don't exactly see that at Starbucks. : )
author: Trevor B.

description:
tasty latte with a pretty design on top - CHECK
location close (well, it's on the way) to the office - CHECK
easy parking (what??? INSANE!) - CHECK
no fuss or muss or a dumb door that makes it impossible to get out with 2 cups in hand without making a mess - DOUBL:E CHECK

it's a winner for me!
author: Holly C.

description: Great meeting place for people, people with bikes or people with dogs. Iced coffee with almond milk is really fantastic. It's just a really nice place to spend some time and catch up. Also the bar stools by the window are great for people watching and the upstairs area is a good work space.
author: mary l.

description:
First visit yesterday, first review today!

So far, so good! I felt a little awkward walking in, there's a lot of nothing to look at which I love! And I do like feeling awkward in safe situations, so this was a good experience.

The coffee was great, got the Guatemalan, iced, "for here". Loved every sip of it. It was kind of like iced tea, in a strange way. Very light and flavorful! Delicious!

The blueberry muffin was great, crispy outside, juicy blueberries inside, generally nice moistness inside. Perfect.

Weirdly, I love the lack of seating! Usually I am a fiend for a variety of seating arrangements, but this place suited me just fine!

We sat upstairs on the floor and it was fun. A few other groups of people came up there and sat down on the floor too. Very casual and relaxed environment up there.

Excited to see how this place evolves.
author: Rikki W.

description:
I think, for the first time, coffee inspires me to work hard for money.   I would like to have a lot of money so that I could have a cup of Sightglass everyday. 

The coffee is not cheap, but it is damn good.  The airy space is great on an otherwise misty morning, with Johny Cash playing on a phonograph turntable.  And the hot coffee smells and tastes delicious.  Minus any attitudes.
author: Jiajia C.

description: I have to admit that I'm am more than a little smitten with Sightglass.  It is almost too hip for me, but I was with a younger friend and was able to fly under the radar.  The $4 cup of coffee was delicious; expensive, but you get what you pay for.  The counter staff is very nice in that overly-caffeinated way and the space itself is amazing.
author: Robert M.

description:
I've been anxious to find some great coffee since moving here from Seattle.  I have to say my hat is off to them for one of the smoothest and complex tasting lattes ever.  The espresso had great depth, a very rich flavor without being over roasted.  Like a fine wine, I almost could taste almond or a nuttiness.  I can't emphasize how rich it tasted. Excellent.

My only complaint besides being on a one-way street that goes in the opposite direction of my commute is that they charge $2.50 for an extra shot.  Really?  The barista seemed embarrassed about it and said they didn't have a button for an extra shot so they have to ring it up as a whole espresso.  Honestly, I have never thought much about this, but I am used to an extra shot being around a dollar or so.  

SO - even though my latte was $6 making it the most expensive latte I have ever purchased, it was worth it.
author: Sophie C.

description:
This is a great coffee shop for so many reasons.  First off, the coffee they roast is top notch and the baristas are all extremely knowledgeable (albiet a little stand-offish).  But the real gem is the interior.  The open space wooden furniture gives a classy, comfortable feel to what otherwise would feel like a warehouse with a coffee roaster.  
A great spot for meetings, people watching, and reading.
author: Anneliese N.

description:
I'm sooooo glad they have opened in SOMA!! Now I can go there on my afternoon coffee breaks! The coffee baristas are fabulous and super nice!

I'm kind of surprised by the 1 or 2 star comments....I guess these people don't know great coffee beans.  And yes, they do roast them differently, they aren't roasted dark or burnt like Starbucks, so that's why people think they are acidic or sour.  The more acidic ones are the fruitier ones, hint hint.......And sad that people are giving Sightglass a 1 star for no bathroom, give me a break!!  Did you guys notice that they are still under construction.....maybe that's why they have no bathrooms....YET.

I ordered an iced coffee today and they messed up my order and gave me another free cup to go with my order -so nice of them.  My office smells so good right now.  And the price isn't much more expensive than Ritual or Fourbarrel or Philz, so I'm fine with the pricing- since they're all local!  

See you guys tomorrow afternoon!!
author: Alvin M.

description:
Love these guys, real down to earth. Roast small batch, direct trade, roaster in the store, little Probat, well trained staff.

The espresso I had wasn't the best I have ever had, but they definitely knew what they were doing. They weren't just under roasting some beans and telling you the acid brightness was the brilliant fireworks you were looking for. The espresso was well roasted, well pulled, and well drunk, it just lacked a certain x factor by its self.

HOWEVER, the cappuccino I had was marvelous! One of the better cappuccino's I have ever had. And since 99% of the people enjoy milk in there coffee, I almost prefer liking the cappuccino over the espresso. They know how people like coffee, and they compliment them very well. Even through the foam I was treated with rich nutty flavors that paired splendidly. Huge props, for knowing where its at.

Highly recommend checking these guys out. Small and smart.
author: John S.

description:
I don't usually drink coffee, but when I do, it better be from Sight Glass!   I work a few blocks away, and on those days where Robert just decided not to sleep, I need a little extra pick me up.  Having developed a caffeine addiction before, I steer clear of the daily habit.  Sight glass tastes wonderful!  I drink my coffee black with a little bit of sugar.  Their coffee is good enough to chug, but I sip very carefully.  Literally 1/4 cup will do the job for me.  

The decor in here is pretty outstanding.  I like the warehouse, industrial look they have.  I never have time to stop and drink coffee in there, but it'd be cool to study and stuff had I a need for such a place.
author: ROB L.

description: Beautiful decor and great coffee. No wifi and no power make it a poor destination for work but a great destination for reading or intellectual conversation.
author: George S.

description:
After living in Sydney for six years, I have become very spoiled, especially when it comes to good weather and coffee. Having just moved to San Francisco, I was a bit worried that I will never taste good coffee again. Boy, was I wrong! Sightglass coffee rocks, end of story. You should try it. Especially if you've been to Australia and miss their coffee as much as I do. 

Couple potential drawbacks for some people - they don't have skim milk and if it's size you're after, you won't get that here. It's all about quality, not quantity here :).
author: Magda W.

description:
The space is beautiful. I love the owl :-)  The upstairs is beautiful...though it kind of smells like pee.  I think it's all the wood.

But $4.25-5.75 for a cup of coffee is a bit overpriced.  That's more than Four Barrels (which has excellent coffee), and the girl making it really did not do as good of a job as Philz.  They put the beakers on fancy looking scales, but I have no idea how that's supposed to help the coffee flavor.  The coffee is decent but as another reviewer said, for the price, you want it to be "WHOA, that's mother friggin' good."  The Tesora at Philz is way better (maybe I should go write a review for them instead.)

Having said that though, this place is definitely worth the stop, if just for atmosphere.
author: Mochi N.

description:
3 stars for coffee.   0 stars for no bathroom.  I'd give negative stars for lying that there isn't one on premises but am too lazy to differentiate w.r.t. "are you fucking kidding me?"

Coffee was ok, but w/in sight of starbucks.
author: D E.

description: The coffee was good, I'll give them that but I felt like I was in a hot barn. It wasn't an enjoyable experience, but it did the simple  job of caffeinating me (for four bucks, I got an African roast- the slow single cup drip type).
author: Leilani W.

description: Damn this place is fresh. they hooked it up and all the months of hard work have really paid off. I will be back, bravo for creating a beautiful space and killer coffee. Love the little extra side pot when you stay, and the bacon brioche. Smaller line than my beloved blue bottle, uh oh.
author: Kennan S.

description:
Coffee snob haters need not visit.

I'm fine with my Starbucks or *GASP* McD's coffee only 'cause it's about 1/4 of the price. But I can tell the difference between THAT and the pour over methodology of serving me an individually brewed cup of coffee imported from the interior jungles of family-owned and operated Costa Rican coffee bean farm. So, I guess for a few bucks more, it's totally worth it on so many levels.

Beautiful, beautiful, BEAUTIFUL space. Minimal, bright, different. I really like it.

Plus it provides a good walk during the middle of the work day, if head clearing is needed.
author: liz c.

description:
So I must've of heard about sight glass coffee for weeks before I realized that hole in the wall (literally) with an espresso machine and hipster couples in painted on jeans sharing a narrow bench was actually The cafe in question. So in my drab jeans and plain black baby tee (required work clothes), all sweaty and smelling like burgers and fries on a rare 90 something degree day in the SOMA I absolutely did not feel adequately attired to duck thru the 10 by 10 hole in the building and buy coffee in front of all the cooler people..

A few days later I was walking by again in a sun dress and sandals with my precious Jack Russel Madison and decided that even if I wasn't cute enough for Sight Glass Coffee, she was. Well nice thing about a whole in the wall, no one minds cute puppies- since your not exactly inside anyways.

The spice infused ice coffee as a product is 5 star no doubt. What an incredible treat. I also bought some of their legendary coffee beans and took them home with me to brew and needless to say I'm hooked. 

So although they have a 5 star product and friendly enough service I think I'll reserve my final star until they open up the rest of the cafe because that is just too much "hip" for so small a pace. Right now it's a scene you can't avoid being seen in, almost feels as though you're on stage and that's not where you want to be if you're sleepy, hung over, or in sweats.  I'm sure a little extra space will be just what's needed to remedy that!
author: Lisa H.

description: This place is really amazing. Fantastic, friendly staff, great atmosphere, and, of course, the coffee is amongst the best in San Francisco. I love going upstairs to the loft area--a cozy spot for great conversation. If you care about getting a great cup of espresso or single-origin coffee, Sightglass is definitely worth a visit.
author: Pam C.

description:
The best part of waking up is Sightglass in your cup. Bar none, these are the best beans in San Francisco. 

Even without ample seating -- that single bench can get crowded -- I'd recommend splitting the Chemex for two  -- even if it means standing. It's the sort of coffee that you want to enjoy with someone else.

So while I'm excited for their full-on space to be fiNished (it's sort of like the Chinese Democracy of roasteries), their bare bones kiosk is the perfect tease as we all await caffeinated perfection.
author: Nish N.

description: Lovely coffee with yummy pastry from Neighbor bakehouse. The location is amazingly spacious and great for hang out. There is coffee beans roasting right no site and smells wonderful. Short walk from downtown but definitely worth it.
author: J Y.

description:
I consider myself a morning person.  I've been known to blast dancehall and chant along minutes after getting out of bed.  However, prior to singing jah blessings, the only sound is the whir of my coffee grinder pulverizing my favorite beans and making myself a cup of hand dripped coffee. My still hazy eyes fixating on the coffee as it bubbles, rises and recedes, my nostrils flared smelling the goodness.

Foresight is not a strong suit- so I inevitably run out of beans and everything comes to a screeching halt.  No music, the groggy eating of a peanut butter sandwich- in all likelihood a skipped shower, and a stumble out the door to find some beans and a cup of coffee to normalize.

Lucky for me, Sightglass is on my walk to work, so I can order up a cup of coffee and buy some good beans at the same time.  Their coffee is really good- both the DIY kind and the kind they make for you.  I usually leave and put something bass heavy on the headphones and walk to work with my head nodding in between sips; and feel a little sad when there is nothing left.  Plus I get to peek in and watch the construction of their cafe and behold! the behemoth of a roaster laying sentry over the not yet finished space.

Some days, I wish they had something to nosh on, like a ham and cheese croissant, but knowing they don't makes eating before hand more vital. (edit: they now have food, pastries, etc. I have yet to try but look good). 

Sightglass- good coffee to allow you to sing the praises of the glorious morning and wipe away the fog. Boh!
author: seth s.

description:
This is the first time I've ever felt compelled to review one of these independet third wave coffee companies, that being said:

 +The coffee is great, duh.  Adding cream and sugar is never, ever necessary. They roast beans onsite (like Four Barrel) which I think is really special and worth every penny. 

+I mostly come back for the aesthetics, what a lovely space.
author: Dalilah A.

description: Can I just move in here? As a regular consumer of Blue Bottle beans and coffee, and customer of Temple and Chocolate Fish in Sac and "coffee tourist" in general, I find it hard to have things stepped up a notch. Sightglass can do it though. A beautiful space, amazing coffee (espresso and brewed), skilled baristas and lots and lots of room. It has everything you would want. GO THERE!
author: Tony J. S.

description:
A delicious Cappuccino and so much potential for more. 

This place recently opened in the Fol-SOMA area and is an other sign that this is developing into an interesting neighborhood to live. The space is currently being build but they are running the shop from the foyer while construction is in progress. I think this says a lot about the owners and what this place will become. This place is being built in a sustainable way but they have done everything they can to make the place comfortable. I would be happy with what they already have and I am extremely excited to see it when it is dont (possibly february).

They dont have any place to sit with tables but there are benches and they also had some delicious looking pastries for sale.
author: Eric G.

description: Religious about coffee, and this is San Francisco's best. But prices are up 16% YoY on my cup, so I'm branching out to find a new home.
author: Jan M.

description:
I was the first cappuccino they had made that morning. Bad sign. I guess all the hipsters are "dripping" these days. Sorry people, this cappuccino was milky, chalky and lacked espresso (despite confirmation that they contain double shots).

Maybe there is some revelation to be had with drip coffee - if so, why bother trying to prove anything else with an espresso machine. Get rid of it then.

Intelligentsia makes the best espresso and sorry I've had every single artisan roaster in SF.
author: Mariangela S.

description:
Woo hoo! What a great find! (Alert: I might qualify as a coffee snob) There are so many great coffee places in SF and I had heard great things about this place. Frankly, it's kind of off the beaten path - I mean I know it's in SOMA and you could theoretically walk there from Market Street but it's not really near that much... I frankly don't know how I'd get there without my car (I know, I know bus blah blah blah... but it wouldn't be easy for a cup of coffee).  

Anyways - the coffee is good. Like real good.  I tend to go for espresso drinks, so I got a latte and my friend got a cappuccino. Both were super delicious.  A little less bitter than Four Barrel, but had more bite than Blue Bottle (which I love).  Best part.... DYNAMO DONUTS! Whaaaat?! How awesome is that... I was so psyched to see the glass case full of these glorious donuts.  GREAT choice, Sightglass, well played...

The space itself is actually really something... it's HUGE and really bright. I don't totally understand what they plan to do with the full space since the upstairs and part of the back was roped off (but nothing was there?) but hopefully they can do something with it? It was also pretty quiet inside, and thus echoey since the space is gigantic.  There probably should've been a bit more furniture or music... kinda cold, but not necessarily a bad thing I guess.
author: Elizabeth B.

description: I LOVE Sightglass. The coffee is absolutely delicious. Plus, the ambiance is fabulous. It's a very SoMa vibe - open warehouse space, lots of light, shared work areas. My only complaints are (1) it is ridiculously pricy for the amount of coffee you get and (2) they truly don't have enough seating.
author: Jennifer P.

description: Amazing coffee and atmosphere. One of the best cafés in SF. Worth a visit over and over.
author: Daniel L.

description:
I consider myself lucky to enjoy the gently roasted, flavorful coffees that Sightglass offers.  Typically, I am a brew-it-at-home, drink a few cups kind of guy.

The coffee here is so good, though, that I am willing to walk, make do with a bit less, and pay a bit more.  That the coffee inspires this type of compromise is evidence of an excellent cup.

A host of other reviewers will explain in detail why the coffee is good, even if the ambiance is a bit controversial (as is the pricing).
author: Ben P.

description:
If you are someone who thinks details matter then there is no better coffee house. 
I work around the corner, making time to have a cup here allows me for a moment to transcend the grime and chaos of the neighborhood.
author: Chris R.
