description: Oh Sightglass. First, the cafe/roastery is a marvel to look at. Meticulously designed, it looks awesome. As does the restored/suped up old La Marzocco GS2 - its really neat to see a machine like that. The espresso was creamy, dense, spicy, with hints of caramel and fruit. The cappuccinos we had were steamed/prepared well, and the guys working there were really friendly. Great place.
author: Andrew C.

description:
Not worth the hype.
The coffee is pretty good, but it's not any better than Blue Bottle/Vega, and the employees here are RUUUUUUUDE.

We were in a bit of a hurry and instead of reading the menu one of my friends simply asked for "the darkest coffee you have" and the employee replied "oh we don't do coffee like that HERE" and refused to serve him unless he read the menu and picked a specific blend by name.

Sorry, but I will take my overpriced coffee without the side order of bitchy attitute, thanks!
author: Daniel M.

description:
I blow my money on coffee, clothing, and lame but addictive online coupon offers.  

Sightglass Coffee is more frugal with their money.  Probably because they don't have Daddy issues and feel an intense need for retail therapy. 

After months of watching Sightglass sink money into their SoMa space (think construction in the back behind sheets + buying an iPad that accepts debit card payments), they've finally made a major revenue breakthrough.

This morning, my coffee was ground from the first batch of official Sightglass beans!  Which, I suspect, means they get to stop using beans bought from external bean roasters.  And....... the coffee was great.

Their cappuccinos call into question my Blue Bottle habit

I've yet to make my final decision, so I'll continue to squander my boyfriend's money on Sightglass and Blue Bottle.  But, shhhhhh, my loyalty can be swayed if you open up that big beautiful showroom hiding behind Sheet #1.
author: Janney B.

description:
Lured in here when I got a glimpse of the Probat roasting coffee and the open space. I don't think I would've ever stumbled upon this place if I hadn't decided to walk the many blocks to the courthouse for exercise.

The interior architecture has soooo much potential, but the open space feel was very comfortable and relaxed. 

Good coffee. Nice staff. Interesting place. =)
author: Jenny M.

description: Sightglass is THE BEST.  The latte and the cappuccino are both so smooth and almost sweet.   Never bitter........love this place.  Also really like the new spot on 20th Street.
author: Marc Ellen H.

description: If I could give this place 0 stars, I would. When I was first told about Sightglass I was extremely thrilled. My love for coffee is that of a family member. I traveled to San Francisco and our first stop was Sightglass. The moment I walked in, all of my warm, excited feelings disappeared completely. The only words I can come up to describe this hell hole are: pretentious, hipster, scum. Keep your tiny cups and stupid ass frisbees and shove them up your ass, Sightglass.
author: Jillian C.

description:
There's not much to review here, but I gotta go with 5 stars because Sightglass is my new fav SF cup of coffee.

Lately, I've been tiring of the really strong cups a la Ritual and Blue Barrel.  Sightglass is a welcome newcomer.  Their coffee has bold flavors but without that "ugh, I can feel the ulcer forming now" feeling in your gut.  The baristas were friendly and the space isn't much now but it looks like they're expanding into a true coffee shop instead of just a stand.  

BF and I shared the "for lovers" pot, which had 2 smallish cups each.  Plenty.  $2.50 a cup isn't cheap but you won't be disappointed with the product.
author: Kristin P.

description:
Just a tiny bar area behind the counter inside an open garage warehouse type building but the rest of the inside looks promising. Tried the Sumatra beans which was the cheapsr one but it was $3.75 before tax for a tiny cup. It took a little while before we actually got the coffee but they use the individual drip cups and pour the hot water over it by hand and everything. But it was pretty good..enough that we went back and bought like the beans. They have a while bunch of different ones.  Kenya was $14.50 for .75 lbs and Ethiopia beans were $16.50. 

They use an ipad mounted in like a wooden countertop holder to charge your credit card and it even gives you the choice to email your receipt to yourself. The while building and barista area had all these woodgrain and paneling and I think they did well in the terms of visual design, esp as an unfinished startup area.  Wish I could see how it'll turn out but it looks like they're already planning for great success and longevity in that location.
author: Serious F.

description: for $4.50 i was expecting that the coffee to taste better then mine. But overall its a nice place with enjoyable place to have a cup of coffee
author: Adam S.

description:
This place has a great space so two stars for that. Pretty much zero stars for everything else.

-THEY HAVE NO WI-FI
-pastries are around FIVE dollars unless you want a plain croissant. Coffee cake was good though.
-a latte is four dollars. Whole milk or almond milk only. Ew. I ordered one, didn't drink it...and definitely not ordering again.

To be fair, just because I don't like the vibe doesn't mean this isn't a cool place. If you like overpriced boutique coffee, this is your spot. If you just want a casual place to lounge on Saturday morning, keep looking.
author: Margaret L.

description:
The interior is gorgeous. It's amazing to see how space Sightglass is willing to devote to just, well, coffee. In a typical SF real estate property, you'll see about at least two restaurants squeezed in here, with possible seats on the second floor. But instead, it's one large open room, where the spacious loft contains some bare-minimum pieces of furniture for management and a few bikes. Not much tables or chairs for lingering around. But you can stand by the "bar" and watching the coffee master fingering through his roaster meticulously. 

Of course people who work here ride bikes. Everyone here, customers and baristas, carry the persona of uber-hipster. For a second, I forgot I was on 7th street, inches away from a dozen crazy homeless or newly-released drunks. I thought I was in an artsy part of an European metropolis. 

I got iced coffee, because I am an addict ever since Blue Bottle introduced me to their New Orleans. Different from the cold brewed New Orleans style iced coffee, Sightglass lets you pick one of the three coffees of the day and basically makes a drip and then mix it with ice after wards. 

I was skeptical for a moment, but as soon as I had my first sip I was pleasantly surprised by how good it was. Full bodied, a little nutty, and not acidic at all. 

It was so good I gulped it down before making it back to the Hall of Justice. 

The only problem? I doubt I will be in this part of town unless I get jury duty again.
author: Candice B.

description:
I have tried almost every coffee roaster/cafe in San Francisco and Sightglass is definitely one of the best, if not, THE best in The City and the Bay Area (at least a close runner-up to Verve in Santa Cruz). Using Clover milk and Hooker's dark chocolate, they make great tasting rich mochas with microfoam and latte art, but also pull great espresso and espresso drinks alike. The owners used to apparently work for Blue Bottle and Four Barrel and they used Verve beans until they began roasting their own beans, so they really know what's up.

The do-it-yourself look for the espresso bar was fun too. I saw some people mention that the baristas were rude, but I had no such issue. Both the guy and the girl working were kind and helpful with answering questions and overall provided good customer service. I wish I could have purchased their house blend, but I think they were sold out.

Come here if you're a coffee snob!
author: Hikaru M.

description:
Awesomeness in a window and in a cup. Sightglass is one of those specialty coffee shops that brews some fantastically fresh coffee, but sets itself apart with it's ginormous interior. I was last there in October 2011, and heard rumors that they would soon offer cuppings to the public in their 2nd floor training facility. Exciting stuff!
It's a coffee BAR. Not for wi-fi (maybe they have it, maybe they don't), but for exquisitely roasted and brewed coffee. They roast onsite! And allow their customers to watch. It's like coffee pornography... Too far?
author: Anna P.

description: Excellent venue for a meet and greet. Two stories with a high ceiling, yet still cozy. Coffee elves in denim work around the perimeter of the building at most times, really elevating the coffee making experience and making you feel, as a customer, as if you are a part of the coffee making itself...an elevation on the customer experience as a whole. Coffee itself is smooth, and they now have a coffee bar upstairs for expediting the line more efficiently. Top notch, and been one of my favorites since the beginning.
author: Lauren P.

description:
Incredible space just blocks away from union square. 

Perfect hideaway spot for reading, writing, working or just enjoying a cup of coffee.

Offering some of the best coffee and pastries in the city, you can't miss this spot.
author: P B.

description: My favorite coffee and coffee shop in the city. Awesome decor. Large table to work at or just catch up with a friend. Inspiring ambiance.
author: Jacqueline S.

description: I always come here since I live close by and coffee is always good. But now they have the Affogato Bar upstairs and oh.my.god. so good. Two of my faves together and not as a coffee flavored ice cream but a shot of espresso AND a flavored ice cream. I've never had an affogato before but I tried the Salted caramel with the Rwanda  (since the guys said it would bring out the smokiness  of the caramel) and it was so delicous. I scarffed that thing down almost too quickly but slowed down not forgetting that...this little cup cost me $5.50 (i think). It's worth it of course and cant wait to try other flavors! I sampled the blood orange ice cream and it was pretty tasty! I should have asked if they sold pints. Good stuff.
author: Mila B.

description:
When it comes to coffee shops and dessert places I don't give 5 stars, so my 4 stars for this place denotes the highest possible rating :)

I really loved this place -- first and foremost, just upon entering -- this is the most beautiful coffee bar shop I've ever seen.  I have a weakness for warehouse lofts, and this place simply didn't disappoint.  I would totally live in a place like this!

The baristas were knowledgeable and very nice, and the coffee was outstanding.  We also had some pastries -- I had the croissant, which I believe they called "a damn good croissant," and they weren't kidding.

Going back to the decor, because it's just so impressive -- I really liked the "bar" setting of the place, it's truly a coffee BAR as opposed to a sitdown type of place.  The aesthetic is completely different, and it comes across as very cool chic.  5 thousand stars just for the setting.

The hotel I was in (the sh*thole across the street) was a negative 5 million stars, but this place was a definite breath of fresh air after some crappy accommodations the night before.

Big thumbs up to SIghtglass.
author: Eduardo X.

description:
I've always been the kind of person that thinks a cup of coffee is a cup of coffee.  Drinking my daily cup was more or less a means to inject caffeine into my system.  No more.  This coffee is THE FUNK.  The smell when you walk in combined with the friendly workers won me over as much as the smooth taste of the coffee.

Dare I say Sightglass is even better than Blue Bottle.  Yes, I dare.
author: Christina K.

description: Cool vibe. Way too many hipsters. Overpriced for what you get, especially the pastries ($5 for a croissant?!). No WiFi. No power. Loud. Not a great place to get work done.
author: John W.

description:
The coffee is great, and the space is beautiful. I don't know if they plan to install more seating, but I think that would be a good idea.  They could also use some work in the customer service department.  
My first time in the new digs, it wasn't clear to me where they were keeping the milk.  I was clearly searching for something, but even those behind the counter who made eye contact didn't bother to ask me if I needed anything.  When I finally asked for a small cup of milk for my Chemex pot, something they should offer with the pot--along with a tray to carry your pot and two cups back to your perch, the one nice boy behind the counter told me they have cream on the back side of the counter (in the rear of the room, where there is no other reason to go back there, in the dark, out of sight).

I'll go back in a month to see if they're a little more organized and friendly at all (the nice folks at Deli Board put these employees to shame).  Then they can either lose or gain a star.
author: N. L.

description: Just in town visiting, but one of the coolest coffee houses I've ever been to. Fantastic coffee, nice people, cool vibe. I'll be back ... someday.
author: Brian P.

description: OK, so I have some shallow tendencies. The indoor appearance of this place warrants 5 stars alone, but being the faithful Yelper I am, I would not allow myself to bequeath 5 stars for the facade alone. Though impressive in its contemporary yet cozy atmosphere, Sightglass provides a 360 degree positive experience. The service was very friendly and the coffee is definitely quality. Might I add it is strong as well, just the way I like it. One cup of black coffee kept me fueled from 2:00-10:00. I have not even scratched the surface of all the great coffee joints in SF, but I can tell you, this one already will become a repeat as I mosey my way through SF. Check it out, it's pretty sexy.
author: Kim S.

description:
This space is beautiful, and the coffee is great. Due to no internet, this is a great spot to take a good book, catch up with a friend, or journal.

Nice people and I can't say enough about the beautiful design of the space.
author: Laura K.

description:
Nice minimalistic interior with the roaster up front.  They roast almost every day, so you can purchase the freshest beans (all bags are dated).  Quality is outstanding, so you pay for it.  There is upstairs table seating as well.  Similar to Four Barrel but less crowded.  I've been able to find parking easily.

Their beans are medium-roasted, which I have begun to prefer as well.  If you want the freshest, high-quality coffees, this is the place.  Rainbow sells their beans in bulk as well (Blueboon Blend is sometimes out).
author: John K.

description: The attitude of the people behind the counter make a not great cup of coffee worse. Way over hyped. Disappointing.
author: Peter W.

description:
the best cafe in the city, the space is amazing and it's been hiding right under my nose this whole time. this is what good spaces feel like when you have the luxury to spread out...I don't know how they rationalized the economics, I don't really care...good job and I'll be back.

p.s. the coffee is great too.
author: Mayur A.

description:
I've loved this place for a while.  I come here every time I'm in SF.  

In regards to a few of the complaints I see on here.....

The staff:
Generally nice it seems to me.  But, for sure they are used to a crowd, and are sometimes abrupt until the crowds calm enough for them to take a breather, calm down, and be more sociable.  This isn't your talkative local neighborhood shop, this is a high volume roastery.  

The coffee:
Yes, their standard espresso does lean a little on the sharp / acidic side.  It's got a really nice soft aftertaste however.  Clearly a well roastered coffee, but if you're a fan of Sumatra, Kona or Columbian, this isn't it.   I think it's one of the best medium tasting roasts I've had.

The space:
Designed for an urban feel, and very open.  Great space to meet someone.  Not oriented towards lingering.  No wifi or outlets.  Not an issue for those of us with mobile hotspots and long laptop battery lives.  I wouldn't object to not using my data plan, and I would really love to see them adopt the policy of a similar shop I visit in Seattle (Vivace) of having WiFi available at off-peak times only, and turning it off when the shop is too crowded to accommodate large laptop using crowds.
author: Duncan C.

description: Good coffee.... but i'm not into paying 425 for a cup of coffee... I didn't notice the 2 dollar quick drip option but if i'm around again i will go for that.
author: Julie B.

description: Just awesome coffee shop ever I have seen and been in my life. I have been having couple lattes here everyday since I found sightglass. No wifi here, but I don't care even I need to use because I can use tethering via my phone if I need to use laptop and need to access internet. Also, this cafe has huge space, so I can have a seat whenever I need and want.
author: Taeyoung L.

description: The ambiance of this place is really cool. Absolutely gorgeous, awe-inspiring interior. And great tunes to top it off. I tried two different coffees here, and both were roasted a bit too light for my liking. You really need to be a fan of bright, acidic coffees to enjoy this cup.  Also, the customer service was okay, but nothing that stood out among some of the other great roasters in the bay area.
author: Amanda R.

description: love the vibe and the second floor with spacious tables. i got the chilled vanilla brew and it was yummy!
author: Ruby K.

description: Wow. First of all, Manhattan - even Brooklyn, which has the room and the similar post-industrial interiors - coffee shops can't even dream of such cool spaces. But of course, it's all about the coffee: I can surely say I've had one of the most exquisite, cream of the crop espresso based drinks I've ever had.
author: Sasha M.

description: What an incredibly cute place. I really want to shrink this place and put it inside my pocket! Great location with lots of room upstairs to speak about your stealth mode start-up or chit chat with an old school friend. In addition to an incredible place is that they also have ridiculously great coffee (can that even happen at the same time at the same place? Yes, it can at Sightglass!)  Great cup of coffee - I got the decaf and it was scrumptious - it was like taking a chunk of gold, melting it down, putting it into a cup, and having it blessed by a clergyman - yes - it was that good. To sum - Great Place + Great Coffee = Happy Pilgrim.
author: Pablo P.

description:
I had a hooker mocha (srs) and man...I grew a beard after drinking that stuff.  Not only was it fully hipster, it was fully bitter and fully strong.  WOO, it'll put some hair on your chest for sure.  
If you're a coffee snob, you'll probably like this place.  
If you're a hipster, you will probably like this place.
If you look like a hipster but don't consider yourself a hipster, you're probably still a hipster and you'll still like this place.
author: Heather W.

description: Excellent espresso and hand drip coffee in a pretty kiosk environmemt.  They have open windows into the roasting and packing area.  If you end up waiting, there's always something to look at!
author: Jenni S.

description: Far from being a coffee Mecca, San Francisco seems to specialize in expensive, crummy brew. This place, though not cheap (same price as every where else, essentially), at least puts their money where their mouth is. I come here everyday, and I'm always pleased with the coffee. Definitely worth the extra walk to not have to drink Philz (which represents to me the over hyped coffee ignorance endemic of SF) which is just expensive, not good. Sightglass is expensive AND good, so I don't feel ripped off! Word to the wise: pass on the pour over; it's nothing but a gimmick to get you to pay twice as much. The difference between that and drip is minimal.
author: Jordan d.

description: No power outlets!!  But I guess coffee is good enough that you can deal with the 'tude.  I've always been tempted to ask for a caramel macchiato and see if I get slapped.
author: Xander M.

description: This place is expensive but damn is it good! I've tried most of their roasts and have settled on Blueboon as my absolute favorite. So smooth, so soft on the finish. The donuts they have in the morning are also top notch.
author: Kathryn M.

description:
Found this place through yelp, wanted to check it out. I have been a heavy advocate of Blue Bottle for years but wanted to see what all the hype was about.

I walked into the open cement, industrial building and already was in love with the modern loft type interior. The aroma of the coffee smelt bold and satisfying. I ordered a latte. One taste and it was perfection. I literally became hooked after the first sip. Worth the money and the trip to SOMA if you are an artisan coffee snob and looking for the next best thing.
author: Crystal C.

description:
I never would have found this place if I hadn't walked past it - even then, I nearly missed the small wooden sign, "Sightglass". 

The barista is outside, near the entrance. Inside is a massive wooden room, 2 levels (under construction I think) with tables and seats to match. They only have one espresso blend, currently. Their 'blue boon' coffee was pretty good, but I'm more of an espresso drinker myself. I bought some to make at home - boy was it tasty. It makes a tasty cappuccino as well. Def coming back here, if only to pickup some more beans.
author: David N.

description: Not a fan.  This cafe is supposed to be a haven of innovation and creative thinking, but for me, that innovation only comes when you have battery life.  There's not a single outlet in the cafe except next to the bathroom.  I've never heard of a coffee shop like that.  It may work for some, but I will pass.
author: Josh Q.

description:
Love the coffee here.  The latte reminds me of lattes in Melbourne (Australia) because of the quality but also because it is just the right size.  I miss Melbourne coffee and this is one of the few places in San Francisco where I can get my fix.  The coffee is fantastic and the baristas know what they are doing.

Can't wait to check out their space when it fully opens - it looks like it is going to be big.
author: Kylie M.

description: Their coffee roast is on point, I buy bags of the Ethiopia to roast at home, but 4.25 for a cup of ethiopia brewed there had no flavor notes of citrus, floral, anything but complete bitterness still bothers me.
author: Riana R.

description:
My favourite place with friends on my days off.
Yummy goat cheese brioches.
They re iced coffee is exellent.
Nice and relaxing place.
author: Vera A.

description: I work nearby and I needed my coffee fix, a customer recommended this place! SOOOOOOO WORTH THE WALK!
author: Emme C.

description: After following @jack on twitter and enjoying his style, I had to stop in to Sightglass during my last visit to SF.  I got a latte and it was a little pricey.  I normally wouldn't pay nearly $4 for one, but I was on vacation.  It was good, but just a latte.  The shop is huge and very minimalist with a lot of windows.  SOMA is one of the only places in SF that gets warm, and Sightglass gets a little warm.  Overall, a cool spot, but a little overpriced.
author: Joe U.

description:
These guys know what they are doing. The care in which they roast and prepare the coffee is noticeable upon the first sip. I have had a regular drip coffee and a Latte and they both blew my mind. It's safe to say that this is the best coffee in SF right now. Not to mention the guys are knowledgeable, cool and friendly.  Glad there is good coffee in SOMA. Can't wait for their space to open.


NOTE: To all you haters out there, since when a is calling anything "hipster" an actual review of taste, menu or service? Seriously, go to the dictionary/thesaurus and get yourself some new adjectives. It's irritating.
author: Javier B.

description: Right when you walk into the store you get wonderful smell of coffee.  They have done a great job of making the environment warm and welcoming.  I have tried most of their blends of coffee of which I really like the Nicaraguan.  The coffee is so smooth with a rich taste that is not over powering.  Their espresso is also one of the best, if not the best espresso I have had in the city.  You must also check out their pastries they have.  They always have new pastries which is nice.  The donuts are very good as well as the croissants.  The price of coffee and pastries are a bit high, but you get what you pay for, great quality.  Top notch place with great service!
author: George K.

description: Wow, great place! The ambiance was great, coffee was excellent. Can't wait to go back.
author: Karina R.

description: I wish this place had WiFi. I really do. The drinks here are your standard pricier coffee fare--I think it's $4 a latte? but they're really good! The space is really neat and open, so you can see all the machinery. It's really too bad about no wi-fi, but it doesn't seem they need it to attract the crowds. One time I came here around 10 on a weekday and the line was out the door because a whole group from a startup did a field trip for sightglass.
author: Vivian C.

description: This place is great. Good coffee, interesting and comfortable building. They do take a long time to make coffee though, but I guess that's part of their business model.
author: Francesco T.

description: Awesome space, great coffee, and a super place to chill.
author: Marty W.

description: Excellent vibe, great decor and layout. Great respect that they roast their beans right inside the cafe. However, the coffee itself tastes like piss. I've tried it twice now, and it's way too acidic and too light for my liking. For slow drip coffee, it is also rrrrrreeaaaalllyyyy sssslllloooooowwww. At least when I go to Blue Bottle, I only have to wait 5 minutes and I get a strong brew. Here, I almost waited 20 minutes for a $4 midget sized cup of pee. For how pretentious this place looks, Sightglass does not live up to the hype.
author: Brian L.

description:
I live a few blocks away and, well, SIghtglass's location had more than a little bit to do with my choice of domicile.

For me the espresso here is just the absolute best.  Anywhere.  And I mean absolutely anywhere.  It's dark-chocolatey, it's an oily emulsion that extends to the bottom of the cup and, best of all it's that, consistently, without fail.  

What more can you ask for in a cafe?  

Well, add the great staff, the chill location, the absence of a line-out-the-door like other places with nigh-perfect offerings ... but, alas, I wish the best success on all my favorite businesses and yet I want this one to stay a hidden gem.  Just a bit more, please, ...
author: J W.

description: A little too snobby for me, even Handsome Roasters in LA has an iced latte. Either way, the coffee tastes great, and they roast in house. I loved walking by the people packaging the fresh roasted beans and sniffing over their shoulders *creepy laugh*. Like most other shops, they sell an array of brewing equipment like Hario, Aeropress, and Chemex. I like the upper floor seating area, you can watch the baristas do their magic.
author: Steven M.

description: Ok first, this place is quite massive. How the heck do they afford the rent. It's a great place for people to come study. It's totally hipstered out with old wood and coffee equipment. Ok. Now for the coffee. I would definitely say that I am a coffee connoisseur. They have your basic drip coffee with the pour over method. I'm not sure if they have their own equipment or if they use the Hario brand. I had cortado and they made it impeccably well. The milk was set at a good temperature and the roast of the been was very course but the drink did taste a little bit acidic to me which is why I'm giving this place a 4 star. I don't know what the vibe of this place is supposed to be but the customer service is definitely forgettable and it seems more like a tourist attraction to me. I definitely like it but would probably not come back to it too often. I like more of the neighborhood feel sort of coffee shop like Flywheel where people great you and remember your orders.
author: Gary I.

description:
They make a great cappuccino. 

Props for being the only micro cafe in San Francisco that accepts credit cards and for somehow making a huge garage feel warm.
author: Lion G.

description: Fresh brewed!  Very industrial.  Large warehouse feel.  You can watch them pack coffee for shipping
author: Tony K.

description: if you want a good cup of coffee, stop by! simply put! i generally get an iced colombian, nothing too fancy. i like things simple.  they have a a friendly staff and an awesome atmosphere. it's architecturally pleasing to the eye! it's great for a quick sit-down or to chill and work from your laptop.
author: Donald G.

description: I love this espresso spot; it is conveniently located and the baristas are great. Ranking somewhere in my top ten coffee spots in SF.
author: Austin P.

description:
9AM, setting up breakfast for fav client: Seasoned foodie (client team) jumps out at me. 

Wow, someone is happy. Sightglass he says. What? You went to spin class? No sightglass. Haven't heard of it. Get the costa rican frekin something here take this I will buy your first cup you must try it. No, I cannot take your money. That's ridiculous, I can't buy you a cup of Coffee? [girl next to us] do it. Me liquid crack in my veins fruity sweet took it black no over roast no feeble coffee water perfection cute guys work there too bonus.
author: Becca A.

description:
They lose points for the pricing of the fudge.   $2 each OR 3 for $7 in a cardboard box!!?!

Macchiato was very good!

Seating is minimal and hanging out is not encouraged.  (Not necessarily a bad thing.)   Leave the laptop at home.

Are we going too far w/ the coffee thing?   And how much does the Kenyan farmer get of that $24 12 oz bag?
author: David H.

description:
I lived in Tokyo, Japan where there was an espresso boom.  

Tried a lot of coffee and espresso's but I have to say Sight Glass is the best. 

The architecture & design is super cool and Simple. 

The people are nice ( Not like in NY)

I had the Espresso which was at the temperature and was very smooth on my palate. 

They fixed up an old Marzocco machine (I think the first dual boiler machine that Marzocoo made) 

I also had the Papua New Guinea Chemex. It was like drink tea. Just well balanced coffee. 

I wanna try the Latte next.
author: Rei S.

description: Been there twice and probably not going back.  Don't get me wrong -- the place is beautiful -- just a gorgeous architectural space that I would mind living in -- but the coffee is just not good.  Cappucino was beautiful but weak.  The mocha was forgettable.  Strange considering all the attention and effort the put into the preparation (it takes forEVer to get your order).  And then there are the hipster coffee chemists sipping and concocting in the private upstairs "coffee lab."  Guess I'll just head back to Valencia to Four Barrel and Ritual.
author: Joe K.

description: Terrific. Beyond the superior coffee, you can bring your bike inside and they have McIntosh audio gear.  Great space. Love it.
author: Scott C.

description:
Sightglass is the only coffee I like hot. It is that good.  I am really weird and prefer luke warm coffee but not here!  Every flavor I have had is delish...I like to mix it up but my latest beans are Kenya.  I think I prefer going to the stand though to my home brewing...mostly because I find the boys very attractive.  Nothing like a hot tasty brew, Hooker's boubon sugar bun, and a cute boy to start your day!

It is going to be extra awesome once they finish the construction.  I may have to move my office there.

Tip: Parking tends to be pretty easy right on 7th there, but bring quarters!
author: Elizabeth R.

description: Seriously good coffee, amazing fresh baked chocolate chip cookies (of which my fat friend Mark H. had 4), great atmosphere, and friendly service. The fact that there didn't seem to be any outlets or free wifi would usually be a dealbreaker at most coffee shops but in this case, it didn't even matter.
author: Tamour K.

description:
Wood and metal contemporary decor fits the SOMA aesthetic.
No comfy tables or plugs that I could find after a quick visual drive through.
The smallest cuppa runs $4 and the coffee cake rocked, though a small piece as well.
Still, I'll come here for more when I have extra funds to burn.
IPad cash register using tiny card swiper attached to it. I was told the founder of foursquare created it.

Fun fact: Om M. is the foursquare mayor!
author: R M.

description: Great espresso and unique bakery items.  Be forewarned that the selection is limited -- only espresso drinks, no tea for those who prefer it instead.
author: Alex D.

description: Good, well thought out coffee with a very airy, hipster-attracting vibe.  Wish they had power plugs, though, so I could work a bit.
author: Arvindh K.

description:
I absolutely love this coffee and the atmosphere.  Heck I event think the people working there are great.  But I haven't been there for about a month for one simple reason, the price is astronomically ridiculous. 

It has always been expensive but it was a trade off.  You want quality you need to pay for it.  but the last time I was there for a plan coffee it was $3.50 to $5 for a tiny tiny 6 oz (maybe 8? the point is its very small) cup.  If I'm spending that much money on coffee I at least want the pot.  The Coffee is good but at that price there is better ways to spend your money.  If they ever decide to bring the price back down to reality or offer a size other than Thimble I'll be first in line.
author: Michael D.

description:
Love at first sip. Love it, love it, love it. I was blown away by the three pour over coffees they offered as I and 2 friends shared the array of deliciousness that was in our cups. 

I strongly urge anyone to make the trip here if you love coffee. They are not gonna let you down!
author: Lauren D.

description: 5 Stars for coffee and overall design.  Everything else meets expectations for what I'd expect in SOMA... right?
author: Chris D.

description: No doubt this place has all kinds of "cool" going on. However: 1) they offer only whole milk or almond milk, no lowfat or nonfat; 2) it took more than 10 minutes to get a latte to go; and 3) the latte was the single smallest I've ever seen. Not my cuppa ...
author: David K.

description: Excellent espresso in a very cool, cozy spot. Delicious cappuccinos. On a recent vacation to SF, I tried every shop recommended to me, from Blue Bottle to Four Barrel. I thought Four Barrel was better, but this was a very, very close second. I'll definitely be back next time I'm in SF.
author: Jamie S.

description:
Man, its sad. When this place was a cart it was awesome. The Owls Howl was some of the best espresso ive ever had. The dude serving it to me was genuinely excited to be making me espresso. Sigh...

Now its nots the complete opposite, every time im in there I try to talk to the baristas about COFEE!!! But no one seems into it. They will give me one word answers and no eye contact til i give up. Im the type of customer you should be excited to have! But I suppose its not a big deal, because there coffee isnt what it what it used to be. So the fact that I will never go back isnt that sad.
author: Coffee N.

description: OMG.... coffee is GREAT! I love Blue Bottle, but Sightglass is out of this world!!!!! They serve  Sightglass at Outerland and it is so good that I had to get a bag of beans to go...so I can have some at home...
author: Jay S.

description: The soy lattes are great here, but its super EXPENSIVE. But I do like that they use almond milk instead of soy which shows there knowledge of current events. So i'll add another star for that. And the atmosphere is great here. It's so simple yet all I want to do is sit here all day and do my homework.
author: Runaway L.

description:
I'm not that big on cappuccinos, and I rarely crave an espresso. If I do crave coffee, I crave a flat white, because lord knows that shit is hard to find and make well around this side of the pond.

At first, Sight Glass was just another "good" coffee joint. So "good" that I didn't bother stepping out the door and had to be convinced by the bf that I should enjoy a cup of coffee. But I've decided that they are better than good. They gave me the flat white I wanted this morning. All my boyfriend had to do was specify the microfoam and mention the associated nostalgia. And there it was -- a lovely cup of flat white. That's really all I wanted. I got it.
author: Chieh T.

description:
Coffee had a distinctive flavor I've never experienced before. 
But a small cup of drip coffee was $4.50.
Coffee was enjoyable, but a little weird.
Did I mention the $4.50 for one small cup of drip coffee?
Room was really big and airy - quite a nice place to enjoy my $4.50 cup of drip coffee.
Now there may be some who can discern all the crazy flavor notes they describe in each blend, but I'd wager 90% of the population just senses "nice-tasting coffee" and then realizes they've just paid 3x the cost of any other coffee joint. I'm part of that 90%
author: Al M.

description: Totally pretentious. No electricity (outlets), or WiFi, but tons of unused open space and gourmet expensive coffee and pastries. I was actually told by the variegated that they "dont want people hanging around forever" thus no outlets or WiFi..
author: O K.

description: The chocolate-chocolate claw tastes so good. Solid coffee and place to hang-out.
author: Satyajeet P.

description:
This is a great cappuccino.   Light and clean.  I'm hooked on 4 a week.

Sightglass is still under major construction, and brewing Verve Coffee, figuring until their roaster is up.  They have chemex style and full espresso bar.  The vibe is great as the owners and baristas are super nice.  They're kind enough to sell available roasts in qtr or half pounds.

It's a new perk to working in SoMa.
author: Annika L.

description:
You know what, I've held my tongue about these fucks for long enough because it's the ONLY coffee shop around my house that's open Sunday but today was the final straw and I'm just gonna lose my shit now.  

1. They refuse to serve me an iced latte because it "alters the taste" or some nonsense.  Well who the fuck cares, I LIKE THE TASTE!! AND I'M THE CUSTOMER!!! AND THAT'S ALL THAT MATTERS!!! Get off your high horse and serve the fucking coffee and move on.  But no, instead I have to hear some snooty bitch's rationalization of why I can't have what I want.  They serve iced coffee, they have ice, just give it to me. Period.

2. My lovely husband went there today to get us coffee (because it's sunday and Vega's closed) and instead of going through the whole iced latte ordeal I just had him get me a double espresso to go so I could make my OWN ICED LATTE AT HOME.  BUT NO they don't serve espresso TO GO AT ALL!!!!  Why? That seems silly! Because- get this one- "it sinks into the cup because it's so little of an amount".  HA! Seriously??  Yep, but they didn't tell him that when they rang him up and took his money, just when they served it up in a ceramic cup and made him drink it on the spot.  

Alright there fascists, thanks for taking ALL of the fun out of drinking good coffee.  Sorry we all don't have the time to sit around sipping espresso (hot espresso that is!) in your giant horrible use of space Four Barrel design rip off warehouse.  Get over yourselves and get back to the only thing you do right- MAKING COFFEE
author: Gwen B.

description:
i am a coffee snob and sightglass is up there on my list! love the atmosphere in there and also buy their beans to french press at home. if you like good coffee, try this place. 
SF has many coffee options for coffee snobs (bluebottle, fourbarrel, ritual etc..) and this is one of the god options.
author: C A.

description:
I was on vacation in San Francisco with my boyfriend and he really wanted to go to Sightglass because they used Square and an iPad to process payments, which at the time was exciting because the iPad was new on the scene, and he loves that sort of stuff. I didn't really understand what any of that meant at the time, but I went along because I love coffee, and he was so curious.
 It took us a while to find it, as it's smack in the middle of a very industrial part of town, and when we did we discovered that they were in the middle of construction and were serving the coffee in a garage- type of situation to the side of where I assume the coffee shop will be. There was a single bench, so we had a chance to sit for a second, but it wasn't very comfy for hanging around. 
This was hands down one of the best cups of coffee I have ever had. They do an individual drip cup, and you can tell it's made with a lot of love. So good that we took about 2 buses to go back from our hotel the next morning before leaving town, and also bought a bag of coffee beans. 
I am looking forward to returning to San Francisco someday and seeing how the renos turned out.
author: Orla M.

description:
Here is my awful experience in list form:

-5 dollar BLACK coffee
-rude, rude, rude, pretentious, you-know-what-kind-of-hole employees
-coffee cups are tiny for the price
-no bathroom WTF

Basically I left patronized, needing to pee, and broke

Never again

Dec 2017 update: still tricking true. Garbage.
author: Carolina P.

description: Pricey. Cool space. Great tasting coffee. Awesome that they have piccino baked goods. Sure it's hipster, but can't blame the hipsters; this is a coffee shop done right.
author: Frank L.

description:
Didn't need another cup of coffee but was walking past this place and the aroma just loured me in and ordered up a cup and it was good.

Small hole in the wall but looks like they are building a cafe next to it, and from peeking in it looks very cool.

If you are in this part of the City its a must stop for a pick me up.
author: G R.

description:
Sightglass is poised to become the best coffee house in S.F. Knowing a thing or two about my audience, I don't say this lightly. I am champing at the bit, counting the days, anxiously awaiting the day that the full cafe opens. I will be a daily patron.

First and foremost is the coffee. It is utterly amazing. I have yet to have anything but a fantastic [pick a menu item]. I find it remarkable is that when here, I don't typically add cream or sugar as I normally do; a testament to the quality and flavor.

Next is the staff. All of them are easy going, quick to smile, and very good at what they do. Somehow they seem to manage to keep the current "nook" off of 7th filled with happy coffee-goers with noticeably less waiting around than most places too.

Finally, is the space. What a beautiful setup they have going on. Lots of light and air. A gigantic library loft of the gods, where the disciples of the bean may come and study. I very much hope that the loft area is open for seating...it would be amazing (hint hint).

I've also been told that once open, they will be WiFi free. I think this is a good idea. It will mix with their mojo well.

Stop by and treat yourself to an amazing cuppa. You too will start counting the minutes until the rest of the cafe is open for business.
author: Erich N.

description: Nice place, quiet, light, airy, coffee quality is up there with Blue Bottle, Ritual, Four Barrels.
author: Sorin N.

description: So expensive, so pretentious, so little coffee for so much money. They really hint heavily at leaving a tip on top of those huge prices too. The location and the building is pretty cool, but then the seating is super uncomfortable.
author: CatsPjs Z.

description: They make good coffee but please don't make the mistake of buying any merchandise. I was hard sold a new coffee bean that they got and they will not take the return next day because it had an expiration date on it which was after a month. I realized it after I bought them that they were beans and not ground coffee. I do not have a grinder and I drink my coffee at the shop. They definitely lost my business for their rudeness.
author: B S.

description: Good coffee, good shop, customer service could be improved.
author: Tom N.

description: Man. The single cup pour over here is the truth. This place makes a REALLY good cup of coffee. Ps, dont come here to work techies.
author: Leon M.

description:
Excellent latte! It's on a par with Ritual and Haus, for my money. 
Can't wait till they get their sit-down space open.
author: Jamey M.

description:
I am obsessed with their coffee beans for home. They have a neat space in the works, and I love the edge the bar out front has while the work is being done inside. They have cute packaging too. I'm a graphic designer, so doing something cute like that is a dream fun project. I save the little tags they added to the bags. 

If you go - the lattes are incredibly delicious with the Owl's blend and the spiced iced coffee is unique. 

We live in Noe and drive down there for a coffee & bean pick up from time to time. I prefer it so far over other coffee spots at the moment. I am also in love with the colors of the inside of the space and that airplane painting on the wall that I wish I could afford to buy! (mama mia)
author: Nicole L.

description:
I had just finished making my regular visit to get tested at the SF City Clinic and passed by this fancy looking coffee stand in what looked to be a huge warehouse being remodeled. There was a nice piece of fancy artwork depicting a plane and minimal decor.

At first, I was confused. I thought, "This is such a random coffee cart in the middle of leather-daddy-ville. What's a fancy coffee place doing here?"

I was wearing only a t-shirt on a windy day in SF and could use a hot cup of joe in my hands to keep me warm and sooth my soul. So I decided to see the menu. It was individual drip coffee! My fav! I asked the (friendly) barista what drip coffee of the 3 they had she liked the best. She said the Colombian. That's what I was eyeing too. It's like she was psychic. I like psychic service.

$2.50 and 3 minutes later, I had a succulent cup of Sightglass Coffee. So good. So smooth. Yum!

I can't wait to see when the whole warehouse is transformed into a magical coffee bar.
author: Will K.

description:
Just moved into their new space two weeks ago - AWESOME look and feel. Ham and gruyere brioche was outstanding - while they don't make the pastries, they've obviously partnered with someone who knows how to make a super product. Espresso was incredible - deep, rich flavors, kinda rough and tumble taste that you don't fight, you just go with it. I can't imagine espresso getting much better than this.

I talked to one of the owners who was very nice - proud in all the right ways. Patronize Sightglass if you can - wish I lived here so I could hit this spot daily. As SOMA area continues to turn over, I've no doubt this place will become even more popular.
author: Brad C.

description:
Walking to the Hall of Justice for jury duty has given me the opportunity to find hidden gems in SoMa.  Such as the coffee bar hidden in the picture on the right.  Do you see it?  Look within that warehouse being remodeled, behind that yellow van.  Ah, there it is.  SightGlass!  I walked by this area and saw all kinds of signs saying SightGlass, but I thought it was some kind of glass shop, until I finally took a good look inside.

The scene:

A full coffee bar, a standing table, and one bench are all that make up the current SightGlass coffee bar.  There's always a few people waiting in line or hanging out on the bench.  Behind the bar is a bunch of curtains covering something going on in the back.  Next to the bench is more curtained off areas where you can hear all kinds of construction going on.  I overheard them talking about remodeling the area for where the actual coffee shop is going to be.  This must be their way of making money during the remodel to make up some of the costs.

The food:

I decided to order the Spice Infused Iced Tea. It was a nice and relatively warm day, although it's been raining all week.  The cup was pretty small, and the coffee was stronger than the watery Starbucks substance I normally get at work.  The Spices were definitely very fragrant.  I recommend adding some creamer in it.  It came out to be $3.
author: Sam L.

description:
Well... for the most part, this place is rated pretty high by almost all the Yelpers. But there are those few that for whatever reason have left this place with a very bad taste in their mouths. Words that have been used to describe Sightglass have been, pretentious, cold, fake, overly yuppie or hipster, etc, etc.... Wishing they could rate it at zero because one star was to good for this place.
This extreme in public opinion peeked my curiosity. I had to find out for myself. So this is my take on the place.
I walked in, went up to the counter, was kindly greeted with a smile and asked what I wanted. I ended up getting a $2 cup of coffee and made my way upstairs to have a seat. Tall ceilings, lots of concrete, steel and wood create a clean industrial look and feel that echo characteristics of a warehouse or factory from the 50's. 
Its 4pm on a Tuesday afternoon and as I look around I start to wonder where all the pretentious hipsters and yuppies are. All I see is the normal SF crew of usual suspects. Nothing out of the ordinary here. The coffee (black) is, well... pretty good. A little to acidic for my taste but non the less... good. All in all... its not a bad place and I really like the atmosphere. 
But... here are a few things that will probably keep me from frequenting the place much. 

1. At least for me... Its kinda out of the way. Unless you work around there, I don't see why you would bother going there just for the coffee.

2. No Internet connection?... Sorry, but its 2012 and everyone and their mom has a Macbook and needs to connect to... whatever it is on the Interweb. Its just excepted in this town and if you don't have it, its kinda like you're making some kind of social statement. Like "Unplug man... burn a candle and stop wasting electricity" lol. 

3. They sell coffee............... Yup. Thats pretty much it. Now, I know I got there at 4pm and I did see a few pastry looking things in the front counter but Jeez. Hook me up with some carbs or something. I mean, This place is huge... you could fit a whole restaurant in here if you wanted.

4. No electrical outlets. Haha... yeah I know, back to the computer thing again, but seriously, its a coffee shop and Id love to just hang out for awhile but without the ability to do work or entertain myself you can only stay there for so long before you start twiddling your thumbs plus, there are plenty of other coffee shops that are way more convenient. 

Summary:

Employees: Seemed nice to me
Coffee: Not bad, I might even say good.
Atmosphere: Loved it.

The not so good.
Location
No Wifi
Almost nothing to eat.

Overall... I give it a Meh +1. I like the place but there is no real reason for me to go back, and its very far from some of the overly negative reviews Ive seen on Yelp.
author: Jeff H.

description:
Great coffee and wonderful people.
This is my favorite coffee spot in the city. The care and consideration they put into every cup is really impressive. 

I'm glad they finally got moved into the new space and they now have Dynamo Donuts!
author: Trystan C.

description: The first thing I noticed - the space is so open with natural sunlight and there's a ton of place to do some work. I ordered my coffee, which took a bit of time to make, but it was so smooth and tasty.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
The Hooker's Chocolate Mocha is heavenly and the owners hail from the Pacific NW where I grew up. 

That's reason enough to get me to come back on a semi regular basis.
author: Lee H.

description: This is a delicious hole in the wall in an industrial part of town. Though, fair warning, you must be a hipster to enter. Just kidding, but it helps. Their coffee is fresh and their lattes divine. Their salted caramel is the perfect sweet treat when walking all over the city. Definitely a favorite spot, makes me wish I lived closer to SF.
author: Dia Z.

description: 5 stars for the beautiful space, 1 star for the terrible, terrible weak hot chocolate. I don't drink coffee so I got a hot chocolate here. It tasted like steamed milk with almost no chocolate. Starbucks makes it better. I hear the coffee is good though.
author: Kyle J.

description: Great coffee and great ambience. Love working here. Wish there was internet, but still 5 stars regardless.
author: Christopher K.

description: amazing coffee! had a peru drip and it was better than i anticipated. great job guys! keep it up!
author: Jonathon C.

description: love the coffee but my oh my the service. Found a baby green caterpilar ( yes a caterpillar ) on my yummy ginger scone ): Told the guy and he just looked at me , no sorry or do you want your money back. I'm pretty easy going and let things slide as sometimes i understand that you cant control everything but come on train the staff on protocol for what to do if someone sends something back. I dumped the scone and the other 2 pastries i had bought. My husband was shocked, i wasnt that shocked its the city sometimes you get that hipster better than you attitude.
author: marissa b.

description:
Deliciously tasty coffee. Super smooth and definitely addicting.

I haven't tried their latte, but their pour over coffee is fantastic. Rivals four barrel, except that they didn't seem to have quite as much love and preciseness for the process itself. I could watch them make the pour over coffee at four barrel all day though...

I believe I had the la Soledad, but I can't quite remember right now. It was wonderfully balanced with hints of brown sugar and dark chocolate. On the sweeter side, but not overly so.

Can't wait to check out the huge, airy space that seems well on the way towards being open. That will most likely boost it up to 5 stars. Right now, it's a great place to stop by to grab a cup and either head somewhere else or stroll around SOMA in the sun. There are a couple benches right next to the register, but nothing super cutesy or comfy.
author: Monica C.

description:
OK, so the MAIN reason I stopped was to see Moses. If you know Moses, you know why I stopped! But I'd also read about the coffee-stained floors, the supposedly beautiful hand-made bar and charcoaled wall coverings, and the coffee.

The place is gonna be gorgeous once it's done. It's huge, and future plans indicate it's gonna be a showplace. What's already finished is impressive.

My first cup of coffee was awesome - a nicaraguan delight. Earthy and chocolate-y with a toasted almond finish, it was divine.

I will be back! :)
author: SisterMable S.

description:
Over priced, over hyped. 3 bucks is a bit much to ask for coffee that's lukewarm. Moreover, I expect at least a SMALL size cup. The amount of coffee you get for your three dollars is like a kiddie cup. 

Not worth the money. Not as good as they say.
author: Meghneel G.

description:
another awesome SF coffee house. Real good handcrafted coffee...not your starbucks BS. 

sustainable and all the goodness that makes your feel good from sip 1 to end. 

Tons of single origin coffees from all around the globe. Great place to taste a variety and not as jampacked as other sf coffee shops.
author: Mohammad G.

description:
This place does great coffee. 

On my last visit (over a month ago), they had not yet got their own coffee roaster up and running, it's an impressive looking restored vintage German roaster from the 1960's.

Apparently those old machines are the best since the huge solid cast iron drum allows for even roasting, and they don't make them like they used to!
author: Marc S.

description: Needed an afternoon pick me up on a Sunday afternoon. Came here to what I thought at first was just an open warehouse. Turns out it was a coffee spot. It's massive and not your typical coffee place. It's modern and simple, which makes it sophisticated. The lines weren't long per se, it's because they take your order really fast and move to the other side to pick up your coffee. They use ipads to take your order and to pay as well. I had the hooker's mocha, and it wasn't that great. It actually tasted bad. I've been all over central america and parts of south america, so my standards for coffee are a lot higher. You'd think with so much ample space, they'd utilize it a lot better, but they fail miserably in this department. Plenty of seating upstairs, and bar like seating downstairs. They need regular seating downstairs. They also need wifi if they want to continue their modern vibe. Price was ok at best.
author: Phan H.

description: Nice space, huge, huge enough to hang out with your laptop and not keep anyone from sitting down with their cuppa. BUT, no outlets for your laptop if you are running our of power, and no wifi. My other bone to pick is  adherence to the increasingly popular attitude that they know better than me how my coffee takes best. So whole milk or soy milk are the only "milk" options. I had a cup of black coffee, it was ok, not any better than many other places, who also offer power outlets and wifi AND LOWFAT and NONFAT milk.
author: Beth W.

description:
Tucked away, half-finished building and people still line up. It's the beans.

I would give this place a 3.5 as it's not really a coffee place you can truly enjoy while sitting/sipping. SF is not a warm place in the morning. But it's a four because the look and feel of the space is awesome... rustic and modern. They also use Square for credit card payments on an iPad, which is pretty cool in my book. I like their minimalist aesthetic.

I had the Hooker's Mocha and the drink was a bit chalky. Not a fan of chalky coffee. But the roast was strong and complex. I'd come back. Enough said.
author: Warren L.

description:
fast becoming my new favorite coffee shop in SF.  Yes, as good as blue bottle, and comparable to four barrels.  Ask them for a recommendation, they're really receptive.  

The interior is also looking pretty spectacular, and I can't wait until I can bring my computer (request for the future: wifi and plugs plz?) there to work or enjoy a good book on what looks like a second floor maybe?  

Plenty of free parking on sunday mornings!  Come n get it.
author: Tracy N.

description: So what's the deal with REFUSING to serve iced lattes...You don't want my $5, I'll happily buy TWO iced lattes somewhere else then and probably enjoy them more anyway.  Too bad 0 stars is not an option for such snooty, upturned nose service.  Bye.
author: Jac C.

description: I Still have not been in there cafe, but I have been buying there Espresso Beans often for the home and love it. def up there with some of the best we have to offer locally, so many good coffee we have the choice of in our town, prob blue bottle is still my fav, but this def isn't far behind.
author: dub g.

description:
In today's marketplace of creative wonders, you can pretty much judge a cafe or restaurant by their graphic design and marketing.  

When I was in San Francisco this past week, we stumbled upon Sightglass...literally!  We were wandering around SoMa trying to find something to eat and drink and we walked past Sightglass and were immediately intrigued by its open air shoppe.  We both had a latte which we enjoyed.  The beans looked great and smelled great -- I love it when I can actually see the mechanics of a roastery.  A big perk of this place!  Love it.  Also, all of their design and marketing was gorgeous and spot-on.  

Also, they used an IPAD for the POS system which I thought was fantastic!
author: Kait K.

description: Brought a gaggle of old friends (we've known EO for 35+ years) and had a mini reunion upstairs for an hour or so. Delicious pastries and coffee drinks. Surroundings will encase you in warm woods and light chatter.
author: Ron W.

description: Attractive interior architecture with lots of open space.  I was there on a Sunday and it was pretty slow (about 25 people sitting upstairs, but no line), so I was served immediately.  The woman who took my order seemed like a manager, and she was pleasant and efficient.  The barista called my name within a reasonable amount of time, and the cappuccino was well made, but the taste was off - an issue with the blend, not the preparation. In my experience in the coffee industry, I have found that it is common for roasters to be good at roasting but perhaps not so good at blending; that's where a great palate comes in.  All in all, a nice place with better than average coffee, but not quite as good as Blue Bottle or Four Barrel.
author: LeftCoast R.

description:
Pros: Gorgeous Space, Good Coffee.

Cons: Ridiculously small serving (Latte in a capuchino sized cup) and pretentious rules.  Almost a parody of hipsterism.
author: Mike R.

description: one of my favorites. I love their coffee and the design of the place. always cool music playing on, always vinyl. love them.
author: Too M.

description: Been coming here a while. Best coffee spot - coffee, people that work here and the space - the trinity of how I grade.  Highest marks for each - especially dig the huge space and really nice folks.
author: Justin M.

description: What a great, unique space! Sightglass has two floors of open space that screams, "Come chill here!" Their coffee is good, too, though not the best ever. Had their cappuccino, and it was tasty. Notes of sweetness. But the atmosphere and space is what this place is all about. Definitely worth a visit.
author: Kevin D.

description: tried every (well...almost) coffee roasters in the city - my fav is still rituals. If I happen to be in the hood, I'll stop by here.   the place is cool.
author: Peaceful S.

description: The roaster machine is really a sight to look at.  The two stories floor plan gives it an open museum style feeling.  The smell of coffee beans is so strong.  And they even do the foam with pictures just like Blue Bottle and Four Barrel.  Too bad the coffee is meh.  I'll come back here if I'm close by and don't feel like struggling for parking near Four Barrel and Blue Bottles.
author: Byron L.

description:
Really good coffee. It is so super hip right now - until February when they expand and begin roasting their own beans. 

The coolest part about it is the technology for credit card usage and what that is doing for small businesses. Check it out - ever swiped your check card on an iphone? Pretty snazzy and SO 2010. 

Plus they make those little foam designs in mere seconds. Watch out!
author: Katherine B.

description:
Sorry, The cold-steeped, spice-infused iced is NOT the new blue bottle new orleans iced.  My coworker said it's 2/3 the price cause it's 2/3 the size.  

Its in the middle of being renovated, but with the little space they got right now there's some nice accoutrements regarding atmosphere, without a doubt it'll be a great place to loiter when everything is complete.  And yes, paying by iphone is fancy smancy.
author: David T.

description:
Nope.

Its no longer that you can just grab a big space in the part of the city that city hall is trying to improve, pay a small rent, toss down some concrete, hire a bunch a tattooed folk and sell bitter coffee without someone saying something.
I went in...stood in a long line, talked to a guy who didnt know if any of the coffee was organic-what!! as though any of it shouldnt be at those prices!!-learned that ONE was organic...he thinks...ordered it in drip form, waited 15 minutes for it while gnawing on a chocolate brioche which was stale....back to tartine please...with nowhere to sit as they are still building the upstairs and feel that their coffee is so good you will stand for it...
finally we got the coffee...how do I write this?  It was so bitter we couldnt drink it and so strong I felt like my stomach was screaming for it to be immediately coated for protection.
COME ON!
There is no soul, no love, no craftmans coffee and NO WHERE TO SIT!
12 bucks later we left way too wired and frustrated.
author: Kate S.

description:
For someone who loves mochas, I think I have found the perfect latte. The strong smell of coffee (roasted on the premises) yet the smooth flavor is what has made this place one that I plan on visiting soon. Often times, coffee will make me feel bloated when it feels too greasy. I don't know what the official term for that is, or the cause for that is, but this coffee is just unique in it's properties and the latte art is nice too.
I don't see all the hype around for Blue Bottle, and to be honest, I don't think Four Barrel is as good. Glad I found Sightglass.

The barista rang me up using an iPad. I told her, and I'm saying it here, that I had never seen anyone give an iPad a good use. I guess iPads should definitely replace cash registers. Give them some use.
author: Alexia R.

description: If you want to experience how a simple cup of coffee is made in SSLLOOWW motion, then you must come here! I waited so long for my small cup of coffee I almost bought an old school grinder they had for sale,bag of coffee, and brewed some myself. Although..the one plus was my cup of coffee really tasted like someone put their heart into it....pretty damn good.....this place is fun if your stoned and not in a hurry.
author: Max H.

description: Well, I paid 3.50 for a tiny latte here, and there is NO wi-fi. Yes, the coffee was good, not sure about 3.50 worth of good, but no wi-fi? In San Francisco? Gimme a break.
author: Paul K.

description:
So I wasn't told by a cool insider about this place - I must admit I read about the Japanese style of spice infused iced coffee in Food & Wine magazine on the flight over, and my interest was piqued. My adventurous local friend complied to my adventure request on a random street - looks like they are expanding?? 
So there is no place to sit really - more of a warehouse environment and you have to walk a bit to find a place outside...but the iced coffee was unlike any thing I had ever tried - bringing the craft to iced coffee stateside.
I am going back for the Hookers Mocha...
author: Adriana K.

description:
The coffee was great, don't get me wrong. I can only give it four stars for a couple of reasons though: 

The coffee was small for 3.50, not really that big a deal and not worth a full star on it's own maybe. 

The location is just really out of the way. Ok so if I gotta travel to get it, its a little inconvenient. It's not like I'm going to 7th St to just hang out at the Knight's Inn or whatever that is. Maybe if I had a court date up the street at Bryant or something. 

I could see this being a destination if they used that enormous space behind the kiosk for a cafe where I could actually sit and relax for a while. Until then only 4, as I can get an equally good cup of coffee at a few other places that aren't so out of the way.
author: aaron f.

description:
I'll admit my bias due to the fact that I live so close, but that notwithstanding, Sightglass is my favorite coffee place in SF.  The venue is gorgeous - great rehabilitation of a SOMA building.  It's open, airy and welcoming.  It can get noisy a bit at times, especially when the upstairs gets crowded by start-up meetings...

The coffee is excellent, and I strongly recommend their pour-overs (instead of the quick-cup).
author: Christopher C.

description: In my opinion this brand is highly hyped (just as Philz coffee) and definitely not worth the high prices that these guys demand. Their Owl's howl espresso coffee is not bad in general, but not great either, and extremely acidic to the point that it actually ruins the good portion of its taste. If they reduce the acidity of this brand, it might improve significantly in quality.
author: batvanio i.

description: Very cool! This place has character but no charm. It is a good place for a simple meeting or to do some work on your laptop.  Indoor parking for your bicycle.
author: Miguel C.

description:
Ok hipsters, I know you guys are relatively enthusiastic about trying to create exclusivity out of otherwise basic activities, such as brewing coffee, listening to music, and standing around  smelling tea leaves and so on, but this place takes it way to far.

Sight Glass "If the Apple store sold coffee, you'd have this place"

1. They weigh the coffee on a scale and it takes 5 minutes for them to give you a house coffee

2. They play records from a record player one by one, cute but come on
     it's all for show we know that you don't really care about those old LP's

3. Prices = absurd 

4. Quality =  Peets totally beats you guys and is so much better tasting

5. The space is nice, but looks like it should be the apple store, not a coffee house. I guess the genius bar in this case is hoard of 20 something coffee snobs enjoying the aromas of over priced cups of joe.

I wanted to like this place, maybe you will?
author: Mr D.

description: Their new space is open, which gives you a look at their roasting process. The place is very SF in that it's well designed. Coffee is great. I had a cappuccino in store, and brought home some Owl's Howl which made for some seriously awesome coffee. There are not very many chairs in the place though. I guess they're going for the european standing espresso bar vibe. There are chairs upstairs, but the upper decker was closed when we went, so don't expect a place where you can chill out.
author: Julian V.

description:
like four barrel and ritual.  gives the feel of seattle coffee roasteries.  barebones.  offer v60 vs. chemex
owner background = prev. four barrel and blue bottle, hence the similarities.
once at this level, hard for me to distinguish the sourcing.
Baked goods are from Firebrand Artisan Breads and the Tell Tale Preserve Company. Chocolates are from Hooker's Sweet Treats.
author: Rob C.

description: One of the best latte I've ever had. Nice atmosphere, amazing coffee.
author: Jean-François B.

description: SO UNFRIENDLY!!! It's really too bad, the coffee is fantastic and the space is beautiful. That being said, wouldn't you want an awesome staff to represent?? I'm so sick of the "I'm too cool for everyone" hipster horse s***! Just smile, we live in the greatest city in the country.
author: Chelsea H.

description:
I'm not sure why this place is getting good reviews. The only good thing that I can say about this place is that they were playing The Pixies' Surfer Rosa when I was in there. I payed $6 for an eight ounce cup of what tasted like every other strong, crappy coffee that I'd ever had. I asked the guy behind the counter why the cost was so much and he looked uncomfortable with the question. He said "I guess it has something to do with the roasting process" and that it probably costs a lot to get the beans from Africa. 
I am quite sure that the people who like this place know a lot more about coffee than I do, but I drink a ton of it and this stuff destroyed my stomach. Not feeling sick is pretty important to me when it comes to coffee selection. The place is nice, though. I would add some tables and chairs to fill up some of that space.
author: Kevin M.

description: I love hanging out at this place, alone to read or work, or to meet a friend to chat.  Usually they place cool, rock-infused background music, but occasionally they turn up the volume and play more punk stuff (to which I immediately leave because you can't hear yourself think).  I interior is gorgeous.  The coffee is overpriced at $4 to $5 a cup, and the place has a bit of a snobby feel to it, but I like it anyway.  They allow dogs, so I sometimes bring my pooch - that's always nice.  NO WI-FI (some of the snob factor at play)
author: Steve S.

description:
Great coffee.  Gracious, unprentious service.  These guys are serious about quality delivery but don't have an uptight disposition.  Love that!  Located in the SOMA 'hood that often gets a bad rap - in some cases for good reason, these guys are building out what appears like it will be a seriously groovy spot.  For now they are operating from a little cart near enough on the sidewalk.

Visited the first time on the VERY FIRST business day after the Apple iPad was realeased to the public and found these guys using one with a custom POS!   Chatting with one of the partners I learned that they had a friend write the program for the iPad whilst it was still in development AND had another friend handmake a custom 'holster' for the iPad to rest in.

No doubt these guys will always be one step ahead of the rest of us...and I don't mind following them!

Great stuff going on here.
author: Lisa D.

description:
Skip the drip.

I get good coffee.  But when coffee costs close to $5 a cup it better be divine. It took 15 minutes to get my simple cup of dark roasted drip, which was served in a medium sized cold mug. Coffee was so-so, nothing amazing, and was lukewarm on the first sip to boot.  I can care less about vinyl records and fancy espressos, which I guess is part of this place's allure. I have had a better cup of jo for 1/4 the price at the corner coffee shop.
author: Eric S.

description: A little bit pricey, but if you want one of the best cups of coffee in the city, you can't go wrong at sightglass.  Additionally, the place is gorgeous and feels very relaxed.  A wonderful place to get some work done and be able to concentrate!
author: Yan L.

description: Wow-- this place is great. I did my research before coming up to SF and heard that this coffee shop is not only beautiful, but has delicious coffee and amazing pastries. I was not disappointed. Sightglass is just plain awesome!! I would move up to SF for this coffee shop alone :)
author: Pav A.

description: No WiFi makes for a much less crowded store. At times though the wait is 10 minutes plus, even for a single latte. Honestly though. But oh those Latte's - prob the best in the city. $4 does seem like a bit much, but the quality is always the same... Excellent. Not sure about the "attitude" that people mention, I've always had pleasant servers.
author: Lorin S.

description: Strong and tasty coffee and espresso. But for the overly-caffeinated faint of heart (aka me at 6pm...) they have delicious gravenstein apple juice that they will warm to a slightly frothy splendor.  Decor in here is kinda gorgeous too.
author: Sasha W.

description: I've tried, for months now, to learn to like the sour, not acidic, but sour taste of Sight Glass coffee and its just not happening for me. Im disappointed because many coffee houses who used to serve Blue Bottle are now serving Sight Glass, and its a huge disappointment. I miss Blue Bottle!
author: Lynn R.

description: Decent cup of coffee--though a bit overrated.  Cool space.  Nice high vaulted ceilings.  Minus one star for the dude sitting across with the 'how dare you bring in an archaic Thinkpad" look.  Minus star numero dos for being a hipster mecca.  Uggghhh.
author: Jasper J.

description: Wow. What impressive architecture! This is the largest coffee shop that I've ever been to. The space is warehouse-like and very dramatic, with exposed beams, lots of natural light, and tons of open floor space. What's really important is the coffee, however, and I'm not a fan of it or the pastries. The former is a bit too strong for my taste (although I do normally enjoy bolder coffee) and the latter is dry and bland. The staff could loose their "better than thou" attitude, too.
author: Brett B.

description: Came back for the espresso and its GOOD.  Macchiato had a smooth creamy texture and I'm still diggin the environment.  Perfect for conversing by the bar stools by the window, or studying and reading upstairs overlooking the cafe.  Whoever designed this place was genius.  Now....open one in the Richmond district please-doesn't have to be big either.
author: Vincent K.

description:
As I mentioned in my Blue Bottle review, I enjoy a hot, bold, smooth cup of coffee each morning.  This past weekend my friend and I did a taste test of three coffee places (a tall cup of drip coffee), Sightglass was included.  Bluebottle was one of the places we re-tried as well as Four Barrel Coffee.  

My second choice out of the three was Sightglass.  I felt the coffee was a wee-tad weaker than Bluebottle and I like my coffee strong, as I typically only have one cup a day.  I would definitely recommend this place to others, as well as par-taking in a taste test, as it allows you to truly figure out the best coffee in the city.
author: Caroline Q.

description: Never enjoyed a cup of coffee on site, but I prefer their beans to every other roaster in the city.
author: Kevin M.

description:
Best cappuccino I've ever had, hands down... would definitely say they are better than blue bottle. 

So glad to have this place right around the corner from work.
author: megan k.

description:
My wife and I went out of our way to try Sightglass based on the Yelp reviews and were sadly disappointed. The location is in transition and will probably be very nice in the future, but right now it's just an espresso stand. This review in no way reflects the setting since I know that it is not permanent and I don't want to knock them while they get their location set up properly.

We were pleased by the service of the barista during our visit and the crema looked very appetizing in our americanos, but that is where our good experience changed. The coffee tasted very watery especially since our americanos were only in 8 or 10 oz cups (I can't remember exactly). They were the same size that Blue Bottle offers, but were just not even close to as good as BB. They of course were better than Starbucks, but not nearly as good as Peet's. My wife really disliked the taste of the coffee and had trouble finishing hers. 

I wish we had found something great with Sightglass, but this place just doesn't do it for us. We drink ridiculous amounts of coffee all over the world and would not rank this place highly on our list.
author: T O.

description: I've never had a better cappuccino. Perfect, smooth taste. Exact drinking temperature. Kind of pricey (almost $4 for a small capp), but worth every penny. My only complaint is that they only carry 2 types of milk: whole or soy. I'd appreciate some low-fat milk
author: Diana P.

description:
Best place since in northern california after Temple in Sacramento (I know right)

been looking for good strong coffee forever! :)
author: Johan M.

description: As good as it gets! We ordered a cup of pour-over at Sightglass. After the first sip, my husband rushed to buy two more bags of beans to bring home (Toronto, Canada). The coffee we have has a full body; it tastes as sweet as honey, layered with fruity peach and berry flavours. Watching the barista take his time to craft a good cup of coffee is hypnotizing. It takes patience, skill, experience, and steady hands. Coffee that comes from love doesn't disappoint. I really appreciate the fact that Sightglass sources their coffee beans from all over the world and roast their own coffee, one small batch at a time. The intimate relationship between sourcing, roasting and brewing must be the key to their great coffee. Sight Glass also offers a great space for their patrons.
