Its warm, spacious, and hip atmosphere attracts many coffee lovers to relax here and enjoy a good cup of joe. Any chance you guys would open up a new location in Toronto, Canada?! :)
author: Rachel L.

description: Nice ambiance.  Pet friendly. Great coffee.
author: April M.

description:
Just moved into the neighborhood and glad to see a real coffeehouse close by to grab my coffee or meet up with friends.  

Although - when we ordered iced coffees - which is what i drink on a daily basis (please add it to your menu) We got two very small paper cups with ice + coffee - no lids ($5 for 2). The flavor of the coffee was great, but please add large plastic cups + lids for us ice coffee drinkers to the menu and we'll surely be back weekly.
author: Ken B.

description:
light, fresh, creative, innovative (technologies), minds, confident, helpful, classic, inspired, WIRED! 

truly "fine coffees for a weary world"
author: Derek T.

description: Awesome space for a coffee shop and good coffee. It kind of seems like a huge waste of space (you'll know what I mean if you go there) but it's done so nicely I can't really see it being filled up any more than it already is.
author: Diana Y.

description: Beautiful on the inside. Good coffee and pastries, served with a hint of hipster pretense. I like the minimalist vibe, and love that it is so spacious on the inside and (at least for now) not crowded. Although it sometimes feels like Sightglass is trying too hard to be cool, this place really contributes to the FolSOMA renewal vibe.
author: C. H.

description:
My first Slayer experience. ;-)  I thought the espresso was very good, but not as great as most Yelpers seemed to think -- slight bit too burnt/ashy for my taste.  I spoke with the (very friendly) barista, asking her about how the Slayer functions.  She explained all the benefits I read about, and also how complex it is to fine tune.  To mitigate the complexity, she said that the owners set up the pressure profiles, etc. each morning (adjusting for the beans/roast), and she simply pulls the shots the same way each time.  This may explain why I was a bit disappointed with the resulting shot.

According to the Slayer site (http://www.slayerespresso.com/2009/05/01/slayer-compared-to-other-brands/): "It gives you control over pressure in an entirely new and intuitive way.  You can intercede in your shot at any point by changing pressure... It's a machine to prepare artisanal coffee BY HAND. You set those pressure deltas quickly and easily, and you use the machine by watching your shots."  So it seems that Sightglass' configure-once/pull-all-day model is not what the Slayer guys had in mind.  But it's obvious that these guys are serious about their coffee, and I'm hopeful they'll perfect their Slayer pulls in due time.
author: Ari M.

description: A must-visit on every trip to SF. And if I find out anyone I know is going to SF, I have them go there and buy me fresh beans. I don't tell them that the decor is exceptional or that the coffee and pastries are superb... but I always hear about it when they get back. Paid with Square.
author: S S.

description:
The atmosphere at this place is just outstanding. Something about it makes me feel inspired when I come here for coffee.

The coffee is really good, Probably in my Top 5 in SF. 

You've got to spend some coin for small cup of drip though,
author: Christian K.

description: This place is a joke. And not a very funny one. It's huge, but has no seating or tables to work at.  The coffee is expensive, but it is not especially good.  They only have ~5 things on the menu, but the service is slow.  There is no Wi-Fi!  A staple in any cafe.I can't think of any compelling reasons to come here for coffee.  Two stars because the interior looks pretty cool (but isn't comfortable), and the coffee is drinkable.
author: Elliott B.

description: Superb coffee. Discovered this amazing roastery when I was at the Marin Bikes factory store  across street.   Spartan and lovely inside. I imagine Julia Morgan might of designed this roastery.  My latte was fantastic. We all watched another batch of coffee being roasted.  Bought a pound of Owls Howl Espresso.
author: ruby l.

description:
Best coffee in SF.
If you're looking for a peppermint chai latte or a gingerbread latte you're in the wrong place. No wifi, free magazines or secure stroller parking either.
Just great coffee.
author: Ted N.

description:
I'm really glad that I'm friends with my friend Chris Juelsgaard. Dude, seriously, you have introduced me to the most amazing coffee joint that I've ever been.

I don't think I have ever had the most consistent Latte in my coffee experience. Consistent in every way; the temperature, the layer of the foam, the espresso base, the thickness of the milk, the taste and the artwork... FLAWLESS!

I have gone there for six times so far and I have been having the same experience as I went the first time.

The two brothers had nailed it. I understand that they may be having the best espresso machine ever..., The Slayer... But seriously, I think the most important thing is coffee making (Latte, Cappuccino, Macchiato, etc.) is the Barista. 

Hail for Sightglass. Can't wait to see the full joint soon!

Congrats..., you have made my coffee day is a great coffee day...
author: Inne S.

description:
Me: "iced espresso please"
Counter: "aye aye"

----
Picking up espresso that doesn't look iced. 

Me: "oh, I wanted it iced"
Batista: "oh, we don't ice espressos here.  Takes away from the flavor."
Me (thinking): "thanks for patronizing me"

Unhappy customer!  Espresso itself was all right, but oh so dang hot.
author: Kanishk P.

description:
loves it. 

ps the gluten free orange cake they carry (from Poccino) - fantastic.
author: camille z.

description:
It has been about two months since I actually visited Sight Glass, but I meant to review it then and am belatedly holding to my convictions.

Sight Glass provided the best coffee that I have had outside of Frank in Austin, TX.  

They had three origins on tap (via 360 or chemex for now) and my boyfriend and I ordered two of those three.  Epically delicious.

Because we, 'just have to try it,' one of the baristas made us a pour over of the third (a Kenya).  Superb.  The baristas were all endlessly friendly, knowledgeable, and involved.  

When I went, Sight Glass was just a well designed website + a tiny store front with glass windows to see into the space they were developing.  Huge and BEAUTIFUL.  Not sure when that space is actually destined to open... but I hope to gaze upon its glory when it does.
author: Hallie T.

description: While the stained concrete floor and wood & steel accents are visually appealing, not to mention the surfeit of space to take it all in, the coffee at Sightglass is merely adequate  -- and pricey.  Better deals and blends can be found throughout the neighborhood.  Having said that, the staff is attentive and the location is perfect for meeting up with a friend before, during, and after work.  If you can put up with the hipsters -- and a truly awful cover of the Beatles' Everybody's Got Something To Hide Except Me And My Monkey blasting over the hi-fi system -- Sightglass is worth a visit whenever you find yourself in SOMA.
author: Paul D.

description: I can't believe someone actually built a 3,000 sq foot coffee shop just to serve as an ironic parody of San Francisco bourgeois douchebags! So clever!
author: Jimmy F.

description: Love it... Great 'quick cup' if you're looking for a quick cup of drip coffee.  If you have time ask them for a recommendation or order your favorite espresso drink.   They also get their food from somewhere REALLY awesome and it's ALL good...  Great place to have a quick coffee meeting and there's lots of people that use it for a work spot, but I don't think they have wifi...  Based on coffee and ambiance... 5 stars
author: Will W.

description: Fantastic iced coffee, better than Four Barrel ~*gasp*~! The cold brew method along with delicate spices makes this iced coffee phenomenal and very refreshing (an adjective not commonly used to describe coffee). While the coffee is strong it is not bitter and will give a kick to your day. The staff was friendly and personable. They use an iPhone app to process your CC; you can have your receipt emailed or textd. Nice to see a small company utilizing technology and rejecting the 'cash-only' attitude oh so familiar to SF. It will be nice to see this place up and running, bringing competition to Four Barrel and the Bluebottle station in SOMA.
author: Cori W.

description:
Second best espresso in San Francisco, the first being Simple Pleasures in the Richmond.
You can take that from a former resident of Seattle and frequenter of Victrola, Vivace, Fiore, Vita....

Too bad they "don't do iced espresso beverages" because "our espresso doesn't taste good over ice."  The baristas are pretty nice, but appear to be suffering under this bizarre dictate from leader on high.  Minus one star.

Also no wifi - Minus another star.  

Still one of the better café experiences one can have in the city due to its design and layout, and again great tasting espresso roast.
author: Jonathan A.

description: Good latte, although I give the edge to blue bottle and four barrel. It's really nice looking inside, but it's in a fairly sketchy neighborhood.
author: Captain B.

description: My succinct review: $5 for a small cup of mocha is a little too expensive for my taste, however the overall look and feel of the coffee shop is quite worth it.
author: Jessica P.

description: I'm not sure what I love more, the coffee, the pastries, or simply being in the expansive, bright, beautiful space. I cherish my quiet moments sitting on the mezzanine looking down at the beautiful people, watching the coffee beans move around in the big roaster and dreaming about how fabulous it would be to transform Sightglass into my own personal living space. Their flowers are always really interesting too.
author: Shae T.

description: Good coffee and good atmosphere. BUT, yes there is a but, no tea (really?), no wifi and no power outlet. If you want to come here to do some work, it might not be the ideal place.
author: S. C.

description: I've been a tea drinker most of my life but after drinking sightglass coffee, I'm loving coffee again! Service is great. The brothers are very friendly. And I keep comparing other coffees I drink to their's. That's certainly a good thing.
author: Nori L.

description: Gorgeous space, good coffee. Pretty much the yummiest latte ever.
author: Olivia P.

description: For serious coffee lovers, this is THE spot. I love the coffee here as much as Four Barrel, Ritual, or any of of the other local roasters in SF. I like this place as much as I like Stumptown in the Pacific Northwest. Whatever blend they use for espresso, it's so smooth and naturally sweet, sugar is not necessary. Although I tend to favor deep roasts, Sightglass is a light to medium roast, not dark and rich like Peet's or Blue Bottle. For a medium roast, it is incredibly flavorful. Love, love, LOVE. :)
author: Kel S.

description: Like most people, I have walked past this place plenty of times without realizing what it was.  First experience at Sightglass was pretty good.  Like most places that roast coffee, their is that "if you have questions about coffee, don't ask what to drink" and this place definitely is like that.  After ordering a latte, that was really good, I purchased a 3/4 pound bag of coffee (not even a whole pound).  I have been making French Press coffee for years and know how the coffee should taste.  With the coffee I purchase, the taste was never right (even when using more coffee).  Every time the coffee tasted sour and I could not drink it.  If I am in the area, I might stop by again, but will probably never buy 3/4 pounds of coffee again (not even mentioning the price)
author: Elliot G.

description: Okay, being just a hop, skip, and jump from Tenderloin and charging $4.25 for drip coffee that is 1/2 size as a nice Starsucks coffee?   That's just wrong!   Okay, the coffee is great and the warehouse is awesome.    The music is somewhat turned up, so don't expect to study here.   Oh, no wi-fi, that is like having a coffee shop without cream.   The NO WI-FI is a deal breaker for me.   If I just want good coffee, I'm probably going to end up at BlueBottle or Philz.    Overall staff is nice and place is great, hope they get real with the prices - It's a RECESSION people!
author: H D.

description:
Probably the BEST coffee experience in the states.  The coffee was great (I had a cappuccino), the croissant very tasty (blackberry & pistachio), but the environment is what makes it.  

Sightglass is in a very cool warehouse.  It's open & spacious with interesting architecture.  When you walk in, you immediately smell the coffee beans roasting (there is a large roasting machine in the center of the building).  They operate a retail coffee shop (plenty of seating), wholesale and mail order business within the one warehouse.  

If you're in the SoMa area, it's definitely worth it to stop by for a coffee.
author: Lori S.

description: Diggin the bar feel and the amazing looking shop next door being built, but wasn't feeling the coffee so much when compared to Blue Bottle. I bought a bag of Blueboon and it lacks flavor and aroma when compared to the Giant Steps at Blue Bottle I bought last week! The baristas were awesome though, and I love paying by Credit Card using Square on the iPad - the ad for Square actually features Sightglass! Movie star status. Woot!
author: Albert W.

description: It is a great setting but if you want a seat, get there early. There are lots of young hipsters who buy a cup of coffee and stay for hours. Cappuccino (three for our party of three) were served at room temperature.  We waited a half hour for a seat but there was zero turnover.
author: tom c.

description: Pretentious describes the service experience.  But ok, the interior architecture is phenomenally cool and the coffee isn't bad.  A little burnt for my taste, but I will go back for a second try.
author: Laura M.

description:
I guess since the darker roast coffees (Philz, Peets) are what I tend to prefer, I'm just not the target customer for this place.

Beautiful spacious place, and the several times I've been there I've never gotten any "attitude" from the people working there...I just find the prices extremely high for coffee that I don't find very enjoyable.
author: Boogee Z.

description: Pretty cool coffee place. Great interior...
author: Ali E.

description: The coffee is good, but holy cow it's expensive. For that price, I would expect to be able to enjoy my coffee sitting down, but there are very few seats in the huge space, and I felt sadly lucky to have a counter on which to rest my cup.
author: Loz L.

description:
sight glass: a transparent tube through which the operator of a tank or boiler can observe the level of liquid contained within.

Sight Glass: a new hip coffee bar in SoMa that will soon be roasting their own beans on-site in a renovated space on 7th and Folsom. 

hooker's mocha: a coffee drink a pimp buys his ho?

Hooker's mocha: served at Sight Glass, a delicious mocha that uses Hooker's chocolate -- a local chocolatier -- making a warm semi-sweet concoction that hits the spot.
author: Joel A.

description:
Today was a good day for me, I traveled around san francisco to some of the finest. My first stop was here at sightglass, coming in i had high expectations. Being part of the specialty coffee world, I know & understand how all the things work. The environment isn't new to me. Its a BEAUTIFUL location, great place to study or hangout with some friends. the facility itself was great!

The coffee I had was phenomenal. I bought my friend a soy gibralter & got me and my brother a pour over (i believe from El Salvador? or maybe Costa Rica....not too sure.) The espresso for the Gib was GREAT! SO good! i loved it! The drip was meh.... they could've done better & i have no yet lost hope that they could make me better next time i visit!

One thing that bothered me, the customer service. I know, i know... the specialty coffee world is full of pricks. That's just what we do, we are a prideful bunch & i knew i was going to be treated like this, but normally us baristas normally get along. I am obviously in the coffee world (i have a portafilter tattooed on my arm as well as a rosetta) and am normally treated more as a guest. (Cause we do that as baristas!) But it was weird there, just dry. I felt like an outcast or like i didnt matter. Not really that big of a deal & it wont stop me from going there...just weird. It felt as if there was a lack of confidence in being able to converse, YOU GUYS HAVE A GREAT PRODUCT!!!! TALK ABOUT IT! share your brew ratio with me, tell me the theory behind how you're pouring, talk to me about the ways you've been playing at home with your V60 & how you can make a better cup at home but your boss wont let you pour like that at work for consistency sake (& then disobey him & pour me a damn good cup of coffee!!). 

All of this to say.....It was great, i loved it, i am excited to return & get to know the fellow baristas there!

-The end

p.s. you guys are badass!
author: Joshua D.

description: The best thing about this place is the decor. Period. No wifi! ( I understand the need for client turn over, but c'mon) their coffee is of the fancy/specialty type but as an avid drinker, I don't think it beats Blue Bottle. Not even close.
author: Alireza R.

description: This place is has come a long ways.  Nice place.  Still the beans are not the best in town, but still solid.
author: Demanding T.

description:
This is one of the new wave coffee places with high standards for coffee and hipster crowd. 

They roast themselves and make good espresso drinks and drip coffee.

I tried espresso and cappuccino - both very good.

What I recommend though is go there and try coffee made in Chemex. 
We usually go there on weekend and get Chemex coffee from a couple of different regions and compare them side by side. Makes a nice weekend coffee outing.

They also sell sea salted chocolate covered caramels from Hooker's sweet treat.
author: BO P.

description: Great place with good coffee. Space for bikes. Very comfortable atmosphere and lots of space to work. A bit pricey and no wifi but otherwise good. Will definitely come back.
author: Gene Z.

description: Coffee was ok, but overpriced.  If I'm going to pay for overpriced coffee, I'm going to go to Blue Bottle not too far away.  But, the ambiance is pretty cool inside.
author: Kim K.

description: Some of the best grumpy hipsters in line asking the most hilarious questions. I can't wait for the actual inside to be open but it doesn't look like they will have many places just to sit and hang out. I love that you can get any of the 3 featured coffee's poured over ice. Lawrence had the hot version of the Bourbon coffee and I had the iced. It was fun to compare how it changes the taste depending on how it is served.
author: Tracy A.

description: Latte was nice but pastries were blah. Don't order food unless you like food that looks decent but tastes horrible.
author: Brian S.

description: awesome space, totally friendly, so sleek and modern, but was suprsised by the little sticky notes that the baristas use to define the drinks...you'd think...anyway...dont over think.  they have a lovely spacious place there.  the coffee is good, and its SO smooth you might actually wish it were a little bitter!  it went down SO easy!  good job guys.  brought some beans home as well.  usually i like to be comped an espresso when i buy 20$ 8oz bag of beans...come on guys!
author: Tim W.

description: Really good sized coffee shop. They even have an upstairs. I love the space and the modern iPad registers. The line goes by fast and the coffee is fast too. I got the ham and cheese poptart which was delish but i wish it could have been warmed (no toasters here). I also like the hooker chocolates.
author: Jenna Q.

description:
This place is OK.  I tried to give it a chance a number of times, but it just didn't work out.  I have to agree with some other reviews about the espresso being sour and acidic.  Not sure what's up with that.  I was also told with a straight face that they have no bathrooms.  I don't believe it for a second, but they won't budge.

On  a number of occasions, I've bought the espresso beans for home.  They're fantastic for the first few days, but even with keeping them in the fridge, their flavor turns and you get that awful source-acidic taste the rest of the bag.

I really wanted to like this place, but reality just won't let it happen.  Guess it's back to Vega.
author: Wesley S.

description:
Why weren't they open when I lived a block away and had to commute just to get a good cup of coffee?  

Awesome Chemex into a glass pitcher process that yields a really decent cup of coffee, especially at only $2.  If it was a biiiit stronger this would be a 5 star revue.  I'm sure they'll get there.

Also, great service.  The lady who served me my coffee was really nice, conversational and all that jazz.  It's rad to get a good cup of coffee without the 'i am a barista with an espress tattoo and you should be so lucky as to have this latte' attitude.  

Go here.
author: Tom T.

description:
First sip, and I was hooked!  
I walk by on my way to/from work, and have been quite curious, but never had cash on me.  Finally stopped in this morning (only to discover they take plastics- huzzah!), and it was an instant addiction.
Simple menu with an excellent base selection.  Simple decor (but VERY well thought out- it just works).  Guy at the counter was very nice, and made an excellent macchiato.  Plus- the giant machines are fun to look at!
I'll be back every morning that I can afford too.
author: Darian H.

description: Staff is supremely knowledgeable and pleasant. Coffee is kick ass. No need for creme and sugar kick ass. Get it? Got it? Good.
author: Shira O.

description: Great coffee! Great venue! great place for meetings.
author: Shmuel F.

description:
This is an excellent coffee establishment with style and plenty of open space. Since I must make the comparison, blue bottle's latte is more milky and creamy (not my thing). We buy beans so we can have drip coffee at home after our daily latte (really). 


Do not go here to:
eat (mediocre pastry)
browse the internet (no wifi)
plug in electronics (not possible)
use the restroom (looks good, smells terrible)

*To all of those who think that sightglass is a deluge of pretentious hipsters -  you've obviously have not been to four barrel. The baristas (also owners) at sightglass are so friendly they make me gush. Don't even get me started on rude blue bottle baristas.
author: Phi T.

description:
Sightglass is a what SoMA needed; an avant garde coffee house--simple menu and outstanding roasting profile of coffee.  Simplicity and individual drip per order.  The roasting profile is medium-dark a nice profile to enjoy the bean you select (if you are having a coffee); the beans are not charred or overly roasted but balanced and give an outstanding veritas per ordered coffee.  

I enjoy the minimalism of the space and look forward to seeing the building out and completion of gallery.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description: Great coffee. What I really love, though, is the space! Beautifully put together.
author: Anu K.

description: Had the decaf mocha and it was delicious - made with delicious chocolate that's not loaded with sugar.  Their coffee bean is great for homemade French press but I will say their beans are relatively expensive compared to other artisan brands like Ritual and Four Barrel but comparable to Verve.
author: Irene C.

description: Great pastries, love the coffee aroma from roasting in house, great space...but my god the service is too slow....and did not care how long the line is...they just too slow for me.......for a big space they only have two baristas with one dedicated to more complicated order...like cafe late...lol!  dont go there if u have limitted time but perfect if you have nothing to do for the entire day lol! I am back to Starbucks!
author: Manila A.

description: How do they have 4 stars?  I would love to love this place.  It's like a block away from my house.  The coffee is not good and it's so overpriced.  Four Barrel and Ritual are so much better.  And now Sextant Coffee just opened up on 10th and Folsom, yay!  The coffee was good and the barista wasn't a total DB
author: McKenzie M.

description: Perfectly roasted beans. Pray they don't go the Blue Bottle route by increasing their volume, and selling in every no name cafe in town. it will kill the quality.
author: Joe M.

description: Great morning hangout in a Warehouse cafe setting. Caramelized hazelnut financier and cappuccino kicks off a great start to the day.
author: Philip T.

description: I live around the corner from these guys, and have been going since they were half open. I think they have the best coffee in the city. I'm really glad you guys opened with such impact - it helps the neighborhood a lot.
author: Alex M.

description: thanks to the observation of a couple friends, we've noticed that the companies that use Clover brand dairy (cream, milk, half & half, etc.) tend to have really tasty coffee. Sightglass has REALLY tasty coffee/espresso! and this was really made evident when i brought home some beans and began brewing my own SIghtglass beans. NOM NOM NOM. so tasty. the flavors in these beans are by far superior to the other local roasters... not to say the other local roasters aren't good... but Sightglass is just on to something. and who knows, maybe i'll have to take a break from they're beans sometime in the future... but until then i'll be brewing up my sightglass beans and enjoying the F*¢k out of it!
author: Kevin W.

description: Was recently turned on to this place by the gf who insisted that I check this place out with her (she's been a loyal customer since they opened) and how could I say no to such a lovely lady?  Well, she was right about them - finely roasted, sustainably-conscious coffee beans (roasted to order from what I understand), espresso with amazing depth and flavor, and really awesome, attentive, friendly service.  A beautiful kiosk that is being built out to a full scale shop and I must say, it's really cool to see the construction in progress and see the giant roaster just on the other side of the wall.  Coffee roasting is a craft and the good folks at Sightglass are virtuosos.
author: Rich G.

description: Awesome place for a fantastic brew.  And the interior ROCKS.  It's gorgeous.  For a while the seating was a problem, but they've opened up additional seating.  It's a great place to meet a friend, especially those who are coffee aficionados.
author: Sam O.

description: Coffee was really good but they did not serve soy milk. No tables for people in wheelchairs. All downstairs seating is on a stool.
author: Lael W.

description:
Maybe it's just me, I don't know.  It used to be smaller and the staff was much friendlier and seemed nicer.

They're primarily a roaster.  So they must not be putting much emphasis on their storefront/coffee house customer service.

The coffees are ok, the lattes are not so good, but the espresso is great!   And be prepared to wait much longer than you would think you'd have to.  It's really expensive, so it takes longer.  Right?

In a neighborhood where there are plenty of great places to get espresso drinks that are just as good, if not better (Bluebottle, Peet's, and many new indie coffee houses),  Sightglass is not the friendly little coffee place it used to be.

Check out:
http://farmtablesf.com/
http://sf.eater.com/tags/machine-coffee/
author: Harry O.

description: The Latte is on average $3.75/cup. The venue is really neat, but it's still pretty empty inside. I dropped off my car a few blocks to get my wheels aligned and came here for a cup and do an hour of reading. Chairs opened up soon after I got my latte and I sat right down by the round bar. It had this nice coffee shop buzz with groups of people coming and going and chit chatting or collaborating on projects. So back to the latte, it was good. Smooth and not overpowered by the warm milk.
author: Stephanie Y.

description: I'm updating my review, their coffee seems small, but the caffeine punch is nice and big.  I had a friend in from overseas who did not get a lot of coffee, and halfway through the cup he could feel it in his face.  For me, I've got a pretty high tolerance for the stuff . . .
author: Lexi B.

description:
awesome place.

best sf coffee.

I've recommended to anyone who enjoys coffee, my apartment never runs out of kenyan when its in season and the staple blueboon is a must have. 

when i feel like i treat i stop by for a espresso.

thanks for great coffee.
author: Frank L.

description: The bourbon blend coffee was excellent. I drink coffee black so I got the full flavor. Reasonably priced and tasty. The place was packed the whole time I was there.
author: Chris D.

description:
I saw Shightglass on my morning commute yesterday and scrounged up the change this morning so I wouldn't miss it today. I want to start by saying that I set the bar high this morning with my own fitercone individually dripped cup of Stumptown that I lovingly cradled with me all the way back from Portland. That said, Sightglass ran a pretty good cup of coffee from a chemex hourglass. 

While still under construction at the moment (and I think still not roasting their own beans yet) they manage to brave the cold from the roll up door and whip out decent caffeine. I wasn't disappointed, but not completely bowled over either. Maybe San Francisco is starting to get spoiled. I just wish they had been open when I lived a block away.
author: Zac H.

description: I didn't like to drink coffee until i was introduced to this place. You have to purchase your coffee to go, as the cafe is still under construction, but once it's completed i'm sure it's going to be a great local spot. The staff members are very nice and the location is great.
author: Mike D.

description:
If you trust that the New York Times novelty reviews of chic touristic spots reflect our San Francisco coffee drinkers' needs, than this place is for you. They sure did invest a lot in an industrial design of their space.
 But if you are a health conscious local, out of the nearby gym, on a lunch break, or before going to your office in the morning - you will NOT find in Sightglass Cafe 2% or nonfat milk to go with their lattes, only 4%. You will NOT find low fat, low sugar pastries to go with your coffee, just the very buttery, sugary stuff. Should you decide  to eat a sandwich instead, in the hope it would be more nutritious than those buttery-sugary pastries, you will find a miniscule, expensive sandwich with ham and cheese. So if you don't eat pork, forget about it. 
Any regular San Francisco cafe, with excellent roasted beans, has non fat, low fat, and whole milk, half and half and sugarless almond or soy or rice milk for those who can't tolerate lactose. Around breakfast time, most San Francisco cafe serve a hefty egg sandwich  for around $5.00. And the price for everything is about 30% less. I guess New Yorkers are used to pay more for good coffee and cholesterol-inducing pastries and milk.
author: Ayala K.

description: Coffee should not be an industry, but a mood to feel just like it. Love the environment, but just a lil bit pricy.
author: Alice C.

description:
the place is still under construction, but the coffee is rich and delicious with a lot of character and depth. Yay for more coffeehouses in SOMA! And they use iPhones to run credit cards which the geek in me loves.

**Update** they now use an iPad, and their coffee has made me a much better human being, it's so good. Also the Joshs and everyone else that works there rules.
author: Allie D.

description: a shortsight of sightglass is no internet.  not cool, dudes.
author: Tina H.

description: I love this roastery. it's big, spacious, simplistic. limited menu makes it a hassle free process to order. tried the el salvador drip. delicious. also was great to see where the whole roasting process in action. im now torn between this place and philz. joint custody it is.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Huh... a great beginning of what could be ultimate coffee experience. 

Pros: 
- Beautiful space, to put in a nutshell, the ultimate hipster cafe. It gave me great pleasure when my hipster friend's eyes lit up when I mentioned this place and proclaimed how much he loves this place. Him, currently landscape architect, me, ex-architect. 
- Pretty good roast. Still think Blue Bottle and De La Paz are better. 
- At $4 a pop, the hazelnut brioche is pretty damn buttery and delicious.
- Did I mentioned how nice this place is again? Every detail is thought of, the space, the light, the fixture, the packaging, the bathroom sink...... 

Cons: 
- I knew a place is trying to hard when they use the ipad as the cash register, yeah, occasionally that doesn't work so smoothly. 
- Only coffee, so no alternative for my non-coffee drinking friend. Yes, there is no tea! But there is water.
- Pricey, but I am willing to pay that for the lofty space. 
- Serves drip coffee in an espresso cup, so you get the rest of the coffee in the container......?! Can't you just give me a mug that will keep the coffee warmer? 
- Open space is poorly soundproofed, you can't hear anything when the machine is running, and the music is blasting.
- Service is hit and miss, the guy took my order is pretty cool, and the girl made my coffee called my name before it was ready, and was not being helpful at all.
- Very limited seating, all the current seating are bar stools along the bars that are facing the front window and around the roasting machine. Standing room only around the brewing bar. 

They are doing a lot of work on the second floor to put more seatings, and a sample roasting station.

I probably won't be a regular customer, since it will become more like a destination instead of a neighborhood cafe.
author: Alice C.

description: I've been here a couple times and don't exactly buy into the hype.  Making an espresso drink in the cold outdoors probably isn't easy, so I'm not going to say they don't know what they're doing.  I just don't enjoy drinking a almost-excellent espresso in the cold when I could find better experiences elsewhere for the same price.
author: Donovan C.

description: A fantastic cuppa coffee awaits you at Sightglass. Just like Bluebottle and Four Barrel roasters, this is another San Francisco Gem.
author: Marco M.

description: Damn, not enough good things to say about this spot.  It was great when it was under construction and all you got the minibar behind the rolly door, now that the cafe is 100% open, it's even better.  THe space is super cool and the beans and roast quality is second to none.  Sightglass delivers a very consistent cup, and their beans tend to produce a complex product that seems to get better with every sip.  Espresso-wise they pull shots from a new Slayer 2 group, a beautiful machine that while I'm not sure delivers quite the product of the La Marzocco, is still pretty great.  It's a little on the pricey side, but you get what you pay for.  I love this place.
author: Adam B.

description: Went here while on vacation in SF on a recommendation. Blew my mind...warehouse style, grinds & roasts their own beans. Low fat Soy Latte was the shit, so many flavors. Talk to Alex! Friendly and totally awesome coffee guy!
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Love this place and visit at least a few times a week since I live around the corner.  Their cappuccinos are fantastic (I've really never seen them on an off day here) and their drip is perfection.  Really great baked goods too.  And they take credit cards!

As much as I love it I have to take away a star for two reasons:

1. They took away the (herbal?) infused iced coffee.  I asked for it one day and was told they no longer had it because they were trying to stay true to the coffee itself or something like that.  It's now just plain old iced coffee.  I wish they would bring it back because as much as I love their regular coffee, sometimes I want something a little different.

2.  Lately on their drip menu (they always have three coffees to choose from), they haven't had a selection that costs less than $4.50.  I'm not one to complain about price if the product is great but sometimes I just really don't want to pay this much for a cup of black coffee.  Lately, I want the drip but I have to get a cappuccino instead because I didn't bring enough cash.  So that's a little annoying.
author: S B.

description: Sightglass finished its build-out a while ago but I hadn't been back until recently.  Though I'll miss the little alcove, the fully-built interior is spacious, bright and airy.  So now it's the same good coffee with people standing (or sitting) around talking about how good it is.
author: Suo L.

description:
I find it interesting that I found this interesting coffee spot through one of my various SF Happenings email lists.  It's an interesting find because the spot is literally around the corner from where I have dwelled for the past three years.  Around a corner I hardly tread, but even so.

Currently SightGlass is merely a kiosk of coffee offerings here in SoMa with plans to expand into the currently storage filled space immediately next door.  They are roasting their beans at a "friend's" roastery in Santa Cruz and seem enthused, if understatedly so, about the expansion and ability to roast their own in house.

They serve their coffee in one size and one size only.  with no plans to offer any variety, at least when it comes to this aspect, in the future.  Their thimble sized cups left me quizzical, because I , like many, have grown accustomed to a hefty sized cup while wandering around the city in the early morning hours.  This cup is just, well, unimpressive.

But appearances can be deceiving.

I asked for an explanation of the different drip cup offerings and went with the one described by one of the owners as "blueberry Pancake" in flavor.  Subtle, fresh, aromatic.  Yum.

With Vega just opened about a block away and Wicked about to open in a week, I have to wonder at all this coffee brew-ha-ha here in SoMa. But SightGlass is definitely keeping the SoMa standard high.
author: Ambere S.

description: This place is GREAT.  It has been fun watching them progress in their store and business development.  I am hoping they are succesful!  Their coffee is FANTASTIC and their eats are also very good.  The space is creative and full of possibilities!! Recommend everyone stop by and give them a try.  Only reason I don't give them a 5 is that there is no wifi and they are a bit pricey, but you get what you pay for.
author: Rod D.

description: What an unbelievably cool space...  Great wood trim, and some of the best espresso I've ever had.  My favorite about this place is the mocha was also the best mocha I've ever had.  Its not too sweet and brings out the best of both the chocolate and espresso flavors, without masking the espresso with sweetness.
author: Justin T.

description: I like this huge space in a former wharehouse but service is too slow and you have to like lining up....
author: Lo P.

description: Honestly I have low standards for coffee shops but sight glass is the worst shop I have been to, possibly ever. The pretentious 20 year old who took my order treated me like an alien, responding with eye rolls,off color comments and other such remarks. She was unprofessional and frankly unwelcoming. The hot chocolate I ordered tasted like bitter mud. There is no WiFi and the chairs are uncomfortable and squeaky to the point of serious nuisance. A little oil, social tact, a cheap internet connection, and a used couch or two would go a long way to making this place worth visiting. Until they get it together, avoid.
author: Evgeny P.

description: Excellent. Great service. Knowledgeable staff. Great layout. Can't wait for it to be fully open. So rad to be able to see the old Probat roaster. RJ let me cup some Blue Boon the proper way, it was great. Highly recommended.
author: Jordan M.

description: I ordered a $4 iced latte that came only half full...
author: Kelly L.

description: pretty good coffee, liked the cappuccino here better than blue bottle.
author: Brian C.

description: Horrible service. If you are disabled, don't come. Skipped my turn. Got my coffee after 4 people who ordered after me because I couldn't stand waiting for the barista to slowly pull the shot (i.e. 15 minute wait because they skippd me).  Also got skipped when spending 10 seconds to look at the menu...  Sadly, the coffee wasn't even worth the wait as the Blue bottle kiosk is far superior tohe coffee served here. Unfortunately, the only thing consistent here is the poor service.
author: C C.

description:
Another reviewer nailed it in saying this place epitomizes the SOMA vibe... Chill and understated but with an undercurrent of absolute awesomeness.

The place is still under renovations so when you walk through the "front door" you are going to see a bare bones set up carved out of a front corner of the actual space, which is tarped off... 

But that basically makes it all the much cooler because it speaks to the fact that it's really the coffee that matters, and it is indeed the best I've had in the city. 

The place is gonna be HUGE! It will definitely be a go-to spot for weekend wifi work sessions and the like.
author: Jonathan H.

description:
best cappuccino in the city. hands down.
friend says only hip young bearded men with dreamy eyes are allowed to work here. said friend may be right.

their coffee is better than blue bottle. ritual. four barrel or any other place i've ever encountered. the pastries they get are outsourced from the dog patch, haven't really tried them. but i'm guessing they are just as tasty.

go on a day when the bun truck is outside: http://twitter.com/chairmantruck, you will feel like such a winner post cappuccino and bun. seriously. 

find it on 7th between folsom and howard.  you will be oh so happy. you did.
author: lucy m.

description:
This is the best coffee hands down I've had. I'm going to have to go back and downgrade all my other coffee reviews based on the delicious treats handed out here. Justin was working the counter and answered all of my annoying questions with a smile- and then rewarded me with a latte from heaven. 

Can't wait until they can do their own roasting...
author: B S.

description: rad interior. great coffee and pastries--especially the cold brew. wish they offered a few more non-coffee options for those in our party that aren't big coffee drinkers.
author: L S.

description: Beautiful and very hip space, ironic classic rock, borderline surly service from attractive counter staff, excellent coffee. It's pretty much everything you would want in a coffee shop this hip, although I could have used a little less of the surly.
author: Jeff G.

description: Great looking shop, impressive facility, these guys are professionals and really do their craft well. That being said, I expected more. I was really not a fan of their espresso, it was a little to ordinary for me, and I got almost 0 customer/barista interaction. That isn't a job requirement for them, I guess, but it is important for me as a barista to connect to my customers and share my passion. Again, the place and my drink looked great, and these guys are at the top of the game in terms of coffee, but since I gotta be knit picky and detail oriented, the final product and experience did not live up to its own image.
author: James O.

description: Gorgeous space: open, very high ceilings, minimalist soma-modern design.  Busy but not crowded. Surprisingly quick service.  Latte was tasty, tho unremarkably so. Prices are typical for fancy coffee in SF.  Highly recommended.
author: Jason M.

description: Really cool atmosphere.  One cup at a time brewing and some great flavors. I like their no wi-fi policy because you get all of the jerks that are loud on cell phones and Skype out of the joint! Parking was pretty easy, but we were there ~4PM.
author: Stephanie C.

description: Friendly staff, nice area upstairs with tables made of recycled wood.  You can watch their roasting machine, which is fun.  The people who work there seem to really care about coffee, and some of them go to barista competitions. Their snacks (tarts) are OK too.
author: Dan C.

description: Seriously the BEST coffee I have had since I lived in Europe.
author: michelle l.

description: Shit coffee, pretty coffee hall/warehouse. California in general seems to have miserable coffee- though my main basis for comparison would be Vivace, which produces some of the better coffee in the US.
author: Nick F.

description: Best coffee in the City. And cool steampunk atmosphere. If you're in SOMA, def stop by. Upstairs bar does experimental brews and single origins.
author: sam l.

description: Great Industrial design and clean. Great coffee and service. On the pricey side but worth checking out at least once to them roasting their own beans in-house.
author: Richard L.

description: Coffee is top notch and the space is impressive.  From the roasting display at the front to the bar in the center to the 2nd floor lounge... it's been well designed. However you can't help but feel that the owners are trying a bit too hard. Witness the training upstairs, the meticulous ice coffee procedures and WCs with the lavabos on the outside.
author: G O.

description:
i am glad that the one day i didn't take my bike to work, i walked down 7th street to accidentally find sight glass. in the last three weeks, i've been there probably 6-7 times, which is a lot for me. (philz is too far away, and i'm sort of getting tired of it, and most coffee shops i go to are disappointments.)

i always get the americano there. so rich and yummy.

i also bought a bag of sulawesi, which is probably the most expensive beans i've bought to date. but it's delicious.

can't wait for the storefront to open--their sense of design is amazing.
author: Kaiser S.

description: Coffee is exceptional. Def a must for an SF visit but seating is horrible. If you're lucky to get there early you'll find a place to sit but this place is def not meant for sitting and catching up or reading...go for the coffee.
author: Malak M.

description:
This is the BEST coffee ever!!!! I am a fan of Stumptown and Blue Bottle. But this recent addition to SOMA is totally the BEST.


Bruzzer M

Portland
author: Bruzzer M G.

description:
Yes, this is among the high end.  They are just getting started, but I am already hitting this place in on the way to work almost daily.  On par with ritual in the bayview and four barrel and such.

I still think blue bottle is pulling a better shot, but these guys will probably improve over time.

I hope the growth of places like this motivates blue bottle to respect people's time and learn to process their lines efficiently.  

The quality of the water these guys pour before you have a shot is something very nice I have never seen in the US....
author: Eric L.

description:
they use crack to roast their coffee which is why it is so intoxicating. the high price does deter me a bit, $4.75 for a drip coffee is extremely high priced, but their excellent customer service and collaboration with other local entities allows me to support them. 

don't be deterred by their clientele in $300 jeans, the neighborhood has changed.
author: shanestar h.

description: Friendly staff and excellent coffee and baked goods.  Stopped by 10 minutes before closing and the cashier added some free items to my order since they would be thrown out anyway.  Decor is cool, I had never seen a coffee roaster setup before.
author: Charles C.

description: Great (sometimes inconsistent) coffee, awesome latte.  On the slower side with service, but nice staff.
author: Tuhin S.

description: I was so excited when this place opens! Especially when I live only two blocks away! I love the way this place is run. They accept credit cards which is run through Square, a device for iPad. Very laid back staff, excellent baristas, great beans! Pastries are often good, although there's only a limited range of sweets there. Could be better if the space next door is opened with tables and chairs.
author: Rika P.

description: Cool vibe, good coffee, nice servoce, a welcome addition to this SOMA area of town.
author: Christin A.

description: Beautiful space.  Consistently high quality beans roasted on the spot, sourced from single origins.  Why only 3 stars?  Price.  $20 for 12 ounces is absurd.  Go to Four Barrel or Contraband for similar quality coffee but 20% less pricey.
author: David C.

description: I love their interior design and the way the natural light fills the open space, but the last two lattes I've had from Sightglass tasted burnt.  I hope they improve with more experience.
author: M R.

description:
I'm moving to this neighborhood and heard that the Four Barrel brothers of Blue Bottle roasting fame were onto their next project, Sightglass coffee on 7th St.  What a welcome addition to the hood! 

I had an Ethiopian drip coffee made in a Chemex, and despite the small serving size, it was a deliciously tangy cup.  My loud and boisterous friend had an elegantly pulled cappuccino which he enjoyed while the owners humored his wild diatribes.   They were polite and courteous and seemed like they hoped to build a friendly atmosphere.  

Right now the space is just an open garage door with a fashionable bar that fits a 70s-retro espresso machine.  But a peek around the curtain to their roast machine unveils a lofty wooden space into which they plan to expand.

For now you can take your coffee "for here" and use a bench or shelf to relax against.  For later, I can only hope that Sight Glass expands with the same quality, friendliness and nonchalant attitude missing from the other micro-roast-houses in The City.
author: Stephen R.

description: Great coffee & the interior was interesting but the coffee is pricey with limited choices & our cashier was less than friendly. It was our first time there & she did not make any time of suggestions or eye contact for that matter. She seemed pretentious and was impolite. The people who were actually making our coffee were a lot nicer.
author: Kat D.

description: Great espresso, pulled to perfection!! Also had a cap which was sweet and smooth. The lb of coffee I purchased has also been spectacular. Will be going back for more!
author: Ted F.

description: Great coffee, yes. Cool atmosphere, yes. We visited 4 times on this vacation and the service has its ups and downs. Still, we'd come back next time we're in San Fran!
author: Julie H.

description: Other than Blue Bottle (Vega) - this is the best coffee around town. Great people, prices and location. Can't wait till they open the full bar...
author: David C.

description: Dare I say it?  IMO, better than BlueBottle.   Had a cappuccino at both Sightglass & Blue Bottle this morning and the former wins it for me...they accept credit and use an ipad as a cash register! I guess ya just have to check it out yourself or take my word for it.  Plus the baristas are friendly, adorably hairy fellows.
author: Laurel S.

description: They are still in the process of building the interior of the coffee shop, but the outdoor coffee bar experience is always fun for true San Francisco coffee lovers.
author: Amy A.

description: I used to live in the alley behind them and now that i am all the way across town definitely miss the coffee. yes its expensive, but the coffee is AMAZiNG! it gives you the buzz that starbucks can't. i like to sip and savor my coffee so for this reason wish they would make larger coffees and think they should lower their price a bit. its kinda hard to pay almost twice the price of a tall latte at starbucks for a drip coffee! for this i am knocking down a star.
author: Alyssa O.

description:
No seriously.  Woohoo!  As good as it gets!  I love coffee, and I particularly love good coffee.  This coffee is going to be one of your top 5 cups of all time.  It is one of those upper echelon cups of coffee...the ones that are just the best...you've had a couple of them in your lifetime, and you may even have been lucky enough to live near a coffee shop that could provide the experience on a regular basis.  That's the kind of coffee we're talking -- nuanced, delicious coffee that compels you to take the next sip.

Besides the coffee the people are nice, they asked my name...sincerely like...and even had water for my dog.  How do you beat that?
author: Matthew G.

description: I ordered the El Salvador which was nice and smooth blend very tasty with a hint of almond flavor. I personally thought $3.50 was a lot for a 12oz coffee. Perhaps in the future they will extend there cup sizes for variety.
author: Ebony B.

description: I don't come through this part of town much, but when I do, I stop by and get a capp or a coffee, both of which are excellent. It might be done by now, but I am really looking forward to what the new store will look like inside. Great baristas too.
author: Wes K.

description: Really cool, big space.  Excellent though expensive coffee.  Wide selection of muffins, scones, pastries.  Street parking available, not too bad.
author: A K.

description: Great space and great coffee.  Although I really think they should serve the coffee to your table if you order it in.  For such a specialty coffee and the artwork they do, I hated the fact that I had to juggle my cup and saucer all the way to a table on my own.  A little table service would go a long way!
author: Courtney J.

description: Great coffee, small servings, super pretentious barristas.  I had brunch with friends close by and saw this place so decided to give it a try. Was shocked with the price tag, but, I ordered without looking at prices, my fault. But, if I buy $4.50 coffee, give $5 cash I expect to be given the change and then decide on the tip. No, the guy never gave me back 50c and when I asked about change, he told me "tip?". Needless, to say, I am not coming back. Coffee 4*, service 1*
author: Svetlana R.

description: I came by this place in March before they officially opened but were working from a "open garage door" space.  Awesome baristas, excellent bean, perfect espresso, and the pastries were perfect.  I can't recall which I had, but I tried at least three types - all were wonderful.  The space looks totally awesome and will be fun to see when it's finished.  I went AT LEAST once each day I was in SF.  I look forward to going there again - can't wait for my return to SOMA!
author: Rich C.

description: Coffee snobs. Don't ask for an iced latte or an iced anything . Rude.
author: Richard I.

description: Ok, now I understand this is only my first review and you would not give it too much credence in the scheme of reviews, but this is how I would describe Sight Glass.  Rad.  I give the coffee 4 stars.  I give the hungover barista 1/2 star.  He was awake, thus gets a half star.  I am looking forward to seeing the place finished, as it looks, again, rad, and bursting with potential.  That said, I am looking forward to finding a 3W coffee joint with passion and great coffee that has a barista not sporting homeless couture.
author: Brian C.

description: Stopped into look at some paint across the street and noticed two lads making coffee in a rather industrial looking space. Intrigued, across the street I walked and had one of the best lattes I've ever tried. Yummy!
author: David G.

description: After having lunch and passing by, I didn't see a line (which I heard that there always is one in the mornings) so I decided to come in. There's not a big menu, in fact, the menu isn't posted anywhere, it's right at the counter/cashier when it was my turn which I was a bit surprised (can't necessarily plan ahead for this reason). The menu was relatively small though so it didn't take too long to look through it and decide what I wanted. I went with the mocha which was a bit pricey ($5) and waited probably for maybe 5 minutes or so for it to be made. They called my name and I grabbed my cup of coffee and went upstairs but since it was my first time here, I didn't know they didn't put sugar in the coffee until I sat down and took a sip - so back down I went for the sugar. Anyways, all that aside, I really liked the coffee here but whether I'll come back here again or not, it's difficult to say; mostly because the cup of mocha I got wasn't particularly big (which is sort of expected) and it was more expensive than I would have liked for a size of that cup. I don't regret coming here though.
author: Richard C.

description:
This promises to be a great location, if they ever finish their build out. (I'm sure that they will.) But Blue Bottle it's not.

The single cup price is ridiculous and the coffee I've had (just straight coffee) has been just fine. I make a better cup every morning.

For $3.50 per cup I want amazing coffee. It's far from amazing.
author: WILLIAM P.

description: This is my new favorite spot in San Francisco. The space and atmosphere is beautiful and extremely spacious. The music is nice and noise level is not bad. The coffee isn't as good as Four Barrel (my consistent favorite) - it's a bit more acidic and I prefer the more earthy/chocolaty taste of Four Barrel, but it's still excellent. My only complaint about this place is the service. Why are the people behind the counter at these places always so aloof and arrogant? In the end, I'd say the arrogance and aloofness at Sightglass is comparable to Four Barrel but less than that of Ritual and Blue Bottle which, frankly, have become intolerable with their "hipster" routines. I guess this just goes with the territory if one wants to enjoy a great coffee in this town. By way of example, I was second in line to order when the woman at the front just simply walked away and left us all standing there. I approached the guy running the second line and asked him to take care of us without forcing us to the back of the second line, which he did.
author: Eater S.

description: Love this place. Been coming since they opened a year or so ago. The overall quality and care taken in roasting the beans and making the beverages is second to none. Every latte, cappuccino, Americano and cup of coffee, for that matter, has been perfect. I love coffee but hate coffee houses, especially ones in the mission that attract a certain pointy shoe wearing, overly aloof, intentionally disheveled clientele. Which makes this place even better because those types can't find places that aren't in the mission. I highly recommend stopping by for a cup of whatever your pleasure is and grabbing a bag of some freshly roasted beans for your french press or Chemex if you're fancy like that!
author: I D.

description: It is so nice to have many local coffee shops in the Bay Area. This shop has a beautiful space. Large wooden room with a very high ceiling and a loft. I had a cappuccino which was excellent, except that it was a little too cold for my taste. Ambiance is 5 star!
author: Zaax A.

description: My new favorite coffee spot... their espresso drinks are outstanding.   Great job; rooting for you to open the rest of the shop!
author: Harry K.

description: Great coffee, but the architecture of the inside is marvelous. Typically get the macchiato or simple espresso. Nice crema on top of their drinks and their baristas are pretty cool. Straight forward good coffee and their beans are delicious!
author: david r.

description: This place is fantastic.  It has been fun to watch the space transform.  Aside from the awesome people and space, the coffee is the best I have ever had (yes, beats out blue bottle's latte for me).  Latte is my favorite, cappuccino my second.  Note - I am not a drip coffee drinker.  Only latte/cappuccinos.
author: Jessica M.

description: the coffee really is good, and the interior is magnificent. but no wi-fi, no outlets, and limited seating in such a huge open space is just plain weird. my boyfriend and i joke they must be serving parallel universes because the staff is always busy and there are stacks of dishes coming out all the time and getting a cup takes for-ev-er (seriously, a ridiculous amount of time) - but there really aren't that many people ordering.
author: Loralyn S.

description: Usually I am completely satisfied at Sightglass unfortunately yesterday I was finally let down. It was late in their workday and rainy so maybe the barista was tired. My cappuccino was bitter, the milk thin like a latte, and the usual cap art was a mess. Generally their caps are great but given what I interpret to be the goals of the company they should be perfect every time.
author: Aaron S.

description:
On of the best Mocha in the bay Area:
http://rama.notowidigdo.com/2010/06/best-coffee-mocha-in-sf-bay-area.html
author: Rama N.

description: Simply put, the best coffee in SF.  Not the best in the West Coast, still have to go way north for that, but in SF, Sightglass just measured by the standard of coffee is better than Blue Bottle, Ritual, Four Barrel, Coffee Bar....
author: Z M.

description:
Divine coffee (love the Owl's Howl), beautifully made, and offering some very tasty offerings of both sweet and savory treats (somewhat unusual for most American coffee places, where it's all about the sweet). I'm really curious to see what the interior will look like once it's finally completed!

Oh, and conveniently enough for me, on the way to work. :)
author: Dido H.

description: I discovered this joint walking to the Hall of Justice for jury duty, too... as did others on my jury. I would have gone nuts without that little cup of ambrosia to take the edge off the robbery-murder trial.  The Chemex-brewed drip coffee is great. I picked up a bag of beans to use at home in my espresso machine, and they're great, too.  Can't wait for the construction to finish--this will definitely become a regular spot for long lunches.
author: Michael C.

description: They have a Slayer machine now. I had  cappuccino which was  comparable to blue bottle. I'd say the quality is high for SF but I must say thay I'm used to European coffee which is a diffedent leaugue.
author: Mike O.

description: Amazing coffee!!!!!  You didn't realize how good it is until you have Sightglass and then go back to your regular coffee and then back to Sightglass.  The online store is great as well to send coffee as gifts.
author: Katherine K.

description:
Would like to ammend my previous review- i guess pretty obvious how aggro I get when denied my afternoon coffee..giving 4 stars because both Sightglass owners came to my office, with coffee and very shortly after my review, to explain why they don't take phone orders. We appreciated that, it was super classy. Because they are so close and we get stuck waiting for shipments on the regular..and require coffee frequently throughout the day, we wish they would take phone orders so -1 point..but we understand why they will not.  Thanks for the visit and for the coffee guys. 
-------------------
author: Carolyn C.

description: On a grand coffee tour adventure in Northern California, a barista at Ritual in Napa, CA googled the address and wrote it on a post-it for me...saying DO NOT MISS THIS PLACE!  It wasn't on my list that included Temple in Sacramento, Blue Bottle and Ritual.  I have to say that hands down, Sightglass out shined them all.  Sitting here in St. Paul, sipping a cup of Blueboon that we brought back with us clinches it.  We visited Sightglass twice during our stay in San Francisco.  It was marvelous both visits.  The Slayer makes the finest latte I have ever had.  The baristas were friendly to boot. The setting is a gorgeous combo of industrial modern barn/warehouse that I could live in.  Punk playing over the speakers, coffee roasting, colorful patrons, Hookers sea salt caramels and the lack of wi-fi make this place an absolute gem.  I shall miss you terribly, as the coffee scene in Minneapolis/St. Paul is seriously lacking in comparison.
author: Ami M.

description:
Pros
- Good Coffee
- Unique

Cons
- Out of the way
- Paid parking

Verdict
- I'd go if I'm in the area
- Want to try it again when they start roasting their own beans
author: Roger R.

description:
Coffee - It's as good as I've had.  This place is just a couple of blocks away from where I live and I see no need to travel further to get Blue Bottle.  It's certainly worth a try.

Service -  I was impressed.  When I asked which roast was best, the barrista gave me a cappuccino sized sample of each.  He then explained the flavors and such.  Keep in mind too that I was provided such top shelf service even though I'm neither good looking nor fashionable.  (At the time of the visit I had just finished a run and had on a Rocky IV themed shirt).  

I say stop by the next time you are in the neighborhood.
author: J Y.

description: I love this place. The coffee is great. My favorite - Baby Caps! When the build-out of the actual cafe is finished this will be the place to meet for coffee and relax. Owners and staff are really nice and friendly. Would recommend to anyone.
author: Anthony H.

description: delicious! so good. sort of inconsistent but when it's good, it's real good. space is the best space ever.
author: Sahil L.

description: Great coffee, prob best coffee in the city.  However, how do you not have WiFi and outlets in this amazing open space?
author: Asheesh B.

description: Good beans roasted, bagged on the spot.  my recommendation is get in, get your shit, get the fuck out.  some staff are extremely helpful.
author: X X.

description: Wow, this place makes a great coffee. I usually go for the cappuccino and the best way to describe it is smooth and full. This is the first coffee shop in SF that has converted me from my morning tea to a morning coffee - Blue Bottle, Ritual and Four Barrel didn't really do it for me for a variety of reasons (like Goldilocks - too acidic, too watery, etc).  Nice mellow vibe at Sightglass and the cutie owners/baristas are a plus:)
author: Joyce K.

description: The coffee is excellent but I wish they would do something about the bugs flying around their pastry case.
author: Eric B.

description: This place opened up a few weeks ago, and is currently just a coffee cart in a garage front, but these guys have big plans (and an amazing space) for their roastery/cafe. Their coffee is amazing, reasonably priced, and the two owners are as nice as it gets (and they're seriously passionate about coffee). Stop by and help get this place off the ground. It'll be a much needed gathering spot for this "emerging" neighborhood.
author: David H.

description: If you're mostly interested in the sourcing, roasting, grinding, and presentation of your coffee beans, this is your place.  If you'd like a comfortable place to have your coffee, hang out, have a variety of pastries, sweets to choose from, etc., this is definitely not your place.  A huge industrial layout with fewer than 15 or so bar stools at narrow bars.  After waiting so long for the cafe build out to be completed, this was a big disappointment.  Large clean bathrooms a plus.
author: Bob G.

description: Great coffee, yes overpriced, but worth it.  Maybe a little too spacious of a venue, but that's OK.  Best part for me was the vinyl.  Listened to the entire Sad Wings of Destiny album while there.  Not something you would hear at SBs, so I fully appreciated that.
author: John A.

description:
excellent coffee experience, staff was super nice and i saw Vinnie Chase(Adrian Grenier) from entourage.
sooooo good! delicious
author: Elliott G.

description: My new favorite spot for coffee in the city, or at least tied with Cento and Four Barrel. Beans are roasted by Verve in Santa Cruz, which is an awesome spot, although it looks like they are setting up their own roaster.
author: jacob g.

description: Game changer. Best coffee. And The Slayer ($18K roaster) still lays in waiting. I can only imagine....!
author: Becky S.

description: Visiting boys in SFO, stayed in SOMA, heaven wasn't at Club Dragon like I thought.. nope it was on seventh street..270 to be exact. A small shop with limited drink selection.. really forces you to appreciate coffee as it is.. YUM!
author: Barry F.

description: needed some information about coffee machines and  called these guys and the guy who answered the phone name Archie ( sorry if I misspelled your name) was an absolute delight! cheerful, proffessional, and knew exactly what he was talking about.
author: Jourdain D.

description: Bluebottle without the hype and the pretention.  Actually, I think it's better than Bluebottle.  The owners are super nice and the shop is such a welcome addition to the neighborhood.  I can't wait to see what it will look like post-renovation, with the roaster going and the coffee-shop area all set up.  The Chemex coffee is great (I love how they use a Chemex as a flower vase btw - great decoration touch!).  Also the baby latte is fantastic.  Note that there's no place for sit for now, but it's totally the pefect stop-and-go coffee shop.  And perfect for my afternoon coffee breaks.  Also, they take credit cards on this cool new iPhone app.  Enjoy!
author: Sandhya R.

description: Sightglass is the best coffee in the city, coffee made right. It'll only get better when its in full swing!
author: Faith F.

description: Great latte and the best caramels on the market from Hooker's Sweet Treats.
author: Cindy W.

description: Best coffee I've had in the city plus it's located in the coolest part of town.  Don't tell anyone, it's a secret.
author: Vivienne B.

description: The Guatemalan was fantastic.  I'm not sure I tasted all the undertones in the description but it was powerful and effective.
author: Seong P.

description: Justin & Jerad are well on their way to creating a gem of a spot in SOMA.
author: Kevin F.

description: very good coffee.  my favorite in SF, no doubt...gorgeous space.
author: Arwyn M.

description: incredible coffee, quiet neighborhood, nice place
author: Ira E.

description:
Great coffee and a friendly crew. I've had a few different coffee drinks from drip to Americano to latte to espresso and each one has been outstanding.

If you get the chance, be sure to check out the Spiced Iced Coffee - quite delicious and a real treat.

Hooker's treats are also for sale here which is a spendy, but added bonus. If the caramel corn is in stock, do not hesitate to buy a bag.

The place is still under construction right now and the new building including roastery looks like it will be pretty impressive and a great place to hang out & sip.
author: Mista Dobalina ..

description: Wow, I still think Mavelous is the best, but this place is great!  The lattes are made perfectly, the space is nice, and staff is kind.  There's no pretense like at 4-barrel or Ritual.  Check it out, the architecture and design is great too, and the prices are very fair.
author: Mark K.

description: Fantastic coffee paired with friendly, knowledgeable service and appropriate prices. I can't wait to see what the new cafe will look like when construction is completed. People with a passion for coffee simply cannot be disappointed at Sightglass.
author: Aaron J.

description: Cool looking place, awesome coffee beverages.
author: Olivia A.

description: Good guys and great coffee.  (Unsolicited review).  I won't say they are better than fourbarrel, blue bottle, and ritual.  They have been involved in some or all of those places.  My palate is not good enough to distinguish between these 4 places, but Jared and Justin know what they are doing and serve top shelf coffee on par with any other in the area.
author: Yowlie Y.

description:
Have been going here a few times a week for the past month. Hands down the best coffee Ive ever had. 

I dont drink coffee black but their coffee is so good, I drink it black because putting anything in it would dilute the incredible flavors you get in their coffees. Yes the cups are small, but the coffee is very strong and this one size cup is all you need to get your morning going.
author: Jared B.

description: was given some beans for Thanksgiving and fell in love with coffee all over again... If I lived in SF I would probably be there daily...
author: Kate Mills T.

description: Pretty darn good coffee.  In my opinion, similar in quality to Ritual, although my favorite coffee shop in the city is still Ma'velous.  The architecture of the place is unique, though--it's really light and airy, and the counters, etc. are really beautiful.
author: Frank F.

description: delicious latte and goat cheese and squash tart!
author: Rebecca S.

description: It's expensive but so worth it. Today it's a smallish space with no seating but it looks like they're building out a larger space. It's fun to watch the progress - certainly looks like it will be an aesthetically pleasing space.
author: amanda w.

description: I was very impressed on my first and only visit to date, and I will definitely be back soon.  Theirs was one of the best espressos I've ever had.  They have transformed this former warehouse into a coffee temple.  It is cavernous, beautiful, and clean, with lots of natural light and a wandering, pleasant layout.
author: Aaron Z.

description: I visited Sightglass this morning on the way to a meeting at the civic center.  I agree with other yelpers: the place has a great feel to it.  They were roasting coffee beans right there in the store, which is something really cool.  It gave me something to watch as I waited and waited and waited for my coffee.  There's my ding. The cashier was polite, but not overly friendly or helpful.  She took my order, placed a post-it on a cup and placed it near a co-worker, who was preoccupied with some important coffee business.  I had ordered a $4 cup of coffee. The cashier swipped my card and on reader connected to an iPAD, which very cool. She flipped the iPAD around for me to add either a $1, $2, $3 or more for a tip, then sign the iPAD with my finger.  I walked over to the coffee bean roaster to watch a gentleman pour and swift beans. I walked back over to the coffee bar and saw my cup hadn't move and the co-worker was still enthralled with transfixing stickers from one sheet to another.  She looked up at me, then quickly looked away. I walked back over to the cashier to see if there was a problem.  She said, she was going to check on it and walked away from me and talked to the sticker worker, then walked away from the counter. I assumed the problem was fixed, but she never told me it would be a few moments more because she just walked away.   Anyway, I got my coffee. No thank you, No sorry about the wait. No enjoy the coffee.  Just "Tom" and handed me the coffee.  The coffee was very good.  Maybe not worth $4. But, good. Service was terrible. I hope it was just an off-day for the sticker lady.
author: Tom B.

description:
This perhaps epitomizes the Soma scene for me. I happen to take 7th st to the BART instead of 8th and I look into this open garage door and there's a guy making coffee in an otherwise empty warehouse. I come back the next morning. Not only is there a line for drinks, people are sitting on the bench and the floor having their coffee there. 

I quickly learned why. The coffee is fantastic. It's head and shoulders better than Brainwash around the corner. They don't have a full range of drinks at the moment, but they have the important ones and I've found both their americanos and cappuccinos to be superb. 

Thanks to the friendly folks and excellent coffee, I've actually changed my standard morning route to brave the skeezier bits of 7th. It's totally worth it.
author: Matt C.

description: Did the macchiato and feel like I learned what good espresso tastes like, and I'm not biased because the bros are cute -- it was actually the best espresso I've ever had. Definitely try the Hooker's Sweet Treats while you're there (dark chocolate covered, sea salted caramels), since it's one of the very few ways to get ahold of them at the moment. The flowers made me smile, although I did not purchase any. Looking forward to many a return trip.
author: Emily B.

description: On my way to Blue Bottle, I saw the sign at the corner. I  stopped there because I was late for work and I knew the BB line would be too long at that time in the morning. I was greeted nicely and received my latte pretty quickly. Latte was right temperature, maybe not as strong as BB's, definitely smaller than BB's, but tasty...I'll definitely continue to go there, especially after 8:30 since BB's is usually packed by then.
author: judith m.

description: awesome coffee - every time i go there, i find my new favorite brew. incredible! and super nice staff, too.
author: Tara H.

description: Amazing. Let me explain. I live in Inner Richmond area...Go to school in Soma 5 days a week. I drive to Sightglass on my days off. I hate DRIVING...but I LOVE this COFFEE. Its amazing. The flavors that they say are going to be there, actually are there. The strawberry infused coffee I had the other day was soooo tasty. They also have some great chocolates for sale there....never too busy, always friendly, consistently good coffee. Loves it...I never hopped on the blue bottle train but for those of you who did, try this...its cute and trendy just like your spot but without the burnt taste....come on I know you've tasted it. Give Sightglass a try, you'll be coming on your days off too.
author: Summer C.

description: I found my new favorite bean...Sumatra! I can't wait til the larger space opens up!
author: Danielle L.

description: I've finally found a place where I can stand at the bar, sip on my espresso served in a proper brown espresso cup, gulp down my cup of acqua frizzante on the side and then go on my merry way. Thanks for making me feel like I'm in Italia for a moment!
author: Kat T.

description: Walked by one day on the way to get my car fixed.. what a find! Their espresso-based drinks are superb -- definitely one of the best cappuccinos in town.
author: Alex K.

description: the very best soy latte !! pricey for what you get but well worth 3 bucks
author: Tony F.

description: stealth beverages even during permitting & construction tape... great folks and a refreshing respite from having to deal with pretension when interested in quality coffee.
author: kenn f.

description: I was rushing to 850 Bryant from civic center muni for the second day of jury selection and hoping to arrive on time enough to avoid contempt from judge J and then to get quickly dismissed. I went by sightglass at a walk/run and registered, what's that gorgeous espresso machine doing in that garage? 2 hours later, having avoided judge j's contempt, I'm so excited to get dismissed before noon that I forget all about the mysterious espresso machine and am walking back to muni on the east side of 7th when I see it across the street. Jaywalked through traffic and wow. Supreme espresso plus tasty info on the probat and tricked out machine that allows for manual control of pre-infusion pressure ("not just 9 bars"). I've been roasting my own beans and pulling shots at home for a long time, and it used to be I'd never dare espresso out. Then blue bottle and ritual and now sightglass and still-to-be-visited fourbarrel. It's great to see SF living up to it's rep for quality coffee.
author: Daniel D.
